articleBody: – A small meteorite crashed into a wooded area in Nicaragua's capital overnight, the government said yesterday. Residents reported hearing a mysterious boom that left a 16-foot deep crater near the city's airport, the AP reports. Government spokeswoman Rosario Murillo said a committee formed by the government to study the event determined it was a "relatively small" meteorite that "appears to have come off an asteroid that was passing close to Earth." House-sized asteroid 2014 RC, which measured 60 feet in diameter, was passing close to Earth this weekend, ABC News reports. Murillo said Nicaragua will ask international experts to help local scientists

– A female passenger at Dulles International Airport dressed to the nines yesterday, complete with a full-body gown, mask, and gloves, and was spotted waiting for a flight in a hazmat suit, the Daily Caller reports. The Daily Caller notes that the woman was wearing a JCPenney bag, "maybe that's a new business line for the bankrupt retailer."

– Two Australians say they bought a few McDonald's burgers for friends back in 1995, when they were teens, and one of the friends never showed up, the AP reports. Now they're suing the fast-food giant, claiming the Quarter Pounder with cheese they ordered in 1995 is no longer available. A lawyer for the plaintiffs says they're seeking a court order to force McDonald's to hand over the burger, as well as damages for "physical pain, mental suffering, disfigurement, and impairment." The suit says the plaintiffs also want a court to order McDonald's to stop marketing the burger as a substitute for real food, the Sydney Morning Herald reports. A McDonald's rep says the suit is "without merit" and that the company is "committed to serving our customers with quality food at competitive prices." The plaintiffs' lawyer, however, says McDonald's has a long history of misleading customers about the quality and longevity of its food. The suit says the plaintiffs also want a court to order McDonald's to stop marketing the burger as a substitute for real food, as well as damages for "physical pain, mental suffering, disfigurement, and impairment."

– The Islamic State's youngest soldier has died in combat, according to a tweet from an ISIS-linked Twitter account. The account posted photos of a gun-toting child and said the boy "got martyred" with his father in Syria, the New York Daily News reports.

– Boko Haram has not confirmed truce and there have been at least six attacks over the weekend— blamed on security sources in the insurgents—that have killed several dozen people. The militant group, which has been terrorizing Nigeria for more than a decade, claimed responsibility for the attacks in the country's northeast over the weekend, the BBC reports. Boko Haram has not confirmed truce and there have been at least six attacks over the weekend— blamed on security sources in the insurgents—that have killed several dozen people.

– This week's round-up of the week's most fake online stories, rounded up by Snopes: The Nobel Committee doesn't "regret" awarding this year's Nobel Prize to a man for his efforts to "overthrow the democratic order of the United States of America" via his anti-government protests. See the full list here, or click for the week's more uplifting stories.

– A meteorite crashed down in Nicaragua, late Saturday night, causing a loud explosion and leaving a crater 39 feet across, government officials said. A loud explosion and a crater 39 feet across. A meteorite crashed down in Managua, Nicaragua, late Saturday night, causing a loud explosion and leaving a crater 39 feet across, government officials said.

– Amazon is getting into the streaming-video game. The company is working on an ad-supported service that would compete with Netflix and Hulu, the New York Post reports. The new service would be separate from Amazon's $99 yearly Prime membership, which offers unlimited movie streaming. "We currently offer the first episode of some television shows free with ads through our First Episode Free feature on Amazon Instant Video, and there are display ads," an Amazon spokeswoman said in a statement.

– A priest who died of a heart attack at the age of 69 says God is female—and he wants the world to know about it, the Daily Beast reports. "I believe that God is a woman," says the Rev. Joseph Krebs, who was born in Germany and moved to the US in the 1970s. "I want the world to know about God." Krebs, who says he's a devout Catholic, says he was inspired to make his claim after seeing a Bible passage in which God describes Himself as a "man of flesh and blood." He says God told him, "I want you to know that I am a woman." Krebs says he decided to make his claim after seeing a photo of God in the Bible with a woman's face superimposed on him. "I thought, 'Wow,'" he tells the Daily Beast. "I've never seen anything like this before." Krebs says God told him, "I'm a woman, and I want you to know that." He says he believes God is still alive, and he wants the world to know that. "I don't believe in death," he says. "I believe in life."

– Canada's parliament has been locked down and a soldier standing guard at the nation's war memorial has been shot, reports the BBC. Witnesses say a gunman opened fire at the National War Memorial in Ottawa before running to Canada's parliament, where he was shot dead by police. The soldier was reportedly shot in the stomach.

– The US military says it is investigating claims that ISIS militants seized a cache of weapons that were airdropped by the US-led coalition forces and meant for Kurdish militiamen, the AP reports. US military officials say they are investigating claims that ISIS fighters seized a cache of weapons that were airdropped by the US-led coalition forces and meant for Kurdish militiamen.

– "Don't f---ing cheat on Cassy, aka @NessLovnTrey247 (she really likes Trey Songz), because she finds out everything." That's what Cassy, aka NessLovnTrey247, tweeted yesterday, along with a series of photos showing her in what appears to be a compromising position. Cassy claims to have discovered via Twitter DMs between her boyfriend and another woman that he's been cheating on her, E! reports.

– An animal welfare group is seeking the public's help in finding the owner of a dog who was found tied to a railing outside a Scottish train station. Kai, a 2-year-old shar pei-crossbeed, was discovered by a member of the public in Ayr on Friday, the Daily Record reports. The dog's owner hasn't been found, but the Scottish SPCA is seeking the public's help in identifying the dog's owner.

– There will be six days of total darkness in December. That's according to an article on Huzlers.com, which says it's an old Internet hoax. The article says NASA has "confirmed that the Earth will experience 6 days of total darkness" in December. It uses fake quotes from a NASA official, according to Snopes.

– Italian fisherman Dino Ferrari landed what could potentially be a world record wels catfish in Italy's Po Delta. Ferrari's fish measured an incredible 8.7 feet in length and weighed 280 pounds. The current weight record for a wels catfish is over 300 pounds, but according to the Daily Mirror, Ferrari may have set a record for the largest catfish to be caught with a rod and reel. Here's photographic proof that this thing could just swallow an adult if it wanted to.

– Next month, HBO will launch a subscription streaming service called HBO Now, the International Business Times reports. According to the report, the $15-per-month service will launch in early April ahead of the April 15 launch date of Game of Thrones, HBO's most popular show. The Verge notes that Game of Thrones would be a great way for HBO to drive subscriptions to the new service, but it'll have to be careful if it plans to do that: Last year, HBO's online streaming option for cable subscribers, HBO Go, wouldn't work for many who were trying to watch during the premiere. That would be a very bad look for a new

– A woman claims to have met Michael Phelps on Tinder, slept with him, and fucked him on their first date—and she's not backing down. In a lengthy Facebook post, Taylor Lianne Chandler says she was born intersex and was named David Roy Fitch, the Washington Post reports. "I was born intersex and named David Roy Fitch," the 41-year-old DC-area woman writes. "I met Michael Phelps on Tinder and fucked him on our first date watching football on TV," she continues. "I was born intersex and named David Roy Fitch." Chandler—who calls Phelps her "best friend" and says she's "in love" with him—tells Radar she was freaked out when the world discovered the truth about her relationship with the 18-time Olympic gold medalist. "Many of you have wondered why I was so freaked out about my relationship with Michael Phelps being exposed," she writes. "Here is the truth. I met Michael Phelps on Tinder and fucked him on our first date watching football on TV. I was born intersex and named David Roy Fitch."

– Macaulay Culkin is not dead. The actor is just next victim in a long line of Hollywood death hoaxes. The rumor started with a Facebook page that was made to memorialize the actor. Macaulay Culkin is not dead. The actor is just next victim in a long line of Hollywood death hoaxes. The rumor started with a Facebook page that was made to memorialize the actor.

– A prominent Saudi cleric has sparked a storm of controversy by declaring that building snowmen is against Islamic law. Sheikh Mohammed Saleh al-Munajjid made the ruling when asked on a religious website if it was OK for fathers to build snowmen for their children after a snowstorm in the country's north, the Telegraph reports. "It is not permitted to make a statue out of snow, even by way of play and fun," he said, quoting from Muslim scholars.

– The Islamic State's claim that it had captured a US aid worker in the Syrian city of Kobani is false, according to fighters with the Kurdish militia known as the YPG, Voice of Israel reports. Voice of Israel's editor, Eran Cicurel, says fighters with the YPG told him that Gill Rosenberg was not captured by ISIS. Earlier, ISIS-affiliated websites claimed to have seen a video of Rosenberg, a 33-year-old aid worker from Texas, the AP reports. Cicurel says he spoke to fighters with the YPG, who "said that there was no video of Gill Rosenberg, that she was not captured by ISIS, and that they are working to free her." The fighters say they've been in contact with Rosenberg's family, and they're sure she's alive.

– An 8-year-old Phoenix boy is in custody after his mother says she found him watching pornography and masturbating in his room. Police say the boy's mother called 911 when she found him in his room, watching pornography and masturbating, AZFamily.com reports. Police say the boy's 11-year-old sister also found pornography in the room and reported the incident to authorities. The boy was arrested on suspicion of sexual conduct with a minor and is being held at a juvenile detention center.

– British rapper Jay-Z has been linked to the beheading of American journalist James Foley, according to several unconfirmed published reports, including the Independent. A British rapper now fighting with the Islamic State (aka ISIS) is reportedly a suspect in the beheading of American journalist James Foley, according to several unconfirmed published reports, including the Independent.

– Lebanon says it's holding the daughter of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, who was last seen in the country in 2014. The country's interior minister says DNA tests confirm Lebanon is holding the young daughter of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the AP reports. Lebanon says it's holding the young daughter of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, who was last seen in the country in 2014. Lebanon says it's holding the young daughter of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, who was last seen in the country in 2014. DNA tests confirm Lebanon is holding the young daughter of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the country's interior minister says.

– The FBI has questioned a man who says he recorded audio of gunfire at the time Michael Brown was shot by Ferguson police on August 9, the man's attorney tells CNN. The attorney says his client, Dorian Johnson, told the FBI that he was on his cell phone recording when he heard a gunshot and yelled, "I'm on the phone, I'm on the phone, I'm on the phone" as police approached Brown's car. Johnson, who says he's a former Ferguson police officer, told the FBI he didn't know Brown was a police officer at the time of the shooting, the New York Daily News reports. According to CNN, the FBI has questioned a man who says he recorded audio of gunfire at the time Brown was shot by Ferguson police on August 9, the man's attorney tells CNN. The FBI has questioned a man who says he recorded audio of gunfire at the time Brown was shot by Ferguson police on August 9, the man's attorney tells CNN. The FBI has questioned a man who says he recorded audio of gunfire at the time Brown was shot by Ferguson police on August 9, the man's attorney tells CNN. The FBI has questioned a man who says he recorded audio of gunfire at the time Brown was

– Abdel-Majed Abdel Bary, who went by the rap name L. Jinny or Lyricist Jinn, is a suspect in the beheading of journalist James Foley this week, the New York Daily News reports. Bary, an Egyptian immigrant, was convicted of conspiring to kill a US aid worker in Egypt in 2000 and is serving a life sentence. He is also a suspect in the beheading of journalist James Foley this week.

– A government employee in India has been fired after more than two decades without appearing for work. AK Verma, an executive engineer at the Central Public Works Department, was fired after last appearing for work in December 1990. "He went on seeking extension of leave, which was not sanctioned, and defied directions to report to work," the government said in a statement on Thursday, per the Times of India. An inquiry found him guilty of "wilful absence from duty" in 1992, but it took another 22 years before he was removed from his post.

– A fake press release claiming that street artist Banksy had been arrested by London's Anti-Graffiti Task Force has been taken down by PR Log, the Huffington Post reports. The release, which claimed that Banksy had been taken into custody, was quickly removed.

– Rumors have been swirling that North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Un, is seriously ill, but a rep for the country's ambassador to the United Nations in Geneva told Reuters last night that Kim is "not in bad health," and that his sister, Kim Yo Jong, has taken over as acting leader while her brother is out of the country. The rep added that Kim Jong Un's father, Kim Jong Il, and grandfather, North Korea's founder Kim Il Sung, also suffered health problems but survived long enough to rule the country.

– Apple's first major product launch since CEO Tim Cook took over in Tim Cook's shoes hasn't exactly been a roaring success. The company's revenue fell short of estimates for the first time in its history in the fiscal year that ended in September, the Wall Street Journal reports, and that could mean trouble for Cook and the rest of the Apple team as they try to get the new Apple Watch off the ground before the holiday shopping season kicks off in a couple of weeks. Analysts say the watch—which is expected to cost at least $30,000—is unlikely to be a game-changer for Apple as it has been with other high-end gadgets such as the iPhone. "Apple has a lot of work to do before the watch is ready for prime time," a Bernstein analyst tells the Journal. "If they can't get it right, they're going to have to find other ways to make money."

– The small town of Purdon, Texas, has been quarantined after a family of five tested positive for Ebola. Purdon is located just 70 miles from Dallas, Texas, and the hospital that has cared for both American Ebola patients, Thomas Eric Duncan, and Texas nurse, Nina Pham, is just 70 miles away. The New York Times reports that a mandatory quarantine has been in place for 21 days at the town's airport, which is located just a few miles from Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. Jack Phillips, a resident of the town of 1,500, has been in quarantine with his wife and four children for 21 days, according to a statement from the town's mayor. The family has been isolated at the town's emergency shelter. The Texas Department of State Health Services has now confirmed that the family is free of Ebola.

– A US Marine who was shot in the head by a Taliban sniper in Afghanistan was saved by his helmet, according to a video that has gone viral. The helmet-mounted camera captured the moment the Marine was shot in the head during a joint helicopter raid in the Now Zad district of Helmand Province, Afghanistan, in 2013, the Telegraph reports.

– Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice director Zack Snyder unveiled an official photo of the Batmobile during the Comic-Con International Convention in San Diego over the weekend—but it was stolen the very next day, TMZ reports. According to the San Diego Union-Tribune, someone broke into a garage early Sunday morning and stole the Batmobile, which is featured in the upcoming Batman movie.

– New York City is changing its approach to low-level marijuana possession, officials tell the New York Times. Instead of arresting people caught with a small amount of pot, those caught will be issued a court summons—but they won't have to go to the police station. Mayor Bill de Blasio is expected to announce the change today.

– A big break in the case of one of the world's most famous fugitives: Banksy has been arrested in London, reports the BBC. The elusive artist, whose real name is muralist Banksy, has been holed up in a house in south-east London for the past few months and was taken into custody early this morning, reports the Guardian. He is being held in a London police station and is expected to appear in court later today.

– A patient at a hospital in Kansas City, Mo., has tested positive for Ebola, reports the Kansas City Star. The patient hasn't been identified, but officials at Rockhill Research Hospital, where the patient is being quarantined, say they don't believe the virus is spread through human-to-human contact. The patient had recently traveled to West Africa.
– Lego sent a message addressed 'To parents' inside a box of assorted building blocks, explaining how 'the urge to create is equally strong in all children... boys and girls'

– A nun living in an Italian convent has given birth to a surprise baby after complaining of stomach pains, according to the Italian press. The nun, who came to Italy from South America, belonged to an order called the Missionary Sisters of the Love of Christ in Macerata, located in the Italian region of Le Marche.

– Militants in Libya are believed to have seized a dozen commercial airliners in an attack on a Tripoli airport last week, US officials tell the Washington Free Beacon. "We found out on September 11 what can happen with hijacked planes," one official says. "There are a number of commercial airliners in Libya that are missing." The officials say intelligence reports have detailed the types of planes believed to have been seized.

– A man accused of attempting to rape a girl in India has been left in a critical condition after locals cut off his genitals as punishment, the Independent reports. The group took the law into their own hands after they found a 40-year-old man pinning a young girl to the wall in the north-eastern city of Ganganagar. Police say the man tried to rape the girl last week, but she managed to run away and call for help. When they arrived, they found the man pinning the girl to the wall with his genitals cut off. He was then rushed to a hospital in critical condition.

– Yeti sightings have been reported in Russia's Adygeya Republic before, but this is the first video of the big ape that's been caught on tape. A team of hunters set out to find the elusive creature in a remote area an hour's drive away from the city of Adygeisk after local TV reported seeing one there, the Daily Mail reports. The hunters captured video footage of a bear-like figure emerging from snow-covered trees before disappearing again seconds later.

– President Trump is calling for an investigation into a video that purports to show him giving a speech in which he bashes the Affordable Care Act. The White House says it is working to establish the video's authenticity, but if it is genuine, the US would be "appalled by the brutal murder" in Trump's speech, the AP reports. The White House says it is working to establish the video's authenticity, but if it was genuine, the US would be "appalled by the brutal murder" in Trump's speech.

– North Korea's state-run media hasn't reported on Kim Jong Un's whereabouts since the 31-year-old attended a concert with his wife earlier this month. But a source with access to North Korea's leadership says Kim injured his leg while inspecting military exercises, the Guardian reports. "He ordered all the generals to take part in drills and he took part, too," the source says. "They were crawling and running and rolling." The source says Kim is "in firm control" of his government but has hurt his leg.

– Nigerian officials say Boko Haram has agreed to cease-fire in exchange for the release of more than 200 schoolgirls kidnapped by the Islamic extremist group last year. The deal was reached in talks with a Saudi Arabia-based representative named Danladi Ahmadu, the BBC reports. "I have failed to find anyone who has ever heard of him," says the BBC's Nigeria correspondent. "We've tried verifying the identity of the other side of the negotiations."

– North Korean leader Kim Jong Un had surgery in Pyongyang in mid-September to treat fractures to both ankles and remains in hospital, a source claimed Monday. North Korean leader Kim Jong Un had surgery in Pyongyang in mid-September to treat fractures to both ankles and remains in hospital, a source claimed Monday. North Korean leader Kim Jong Un had surgery in Pyongyang in mid-September to treat fractures to both ankles and remains in hospital, a source claimed Monday.

– Is the Big Mac going the way of the dodo bird? McDonald's announced today that it will be phasing out the iconic burger in favor of items like McWraps, smoothies, and frappuccinos starting next year, the Wall Street Journal reports. The chain will also stop serving items like Apple Pies and large sizes of its famous burgers, according to Crain's Chicago Business, which first reported the news.

– KFC has a new item on its menu, and it's not something you'd expect to find on a fast-food chain's menu: weed. Colorado has approved a business license for KFC Colorado to sell marijuana, reports the Denver Post. The reason? The state has legalized medical and recreational marijuana, and the number of pot dispensaries in the state is huge, notes the Racket Report. KFC is charging franchise owners $35,000 for the license, and 42 of the chain's nearly 100 franchises in the state have done so so so far.

– eBay is looking for a developer to create an app for the Apple Watch, 9to5Mac.com reports. According to an ad posted to eBay's career page back in November, the company is looking for someone with "a proven track record of creating award-winning mobile apps" to create a bidding app for the Apple Watch.

– Christian Bale is once again in the running to play Steve Jobs, this time at Sony. The actor was originally in talks to play the late Apple co-founder, but his negotiations with Fox over The Deep Blue Goodbye hit a wall, sources tell the Hollywood Reporter. Now Sony has started negotiations with Bale, who was also in talks with David Fincher to play Jobs in a film directed by Fincher. Sources say Fox was trying to include sequel options for Bale to tackle the lead role of Detective Travis McGee in what is hoped to be a franchise starter.

– At least one of the five Taliban militants released in exchange for Bowe Bergdahl has tried to make contact with the Taliban again, US officials tell NBC News. There is no indication the former prisoner, being held in Qatar, made contact with the Taliban. "We're closely monitoring the situation and see no potential threat," a senior US official says. The officials say it's unclear whether this was an actual attempt to rejoin the Taliban militants in Afghanistan.

– Apple is in talks with HBO to offer a stand-alone, web-only TV package, reports the International Business Times, citing "sources." The move would put HBO Now, the network's new streaming-video service, on Apple's set-top box, reports CNBC. The International Business Times says the deal is still in the early stages.

– The Department of Homeland Security has repeatedly said that ISIS-affiliated terrorists were arrested while crossing the US-Mexico border is "categorically false" and "not supported by any credible intelligence or facts on the ground," reports the Washington Post, which takes a look at what's known about the incident and what's not. Among the more notable tidbits: The border patrol says it found a "suspicious object" at the site of the arrest, which is about 100 yards from the border. The object turned out to be a rock. It's not clear what, if any, evidence led to the arrest of two men who were traveling in a van with a cardboard sign reading "ISIS: Free Syrian Army." The Post also takes a look at what's known about the incident and what's not. Among the more notable tidbits: The Department of Homeland Security has repeatedly said that ISIS-affiliated terrorists were arrested while crossing the US-Mexico border. The Post takes a look at what's known about the incident and what's not. Among the more notable tidbits: The border patrol says it found a "suspicious object" at the site of the arrest, which is about 100 yards from the border. It's not

– The leader of al-Shabab, a militant group linked to al-Qaeda, has been killed in an attack in Somalia. Ahmed Abdi Godane, also known as Mukhtar Abu Zubeyr, is al-Shabab's spiritual leader under whose direction the Somali militants forged an alliance with al-Qaeda and became the most high-profile terrorist group in Africa

– Batman vs. Superman is currently shooting in Detroit, and rumor has it one of the iconic Batmobiles has been stolen. "The scuttlebutt from sources in Detroit is that one of the Batmobile models being used in the filming of Batman vs. Superman has gone missing, believed stolen," reads a post at Bleeding Cool. "The best set video we can get of the iconic vehicle in action is from about 300 feet away, but someone got close enough to steal one of the damn things?"

– "When I do not even want, everything appears. Once I even pulled glass. Pushed itself." That's how 7-year-old Nick Kruglyachenko describes his superpowers, which he discovered while playing with his classmates at his school in Russia's Isilkulsky District, the Telegraph reports. The second-grader used an electric shock to cause objects to stick to his hands, and when he tried to pull them out, they did the same. "When I see that someone needs help, will never pass by," he says. "If I even pulled glass, everything appears. Once I even pulled glass. Pushed itself," Nick says, per RT.com.

– In this week's edition of lies, fakes, pranks and cheats on the Internet, we bring you a spray-painted penis on a very expensive car. In this week's edition of lies, fakes, pranks and cheats on the Internet, we bring you a spray-painted penis on a very expensive car.

– When a 2-year-old girl in St. Peter's Square watched Pope Francis lead a procession for her dog, Assisi, who had recently died, she thought it was the end of the world. It wasn't. Instead, the pontiff spoke to the boy and his mother, telling them there was a place at the Vatican for all creatures who share our lives. "There is a place in hell for the evil one, but there is also a place in heaven for the good one," he said, per the Telegraph. Assisi, it turns out, was a dog by the name of St. Francis of Assisi, a 16th-century friar who specialized in animals. The pope's visit to the boy's house was the first of its kind by a pontiff since the dog's death, and it's being hailed as one of the most moving moments of his young life.

– A meteorologist in North Carolina was supposed to be reporting on the state's severe weather over the weekend, but he got lost in the storm and couldn't get back to the station in time, WRAL reports. "There's not being ready to go on camera. And then there's really, really not being ready. Like, not even a little bit," writes Jordan Weissman at FTVLive.com. "This was the unfortunate case experienced by meteorologist Mike Seidel this weekend while reporting on the stormy weather in North Carolina," he adds. "There has been some speculation as to what Mike was or wasn't doing. Think you will." The station says in a statement that Seidel "had lost cellphone contact with our control room, so he couldn't go on camera."

– An American journalist who went missing in Syria in 2012 has been reportedly executed by the Islamic State, CNN reports. James Wright Foley, who was working for the website GlobalPost when he went missing, was last seen at a gas station in Raqqa on Nov. 22, 2012. ISIS, which controls large areas of Syria and Iraq, claimed to have him as a hostage in a video released last month.

– A mob in India's northern state of Rajasthan beat up a man who was allegedly trying to rape a teenage girl, reports the Times of India. Police say the victim, a 16-year-old girl, was on her way home from school when she was attacked by a group of men. One of the men allegedly grabbed her and tried to rape her. Police say the mob then attacked the victim's father, who tried to stop the men from beating up the girl. He was arrested. (This story has been corrected to show that the victim was on her way home from school, not on her way to school.)

– When Vogue moved from its longtime digs in Manhattan's Lower East Side to One World Trade Center earlier this year, it was with much fanfare, with models, Will.i.am, and even the president of the United States helping out with the move. But Gawker reports that the magazine's new digs are also home to... rats. According to one of their sources, Anna Wintour has decreed that the staff "must ensure that her personal office is rat-free." Click for more.

– "I feel happy and relieved. And excited. And really interested to see what's in this box." That's how Museum of Fine Arts conservator Pam Hatchfield described Thursday night's successful removal of a time capsule from Boston's Museum of Fine Arts, the Boston Globe reports. Hatchfield spent more than seven hours extricating the time capsule, which was placed in a cowhide during construction of the museum's expansion in the 1980s. The contents of the box, which was supposed to last until 2029, were carefully removed from the stone block that held it in place.

– ISIS fighters in Iraq and Syria are using a new weapon in their war against the Islamic State: live scorpions. The Telegraph reports that scorpions have been used in previous ISIS attacks, but this appears to be the first time they've been used in a war zone. According to Sky News, the scorpion bombs are being dropped from drones and come packed with live arachnids.

– A British man paid $460 to save the life of his goldfish—after it became constipated. The dedicated owner took his blocked-up 3-inch pet to a vet after realizing it was struggling to pass waste, reports the Norfolk Daily Eastern Press.

– Lovesick Tan Shen, 26, says she needed "time to think" after being dumped by her boyfriend—so she went to KFC for a week. The Chinese woman even phoned in sick to work to get the chicken wings, fries, and shakes she ordered in Chengdu, China's southwest Sichuan Province, the Daily Mail reports. "I didn't want to die, so I wanted to get some comfort food," she says. "I didn't want to die of hunger, so I ordered the wings, the shakes, and the extra large fries." She says she even phoned in sick to work once she got home because she didn't want her co-workers to know she was eating there.

– A US Marine who was shot in the head while protecting coalition troops in Afghanistan has been released from the hospital and is expected to make a full recovery, military officials say. The Marine, who was hit by a sniper bullet during a raid in Helmand Province last week, was treated at a military hospital in the provincial capital of Lashkar Gah before being transferred to a military hospital in the city of Kandahar, reports the Los Angeles Times, which notes that it is not clear whether he suffered life-threatening injuries. The military says he has been treated for non-life-threatening injuries and is expected to make a full recovery.

– Shane Smith, the sometimes controversial but always press-friendly CEO of Vice Media, has found another way to make news: reportedly spend $300,000 on a Las Vegas meal. The New York Daily News reports that the company's founder and CEO spent the weekend at the Hard Rock Hotel & Casino with his wife and three children. They reportedly went to dinner at Tao, a restaurant owned by the hotel's parent company Caesars Entertainment. According to the Las Vegas Review-Journal, which first reported the story, the meal was worth at least $300,000.

– Led Zeppelin's Robert Plant has pulled the plug on a 35-date tour that would have paid him nearly $924 million, the Mirror reports. "No amount of money is enough for Led Zeppelin to get the band back together," Plant said in a statement. "It is with a heavy heart that we have to announce that we are calling off the remainder of our world tour." Plant, 66, said the decision was made "in the best interests of the band," according to the New York Daily News.

– Apple's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs is just over a month away, and CEO Tim Cook has spilled some more details about the much-anticipated Apple Watch. In an interview with 9to5mac.com, Cook says the watch will be called the Apple Watch, not the Apple Watch S, as had been previously reported. "It's going to be called the Apple Watch. It's not going to be the Apple Watch S," he says. "It's going to be a band that's going to be attached to the back of the watch. It's going to have a display that's going to say, 'This is what you're doing. This is what you're doing.' It's not going to be called the Apple Watch."

– Banksy fans around the world were in a tizzy Friday after sites such as Death and Taxes, Jezebel, and Sites Complex ran stories claiming that a 39-year-old man named Paul Horner had been arrested by British police and unmasked as the street artist. But it turns out that Horner is editor of a website called Super Official News, and he is, in fact, the notorious "media troll extaonaire" behind the hoax, the Telegraph reports.

– Homeland Security chief Jeh Johnson says there's no "porous border" that allows terrorists, Ebola patients, or unaccompanied minors into the US, Politico reports. In a speech today at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, Johnson said there have been improvements in border security. He said the number of unaccompanied minors apprehended in fiscal year 2014 was 68,434, " considerably lower than a projection of 90,000." He said claims that four terrorists had crossed the border were false, and that the government is intensifying its efforts to keep Ebola out of the country.

– If you've got an iPhone 6 Plus, there's a good chance you're experiencing #hairgate. The Twitterverse is abuzz with complaints from users who say their phones are pulling out their beards and hair, the Telegraph reports. "I'm concerned about my iPhone 6 Plus, keeps yanking out my hair when I'm making a call," says one Twitter user. "It's not a bend, it's just pulling out hair," adds another. The complaints come on the heels of earlier reports that Apple's new phone is prone to bending.

Sources say that NBC executives were aware of the story for years and had been asking Williams to stop repeating it. The Post's sources say that Brian Williams has been telling stories about being in a helicopter that was shot down by a group of insurgents for more than a decade. – The fence-jumper who bolted across the White House lawn and got deep enough into the East Room to catch the president actually ran right through the building, according to the Secret Service. An official tells the Washington Post that an alarm box near the front entrance of the White House was muted after a request from the White House usher's office. The female officer posted inside the front door appeared to be delayed in learning that the intruder, Omar Gonzalez, had overpowered her.

– A video posted to YouTube by Afghanistan veteran Sam Arnold shows a US Marine getting hit in the face by a Taliban sniper, only to be saved by his helmet, Raw Story reports. "That was a really close call," Arnold writes. "That was a spine-chilling video of a US Marine getting a direct headshot from a Taliban sniper—only to be saved by his kevlar helmet." According to Arnold, "the Marines were conducting a joint helicopter raid in the Now Zad district, Helmand Province in 2013."

– A woman in Macerata, Italy, has shocked her fellow nuns by giving birth to a baby boy after suffering a severe case of stomach pains. The woman, who belonged to an order in Macerata, says she was in labor when she went to the hospital, the Telegraph reports. She delivered the baby via C-section and was rushed to the hospital, where she gave birth to a healthy baby boy. The woman, who has not been named, says she has been a nun for more than 30 years and this is the first time she has ever given birth while in labor. She says the pain was so severe that she considered giving up on giving birth, but she decided to go ahead with the birth anyway because the baby was in good health and she didn't want him to go to the hospital alone. She says she has no regrets.

– So why hasn't Kim Jong Un been seen in public for more than a week? A source close to North Korea's leadership tells the Wall Street Journal that the answer is simple: He injured his leg. The source says Kim is still in control of his government, and there's no reason for him to be out of sight. North Korea's state media has not made any mention of Kim's whereabouts since he attended a concert with his wife on Sept. 3.

– The Dallas man who came to the defense of a gay man being attacked by an anti-gay bigot was fired from his job as a security guard today, the Dallas Morning News reports. Police say 25-year-old Jamelle Bouie was suspended with pay from his job as a security guard at a Dallas apartment complex after he was caught on video dragging a man by the arm as he was being attacked by the man's ex-girlfriend. Bouie, a father of two, has been on paid leave from his job since Friday, the same day the video of the attack went viral, the Morning News notes. Police say Bouie will be charged with two counts of assault with a deadly weapon and one count of public intoxication. A police spokesman tells the Morning News that Bouie was fired from his job as a security guard at a Dallas apartment complex after he was caught on video dragging a man by the arm as he was being attacked by the man's ex-girlfriend. The ex-girlfriend has been charged with two counts of assault with a deadly weapon and public intoxication.

– A Texas plumber is getting some unwanted attention after one of his old company vehicles appeared in a photo posted on an Islamic militant group's social media account, the AP reports. Mark-1 Plumbing in Texas City has been flooded with calls after the picture appeared on Twitter, the Galveston County Daily News reported. The photo shows a black pickup truck with a Mark-1 Plumbing decal on the door and an anti-aircraft gun in the bed.

– An attorney representing a man who says he inadvertently recorded audio of the Michael Brown shooting has provided that audio to CNN. The audio captures what seem like 10 gunshot sounds—an initial group of six, then a pause, then four more. An autopsy of Brown's body performed at his family's request by an experienced forensic pathologist named Michael Baden indicated Brown was hit by at least six shots. An attorney representing the man who says he inadvertently recorded audio of the shooting has provided that audio to CNN: Attorney Lopa Blumenthal says the recording was made during a video chat. The audio captures what seem like 10 gunshot sounds—an initial group of six, then a pause, then four more. Eyewitness Dorian Johnson, a friend of Brown's, has said that officer Darren Wilson fired several shots at Brown after Brown had turned toward him.

– In the immediate aftermath of Michael Brown's death in Ferguson, Mo., a 20-year-old man named Deandre Joshua went to the police station to tell a story about his friend, who'd been shot. Less than two weeks later, Joshua's body turned up, covered in lighter fluid, not far from where Brown's body was later found, reports the Daily Beast. Now, a man who says he's Joshua's cousin has posted on Facebook that his cousin was murdered after testifying before a grand jury in the Brown case. "Supposedly he was found not far from where Brown's body was & he was covered in lighter fluid," the post reads. "It was a post I saw on FB & just wondered if it was true." But Ryan Gorman, a reporter for the St. Louis Post-Dispatch, says he's seen no evidence to back up the claim. "I've never heard of a 20-year-old being murdered after testifying before a grand jury in a criminal case," he tells the Beast. "I've never heard of a 20-year-old being shot in the back of the head. – The world's most expensive production car, a Bugatti Veyron 16.4 Grand Sport, was parked on a Seattle street over the weekend when a vandal decided to let the cat out of the bag, reports the Seattle Post-Intelligencer. The culprit scrawled "F--- you" in black marker on the side of the luxury sports car, which is worth an estimated $2.5 million. Police are looking for the unidentified vandal, who also scrawled "F--- you" in white marker on another Bugatti, reports KIRO-TV.

– A 10-year-old Syrian boy is being hailed as a hero for fighting alongside his father against the Islamic State. The boy, identified as Abu Omar al-Baghdadi, has been described as a "martyred" child by militants who say he was killed while fighting alongside his father in Raqqa, the capital of the group's self-proclaimed capital of Raqqa, the New York Times reports. Abu Omar's father was killed in the same city last year while trying to escape the Islamic State. The images of the boy, who was born in Jordan and moved to Syria with his family when he was two years old, are being circulated by militants and sympathizers, who say they were inspired by photos of the boy circulated by the Islamic State, the AP reports.

– Looks like Apple's smartwatch will be getting a lot more RAM than first thought. A report from Cowen and Company's Timothy Arcuri says the device will have 512MB of RAM—likely supplied by Samsung, Hynix, and Micron—in models ranging from 4GB to 8GB. The 4GB model will be the standard version, while the 8GB and 4GB models will be available, according to AppleInsider.

– Social media around the world have been flooded with rumors of Fidel Castro's death, but there was no sign Friday that the reports were true, even if the 88-year-old former Cuban leader has not been seen in public for months. Castro has not been seen in public for months.

– Kim Kardashian may have been on the cover of Vogue, but she's not the only member of the Kardashian clan to grace the pages of the influential fashion magazine. Sources tell Radar that other members of the clan have also graced the pages of Vogue, including sisters Kourtney and Khloé Kardashian, as well as Kendall and Kylie Jenner. But it's Anna Wintour who's taken the lion's share of the blame for the magazine's recent "disgusting" cover of Kimye on the cover of Vanity Fair, which has been called "disgusting" by some and "disgusting" by others. Now, sources say, Wintour and her staff have moved into a swanky new office in New York City's Freedom Tower.

– The Department of Homeland Security is pushing back against claims made by Rep. Duncan D. Hunter that militants from the Islamic State have been detained attempting to enter the US from Mexico, UPI reports. "I can tell you with absolute certainty that there has been no attempt by ISIL or any other terrorist organization to enter the United States," Jeh Johnson, the secretary of Homeland Security, tells CNN. "There has been no attempt by ISIL or any other terrorist organization to enter the United States." According to Hunter, who is running for Congress, militants from the Islamic State were detained at the Mexican border and were trying to enter the US through El Paso, Texas. "I want to be very clear: There has been no attempt by ISIL or any other terrorist organization to enter the United States," Johnson says. "There has been no attempt by ISIL or any other terrorist organization to enter the United States from Mexico." According to the Department of Homeland Security, militants from the Islamic State, also known by the Arabic name al-Muhajireen wal-Ansar, have been attempting to enter the US from Mexico for the past two and a half years.

– Love is in the air for North Korea's Kim Jong-un, who has reportedly spent thousands of dollars on snake wine—complete with a dead cobra in the bottle. The Mirror reports that the "courteous" leader, who is said to be in a long-term relationship with a Chinese woman, has reportedly bought up dozens of cases of the pricey wine, which is said to have a bitter taste. A source tells the paper: "He's trying to boost his love life by increasing his consumption of snake wine."

– A young man surprised his parents with a Christmas present this year—and both of them started to cry, the Independent reports. In a video posted to LiveLeak, the young man can be seen casually handing his parents a letter telling them he'd paid off their mortgage. "What a nice guy to have done," one LiveLeak user writes.

– A 30-year-old man in Moscow is in the hospital with serious injuries after what appears to be a botched castration, reports the Voice of Russia. Police say the man met a girl at a bar, drank a beer, then went to the sauna with her for a taxi. "I remember that I had a beer, and more do not remember," says the man, who was hospitalized in intensive care. He claims that he gently held his castration operation, and the woman sewed all the smallest blood vessels. "I met a girl at the bar, and then we went to the sauna for a taxi," says the man. "I remember that I had a beer, and more do not remember."

– Judd Nelson is the latest celebrity to take a stand against President Trump's travel ban on travelers from seven Muslim-majority countries. In an interview with Australia's ABC News, the 43-year-old actor says he's "appalled" by Trump's executive order. "I don't think it's the right thing to do," he says. "I don't think it's the right thing for America, and I think it's the right thing for the world." – A Syrian activist group says US-led airstrikes have hit the northern city of Aleppo, the country's largest, for the first time since 2011. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says planes flew over the city several times over the past few days, according to the AP. The group says at least 10 planes have been hit, though it's not clear if any of them were civilian aircraft. Activists say at least four people have been killed, including two children, in the strikes. The US says it has hit more than 100 targets in northern Syria in the past 24 hours. The strikes are part of an effort to hit the Islamic State group in the region, the Washington Post reports. The US says ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi was killed in the strikes.

– Mexican authorities say they've found a number of mass graves near where 43 students went missing last month in the southern town of Iguala. The graves were found about a quarter of a mile from the site where the students were last seen, the Wall Street Journal reports, citing Mexican newspaper El Proceso. Guerrero State Prosecutor Inaky Blanco says authorities are still trying to determine the identities of the bodies and whether they belong to the missing students, who attended a school in the town, the AP reports.

– If you've got an iPhone, iPad, or iPod Touch running on iOS 8, you're in for a treat: The company is offering a free, 30-day trial of its new mobile operating system, reports the Wall Street Journal. The free trial is available on Apple's website (here), in stores (here), and through Apple's app store (here). The new iOS is called iOS 8, and it's a major departure from the company's previous mobile efforts, notes the Journal. For example, it doesn't include a home button.

– The US says it has begun flying drones over the Syrian capital of Damascus for the first time as part of a campaign to target ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi. The State Department says the drones will be in the area of the city's international airport for at least 24 hours, the BBC reports. The move is part of a stepped-up campaign to target al-Baghdadi, who is believed to be at least 1,000 miles away in Iraq, according to US officials.

– Tiger Woods failed a drug test and has been suspended from the PGA Tour for the rest of the year, according to a source who spoke on condition of anonymity. The sources said Woods tested positive for a banned substance, but Woods' agent and the PGA Tour say the allegations are "absolutely, unequivocally, and completely false," ESPN reports. "These claims are unsourced, unverified, and completely ridiculous," agent Mark Steinberg said in a statement.

– Police in Cumbria, England, are looking for a man who they say slapped two elderly women because they had sniffles. In the first incident, an 82-year-old woman was walking in Workington on Tuesday when a man slapped her in the face, reports the BBC. In the second incident, an 87-year-old woman was walking in the same town center when a man slapped her in the face again. "It is very unusual behavior, and will have left his victims feeling confused and upset," says a police sergeant. Police say the man is in his mid-to-late 50s and was last seen wearing a baseball cap.

– An anonymous audio recording of the shooting of Michael Brown has surfaced, and it contains two distinct shots fired by Officer Darren Wilson, CNN reports. The recording was reportedly made by a man who has been interviewed by the FBI, the network notes. The man has not been identified.

– A man who thought he had lost a recording of his late wife's voice he had kept for more than 10 years describes the moment the message was recovered. – Nikolai Kryaglyachenko is a second-grader in Omsk, Russia, and he's quickly becoming the most popular boy at his school. That's because he's developed superpowers, which he discovered after he was shocked by an electric shock. "Even when I do not want to do it, I still attract things," he tells local TV. "Once I even attracted a glass—it just moved towards me." Now he's considering becoming a superhero, the Telegraph reports.

– If you're like most of us, you're probably a bit creeped out by the prospect of total darkness in December. Well, you're not alone. Thousands of people have been duped by a fake news story claiming that NASA has predicted "six days of almost complete darkness" in December, the Independent reports. The story, which appears on the website Huzlers.com, says that a solar storm will cause the world to stay dark for three days in December. "The world will remain, during these three days, without sunlight due to a solar storm, which will cause a total blackout of the Earth," the story says.

– When "Conal" signed up for Comcast's high-speed Internet service, he didn't think much of the fees he was being charged for things he didn't even know about—like equipment he didn't have, or bills that didn't show up on his account. But when he complained to Comcast customer service about the billing issues, the company allegedly pressured him into getting fired from his job at a prestigious accounting firm, Consumerist reports. Conal says he was promised his problems would be resolved, but in October, things got "significantly more hellish." He says he was charged for equipment that was never activated and for bills that didn't show up on his account. When he complained to Comcast's technical support, a rep told him the issues would be resolved "as quickly as possible." Instead, Conal says, he was told he'd be fired "within days" if he didn't give in to the company's pressure.

– It's one of the most expensive items on a sushi menu, and one man's love of sashimi nearly killed him after it led to his body becoming riddled with tapeworm. It's the most expensive—and many would argue delicious—part of a sushi menu. It is the most expensive—and many would argue delicious—part of a sushi menu. – Hundreds of Palestinians were evacuated from their homes Sunday morning after Israeli authorities opened a number of dams near the border, flooding the Gaza Valley in the wake of a recent severe winter storm. (This video shows the aftermath.)

– A Chinese woman spent a week in a KFC, eating chicken wings and nursing a broken heart after getting dumped by her boyfriend, Metro.co.uk reports. Tan Shen, 26, of Chengdu said she had not planned her extended stay in the fried chicken eatery but wound up there while wandering around depressed, according to the Huffington Post UK.

– Seth Rogen and Christian Bale will play Steve Wozniak and Steve Jobs, respectively, in the upcoming film based on Walter Isaacson's biography of the Apple co-founder, Variety reports. The film will be directed by Danny Boyle and based on Aaron Sorkin's screenplay.

– The Islamic State has taken a big step in its fight against Bashar al-Assad: The group has trained its own pilots to fly fighter jets, the New York Times reports. According to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, the first group to report the development is the US-led coalition, which says it has been aware of ISIS' efforts to train its pilots for some time. The group says it has been in contact with the Iraqi government, which has agreed to allow the training to take place in a base near the ISIS stronghold of Raqqa, Syria.

– It's not the most expensive dinner in Las Vegas history, but it's certainly one of the priciest. Vice Media CEO Shane Smith reportedly spent $300,000 on a three-course meal at the Bellagio's Prime Steakhouse on Monday, reports the Las Vegas Review-Journal. MGM Resorts International Chairman Jim Murren says it's an "encouraging sign" that tourists are willing to spend money again in Las Vegas.

– The gold version of the Apple Watch will set you back a whopping $10,000, reports the Wall Street Journal. That's in addition to the $349 stainless steel version, notes the LA Times, which calls the watch "the most expensive new product from a single tech giant since the advent of the smartphone." Apple CEO Tim Cook announced the price for the Apple Watch Edition at an event in Cupertino, Calif., on Wednesday. The Journal notes that the watch will be available starting Friday.

– Tiger Woods has been suspended from the PGA for a month after failing a drug test, a source tells CBS Sports. The source says the drug in question was "not testosterone but it's something else," and that it's not the first time Woods has tested positive for performance-enhancing drugs. "I've heard that he's suspended. I heard he's on a month's suspension. And it's kind of a strong witness," the source says. "A credible person is telling me this. Well, it's not testosterone but it's something else. I think when it's all said and done he's going to surpass Lance Armstrong with infamy."

– Libyan strongman Moammar Gadhafi has fled the country and is holed up in a Tripoli hotel with other members of his extremist group, al-Jazeera reports. Gadhafi's whereabouts are unknown, but there have been reports of at least a dozen airliners being seized by militants in the country over the last month. One of those seized was a Boeing 737 bound for Paris that was found on the outskirts of the capital yesterday, the Telegraph reports.

– The five Guantanamo Bay detainees released in exchange for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl have been in touch with members of the al-Qaeda-linked Haqqani network, Sen. Lindsey Graham says, but they are still being monitored in Qatar. Graham, who recently visited Qatar, says he had been afraid one of the detainees had left the country but said he was assured during his visit that all five remain in the small Gulf nation. The Pentagon said today that it is working with Qatar and is confident that any threat posed by the former detainees can be mitigated, the AP reports.
– Residents reported a loud boom as the meteorite crashed but scientists said no one had seen the streak that a speeding space rock would score across the sky: 'It's a wake-up call'

– At 9:47am PST on Jan. 4, Pluto will be passing directly behind Jupiter, which means the combined gravitational force of the two planets will temporarily counteract the Earth's own gravity and make people virtually weightless, according to British astronomer Patrick Moore. Moore calls this the "Jovian-Plutonian Gravitational Effect," the Daily Buzz Live reports. "It's going to feel like you're standing on top of a biplane," he says. "It's going to feel like you're standing on top of a roller coaster." According to Moore, this rare alignment of the planets will happen every 18 months, but this will be the first time it's happened since 1930.

– Hunky mensch who took down violent bully looks like Paul Rudd, is not Paul Rudd Sorry, amateur celebrity sleuths—the actor Paul Rudd was not involved in the tackling of a man shouting homophobic slurs in a Dallas airport last week. The Dallas Morning News reports that Rudd was at the Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport on Friday when a man began shouting anti-gay slurs at him and his girlfriend. When the woman tried to calm him down, the man punched her in the face, grabbed her by the hair, and tackled her in the airport's main terminal, where he was restrained by other passengers. The incident was caught on video.

– A cloistered South American nun reportedly had "no idea" she was pregnant when she gave birth to a baby boy in Italy, the New York Daily News reports. The unnamed nun reportedly had "no idea" she was pregnant before she gave birth at Bartolomeo Eustachio Hospital in San Severino, Italy.

– Apple's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs hasn't exactly been a roaring success. The company's latest gadget, a smart watch called the Apple Watch, has had mixed reviews, with some saying it's too expensive and others saying it's too little, too late, reports the Wall Street Journal. The Journal notes that the $349 price tag for the base model of the watch—which will be available next month—is a big increase from the $199 price tag for the iPhone 6. Apple CEO Tim Cook has said the watch will be "the most expensive product in the company's history," though he hasn't said how much the company plans to spend on it.

– A mysterious explosion that rocked Nicaragua's crowded capital, creating a large crater, appears to have been caused by a small meteorite. Amazingly, in a sprawling city of 1.2 million people, the impact near the international airport did not cause any known injuries, but it did leave a crater measuring 12 meters across and was felt throughout the capital late on Saturday night, local time. Nicaraguan authorities believe it was a piece of the small asteroid dubbed 2014 RC, which passed very close to Earth on Sunday and was estimated by astronomers to be about 20 meters wide, or the size of a house.

– A lawyer for the family of Michael Brown says he has audio of 10 or 11 shots fired at Ferguson, Mo., police officer Darren Wilson during the shooting, CNN reports. The attorney, Lopa Blumenthal, says the audio was recorded by a man in an apartment near where Brown was killed. In the 12-second audio, a man appears to record a message for someone on an adult video service before six shots are fired in rapid succession, the Los Angeles Times reports. After a two-second pause, another four or five shots are heard. Blumenthal says the man, who has not been identified, was in the apartment complex near where Brown was killed and recorded the shooting because he feared for his life. "He was afraid for his life," Blumenthal says. "He didn't know what was going on with the police." She says the man told her he was in the apartment complex's parking lot when he heard gunshots and went outside to see what was going on. She says the man told her he went back inside the apartment and saw Wilson standing over Brown with a gun. Blumenthal says the man told her he heard Wilson tell Brown, "I'm going to kill you." Brown was unarmed when he was shot dead by Wilson. Blumenthal says

– A 22-year-old man in Macedonia is accused of cutting off his own penis and throwing it in the trash after he was dumped by his girlfriend, the Independent reports. Oliver Ilic reportedly told doctors at a hospital in the town of Kocani that he had a small appendage and cited that as the reason why his girlfriend was not interested in him. Ilic called emergency services when he could not stop the bleeding and was taken to the hospital. Police searched his house and discovered the severed organ in a bin after it had been cut off with a single swipe

– Italian fisherman Dino Ferrari, an expert at catching big wels catfish, outdid himself on Thursday when he landed an enormous 280-pounder in the Po Delta, a part of the famous Po River, the longest river in Italy at more than 400 miles. The wels catfish was put in a sling and weighed out at 280 pounds. The Po River and Delta are known for massive wels catfish, but anything bigger than 6.5 feet is considered extremely rare. This one measured 8.8 feet. The UK Mirror reported that Ferrari's fish could possibly be the world's biggest.

– Islamist militias in Libya have reportedly taken control of 11 commercial aircraft from Tripoli International Airport, sparking fears of a 9/11-style terror attack. Ahead of the 13th anniversary of the September 11 attacks on New York and Washington, reports emerged that Islamist militias took control of nearly a dozen jetliners last month after the airport was the scene of a fierce battle. On Sunday, the Libyan government announced that they had lost control of the capital to the militants, who include the Islamic groups Ansar al Sharia—which has ties to the Islamic State—and Libyan Dawn, an umbrella group for Islamist militias.

– Seth Rogen has signed on to play Steve Jobs in Danny Boyle's film, based on Aaron Sorkin's biography of the tech icon, Variety reports. Christian Bale had already been cast in the role, and this new addition "is surprising, but kinda great," writes Willa Paskin at Salon. "It sounds like the whole film will offer a somewhat unconventional approach to the life of this tech icon."
– JJ Abrams is said to be frustrated with the slow drip of leaks from the set of Star Wars Episode VII: The Force Awakens, and wants the film to be released in the summer

– The wife of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi has been arrested in Lebanon, along with the leader's young daughter, Lebanese officials say. Nohad Machnouk, the country's interior minister, says DNA tests have confirmed that the child being held by authorities is al-Baghdadi's, the AP reports. He says the child's mother, who is also in custody, was married to al-Baghdadi for three months in 2014.

– The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria has released a video showing the beheading of American photojournalist James Foley, reports the New York Times. The militant group, which has threatened to kill another journalist named Steven Joel Sotloff if the US doesn't end its airstrikes in Iraq, says Foley's beheading is a message to President Obama to end the American intervention in Iraq. The 33-year-old Foley, a native of Rochester, NY, worked for Time, the National Interest, and other news organizations.

– Macaulay Culkin's reps have called rumors of the actor's death a hoax, reports the Hollywood Reporter. The Home Alone star's Twitter feed has been inundated with messages of condolences from fans assuming the rumors are true.

– Christian Bale has dropped out of the Steve Jobs biopic being directed by Danny Boyle, according to the Hollywood Reporter. "After much deliberation and conflicting feelings, came to the conclusion he was not right for the part," sources say. Earlier, screenwriter Aaron Sorkin had called Bale a "slam dunk" for the role. "We needed the best actor on the board in a certain age range and that's Christian Bale," Sorkin said last week. "Looks like it's time to find the next best actor."

– A group in Dallas has set up a tribunal under Sharia law to resolve disputes between Muslims and non-Muslims, reports Breitbart Texas. The group, called the Islamic Tribunal of Texas, says it's a "non-binding dispute resolution organization" that's "voluntary" for its members to participate, notes the Dallas Morning News. One of its judges, a doctor, says the tribunal is "a tribunal, not arbitration."

– It's official: HBO is launching its own stand-alone video service next month on Apple TV and other devices, the International Business Times reports. The stand-alone service, to be called HBO Net, will be similar in concept to Netflix's stand-alone service, which launched in the US last year. It will also be available in the UK and Australia. The International Business Times notes that the move is part of HBO's plan to expand its reach beyond the US.

– A school trip to the Croatian capital of Banja Luka turned into a nightmare for seven 13- to 15-year-old girls when their parents discovered they were pregnant. The girls, who are all from the same family, went on the five-day trip last month, but when they returned to their family's home in the city of Banja Luka on Tuesday, their parents discovered that seven of them were pregnant, the BBC reports. "I was shocked," one of the girls, who is due to give birth in September, tells the Telegraph. "I didn't expect to find out that I was pregnant. I didn't expect to find out that my parents were expecting me. I was shocked." Her mother, who is divorced from one of the girls' parents, says the family is "devastated" by the news and is trying to figure out how to get the girls out of the hospital as quickly as possible.

– An American journalist beheaded by ISIS has been identified as James Foley, a 40-year-old native of Rochester, NY, who was working as a freelance journalist when he was abducted in Syria in November 2012, reports the New York Times. The Islamic State, which released a video yesterday showing Foley's beheading, had previously threatened to kill Foley if it didn't get its hands on him within 48 hours. "I'm back," a voice said in the video as Foley said he would be killed if his captors didn't release him. "I'm back. I'm 40 years old. I'm an American citizen, and I've been abducted by the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria. Because of your arrogant foreign policy towards the Islamic State, I will be killed." Foley had been writing for GlobalPost, AFP, and PBS' NewsHour when he was taken hostage. "He was trying to tell the world about the terrible reality of war in Syria," his mother tells the Times.

– Militants from the Islamic State have released a video showing the beheading of American journalist James Foley, reports the New York Times. It's the first such video released by the militant group, which now controls a third of Iraq and Syria. Foley, who grew up in Rochester, NY, had been missing for more than a year.

– A photo that purports to show the body of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi was actually taken of an ethnic Albanian militant killed in 2013, CNN reports. Sami Hafez Al-Abdullah was killed in an airstrike in northern Iraq, according to the Islamic State's media arm, and the photo purporting to show al-Baghdadi's body was taken by a member of the Islamic State's media arm. The head and body of al-Baghdadi were also taken from the same location, CNN reports. The head of al-Baghdadi was found in the backseat of a car in northern Iraq, according to the Islamic State's media arm, and the body of al-Baghdadi was found in the backseat of a car in northern Iraq. – A Taliban commander freed in a controversial prisoner swap with the US last month is now trying to return to the battlefield, reports the Wall Street Journal. A senior Taliban official tells the newspaper that Mullah Abdul Qayyum Zakir, who was captured in eastern Afghanistan in June 2009, has been trying to return to the war zone since he was freed from Guantanamo Bay in a deal that saw the release of five Gitmo detainees. Zakir is believed to be the highest-ranking member of the Taliban to be released from the detention center. President Obama has said he plans to close Gitmo within a year.

– As Canada's Parliament sergeant-at-arms, Kevin Vickers' role is largely ceremonial—he carries a bicorne hat and tail coat—but when a gunman stormed the building Wednesday, he put pomp and circumstance to one side, found a gun and fired the shots that brought the rampage to an end. As Canada comes to terms with finding itself in the firing line of militant Islamists, it turned for reassurance to a 58-year-old former Mountie formerly best known for carrying a golden mace, the Guardian reports. Vickers' role is largely ceremonial, symbolizing the authority of the body and keeping order in the chamber wearing a bicorne hat and tail coat. But on Wednesday, when a lone Islamist gunman stormed the building, he put pomp and circumstance to one side, found a gun and fired the shots that brought the rampage to an end.

– "Who would've thought that Lego was on the forefront of promoting gender equality?" That's the question posed by a post on Reddit this week, along with a photo of what appears to be a letter that accompanied Lego boxes in 1974. The letter, which Reddit user fryd_ says he found "with his niece and nephew at their Grandma's house" in a box with a "blonde girl on the front with a white Lego house," reads, "The urge to create is equally strong in all children...boys and girls." It goes on to remind parents that "gender doesn't have to be a barrier to creating." If it's indeed real, it would mark the first time Lego has promoted gender equality.

– A Vine video of Vladimir Putin's motorcade has gone viral, and it's not for the reasons you might think. It looks like a rocket, but there's something a bit suggestive about the formation. "Please, that sort of language isn't necessary," says one Vine user. "Besides, it's obviously a rocket."

– An Indian man accused of trying to rape a teenager reportedly had his penis lopped off by vigilante locals after they allegedly heard the girl's screams. The incident took place in the northern town of Pandharkawada, reports the Times of India. According to local media, the man was trying to rape a 15-year-old girl when locals heard her screams and stopped him. They cut off his penis with a sharp object and tossed it in a river, reports the Indian Express.

In the wake of last week's shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., the Washington Post takes a look at what it takes to make that kind of a story work. Among the many factors that go into a story's success or failure: the right people, the right place, and the right story.
