– When a young boy was mourning the death of his dog, Pope Francis was there to console him—and now the pontiff has confirmed that dogs do indeed go to heaven, Time reports. "There is a place in heaven for dogs and all of God's creatures," he said during his weekly address in St. Peter's Square. "The Lord has a place for all of God's creatures," he added, according to the Independent.

– Syrian activists claim militants from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) seized earlier this week a cache of weapons airdropped by US-led coalition forces that were meant to supply Kurdish fighters battling the extremist group, the AP reports. According to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, the weapons were found in the town of Kobane, which has been under the control of ISIS for more than a year. The group says the weapons were intended to be delivered to Kurdish fighters fighting ISIS in northern Iraq, but were instead seized by the militants.

– Boston Marathon bombing suspect Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was rushed to the hospital yesterday after suffering an "unfortunate accident," the warden of the Massachusetts detention center where he's being held tells the Boston Globe. Tsarnaev, 21, suffered a pulmonary embolism, which occurs when a blood vessel in one's lung is blocked by something else in one's body. Luckily, no one was seriously injured in the accident, which took place in his cell.

– A small meteor thought to have broken off from an Earth-passing asteroid crashed into a 40-foot-wide crater near an airport in Nicaragua's capital over the weekend, but luckily no one was hurt: A small meteor, thought to have broken off from an Earth-passing asteroid, left a 40-foot-wide crater. (See video here.)

– Condé Nast has signed a deal to occupy 1 million square feet in the new World Trade Center tower, but not everyone is thrilled about the move. The magazine publisher, which has signed a 25-year lease for 1 million square feet in the tower, has been accused by critics of turning the World Trade Center into a "blank slate" for the company, the New York Daily News reports. "A bunch ate through the ceiling of a sports editor's office and crawled all over his desk and left poops on his keyboard," a former editor tells the Daily News.

– The Indian government sacks a civil servant who went on leave in 1990 and never came back to work, in a case of "wilful absence," the government says. The Hindustan Times reports on the bizarre case of DS Rawat, a 59-year-old civil servant. Rawat was on leave in 1990 when his wife died, and he was told by his superiors that he should return to work. But he never came back, and now the government is punishing him for his "wilful absence." The Times of India reports that Rawat's case was brought to the attention of the government's Vigilance Commission, which investigated the death of his wife. The commission found that Rawat's "wilful absence" was the cause of her death and recommended that he be punished. Rawat's lawyer says his client had gone on leave to attend to his ailing mother, but never returned to work. The government is now punishing him for his "wilful absence."

– President Obama today confirmed that airstrikes in Somalia earlier this week killed the leader of al-Shabab, a militant group linked to al-Qaeda. "The success against al-Shabab should leave no doubt about our determination to degrade and eventually destroy [ISIS] in Iraq and Syria," he said at the conclusion of a NATO summit in Wales, reports the Wall Street Journal. The airstrikes were part of an effort to push al-Shabab back from its strongholds in southern Somalia, notes the New York Times.

– A ceasefire between Nigeria's security forces and Boko Haram militants appears to be unraveling, with at least five attacks blamed on the Islamic extremists since the deal was announced on Friday, the New York Times reports. The attacks come a day after the country's president announced that negotiations were underway with Boko Haram to secure the release of more than 200 schoolgirls kidnapped by the militants in April. But the militants haven't confirmed the ceasefire, and security sources say at least five attacks have been carried out since the deal was announced—and dozens of people have been killed, the Times reports.

– Lana, a self-described feminist, says she was "shocked" when people questioned her decision to abort her baby because it was a boy. The reason, she tells Injustice Stories via Raw Story, is that she's a "child of privilege." Lana, who only uses her first name, "appears to be a child of privilege," writes Emily Shire at the Daily Beast. "It's hard to believe this is real, but according to the website 'Injustice Stories,' a woman named Lana, a self-described feminist, boasted of aborting her baby because it was a boy," writes Shire. "Then, after making that declaration, claims to be shocked that some people might have a problem with that. Lana, who only uses her first name, appears to be a child of privilege."

– Sandy Summers is the highest-paid " performer" on You Tube, making an estimated $5 million a year unwrapping toys, the Daily Mail reports. She's also a former porn star, according to former neighbors. They knew her as Daiane DeJesus for years, but for years they didn't know who she was—until a family friend named her as Sandy Summers.

– A photo purporting to show the young son of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi has been making the rounds on social media. The image, which purports to show a boy about 10 years old, has been shared more than 10,000 times since it was posted on a Twitter account that Emergent Media describes as "seeking information on 'the cub of Baghdadi'; an image of a child, about 10-years-old, being shared online." The Twitter account claims the child is the son of an ISIS fighter named Abu Muhammed al-Absi. The child is believed to be the youngest ISIS fighter to have been killed in Syria, the Washington Post reports. According to some sharing the image of the child, his father is also an ISIS fighter, possibly named Abu Muhammed al-Absi.

– Apple will offer a low-power mode on the Apple Watch to help boost it through longer days, according to a new report that also takes a stab at dispelling rumors that the company may have elected to all some long-rumored sensors last minute. Apple will offer a low-power mode on the Apple Watch to help boost it through longer days, according to a new report that also takes a stab at dispelling rumors that the company may have elected to all some long-rumored sensors last minute.

– Looks like Christian Bale won't be playing Steve Jobs in Danny Boyle's film. Sources tell the Hollywood Reporter that Bale decided he wasn't right for the role, and pulled out of the movie after screenwriter Aaron Sorkin confirmed he would be playing the tech icon. No word on whether Seth Rogan will replace Bale.

– President Obama met with Saudi Arabia's King Salman today in Riyadh, and a YouTube video seems to show that the first lady's face was digitally blurred in the presence of the king, the Washington Post reports. Twitter was quick to point out the distortion, with one user tweeting, " Saudi TV blurred out Michelle Obama's face when she and Barack met King Salman!" Another tweeted, "Our producer just referred to the blurring of Michelle Obama here as a 'kablur.' Only it's bullshit. The YouTube uploader appears to have added the blur, not

– It's not every day you get the chance to chop off your own penis, but that's exactly what happened to Yang Hu, a 23-year-old man from Taiwan who was apparently fed up with not having a girlfriend and decided to do just that, reports the Daily Mail. He cut off his own penis—which he had no real use for—and posted the video on YouTube.

– Batman v. Superman: Dawn of Justice is in the midst of filming in Detroit, and the internet went into a tizzy Friday over a rumor that someone had stolen the iconic Batmobile, reports the Detroit Free Press. But police say that's not true. “The Batmobile is safe in the Batcave where it belongs,” says a police spokesman.

– A soldier standing guard at Canada's National War Memorial shot and killed a gunman Monday morning before he was himself shot and killed by police, authorities said. The assailant, identified as Canadian soldier Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, ran at the soldier before shooting him twice, officials said. Zehaf-Bibeau was shot dead by police as he approached a building where they were meeting to discuss plans for the war memorial. The soldier, who was in his 20s, was pronounced dead at the scene. Police have not released a possible motive for the attack.

– Apple CEO Tim Cook says the company is "off to a great start" with its much-anticipated Apple Watch, which will be unveiled next week. In an interview with the New York Times, Cook says the watch, which will be available in stores on April 24, will be different from previous Apple devices in that it won't have a display like the iPhone. Instead, it will have a screen that is four inches diagonally, reports the Wall Street Journal, which notes that this is the first time Apple has used a "phablet" device instead of a smartphone. Cook says the watch will have a price tag in the same ballpark as the iPhone: $349 for the basic model and up to $10,000 for a "step-up luxury" model. He didn't give a date for when the watch will be available in stores, but he did say it will be "a little bit later" than the iPhone.

– Axl Rose, lead singer of Guns N' Roses and the last remaining original member of the band, has been found dead at the age of 52, the band's rep confirms to the Los Angeles Times. The cause of death hasn't been determined. Rose, who was found dead in his Las Vegas home, started Guns N' Roses with Slash in 1983 and left the band two years later, according to the band's website.

– If you're using iOS 8, there's a good chance you're going to want to reset your settings. But if you're also using iCloud Drive, there's a chance you're going to want to delete all those documents you stored there. That's because, according to MacRumors, an alleged bug in iOS 8 appears to be deleting those documents without the user's permission. The problem appears to be triggered by the option to " Reset All Settings," which, according to some forum users, is supposed to simply reset your settings but leave your data and media untouched. But some forum users say that's not the case, as certain iCloud documents also vanished after they reset all settings.

– A 70-year-old priest in Massachusetts is being hailed as a miracle worker after he was found unconscious in his office and declared dead 48 minutes later, the AP reports. According to WCVB-TV, the Rev. Joseph Murphy was found by a co-worker who had gone into Murphy's office to check on him. Murphy was pronounced dead at the scene, but he was revived with CPR on the way to the hospital. Murphy, who is Catholic, tells the station he believes God saved his life. "I don't know if I would have made it if they hadn't found me," he says. "I don't know if I would have made it if they hadn't found me." According to WCVB-TV, Murphy says he believed he was dead for 48 minutes before he was revived. He says he thought he was dead for two hours before he was revived. – Taylor Lianne Chandler was born David Roy Fitch in 1973—but she's intersex, meaning she has male genitalia but no testicles. She also has a uterus and no ovaries, the Independent reports. At 15, she changed her name from Paige Victoria Whitney to Taylor Lianne Chandler. Now 41, she's dating 29-year-old Olympic swimmer Michael Phelps.

– The next generation of Apple's smartwatch is reportedly in the works. The Wall Street Journal reports that the company has "studied platinum watch casings," which could be the material for a luxury edition of the next-generation Apple Watch. For the current Apple Watch, the most expensive version will boast 18-karat gold plating. For the next one, Apple is reportedly working on a model that will cost at least $20,000.

– An airstrike in the ISIS stronghold of Mosul killed at least two members of the group, including an aide to ISIS leader Abu Bakr Al-Baghdadi, according to the Iraqi Defense Ministry. An airstrike in the ISIS stronghold of Mosul killed at least two members of the group, including an aide to ISIS leader Abu Bakr Al-Baghdadi, according to the Iraqi Defense Ministry. – It's not every week that a pope makes headlines, but that's exactly what happened last week when Pope Francis addressed a young boy who was distraught over the death of his dog, Time reports. "One day, we will see our animals again in the eternity of Christ," the pontiff said during his weekly address in St. Peter's Square. The boy looked at the pope and said, "That's what you say to me, 'I will see your animals again in the eternity of Christ,'" according to a video of the pontiff's remarks, which can be seen here.

– Robert Plant’s publicist called a report that he ripped up an $800 million deal to reunite Led Zeppelin “rubbish,” the Guardian reports. According to the Daily Mirror, Plant, Jimmy Page, John Paul Jones, and Jason Bonham were offered the deal to perform a 35-date, three-city reunion tour. But Plant’s publicist says the story is “rubbish.”

– Police in Kansas City, Mo., are investigating a shooting that left one person dead and another seriously ill, reports the Kansas City Star. Police say the shooting occurred about 9:30pm Saturday at an apartment building on the city's north side. No other details were immediately available.

– A photo purporting to show the slain body of Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi appears to be a doctored picture of another slain militant killed in Syria in 2013. A photo purporting to show the slain body of Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi appears to be a doctored picture of another slain militant killed in Syria in 2013. – The World Health Organization is testing ISIS fighters in Mosul, Iraq, for Ebola, according to an Iraqi newspaper report picked up by the New York Post. The WHO is also checking a hospital in the city 250 miles north of Baghdad for other ISIS fighters who might have the disease, the report says. ISIS fighters are being treated in the city's main hospital, Al-Sabah reports.

– Batman V Superman: Dawn of Justice is currently filming in Detroit, and one of the cars used in the movie is missing, according to a report at Bleeding Cool. "The scuttlebutt from sources in Detroit is that one of the Batmobile models being used in the filming of Batman Vs. Superman has gone missing, believed stolen," the report reads. "Warner Bros representatives did not respond to inquiries."

– Matt Taibbi, a reporter for Rolling Stone who was recently hired by e-Bay founder Pierre Omidyar to cover political corruption, has taken a leave of absence from his new job, New York Magazine reports. According to the magazine's Andrew Rice, Taibbi has been absent from First Look Media—which also hosts Glenn Greenwald's The Intercept—for "several weeks." Taibbi was hired by Omidyar in February to cover political corruption, and his new publication, Racket, was supposed to be out this fall. But Rice says there have been "differences with executives" at First Look, and that Taibbi's leave is "only the latest in a series of shifts" since Omidyar hired him.
– ISIS militants have released a video that purportedly shows the beheading of British citizen David Haines, reports Reuters. The 44-year-old aid worker was kidnapped in March 2013.

– A Canadian-born woman has been taken prisoner by the Islamic State in Syria, according to Israeli media. Israel Radio reports that Gill Rosenberg, a Canadian-born resident of Tel Aviv, has been taken prisoner in northern Syria by Islamic State (Isis) fighters

– A mother in China is accused of cannibalizing her newborn after a nurse found her trying to eat the baby's arm, the Telegraph reports. The 24-year-old, identified only as Li Zhenghua, was in the hospital recovering from the birth when a nurse noticed she had her teeth stuck around her son's arm. The nurse tried to prise the woman off the baby, but she wouldn't let her go. She was sedated and removed from the baby. "It was really shocking, the arm," said a hospital spokesman.

– The wife and daughter of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi were detained by the Lebanese army as they crossed from Syria into Lebanon nine days ago, security officials say. The woman has been identified as Saja al-Dulaimi, an Iraqi, by a Lebanese security official and a senior political source. Lebanese newspaper As-Safir reported she had been detained in co-ordination with "foreign intelligence." A Lebanese security source says the arrest was "a powerful card to apply pressure" in negotiations to secure the release of 27 members of the Lebanese security forces.

– A Canadian-Israeli woman says she is "safe and secure" after ISIS claimed to have kidnapped her from the Syrian city of Kobani, the CBC reports. Gill Rosenberg, a Canadian-Israeli woman, said on Facebook yesterday that she was "safe and secure" after a number of jihadist platforms claimed she had been captured by ISIS while fighting with the Kurds. "I am safe and secure," she wrote. "My family and I would like to thank all the people who have reached out with messages of support and love." Rosenberg, who was born in Toronto and moved to Israel when she was 12, had been working as a volunteer at a school in Kobani.

– Apple was aiming for a full day of battery life in its upcoming Apple Watch, but "sources familiar with the Watch's development" tell 9to5mac.com that's not going to be the case. The site says the watch will boast "similar longevity" to Android Wear devices at this point, and will likely ship sometime this year. "Obviously that's not all active use; in fact, that's not all active use," the sources say. But that doesn't mean the watch won't be useful: The sources say the company is working on a way to extend the watch's battery life to up to 24 hours.

– Former Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein's military pilots have been training ISIS militants to fly fighter jets captured from the Syrian military, the Telegraph reports. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says former pilots from Saddam's air force have been training fighters from the Islamic State, also known as ISIS, to fly three captured F-16 fighter jets. The planes are believed to have been captured by the Syrian military as part of its campaign to drive ISIS out of the northern city of Raqqa, where the group's self-proclaimed capital is located.

– The wife and son of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi have been arrested in Lebanon, security officials and politicians tell the Telegraph. Saja Hamid al-Dulaimi and her 11-year-old son were detained 10 days ago at a checkpoint north of the Lebanese town of Tripoli, a senior security source says. "She had crossed into Lebanon from Syria," the source says. "She and her son were traveling on fake passports." The boy is said to be no older than 11 years old.

– Bono's awkward interaction with Apple CEO Tim Cook at the company's Worldwide Developer's Conference was the talk of the tech world on Wednesday, and not in a good way. The U2 frontman was onstage for a Q&A after Cook announced that the new Apple Watch would have a built-in battery that would last up to 24 hours, the Wall Street Journal reports. "I don't know how long it's going to last, but it's going to be 24 hours," Bono said. "I don't know how long it's going to last, but it's going to be 24 hours," Cook replied. "Bono really should ask Tim Cook about the Apple Watch's battery life," tweeted Henry Blodget of Business Insider. "You have to charge it every day," he added. "Bono really should ask Tim Cook about the Apple Watch's battery life."

– In the wake of the Ray Rice brouhaha, the NFL has decided to do away with its personal conduct policy—at least for the time being. An ESPN panel discussion on domestic violence, originally scheduled to take place today, has been canceled, reports ESPN.com. The network says it decided not to move forward with the discussion "out of sensitivity to the tragedy that took the life of Ray Rice." Rice has said he knocked out his then-fiancee in an elevator, and the league suspended him for the rest of the season after determining he violated the league's conduct policy.

– A 26-year-old high school teacher in Mexico may lose her job after a student leaked a video of her having sex with him, the New York Daily News reports. According to Fox News, Lucita Sandoval has been accused of romping with students in the past, but this is the first time it's been proven she's had sex with a student. In the video, the teen is seen giving the camera a thumbs-up before panning around to show he's having sex with Sandoval. The boy, who has not been identified, allegedly told Sandoval he had deleted the video. She asked him to delete it but he ended up sharing it on the web instead.

– Apple's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs isn't expected until later this year, but the company's smartwatch is already causing a fuss. According to a post at 9to5mac.com, the $349 Apple Watch will be priced at $500 for the mid-tier steel model and up to $5,000 for the top-end gold Edition. That's a number much higher than previous estimates, the Wall Street Journal reports. The Journal says it's based on "a source familiar with the company's plans." Apple hasn't commented on the rumor.

– A group calling itself A3maq News says it has posted a video online that purports to show an Islamic State militant inspecting an airdropped package of weapons the US is believed to have sent to help Kurdish fighters defending the Syrian town of Kobani. The video, which could not be independently verified, shows a masked militant examining a package attached to a parachute. Later, he looks into crates containing various munitions, including RPG rounds and grenades. The video could not be independently verified, but A3maq News has previously posted ISIS-linked content and the some of the weapons in the video were said to have been airdropped by the US near Kobani.

– In his weekly address in St. Peter's Square, Pope Francis confirmed what we've always known: All dogs go to heaven. The pontiff consoled a little boy who was heartbroken over the death of his beloved pup.

– Axl Rose is alive and well, TMZ reports, after the singer's Facebook page was inundated with more than a million "likes" following a false report that he had died. The gossip site says it's not the first time Rose has been the victim of a hoax, but it's the first time he's been so widely spread online. Axl Rose's Facebook page attracted nearly 1 million "likes" on Monday after a story claiming the Guns N' Roses frontman had died suddenly appeared on the site, Gawker reports.

– Led Zeppelin fans will be disappointed to learn that there's no reunion tour and a story that appeared in the Daily Mirror suggesting that Robert Plant ripped up an $800 contract for such a gig is false, according to the Guardian. The story claimed that Plant had agreed to reunite with Jimmy Page, Robert Plant, and John Paul Jones for a tour that would have included a London show at the O2 Arena in November. But a rep for the band tells the Guardian that there's no reunion tour and that the Mirror's story is "false."

– When Apple announced its Apple Watch earlier this month, it said its starting price would be $349. Now, anonymous sources tell French website iGen that the stainless steel version will start at $500, while the high-end gold Apple Watch Edition will start between $4,000 and $5,000, according to 9to5mac.com. The aluminum Apple Watch Sport will start at $349, the sources say. Apple will ship its smartwatch in time for Valentine's Day, the sources say.

– Michael Zehaf Bibeau, the man believed to have opened fire at Canada's National War Memorial yesterday before being shot dead by police, was a 32-year-old Canadian who had recently converted to Islam, sources tell the CBC. The sources say that Bibeau, who was born in Quebec and moved to Canada when he was 12, was a member of the Order of Canada, the country's highest civilian honor. He was also a member of the Order of Canada's armed forces reserve and the Order of Canada Order of Merit for his service in the Royal Canadian Air Force. According to the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to release the suspect's name, Bibeau was shot in the back of the head by a soldier standing guard at the National War Memorial before he was shot and killed by police.

– Militants from the Islamic State have reportedly killed a 10-year-old boy in Syria, making him the youngest foreign fighter to die in battle for the group, the Telegraph reports. According to the Center for Strategic and International Studies, images of the boy, believed to be from Yemen, are circulating on social media. They show him posing with a balaclava and what appears to be a gun. The center says the boy is believed to be the son of a militant from Yemen who was killed in an airstrike in Raqqa, Syria.

– The price of an Apple Watch may be going up, and not in a good way. The Wall Street Journal reports that the price of the stainless steel and gold versions of the watch, which went on sale in the US in early September, could be as much as $500 more than the $349 price tag for the non- stainless steel version. That would mean the watch would cost more than twice as much as the cheaper stainless steel version of the Apple Watch, which is expected to go on sale in China next month. The Journal also notes that the price of the gold version of the watch, which is expected to go on sale in the US next month, could be as much as $5,000 more than the $349 price tag for the non- stainless steel version.

– Apple is set to unveil a new version of its MacBook Air at the Consumer Electronics Show next week, 9to5Mac reports. The new model will be a 12-incher with a "radically new design," according to the site, ditching the MacBook Air's standard USB ports, MagSafe connectors, and SD card slots. The new design will be showcased at an event in San Francisco on Jan. 10. According to 9to5Mac, the new MacBook Air will have a "higher-resolution display" and "few of the trappings we've come to expect from a MacBook Air."

– Judd Nelson’s agent hustled to the Los Angeles Times to clear the air: “Reports of Judd Nelson’s death are not accurate, please see attached photo,” said Gregg Klein in response to a Times question about the actor’s status. “I went to his house this morning to take a photo of the front page of today’s newspaper,” Klein continued. “It’s not in the building mentioned in the original false report.”

– Cesar Millan, the celebrity dog trainer who gained fame with his book The Dog Whisperer, has died at the age of 45, TMZ reports. He suffered a heart attack. Millan, who was born in Mexico and grew up in California, made a name for himself with his "incredible rehabilitation and trainingtechnics dogs," according to the gossip site. He also starred in his own TV series The Dog Whisperer.

– A US Marine who was shot in the head by a Taliban sniper while leaving cover during a 2013 raid in Helmand province, Afghanistan, was saved by "Lady luck," Fox News reports. Video of the incident shows the marine's helmet being ripped apart by the bullet, only for it to be replaced with a new one. "Definitely should have laid some accumulator bets as soon as he returned to base," the Independent states.

– For those who can't make it to an Apple Store to pick up an Apple Watch, the Wall Street Journal reports that the company is adding "new spaces" at those stores where people will be able to book appointments to try on different watch models. The idea is to make it easier for people who don't have time to make an in-person visit to an Apple Store to buy the watch, according to the Journal's sources, who say sales people are being trained to help customers pick out the best model for their money. 9to5Mac reported last week that Apple was planning a major retail push for the Apple Watch.

– Nigeria says it has reached a deal with Boko Haram militants to release more than 200 schoolgirls kidnapped by the group six months ago, the BBC reports. "We have reached an agreement with Boko Haram for the release of all the girls and women who were abducted by the terrorist group," the country's president said in a statement. "We are also in the process of negotiating with the abductors of the girls." According to the AFP, President Goodluck Jonathan said in a televised address to the nation that the deal was a "big step forward." Boko Haram, an Islamist militant group based in Nigeria, has been terrorizing the country for more than a decade.

– The Islamic State has released a video that purports to show the beheading of American journalist James Foley, and the White House is confirming the video's authenticity, the New York Times reports. "We condemn these barbaric acts in the strongest possible terms," President Obama said in a statement. "The secretary of state, the president of the United States, the government of the United States, and the people of the United States stand in solidarity with the family of James Foley, and in solidarity with the people of Iraq, Syria, and around the world." The video, which the Times says was shot in the Syrian city of Raqqa, also shows the beheading of journalist Steven Sotloff. Sotloff, who was kidnapped in Iraq in 2012, had been working for the website GlobalPost.

– A US drone strike killed the leader of an al-Qaeda-linked militant group in Somalia early today, US and Somali officials tell the AP. Ahmed Godane was the No. 2 leader of al-Qaeda in Somalia, according to the SITE Intelligence Group, which describes al-Qaeda as the world's most active terrorist organization. Godane was killed near the town of Bossaso, which is controlled by the al-Qaeda-affiliated al-Shabab group, the New York Times reports. Al-Shabab claimed responsibility for the strike in a text message to the Times. "Godane was the leader of al-Qaeda in Somalia, and he was killed in a US airstrike in Bossaso," said a commander of al-Shabab, which controls much of southern Somalia.

– It's not every day that a TV weatherman gets caught on tape urinating in the woods, but that's exactly what happened to NBC weatherman Mike Seidel over the weekend in North Carolina, reports Mediaite. In a video that has since gone viral, Seidel can be seen urinating in the woods as Lester Holt cuts to a satellite feed. He then zips up his fly and puts his gloves back on. The network says Seidel was simply "checking his phone," which he had apparently dropped in the snow. But there are a lot of unanswered questions: Why didn't one of the PAs in the film crew grab his phone for him? Why has he been urinating in the woods?

– A man with a rifle shot a soldier standing guard at the War Memorial in downtown Ottawa, and witnesses said there were further shots fired at Parliament Hill nearby. – Beck took home album of the year at last night's Grammy Awards, beating out Beyonce and Sam Smith. But before Beck took the stage to accept his award, Kanye West jumped up and rushed the stage—just like he did at the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards when he interrupted Taylor Swift's acceptance speech, the Adobo Chronicles reports. As Beck took the stage to accept his award, West suddenly appeared, turned away, and jumped back down.

– Kurt Sutter, creator of the hit FX drama Sons of Anarchy, has announced plans to turn the popular television series into a major motion picture. In an interview with the Hollywood Reporter, Sutter says he's "thrilled" to be working on a big-screen adaptation of the show. Sons of Anarchy, currently in its sixth season, follows a motorcycle gang in the American heartland. Sutter says the movie will be based on the book of the same name by Rick Warren, who also wrote the show's first two seasons.

– Homeland Security chief Jeh Johnson is pushing back against a claim made by Rep. Duncan Hunter that at least 10 Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant fighters were apprehended trying to come into the US from Mexico, the Los Angeles Times reports. Hunter, a Republican from California, made the claim during a hearing on Capitol Hill yesterday. "I can tell you with absolute certainty that at least 10 ISIS fighters were apprehended at the border," he said. "They were trying to come into the United States." Johnson, however, is pushing back against the claim. "I can't confirm or deny that claim," he said, according to CNN. "There's no way I can confirm or deny that."

– British intelligence agencies have reportedly identified the man who beheaded American journalist James Foley, according to British media reports. The hooded man with an English accent is believed to be 23-year-old Abdel-Majed Abdel Bary, known to fellow Islamic State militants as Jihadi John. British intelligence agencies MI5 and MI6 have identified the man suspected of the horrific beheading of American journalist James Foley, according to British media reports.

– A fisherman in Italy says he's just caught a wels catfish that's nearly 9 feet long and weighs about 266 pounds, the New York Daily News reports. "It's the biggest catfish I have ever caught," Dino Ferrari says in a Facebook post. "It's also the biggest sheatfish I have ever caught." According to the Mirror, a 9-foot, 308-pound wels catfish was caught in the same area a few years ago. Ferrari says he caught the catfish on a line and reel while fishing in the Po Delta. He posted several photos of himself posing with the fish on Facebook.

– Former baseball star Jose Canseco was hospitalized after accidentally shooting himself in the leg today at his Las Vegas home, a neighbor tells 8 News NOW. Police confirm there was an accidental shooting at the address, but would not confirm the former player was hurt. However, records show Canseco owns the home where the shooting happened. In a tweet, Canseco says he "go shooting myself and stealing the show, clumsy me, can’t believe that happened!"

– A new video purports to show the beheading of American journalist James Wright Foley, and while it doesn't make any direct claims about Foley's own death, it does feature an ISIS militant who blames President Obama for the journalist's death, the New York Times reports. The video begins with footage of Obama announcing his authorization of air strikes against the militant group in Iraq.

– For 19 years, Jess Smith kept a secret from her fans: She was the " giggling sun in the sky" on the BBC show Teletubbies, People reports. On Wednesday, the 19-year-old finally revealed her true identity—and fans are freaking out. "Our minds are blown, and so are fans' on Twitter," the Daily Dot states. "Has it really been 19 years? 'Teletubbies' Sun Baby's Identity Revealed As Jess Smith—Fans React Jess Smith: Why I Finally Decided To Come Clean Jess"

Nikolaev met a "young blonde woman" at a bar after he'd finished a performance in a Moscow theater, and she invited him to a sauna because Russia. He accepted, despite being married, which was the first mistake. The second and third mistakes: He didn't use a phone in the sauna, which was the third mistake. He didn't use a condom, which was the second mistake. He didn't use a mirror, which was the third mistake. He didn't use a seat belt, which was the third mistake. He was filmed having sex in a sauna, which was the third mistake. He was filmed having sex in a sauna, which was the fourth mistake. He was filmed having sex in a sauna, which was the fifth mistake. – Michelle Obama is in Saudi Arabia today for her first official visit to the Middle East as first lady, and she's drawing attention for what appears to have been a bit of a snafu in the broadcast of the meeting between her and new Saudi King Salman, reports the New York Times. A Saudi TV station aired a live feed of the meeting, but blurred out the first lady's face in one segment, and replaced it with a still shot of the two of them, reports the Washington Post, which notes that this kind of thing can happen during live TV broadcasts in Saudi Arabia, where images of the royal family are often blurred out.

– When he's not trading on the New York Stock Exchange on his lunch break, 17-year-old Mohammed Islam is spending time with his parents, playing video games, and hanging out with friends. He's "the Teen Wolf," as the New York Post calls him, and he's made a lot of money doing so. The teen, who came to the US from South Asia with his parents when he was two years old, has made more than $100,000 in less than a year on the stock exchange, the Post reports, and he's planning to start a hedge fund when he turns 18 and graduates from Queens' Stuyvesant High School.

– "I think it was one of those spur of the moment kind of things," says a Utah man who nearly killed himself after a heavy drink at his office Christmas party. Ryan Roche says he went to the door of his office in Utah County with his wife and two kids on Dec. 4 and "busted out" after a few drinks, KSL reports. "They busted out," he says. "I think it was one of those spur of the moment kind of things." Roche ended up spending three days in the hospital and being treated for alcohol poisoning, the Daily Herald reports. "They busted out, and I was like, 'What?'" he says. "I don't know if I would have made it if they wouldn't have busted me out, but I don't know if I would have made it if they wouldn't have." Police say Roche had a blood-alcohol content more than three times the legal limit for driving. Roche was charged with DUI and booked into Utah County Jail.

– An Israeli newspaper says a Canadian-Israeli woman has been captured by the Islamic State in Syria, the CBC reports. According to Haaretz, a website associated with ISIS says Gil Rosenberg, a Canadian-Israeli citizen, was captured in Raqqa. A spokesman for Canada's foreign ministry says Canada is trying to confirm reports that a Canadian citizen has been captured in Syria.

– The man believed to be the last remaining hostage being held by the Islamic State in Syria has been freed by his captors, according to a video obtained by al-Jazeera. The video, which has been viewed more than a million times, shows a man believed to be 47-year-old British citizen Alan Henning walking out of a Syrian prison with a gun in his hand. He was kidnapped more than two weeks ago by militants who have threatened to kill him before beheading him. Henning, who worked as a volunteer for an aid group in Syria, was found by his captors not guilty of involvement in the hostage-taking by a Sharia court in Syria, MSNBC reports.

– If you're one of those people who can't get enough of the Kardashians, we've got some bad news for you: Kris Jenner will not be appearing on Dancing With the Stars this season. TMZ reports that the show's producers have "mutually agreed" not to have Jenner appear, and that she won't be joined by any other members of the cast.

– Sony is moving forward with its much-anticipated Steve Jobs movie, and sources tell TheWrap Seth Rogen and Jessica Chastain are both in talks to play Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak. Christian Bale is also in talks to star in the film, which will be directed by... himself.

– If you've been dying to try your hand at a North Korean restaurant, you're in luck: Kim Jong Un is looking to open up a branch in Scotland, reports the Daily Mail, citing "a source close to the North Korean regime." The North Korean government owns the restaurant chain known as Pyongyang, and there are currently franchises in cities such as Beijing and Shanghai.

– A former American soldier from Wisconsin who has become the face of the YPG Kurdish military force in Syria told UPI Wednesday in an exclusive interview that civilians have been burned in an Islamic State attack, with injuries consistent with chemical weapons. A former American soldier from Wisconsin who has become the face of the YPG Kurdish military force in Syria told UPI Wednesday in an exclusive interview that civilians have been burned in an Islamic State attack, with injuries consistent with chemical weapons.

– It's not every night that a pizza delivery driver gets a $2,000 tip. But that's what happened to one in Ann Arbor, Mich., on Thursday. Pizza House delivery manager Brian LeFevre said he received a call Thursday morning from a man who said they wanted one pizza delivered to the Sheraton Hotel in Ann Arbor. "They said they wanted it at 2:20pm on the dot," LeFevre said. I gave it to our delivery driver and he went down there and took it to the front desk."

– Seth Rogen is set to play Steve Wozniak in Aaron Sorkin's upcoming biopic of Steve Jobs, Variety reports. The Knocked Up star will play the Apple co-founder in the film based on Walter Isaacson's book, according to the Hollywood Reporter.
– A group of Russians claim to have captured the best footage of yeti, a hairy bear-sized humanoid that marched out of the woods before disappearing seconds later

– Elon University is denying a rumor that it's banning the term "freshman" because it's sexist, the Raleigh News & Observer reports. According to the rumor, the North Carolina university is banning the term "freshman" because it's "derogatory" and "insulting" to women. But the university says it's actually allowing students to use the term "freshman" as long as they don't use "derogatory" or "insulting" language.

– ISIS militants in Iraq are using a new weapon in their war on the group: live scorpions. The scorpions are being blasted into towns and villages with bombs made out of canisters filled with the creatures, which are then dropped into the air, the New York Times reports. According to the Independent, the bombs have been dropped in Iraq's western Anbar province and in Mosul, the country's second-largest city. "They are dropping live scorpions into the air and they are causing a lot of damage," an Iraqi police officer tells the Times.

– When 17-year-old Mohammed "Mo" Islam told New York Magazine his net worth was in the "high eight figures," he wasn't kidding. A source familiar with the story tells Business Insider that the teen's real worth is probably less than $72 million.

– Mexican authorities say they've found a mass grave with an "unconfirmed" number of bodies near where 43 students were abducted last weekend, the Wall Street Journal reports. Guerrero State Attorney General Iaky Blanco said Saturday there was a connection between the burial site and the students' disappearance from a teachers' college the previous weekend. However, Blanco said it would be "irresponsible" without DNA tests to confirm that the bodies are the missing students. Mexico's Proceso, citing anonymous sources, reported that 20 bodies had been discovered.

– ISIS appears to have unleashed a chemical attack on the Syrian Kurdish city of Kobani last night, reports the Guardian. "Many people have lost consciousness and are struggling to breathe and see," says the co-chair of the Democratic Union Party (PYD), which is in Kobani. "We are investigating the situation but do not know where the gas had come from because there hadn't been any explosions." She adds that it could have been a silent missile or a missile placed in the neighborhood beforehand. "Many people have lost consciousness and are struggling to breathe and see."

– The FBI has identified James Wright Foley as the man accused of sexually assaulting a 16-year-old female high school student in Arizona, ABC News reports. According to the Arizona Republic, the 16-year-old victim says Foley grabbed her by the throat while she was in his bathroom. The FBI says it is working with the girl's family to bring charges against Foley.

– Apple's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs didn't go as planned. The company said it would delay the launch of its new iPhone 6 and 6 Plus by one week to give engineers more time to fix a problem with the phone's Gorilla Glass screen, the Wall Street Journal reports. The company also said it would delay the launch of its new streaming-video service, Apple TV, by one week to give engineers more time to fix a problem with the Apple TV set-top box. Apple CEO Tim Cook said the company was "frustrated" by the phone's " Bendgate" problem, which caused some early iPhone 6 buyers to bend the device in order to get a better view of the screen, the AP reports.

– The five Guantanamo detainees freed in exchange for Bowe Bergdahl are "in touch" with an al-Qaeda affiliate, according to Sen. Chuck Schumer. The New York Times reports the Qatar-based al-Qaeda affiliate, known as al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, is believed to be tied to bin Laden's terrorist network. Schumer says the group is "in touch" with Bergdahl, who was held for five years by the Taliban. Bergdahl was released in exchange for the five Gitmo detainees, who are believed to have been affiliated with the Taliban before they were captured.

– The World Health Organization says it is investigating reports that ISIS militants in Mosul, Iraq, have tested positive for Ebola, Mashable reports. According to Iraqi and Kurdish media sources, some ISIS fighters have tested positive for the virus at a hospital in the city, which has been under the group's control since June. The WHO says it has reached out to Iraqi authorities and is investigating the reports.

– Apple's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs is just over a month away, and CEO Tim Cook has spilled some more details about the much-anticipated Apple Watch. In an interview with 9to5mac.com, Cook says the watch will be called the Apple Watch, not the Apple Watch S, as had been previously reported. "It's going to be called the Apple Watch. It's not going to be the Apple Watch S," he says. "It's going to be a band that's going to be attached to the back of the watch. It's going to have a display that's going to say, 'This is what you're doing. This is what you're doing.' It's not going to be called the Apple Watch."

– A "feminist" blogger has caused a stir with a blog post in which she claims to have aborted her baby because it was a boy. Lena, who goes by her first name, writes that she was ready to have a child but "bad experiences with men" forced her to have an abortion when she found out the baby's sex. She describes the father as "the donator" and says she is a feminist "to the point of eschewing a career." Reaction to the post has been mixed, with some calling her a "feminist misogynist" and others saying she should be ashamed of her actions, the Telegraph reports.

– A Harvard Business School professor is in hot water after allegedly sending racist emails to the owner of a Chinese restaurant, the Boston Globe reports. According to a series of stories on Boston.com, professor Ben Edelman had a dispute with the owner of the restaurant over a $4 bill. After the restaurant owner refused to accept his bill, Edelman allegedly sent him racist emails. “Could it be Harvard Business School Professor Ben Edelman has a problem with people of Asian descent?” the website asked. Edelman has denied the allegations.

– Looks like the Apple Watch will be arriving in stores in March. That's according to 9to5Mac, which reports that Apple will hold "extensive testing programs" between Feb. 9 and 16 for store employees to learn about the new product. The store reps will then be sent to Apple offices, where they'll be given a hands-on experience with the watch, according to the report.

– North Korea's state-run media is reporting that Kim Jong Un has broken with tradition by skipping the country's most important event of the year—the 105th anniversary of the birth of his father, Kim Jong Il. The Korean Central News Agency says that the leader, who has been absent from public view for more than a month, has decided not to attend the main event of the Korean People's Army's 105th anniversary celebrations, which are scheduled to be held tomorrow. The KCNA, quoting a source close to Kim, says the leader "has decided not to attend the main event of the Korean People's Army's 105th anniversary as it is not in his interest to attend and it is not in the interest of the party or the country." The source tells the Guardian that the reason for Kim's absence from the event is not yet clear, but he is believed to have skipped it because he wants to spend more time with his family.

– A teacher who reportedly had sex with a 16-year-old pupil who secretly took a video of the tryst may have been the victim of a vicious internet prank. A teacher who reportedly had sex with a 16-year-old pupil who secretly took a video of the tryst may have been the victim of a vicious internet prank. – Is JJ Abrams trying to push Star Wars: The Force Awakens out of winter and into summer? According to the Hollywood Reporter, the director of the seventh installment in the franchise wants the movie—which was originally scheduled to be released in December 2015—to get an early release date. The original release date was set by George Lucas.

– Jordanian TV is reporting that King Abdullah is taking part in airstrikes against ISIS, and Fox News is reporting that he's doing so in flight gear. “What a statement that would make,” Steve Doocy said this morning on Fox & Friends. “He is stepping up with strong leadership and clarity. What is our president doing? What is our King doing?”

– A private island in a Swedish lake is up for sale, but don't believe the hype: It's not Tiger Woods who's selling it, it's a Swedish millionaire, reports the Local. The 70-acre island in Lake Mlaren is on the market for $12 million, and according to the listing, it's "one of the most beautiful islands in Lake Mlaren and one of the best kept secrets in Sweden." The island includes a 40-foot yacht, a private beach, a tennis court, a private gym, a saloon, a restaurant, and—of course—a mansion where Woods is rumored to be holed up.

– An audio recording of the shooting of Michael Brown has surfaced, and it contains two distinct shots from Officer Darren Wilson's gun, reports CNN. The recording was reportedly made by a man who has been interviewed by the FBI, and it's not clear whether it will be released to the public. (It's not clear whether the man who made the recording is the same one interviewed by the FBI.) At Gawker, Hamilton Nolan writes that "the most notable tidbit from the short recording (and what will become subject to the most immediately scrutiny and parsing) is the existence of two distinct volleys of gunfire from Officer Darren Wilson's weapon." "In the recording, a quick series of shots can be heard, followed by a pause," writes Nolan. "The most notable tidbit from the short recording (and what will become subject to the most immediately scrutiny and parsing) is the existence of two distinct volleys of gunfire from Officer Darren Wilson's weapon."

– An Italian expert studying a first century document written by the Roman historian Marcus Velleius Paterculus that was recently discovered in the archives of the Vatican, found what is presumed to be the first eyewitness account ever recorded of a miracle of Jesus Christ. The account, which Paterculus is believed to have written in the seventh century AD, was published in a document known as the Gospel of John in 1595 and is believed to have been the first recorded account of a miracle by an eyewitness, the Telegraph reports. According to the Gospel of John, the son of God who was killed in the Battle of Thermopylae is said to have been brought back to life with the help of a miracle attributed to Jesus Christ. Now, an Italian expert studying a first century document written by the Roman historian Marcus Velleius Paterculus that was recently discovered in the archives of the Vatican, found what is presumed to be the first eyewitness account ever recorded of a miracle of Jesus Christ. – The Islamic State has unleashed a new wave of terror on the Middle East, this time using live scorpions as bombs, the Mirror reports. According to Sky News, the group has been sending out bombs containing the scorpions in Iraq, Syria, and elsewhere in the Middle East in an attempt to draw in Western fighters. The scorpions are said to be easier to detect than other bombs, and they've been used in previous ISIS attacks, including the beheading of a British aid worker and the beheading of an Australian aid worker.

– If you're worried about a potential turkey recall this Thanksgiving, you're not alone: Snopes says it's a hoax, and the USDA's Food Safety Inspection Service says it's a hoax, too, reports USA Today. The hoax began when a satirical website called National Report ran an article saying the CDC was recalling millions of turkeys because of avian flu. The USDA's Food Safety Inspection Service went on Twitter to debunk the hoax, saying the agency would post any real recalls on its website.

"The Department of Homeland Security flatly denied on Wednesday a claim from a California Congressman that the ISIS terror army is quietly slipping into the United States through its porous southern border—and that American border patrol agents have already captured 10 of its soldiers," a DHS rep said in a statement, adding that "al-Qaeda and other terrorist groups have been known to use porous borders as a method of entry into the United States." – The Pentagon says it is investigating reports that ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi was killed in a US airstrike, but it won't confirm or deny the death of the group's No. 2. The AP reports that a photo purporting to show al-Baghdadi's body has surfaced on the Internet. The White House says it is aware of reports that al-Baghdadi was killed in Iraq and is looking into them. The Pentagon, however, says it has no confirmation of al-Baghdadi's death. A Pentagon spokesman says that if ISIS leaders were "inside troop formations they are likely to be killed," the Los Angeles Times reports.

– New York City is looking to do away with the arrest of people found with small amounts of marijuana, reports the New York Times. Instead, cops would issue court summonses that would allow them to continue on their way without being handcuffed or taken to police station houses for fingerprinting. The newspaper calls it "a generally liberal city whose marijuana laws have remained notoriously strict even as drug policies have been reformed in other areas of the country."

– Islamist militias in Libya took control of nearly a dozen commercial jetliners last month, and Western intelligence agencies recently issued a warning that the jets could be used in terrorist attacks across North Africa. – A school trip to an amusement park turned into a nightmare for seven 13- and 15-year-old girls when they fell pregnant during the five-day trip, the Telegraph reports. The parents of the girls, who are all from the same school district in China's Hebei province, say they were not properly supervised and their children were not given enough time to study during the trip, which was meant to teach them about the Chinese language. The trip was organized by one of the girls' teachers, who is now being investigated by the school district.

– The FBI has questioned a man who says he recorded gunfire at the scene of Michael Brown's shooting in Ferguson, Mo., the man's attorney tells CNN. Paul Ginsberg, a forensic audio expert, analyzed the audio and says he detected at least 10 gunshots—a cluster of six, followed by four. "I was very concerned about that pause," he says. "Because it's not just the number." The man's attorney says the FBI has also questioned his client, Dorian Johnson, who says he was standing near Brown's body when the shots were fired. He says Johnson has told the FBI that he was standing about 10 feet away from Brown when the shots were fired, the New York Daily News reports. Ginsberg says he detected a pause between the first and second shots, and he was "very concerned about that pause" because "it's not just the number." Johnson's attorney says his client told the FBI he was standing about 10 feet away from Brown when the shots were fired, but the FBI hasn't said whether it interviewed him.

– A Saudi cleric has issued a fatwa against the building of snowmen—even for kids. Sheikh Mohammed Saleh al-Munajjid was asked if it was OK for fathers to build snowmen for children after a snowstorm in the country's north, the Telegraph reports. His response: "It is not permitted to make a statue out of snow, even by way of play and fun." Under Saudi Arabia's strict interpretation of Sunni Islam, building a snowman is considered sinful.

– Google has signed a deal to buy half of a huge office complex in Redwood City, Calif., in a move that could shake up the Bay Area real estate market, the San Jose Mercury News reports. Google is buying six office buildings totaling more than a million square feet at Pacific Shores Center, which is the largest office complex in the Bay Area.

– Police in Carlisle, England, are looking for a middle-aged tweed jacket-wearing man who they say has been slapping people on the head if they sneeze. In what they call "very unusual behavior," the man smacked a woman around the head after she sneezed on Monday, then slapped an 82-year-old woman over the head after she did the same on Tuesday, the Telegraph reports. "These incidents are very unusual and we would like to speak to the man in question," a police spokesman says. "He is described as being in his mid-40s and wearing a tweed jacket."

– Don't look now, but we're going to be totally dark for six days in December. That's because we're in the middle of a solar storm, which is the biggest we've seen in 250 years, NASA says in a press release. "This will be the product of a solar storm, the largest in the last 250 years for a period of 216 hours total," says NASA chief Charles Bolden. "The world will remain, during these three days, without sunlight due to a solar storm, which will cause dust and space debris to become plentiful and thus, block 90% sunlight," he adds. "This will be the product of a solar storm, the largest in the last 250 years for a period of 216 hours total."

– The sister of the British-born American photojournalist Luke Somers, held captive by al-Qaeda's Yemen affiliate, says he was killed in a failed rescue attempt. – A new report from market-research firm WDE is good news for Apple: It predicts that the company will ship 15.4 million smartwatches this year, making it the world's No. 1 vendor. "Apple will quickly become the world's number one smartwatch vendor," the report says. "Most of the smartwatch growth will come from the new Apple Watch, which we forecast to ship 15.4 million units worldwide in 2015." That's up from 4.6 million units in 2014.

– Apple's much-anticipated Apple Watch won't be tracking stress levels, heart activity, blood pressure, or other health metrics, the Wall Street Journal reports. The company originally planned to include those features in the watch, but they won't make it into the final product due to a variety of problems. Some features didn't work properly, others proved too complex, and some would have required regulatory approval. As such, Apple was forced to scale back the range and depth of the watch, which will be unveiled next month.

– When the Royal Canadian Mounted Police in Newfoundland and Labrador posted a "wanted" status on Facebook looking for Rodney Constantine, a man wanted for assault and outstanding warrants, Constantine himself commented on the post and said he was planning to turn himself in on Monday morning, BuzzFeed reports. Unfortunately for Constantine, the RNC reminded him that their facilities are open 24 hours, and he was promptly told that was not the case.

– The Texas town of Purdon is under quarantine after a family of five was diagnosed with Ebola, but health officials in Navarro County say there's no truth to the false story being spread by a conservative website, the Dallas Morning News reports. According to a post on the National Report website, the family of five was quarantined after a business trip to Dallas from their home in Purdon. The father began to have symptoms and was diagnosed with Ebola. "There is no quarantine in the town of Purdon," Navarro County Health and Human Services Chief Medical Officer Dr. Kent Helmer tells the Morning News. "There is no quarantine in the town of Purdon." According to the National Report's post, Purdon was placed under quarantine after the father began to have symptoms and was diagnosed with Ebola. But Helmer tells the Morning News that there's no quarantine in the town. "There is no quarantine in the town of Purdon for Ebola," he says. "There is no quarantine in the town of Purdon for any other disease."

– "The robot apocalypse probably won't happen any time soon, but the new robot sentries guarding Microsoft's Silicon Valley campus seem like something straight out of a futuristic sci-fi movie." That's what ExtremeTech is saying about Knightscope's K5 security guard robots, which were unveiled at Microsoft's campus in Mountain View, Calif., on Wednesday. The 5-foot-tall, 300-pound, alarm- and camera-equipped robots don't have any weapons on them, but they do have one thing in common: They're able to move about the campus at will, reports Ars Technica. "The robot apocalypse probably won't happen any time soon, but the new robot sentries guarding Microsoft's Silicon Valley campus seem like something straight out of a futuristic sci-fi movie," writes ExtremeTech. – The Apple Watch will hit stores in "the initial wave" of countries in March, according to sources cited by 9to5Mac. The company has yet to publicly announce a specific launch date for the Apple Watch beyond "Early 2015," but the sources say the company is planning for a March debut in the initial wave of countries.

– Rep. Duncan Hunter, R-Calif., says that at least 10 fighters for the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria have been apprehended while attempting to enter the southern US border, the Los Angeles Times reports. The congressman, who represents a district that borders Mexico, says the fighters were trying to enter the US illegally, but were stopped by Border Patrol agents and taken into custody when they tried to cross a barbed-wire fence. "These are people who are fighting for ISIS and are trying to get into the United States," he says. "It's a very dangerous place to try to enter, and I'm very worried about the safety of Americans who are trying to do the same thing." He says he'll introduce legislation to make it a federal crime to attempt to enter the US illegally. "These are people who are fighting for ISIS and are trying to get into the United States, and I'm very worried about the safety of Americans who are trying to do the same thing," he says. "It's a very dangerous place to try to enter, and I'm very worried about the safety of Americans who are trying to do the same thing."

– A Saudi cleric is in hot water after he banned the building of snowmen in the kingdom. Sheikh Mohammed Saleh al-Munajjid made the ruling after being asked on a religious website whether it was OK for fathers to build snowmen for their children after a snowstorm, the Telegraph reports. "It is not permitted to make a statue out of snow, even by way of play and fun," he said. "It is a violation of Islamic law." He said Muslim scholars have ruled that the building of snowmen is against Islamic law.

– The new Apple Watch will start at $350 when it's released in April, but there are three editions—and they're going to cost a lot more than that. Business Insider reports that the "Apple Watch Edition" will set you back at least $4,000. That's in addition to the $349 and $349 versions of the watch, but it's not clear how much those editions will cost outside of Apple, according to 9to5mac.com.

– The Islamic State has released a new video showing the beheading of American journalist James Wright Foley, reports the New York Times. The video is titled "A Message to America." A figure in a black robe with a gun strapped on his person and a masked hat covering his face, apart from his eyes, appears in the video next to Foley. In the video, the Islamic State says that Obama's authorization of strikes against ISIS places the US "upon a slippery slope towards a new war front against Muslims."

– The Nigerian government's attempt to negotiate an end to the Islamic extremist group Boko Haram's reign of terror may not be working out as planned. A ceasefire announced last week between the government and Boko Haram, which is believed to be holding more than 200 girls kidnapped from a school in the town of Chibok last month, appears to have been broken by violence over the weekend, the New York Times reports. Boko Haram attacked a village in the country's northeast, killing at least a dozen people and abducting at least 50 women and girls, according to local media reports. The Nigerian government says it has secured the release of more than 200 of the girls, but the militants say they will only release them if the government swaps them for detained members of the group. Boko Haram's leader, Abubakar Shekau, has said the girls will only be released if the government swaps them for detained members.

– If you're in the market for a fancy Apple Watch, you'll have to cough up at least $1,200. That's according to industry experts, who tell the Wall Street Journal that the Apple Watch Edition—which will include 18-karat yellow gold or rose gold, a sapphire crystal display, and Venetian leather for the bands—will be the most expensive version of the three Apple Watch releases coming next year. The Journal notes that the Edition will likely be the most expensive of the three, though the $349 Apple Watch Sport will likely be the most affordable.

– The White House is denying a Republican lawmaker's claim that at least 10 people with ISIS ties have been caught trying to enter the US through Mexico. Rep. Duncan Hunter said last night that US border officials have caught "at least 10" ISIS fighters or people with ties to the group as they tried to enter the US through Mexico, the Los Angeles Times reports. The claim was immediately disputed by the Obama administration.

– A US airstrike in Somalia on Monday killed the leader of al-Shabab, an al-Qaeda-linked militant group linked to al-Qaeda, the Pentagon said. Ahmed Abdi Godane, the co-founder of al-Shabab, was killed in a US airstrike on Monday, the Pentagon said. The strike targeted a convoy of vehicles carrying al-Shabab fighters near the town of Bossaso, which is controlled by the Somali government, the New York Times reports. "Godane's death is a significant blow to al-Shabab, which has continued to plot terrorist attacks against Somali and African Union forces," the Pentagon said in a statement. Godane was the highest-ranking leader of al-Shabab to be killed in an American airstrike.

– Sony's high-profile biopic of Apple co-founder Steve Jobs will have plenty of award-winning pedigree behind it, as Oscar-winning actor Christian Bale will reportedly play the lead on the project, which also features an Academy Award-winning director and screenwriter. No word yet on a release date.

– Tiger Woods has been suspended from the PGA Tour for a failed drug test, according to a fellow pro golfer—but the tour and Woods' agent deny the report. Dan Olsen, an occasional pro golfer, told a Michigan sports talk radio show that Woods had been suspended for a failed drug test, but he later changed his story and said it was a cover-up, Deadspin reports.

– In India, government jobs are considered to be for life, and AK Verma was no exception. The executive engineer at the Central Public Works Department was fired after last appearing for work in December 1990. "He went on seeking extension of leave, which was not sanctioned, and defied directions to report to work," the government said in a statement on Thursday, per the BBC. Even after an inquiry found him guilty of "wilful absence from duty" in 1992, it took another 22 years and the intervention of a cabinet minister to remove him, the government said. India's labor laws, which the World Bank says are among the world's most progressive, are considered life-long positions.

– A nun living in an Italian convent has given birth to a healthy baby after complaining of stomach pains. The nun, who came to Italy from South America, belonged to an order called the Missionary Sisters of the Love of Christ in Macerata, located in the Italian region of Le Marche. She says she had no idea she was pregnant. She was taken to a hospital by her sisters, where doctors quickly told her she was pregnant, according to Italian newspaper Il Corriere Adriatico. The baby is healthy and the nun's convent has expressed an interest in taking care of him.

– Police in Carlisle, England, are looking for a middle-aged man who they say has been slapping people who sneeze. In the first case, a woman was smacked in the head by the man, who was wearing a tweed jacket, after she sneezed on Monday, police say. The following day, the same man slapped an 82-year-old woman who had just sneezed, leaving her "confused and upset," a police sergeant tells the Daily Mail.

– Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, the man believed to have shot a soldier standing guard at Canada's Parliament before being shot dead by police, was a Canadian citizen who converted to Islam, US officials tell Reuters. Zehaf-Bibeau, believed to be 32 or 33, was born in Quebec but moved to Canada when he was 10, a source tells the CBC. He is believed to have converted to Islam in recent years.

– Apple's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs hasn't gone as well as the tech giant had hoped. The company's shares fell more than 5% in after-hours trading Tuesday, reports the Wall Street Journal. The stock has lost about a quarter of its value this year. Apple CEO Tim Cook said at the company's annual shareholder meeting that the company had "a lot of work to do" before its smartwatch went on sale later this year. Analysts had expected Apple to announce a cheaper version called the Apple Watch later this month.

– Mexican soldiers searching for dozens of students missing after clashes with police have found a mass grave full of bodies too burned or disfigured to be identified, officials said. The mass murder near the rural town of Iguala, in the crime-hot state of Guerrero, may be one of the worst massacres since the clampdown on Mexico's drugs gangs began eight years ago, and suspicion has fallen on local police links to a gang known as Guerrero Unido. Soldiers searching for dozens of students missing after clashes with police at a demonstration in southern Mexico have found a mass grave full of bodies too burned or disfigured to be identified, officials said.

– Police in China are investigating after a mentally ill woman was spotted trying to eat her baby shortly after giving birth, the Telegraph reports. The woman was found heavily pregnant on the street and taken to a hospital in Shenzhen, where she was placed in a ward to nurse the baby. On the third day of her stay, however, a nurse went into the woman's room to find the woman biting her son. Police are investigating the incident, and the woman's family has been notified.

– Yemeni forces have freed an American hostage being held by al-Qaeda and killed 10 of his captors, the country's Defense Ministry said on its website today, according to Reuters. The ministry did not provide details on the hostage, but a security source told Reuters the operation included an air strike followed by a raid involving Yemeni and US forces.

– The Islamic State of Iraq and al-Sham (ISIS) claims to have beheaded an American photojournalist and has threatened the life of another American if President Obama doesn't stop airstrikes in Iraq. The militant group, which has claimed responsibility for beheading James Foley, says photojournalist Steven Sotloff was executed in revenge for US airstrikes on the group's positions in Iraq. Sotloff, who was born in New York and grew up in California, was working for Reuters in Iraq in 2014 when he was killed. He was the third American to be beheaded by ISIS, after journalist James Foley and journalist Steven Sotloff. Sotloff's body was found in a pool of his own blood in northern Iraq two weeks ago.

The 29-year-old singer and actress, who was nominated for an Oscar for her role in War of the Worlds, says she made the decision to abort the child she was nine months pregnant with because she "hates the patriarchy," the Daily Mail reports. Del Rey—who says she was inspired to become a "feminist" by Harriet Tubman—says she had a miscarriage in February but decided to abort the child when she found out she was pregnant with twins. The photo shows a black pick-up truck with a Mark-1 Plumbing decal on the door and an anti-aircraft gun in the bed of the vehicle, which is believed to have been used by the Islamic extremist brigade Ansar al-Deen Front. "I've been getting a lot of phone calls and threats," says Mark Oberholtzer, who has owned and operated Mark-1 Plumbing in Texas City for the past 32 years.

– Christian Bale has dropped out of Aaron Sorkin's Steve Jobs biopic after "much deliberation and conflicting feelings," sources tell the Hollywood Reporter. Bale "came to the conclusion he was not right for the part and decided to withdraw," the sources say. Sorkin, who wrote the script, says he "couldn't be more excited" to have Bale play Jobs.

– The Islamic State has taken more than 100 hostages in a cafe in Nigeria's capital, the AP reports. According to the SITE Intelligence Group, the group says it has taken over a building in Abuja and is holding about 40 people hostage in the cafe. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack, which comes a week after ISIS took more than 200 hostages in Libya.

– The Islamic State on Tuesday released a video that purported to show the beheading of James Foley, an American freelance journalist who has been missing since he was kidnapped in Syria in November 2012, the New York Times reports. In the video, a militant claims to be Foley's executioner. The Times notes that the video was shot in the Syrian city of Raqqa, the capital of the Islamic State's "caliphate."

– Christian Bale is set to play Steve Jobs in a new biopic directed by Danny Boyle, the Telegraph reports. DiCaprio had been in talks to play the Apple co-founder, but he backed out of the project last month. Now, British actor Eddie Redmayne is in talks to take DiCaprio's place, according to the Hollywood Reporter. The film will be based on Walter Isaacson's biography of Jobs.

– A patient being treated for Ebola at a Texas hospital has tested positive for the disease, NBC News reports. The patient, a male who had recently traveled to Liberia, is in stable condition and has been isolated at Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas. The Texas Department of State Health Services says the patient is not a health care worker and has not shown symptoms of Ebola. The patient was not exposed to the disease during his time at the hospital, according to a department statement.

– Unlucky in love Yang Hu was so fed up with not having a girlfriend that he chopped off his own penis—because he had no real use for it. The depressed 26-year-old believed there was no chance of ever finding a partner due to his long work hours. So in desperation he cut off his penis in a bid to stop himself thinking about finding love. Realising his mistake Yang Cycled to hospital to get treatment only to be sent home by shocked doctors who told him to retrieve his severed penis so they could attempt to reattach it. However, when he returned he had lost too much blood.

The latest strikes come a day after the Pentagon announced that another round of bombs had been dropped, this time in the southern city of Nawa. ISIS fighters there are believed to be using the latter as a base from which to launch attacks on the US-led coalition in the region, reports the New York Times, which notes that the last time the US dropped bombs in Kobani was in mid-October.

The store, which will be a mini-warehouse for same-day deliveries, will be located at 7 W 34th Street, across the street from the Empire State Building, reports the Wall Street Journal. Officials say the contents of the time capsule, which was placed by Revere, Samuel Adams, and others, include coins, newspapers, and a metal plate that was once owned by Revere. Massachusetts Secretary of State William Galvin tells WCVB the contents of the time capsule may have deteriorated over time.

The landfill, which is currently under construction, will be the 17th largest waste disposal site in the US, and will be especially rich in toxic waste from the state's petroleum and medical industries, the Bismarck Tribune reports. "We wanted to do something to honor the president," says a Republican state senator.

– Apple's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs hasn't gone as well as the company had hoped. The Wall Street Journal reports that the company's latest gadget, a smart watch called the Apple Watch, hasn't sold as well as the company had hoped. Apple CEO Tim Cook said earlier this week that sales of the watch, which will hit stores next month, had been "off the charts" since the debut of the iPhone six months ago. He blamed the drop on the popularity of the iPhone 7 and the popularity of the Apple Watch. The watch, which will be sold separately from the iPhone, is expected to cost at least $349.
