The video was captured on the helmet camera of a marine in 2013, when he and two other marines were taking part in a reconnaissance mission in the NawZad district of the renowned Helmand Province, Afghanistan. The video was captured on the helmet camera of a marine in 2013, when he and two other marines were taking part in a reconnaissance mission in the NawZad district of the renowned Helmand Province, Afghanistan. Dramatic footage has emerged of a US marine being shot in the head by a Taliban sniper, only to be saved by his Kevlar helmet.

– A female passenger at DC's Dulles International Airport was spotted yesterday wearing a hazmat suit, complete with full-body gown, mask, and gloves, the Daily Caller reports. The woman was waiting for a flight. Ebola patient Thomas Duncan had a layover at Dulles last month. Health officials have said that passengers at the airport were not at risk for exposure to Ebola because Duncan was not

– North Korea's official Korean Central News Agency says Kim Jong Un is recovering from ankle surgery and will be making a full recovery. "He is doing well and he will be back to work as soon as he is able to do so," the KCNA said, according to the BBC. Kim has been missing from public view for more than a month, leading to speculation that he has suffered a stroke or some kind of coup.

– The woman who claimed to be the girlfriend of Michael Phelps has revealed that she was born a boy. "I was never a man, never lived as a man," Taylor Lianne Chandler wrote on Facebook. "No one can say they knew me as a man or produce a photo of me as a man." The 41-year-old said she changed her name and used testosterone blockers as a teen before having surgery to remove her male genitalia in her early 20s, the Daily Mail reports.

– A Syrian activist group says ISIS fighters are training at a military base in the country's north. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says the group has Russian-made MiG 21 and 23 warplanes and is being trained at al Jarrah airbase in Aleppo, the AP reports. The group says the planes were brought in from Russia.

– Nikolai Kryaglyachenko, 12, was walking home after school when he lent briefly against the lamppost that was live from a faulty wire, and was blasted across the pavement. A freak accident may have saved his life. Nikolai Kryaglyachenko, 12, was walking home after school when he lent briefly against the lamppost that was live from a faulty wire, and was blasted across the pavement. A freak accident may have saved his life. – It's the most expensive production car in the world, capable of going from zero to 60mph in 2.6 seconds, and it's also the one with the biggest penis in the world. The owner of a £1.5 million Bugatti Veyron supercar could be left with a $500,000 dent in their pocket after crude vandals painted a huge penis on its bonnet, the Daily Mail reports. Yobs targeted the silver-colored car, which was parked in a street in Seattle, US. The image was posted on Reddit this week, with some users condemning the graffiti.

– A newly released audio recording purportedly captures the sound of gunfire from the police shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., reports CNN. The unauthenticated audio was recorded by a man who says he was taping a video chat conversation when the shooting of the unarmed black teen by a white police officer occurred around noon on Saturday, Aug. 9.

– A member of Iraq's parliament says ISIS militants have killed 300 Iraqi soldiers with chlorine gas in the city of Fallujah. Ali al-Bredi, a member of parliament from the country's Anbar province, said at a press conference on Monday that "the responsibility for this lies with Iraqi PM Haidar Abadi and the commander of the forces in Anbar as they failed to rescue the soldiers," al-Jazeera reports. He added that ISIS used the gas in the Siqiliya area of Fallujah, which is about 70 miles from Baghdad.

– Canada's House of Commons sergeant-at-arms is being hailed as a hero for his quick thinking and decisive action after a bomb threat was phoned in to the chamber Wednesday. Kevin Vickers tells the CBC that he was in his office when a package arrived, and when he opened the door to check it out, it was filled with nails and bits of metal. "I've never seen anything like it in my life," he says. "I've been around long enough to know that there could have been a lot more serious damage if he hadn't acted." Vickers says he managed to diffuse the package before it exploded, and the House of Commons sergeant-at-arms was rushed to a local hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. (The Globe and Mail has video here.)

– Oliver Ilic says his girlfriend broke up with him because he wasn't good in bed. So the 22-year-old Macedonian man cut off his penis, threw it in a trash can, and called 911—but he couldn't stop the bleeding, the Daily Mail reports. He was taken to a hospital in Kocani, Macedonia, where medics found he'd suffered a wound so bad he couldn't stop it. Ilic told medics his girlfriend had told him he wasn't good in bed.

– A man who was dumped by his girlfriend when she told him he was not any good in bed chopped off his penis and threw it in the bin. The unnamed man told medics he felt his small penis was to blame for the fact he was in bed when she told him he was not any good, the Telegraph reports. He said he then tossed the penis in the trash. The unnamed man, who was taken to a hospital for treatment, told medics he felt his penis was to blame for the fact he was in bed when she told him he was not any good.

– The fence-jumper who bolted across the White House lawn with a knife and made it deep into the executive mansion was probably just trying to get a better look at the place, sources tell the Washington Post. The sources say former Army soldier Albert Gonzalez made it past a White House guard who opened the front door because a nearby alarm box had been muted. Gonzalez then ran into the East Room, where he was tackled by a counter-assault agent.

– The world is going to be plunged into darkness for six days in December. That's according to a website called Huzlers.com, which says it's behind the latest major hoax: the "Days of darkness" story, which claimed that the world would be plunged into darkness for six days in December, according to the Telegraph. The site's editor tells the Telegraph that the story, which claimed that the world would be plunged into darkness for six days in December, is a hoax.

– Islamist militants in Libya have stolen as many as 11 commercial jetliners from Tripoli International Airport, according to a report from Magharebia, an online news site covering North Africa. Last month, Islamist radicals seized Tripoli International Airport and took possession of as many as 11 commercial jetliners, according to a report from Magharebia, an online news site covering North Africa. The report has now created concerns for officials, who fear the militants may use them to carry out acts of terrorism against America.

– The wife of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi has been detained in Lebanon along with her young son, Lebanese officials tell the Wall Street Journal. The officials say the woman is Saja al-Dulaimi, who was freed by Syrian authorities in a prisoner exchange with an al-Qaeda-linked branch of Syria's al-Qaeda-linked branch earlier this year. She is believed to be the wife of al-Baghdadi's son from a previous marriage. DNA tests are being conducted to confirm their identities. If their identities are confirmed, Lebanon may use the pair as bargaining chips to win the release of soldiers and police taken hostage by ISIS militants in cross-border attacks earlier this year.

– For those who can't get enough of the Apple Watch, Selfridges in London is getting in on the action. The high-end department store is planning to open a dedicated pop-up shop for the Apple Watch, reports the Telegraph, citing "sources." The store will be located in the swanky Selfridges department store on London's High Street.

– A Russian airport worker stripped naked and walked through a security scanner in his socks—in protest of "rough" security guards. Georgy Myakinkin, 31, left his keys at work following his shift at Pulkovo Airport in St Petersburg, Russia, the Daily Mail reports. According to the Telegraph, Myakinkin stripped naked and walked through a security scanner in his socks—in protest of "rough" security guards.

– It looks like Star Wars fans won't have to wait long to get their hands on the much-anticipated JJ Abrams-directed The Force Awakens. According to the Hollywood Reporter, the JJ Abrams-directed movie will be released this summer. The original release date for the much-anticipated Star Wars movie was December 2015.

– Big Bank Hank, the New York rapper who, as part of the Sugarhill Gang, released what is generally regarded as the first rap record, has died at the age of 57. The rapper, whose real name was Montel Williams, was found dead in his New York City apartment Sunday morning, the New York Daily News reports. He was reportedly suffering from liver failure. According to the New York Post, the cause of death has not been determined.

– Kanye West's interruption of Beck's acceptance speech at last night's Grammy Awards—and his subsequent rant about Beyonce and Jay-Z—got him banned from all future award shows, Entertainment Weekly reports. "Kanye West has been banned from all future award shows," said a statement from the Recording Academy, which hosts the Grammys. "His behavior last night was not in keeping with the values and traditions of the Grammy Awards, and he has been permanently banned from any association with the Grammy Awards." Adobo Chronicles, an entertainment website, reported earlier this month that West had been banned from all future award shows.

– China is cracking down on what it calls "crank-boosting," a practice in which people crank up the number of times an app is downloaded in order to boost the app's rank on Apple's App Store, the Telegraph reports. The country's Ministry of Foreign Affairs says it has set up a special task force to crack down on the practice, which it says is a big problem in China and a "threat to national security." The task force will look into how to combat the practice, which the foreign ministry says is being used to "flood the App Store with fake apps" and "damage the credibility of the App Store," the People's Daily reports. The task force will also look into whether apps can be blocked from the App Store if they don't meet Apple's standards for safety and security, the Telegraph notes. The App Store is the world's biggest source of apps for iPhone and iPad users.

– A Russian TV star woke up one day to find that his testicle had been removed. Dmitry Nikolaev, 30, says he had been drinking with a blonde woman in a Moscow bar before they went to a sauna, had a beer, and then kissed her. He woke up the next day in a lot of pain and discovered that his testicle had been removed, the Telegraph reports. Nikolaev, who is married, says he believes he was drugged after taking the woman to a sauna, enjoying a beer, and then kissing her. He woke up the next day in a bus stop in a lot of pain and found bloodstains on his clothes. He was taken to a hospital, where he was told his testicle had been removed in a medically-educated surgery. Russian police fear a gang seeking to sell organs on the black market could be behind the bizarre case.

– Dera Sacha Sauda chief Gurmeet Ram Rahim Singh has been booked by the Central Bureau of Investigation in connection with alleged forced castration of followers inside his ashram in Sirsa, Haryana, reports the Times of India. The case stems from an alleged incident of rape that took place at the ashram in September last year.

– Six months after more than 200 girls were kidnapped from a school in Chibok, Nigeria, Boko Haram has agreed to a ceasefire and release the girls, the BBC reports. "Boko Haram issued the ceasefire as a result of the discussions we have been having with them," says a rep for the Nigerian government. "They have agreed to release the Chibok girls." The rep adds that negotiations are ongoing with neighboring Chad.

– Apple wanted its smartwatch to be all about health-related features—so much so that the company originally planned a device that could monitor heart rate, blood pressure, and stress levels based on the conductivity of the skin, the Wall Street Journal reports. Unfortunately, the sensors they tested just didn't pass muster, which isn't entirely surprising, since we've reviewed plenty of wearables with patchy heart rate monitors in the past. The company's engineers found that hairy arms, dry skin, and even how tightly the watch is worn can affect the results, and they didn't

– A 22-year-old man in Macedonia has reportedly cut off his own penis after his girlfriend told him he was no good in bed. Oliver Ilic reportedly took a razor to his penis and tossed it in the trash after his girlfriend told him he was no good in bed, the Metro reports.

– It's that time of year again: time for pumpkin spice latte-flavored condoms. Yes, that's the name of a new condom from Durex that's causing a bit of a stir on social media, reports the Daily Dot. The offending condom is an altered image of the company's "Taste Me" flavored condoms, but it still features the letters "T" and the letters "S" in place of the letters "E" and "F" in place of the letters "N" and "O" in place of the letters "R" and "S" in place of the letters "A" and "B" in place of the letters "C" and "D" in place of the letters "E" and "F" in place of the letters "G" and "H" in place of the letters "I" and "L" in place of the letters "M" and "O" in place of the letters "P" and "R" in place of the letters "T" and "V" in place of the letters "X" and "Y" in place of the letters "I" and "V" in place of the letters "X" and "Y

– At this year's Consumer Electronics Show, Apple is rumored to be unveiling a new version of its MacBook Air, 9to5mac.com reports. Rumors of a 12-inch refresh first surfaced earlier this month, and 9to5mac.com notes that it's "not just a spec bump": It's rumored to have a faster Intel processor, a longer battery life, and an improved camera. The new MacBook Air will be unveiled during an Apple event on Jan. 10, according to 9to5mac.com.

– A Massachusetts priest was pronounced dead at the hospital more than 48 minutes after he went into cardiac arrest, but his heart started beating again when medics revived him, the Boston Globe reports. According to WCVB-TV, 69-year-old Father Lawrence DiGiulio was pronounced dead at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. DiGiulio's heart started beating again after he went into cardiac arrest while giving a Sunday Mass at a local Catholic church. He was in cardiac arrest for more than 48 minutes before medics were able to restart his heart.

– "I won't be eating any of that." That's what gardening expert Alan Titchmarsh has to say about spotted toadstool, a hallucinogenic fungi found growing in the Queen's garden at Buckingham Palace. Titchmarsh, 65, was touring the private 40-acre plot for an ITV show called The Queen's Garden when he came across the red and white spotted toadstool—called Amanita muscaria, or fly agaric—"on a tour of the private 40-acre plot with ecology expert Professor Mick Crawley," the Telegraph reports. Titchmarsh says he was "flabbergasted" to find the fungi, which he describes as "hallucinogenic" but says "I won't be eating any of that."

– An 85-year-old Texas woman has been charged with kidnapping her neighbor's cats and making them into fur coats, reports the Waco Tribune-Herald. Police say the retired fashion designer skinned about 20 of her neighbor's cats in her basement and made at least 30 into coats. Neighbors hired a private investigator after their cats started disappearing. The woman has been charged with animal cruelty.

– A homeless man was given a hundred dollars, and what he did will make you cry. YouTube channel owner Josh Paler Lin decided to see it for himself and capture it all on camera. Normally when you think of the homeless, you probably picture some drug or alcohol addict who is only taking money from passerby to support their next fix. Some of them even make more money than the average full-time employee working legally just because they’re good actors with bad clothes and not homeless at all. Instead of assuming the worst, Josh put his money into finding the truth.

– Boko Haram extremists and Nigeria's government have agreed to a ceasefire, according to the country's official news agency—though details of the deal are still being worked out, al-Jazeera reports. "Both sides have agreed there will be no more attacks, no more bombs, and no more attacks on Boko Haram," Nigeria's chief of defense staff says. "The government will immediately implement the agreement." The development comes as officials in neighboring Chad say they've had direct negotiations with Boko Haram this week.

– A homeless man in Los Angeles got quite the surprise when YouTube star Josh Paler Lin handed him $100—and filmed the whole thing. Paler Lin, who calls himself a "nominal reverend," wanted to find out how the money would be spent, so he approached a homeless man by a highway and handed him the cash, Mashable reports. He then followed the man in secret with a camera as he spent the money. "He's been down on his luck lately," Paler Lin says of the man identified only as Thomas. "I wanted to see how he'd spend the money to see if I could change his life." Thomas, who says he's been sleeping on the side of the road for the last few months, spent the money on food and clothes. "I don't know how I'd spend it," he says. "I don't know what I'd do with it." The result of the experiment is a viral video that has more than a million subscribers.

– The man who shot Parliament gunman Michael Zehaf-Bibeau got a standing ovation from members of Canada's House of Commons today. Kevin Vickers, the 58-year-old sergeant-at-arms who shot Zehaf-Bibeau dead, struggled to keep his emotions in check as he was praised for his bravery, the Telegraph reports. Video footage shows Vickers leading a ceremonial parade into the House of Commons this morning and being greeted by applause from members of Parliament. He managed to stay mostly expressionless throughout the standing ovation—simply nodding in thanks several times—but as the cheers continued, he appeared emotional.

– An Italian newspaper says a nun in her 60s gave birth in a hospital in San Severino Marche, after complaining of a bad stomach ache. The nun, who hasn't been identified, had been staying at a cloistered convent in the province of Macerata since June. The hospital hasn't confirmed the birth and the bishop of nearby town Camerino, Francesco Brugnaro, hasn't made any comment, ANSA reports.

– Henry “Big Bank Hank” Jackson of the Sugarhill Gang died early Tuesday from kidney complications due to cancer, his manager said. He was 70. The Los Angeles Times reports the rapper, whose real name was Henry Earl Jackson, was a founding member of the Sugarhill Gang, which rose to fame in the 1960s and went on to become one of the most popular hip-hop groups in the country.

– Mexican authorities say they've found a mass grave containing at least 15 bodies near the town of Iguala, where 43 students disappeared after a protest last week, the AP reports. The grave was found Saturday near a highway leading from Mexico City, AFP reports. Authorities say they're working to identify the bodies and determine whether they belong to the missing students. Witnesses say municipal police officers in Iguala whisked several of the students away when a protest turned violent last week.

– The wife and son of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi have been arrested in Lebanon, a security source tells the AP. The source says the wife and son were detained in a house in the southern city of Daraa, near the Syrian border. The source says security forces are working to track down the ISIS chief's son, Omar al-Baghdadi. The BBC reports that the younger al-Baghdadi, believed to be around 20 years old, is believed to be the leader's son from a previous marriage.

– Macaulay Culkin may be dead, but he's still very much alive. That's the takeaway from a bizarre hoax that has gone viral on Facebook and Twitter. The hoaxer offers a still from an actual TV news broadcast about the Home Alone star's death, complete with a URL that appears to be from MSNBC, the Huffington Post reports. Facebook users have been flocking to the page since news of Culkin's death spread, and it's now trending on the social networking site.

– A South Korean newspaper has reported that North Korean leader Kim Jong-un underwent surgery to repair fractures in both ankles earlier this month. The Chosun Ilbo report cited a source who had recently visited the North and claimed that the 31-year-old had undergone the operation at an exclusive hospital for high-ranking Communist Party members in Pyongyang. According to the report, Kim broke both ankles in two places during a fight with another member of his inner circle and needed surgery to fix the fractures. Kim is said to be in stable condition and eating normally.

– Two members of ISIS who traveled to Syria to fight are believed to have tested positive for Ebola, the Telegraph reports. According to Sky News, the two fighters are being treated at a hospital in northern England, though it's not clear whether they've tested positive for the disease. The Telegraph notes that the UK has had three people diagnosed with Ebola since returning to the country from West Africa, where the disease is rampant.

– A 21-year-old Australian man was on vacation in Bali when he suffered an allergic reaction to an insect bite and was sent away with an antihistamine cream, the Independent reports. But three days later, when the red mark on his stomach started to blister, Dylan Thomas knew something was wrong and went to the Bali International Medical Center, where doctors told him he had just been bitten by a tropical spider. Thomas tells the Sun he was "horrified" when he discovered the spider had burrowed under his skin and was only two inches from his stomach. He says doctors told him the spider had likely been trying to get into his stomach to find food. "It was a bit of a shock when I found out it was a spider," he says. "I've never had an allergic reaction to anything before, so it was a bit of a shock to find out it was a tropical spider." He says doctors told him the spider had likely been trying to get into his stomach to mate. "I've never had an allergic reaction to anything before, so it was a bit of a shock when I found out it was a tropical spider," he says. "I've never had an allergic reaction to anything before, so it was a bit of

– If you're using iOS 8's iCloud Drive feature on your iPhone, you might want to avoid the "Erase All Content and Settings" menu, MacRumors reports. According to MacRumors, a newly discovered bug causes iCloud Drive documents to be permanently erased from the cloud whenever a user picks "All Settings." This option would simply do what it says: reset the iPhone's factory defaults. No media (music, photos, etc.) or documents are supposed to be erased or otherwise affected when performing this action—that should only happen if you choose "Erase All Content and Settings" and

– American and British intelligence officials are eyeing a British-born rapper as the militant who beheaded journalist James Foley, Fox News reports. A senior Western intelligence official told Fox News that 23-year-old London rapper Abdel Majed Abdel Bary is the suspect believed to be Foley's executioner.

– A note to parents in a 1970s LEGO set has caused a stir on the Internet—but is it real? Redditor fryd_, who posted a photo of the note to imgur, says it is, in fact, real and has been retweeted more than 31,000 times. The note, which appears to have been printed on a pamphlet included in the set, reads in part: "Thank you for all your love and support of our family. We hope that you will continue to be an inspiration to us all." The note has been called into question by some, but there's "good reason to believe" it's real, the Atlantic Wire notes. A photo of the note was posted to imgur yesterday by redditor fryd_, where it's received a lot of attention. It's also gained purchase on Twitter. As of this posting, this tweet by @henrywarren has been retweeted over three-thousand times: Pretty great, right

– If you've ever wondered what it would be like to have sex on a slice of pie, well, here's your answer: waffles. BuzzFeed has compiled a list of the best and worst ways to have sex on a slice of pie, and the one that's getting the most attention is this: "Just eat a slice of pie and then have sex. Or sex then pie." "Just eat a slice of pie and then have sex. Or sex then pie." "Just eat a slice of pie and then have sex. Or sex then pie." "You're gonna think it's a good idea, but, girl, it is not a good idea." "Just eat a slice of pie and then have sex. Or sex then pie." "Just eat a slice of pie and then have sex. Or sex then pie." "Just eat a slice of pie and then have sex. Or sex then pie." "You're gonna think it's a good idea, but, girl, it is not a good idea." "Just eat a slice of pie and then have sex. Or sex then pie. Or sex then pie. Point is, waffles come first."

– Abdel Majed Abdel Bary, a 23-year-old London hip-hop artist, has emerged as one of the main suspects in the investigation into the beheading of journalist James Foley, London's Sunday Times quoted counterterrorism officials. Abdel Majed Abdel Bary, a 23-year-old London hip-hop artist, has emerged as one of the main suspects in the investigation into the beheading of journalist James Foley, London's Sunday Times quoted counterterrorism officials.

– They're egg-like, they're equipped with lasers, GPS, and heat-detecting technology, and they can predict where criminals will strike next and the likelihood of future crimes. That's right, robots are now being used as security guards in Silicon Valley, the Telegraph reports. Microsoft is one of the companies using the Knightscope K5 robot security guards, which can read 300 car registration plates a minute and are equipped with surveillance cameras and sensors, a thermal imaging system, scanners that can read 300 car registration plates a minute, and odor detectors. Unlike human security guards, the egg-like Knightscopes are not armed. The robots are designed to operate without human control and are equipped with surveillance cameras and sensors, a thermal imaging system, scanners that can read 300 car registration plates a minute, and odor detectors.

– The Internet is aflutter with the news of yet another celebrity death, but this time it's none other than Willie Nelson. The singer is alive and well, reports Rolling Stone, which notes that a Facebook page dedicated to Nelson's music has been up and running for a few days now.

– North Korea's Kim Jong Un is said to be in stable condition after undergoing surgery on both ankles, the Telegraph reports. The 31-year-old leader is said to be under armed guard at a hospital in Pyongyang. Sources in South Korea say elite officials are now visiting the ward after Kim's official car didn't appear to have left Pyongyang in recent weeks.

– The Weather Channel's Mike Williams had to issue a mea culpa today, after he was widely accused of writing his name in the snow during a live report on Saturday night's blizzard. "I apologize to anyone I may have offended in any way," he wrote on the channel's Facebook page, calling for "social media" to apologize as well. "I was just trying to be a good sport and not get into a situation where I was accused of writing my name in the snow." It turns out he wasn't writing his name in the snow at all, nor would it have been, ahem, "writing his name in the snow."

– The Nigerian government said Friday that it reached a cease-fire agreement with Boko Haram, the jihadist organization that kidnapped 219 girls in April, according to the AFP. Boko Haram, whose name means "Western education is forbidden" in the local language, has been terrorizing Nigeria for more than a decade. The government had been under increasing pressure to crack down on the group after the girls were taken from their school in Chibok in April.

– Two Australian mates had to be talked out of the gnarly honor of eating what they claim is the world's oldest burger, which they bought at an Adelaide McDonald's 20 years ago. The burger, described by one of the men as "the most delicious thing I've ever had," is said to be a 20-year-old McDonald's concoction made of beef, cheese, lettuce, pickles, onions, and a "special sauce" that's said to have been invented by one of the men's great-great-great-grandfathers. (It's also said to be the oldest McDonald's burger ever made.)

– A video that went viral over the weekend shows a guy who looks a lot like Paul Rudd walking around with a cardboard cut-out of Rudd's face on his back, reports Vanity Fair, which got in touch with the actor's reps and learned that the guy in the video is not, in fact, Rudd. "Update: wink wink nudge nudge—the man in the video is definitely not Paul Rudd," reads the tweet. "Either that, or we have a much bigger clone problem." (Click to watch the video.)

– Apple's first major new product since the death of Steve Jobs isn't expected to boost the company's profits any time soon: A new report from investment firm Piper Jaffray predicts that selling prices for the Apple Watch will fall to as low as $550 by the end of the year, the Wall Street Journal reports. That's because consumers will be able to use the watch as a case or as an internal storage option, according to the report, which notes that the $349 price tag for the basic Apple Watch isn't going to cut it for most consumers. The report says the $349 price tag for the basic Apple Watch doesn't take into account the watch's various options, including the possibility of pairing it with an iPhone, the Journal reports. The report predicts that Apple Watch prices will fall to $575 to $600 for the basic Apple Watch, $575 to $600 for the Apple Watch Sport, and $600 to $600 for the Apple Watch Edition, according to 9to5mac.com.

– Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, the man believed to have shot a soldier near Canada's Parliament yesterday before being shot dead by police, has been identified as a 32-year-old Quebec man who had been designated a "high-risk traveler" by Canadian authorities, the Globe and Mail reports. Sources tell the AP that Zehaf-Bibeau, who converted to Islam, had been living under a different name in Quebec and was not on a terror watchlist.

– When his wife died in 2003, Stan Beaton refused to change his phone company out of fear that he'd lose the voicemail message she left on their phone—the only way he could hear the sound of her voice. So when Virgin Media lost the message during a service upgrade in December, the 68-year-old Brit was "absolutely devastated" and "extremely angry," the BBC reports. So he contacted Virgin Media to see if they could retrieve it and—with the help of nearly a dozen engineers—they did.

– The World Health Organization is investigating reports that ISIS militants have contracted the deadly Ebola virus and are seeking help at a hospital in Mosul in Iraq, the Daily Mail reports. WHO spokesman Christy Feig confirmed that the health agency is reaching out to ISIS officials in the region to gather more information. ISIS militants are believed to have brought the Ebola virus to Mosul from West Africa, where it has killed thousands. Feig said the Iraqi government hasn't yet responded to the news of possible Ebola cases in the country.

– A woman who claimed to have been the girlfriend of Michael Phelps before he went to rehab says she was actually born a male. Taylor Lianne Chandler, 41, tells Radar that she was an "intersex baby," with partial male and partial female genitalia. When she was a teenager, she started going by Paige Victoria Whitney and underwent surgeries to become a woman, she says. Chandler, who says she met Phelps, 29, when he was 29, says she never told Phelps that she was born a male, the New York Daily News reports.

– If you needed another reason to hate Comcast, the most hated company in America, they've just given it to you: they've declared war on Tor Browser. If you're one of the millions of people who use Tor to dodge Comcast's cord-cutting and other anti-competitive practices, well, you're in for a treat. The company has announced plans to block users of the popular online anonymity service from using its broadband service, reports the Los Angeles Times. The move comes a day after the Obama administration announced plans to end Comcast's monopoly on Internet service.

– If you want a gold version of the Apple Watch, you're going to have to shell out at least $5,000, an analyst tells 9to5mac.com. That's "as much as a middle-class worker's monthly salary in the United States," says John Gruber, a senior fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. He predicts that the gold version of the Apple Watch will sell for between $349 and $5,000 when it's released later this year. (The vanilla version of the watch only costs $349.)

"This is a sickening act of terrorism and I condemn it in the strongest possible terms," Cameron said in a statement. "It is sickening to see the murder of a British aid worker in the name of freedom, and I condemn it in the strongest possible terms the terrorists who carried it out." Father John O'neal was pronounced dead within an hour of being rushed to the hospital after suffering a heart attack last week, the Irish Times reports. – Is JJ Abrams trying to push Star Wars: The Force Awakens out of its original December 2015 release date? That's what he reportedly told a group of attendees at a recent industry event, according to the AV Club. "I've approached Disney about moving up the release date for The Force Awakens," he said, according to the Hollywood Reporter. "I'm not saying it's a done deal, but I'm open to it." The officers, who served in the Iraqi military during the 24-year rule of Saddam Hussein, are conducting the training at the captured al-Jarrah military airport east of Aleppo in northern Syria, the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights said.

The militant group, which released a video showing the beheading of British aid worker David Haines earlier this year, says Foley was killed because the US has been conducting airstrikes against its positions in Iraq. The FBI is investigating the video, reports AP.

– Sorry to burst your bubble, but RoboCop-style robots aren't roaming Microsoft's Silicon Valley campus, the Seattle Times reports. The rumor started when a robot company called Knightscope showed off its K5 security robot at an event at Microsoft. The Sept. 15 attack on officers in the town of Duluiyah took place after an exchange of fire between militants and members of a Sunni tribe who were guarding the town's borders. "It was a strange explosion," a witness tells the Post. "We saw yellow smoke in the sky." According to Iraqi officials, 11 officers were hospitalized after the attack.

– The small town of Purdon, Texas, is under quarantine after a family of five there tested positive for Ebola, but health officials say there's no indication the disease is spreading, the Dallas Morning News reports. The family has been isolated in a local hospital, and no one else in the town is showing symptoms, officials say. Purdon is around 70 miles from Dallas, where Ebola patient Thomas Duncan died, but it's not clear how far the disease has spread, the New York Times notes.

– The World Health Organization is looking into reports that ISIS fighters in Iraq are showing up at hospitals with Ebola symptoms. According to the pro-government Iraqi newspaper al Sabaah, an unknown number of ISIS militants have shown up at a hospital in the militant-controlled city of Mosul, about 250 miles north of Baghdad. The paper reported that foreign terrorists brought the disease into Mosul from "several countries" in Africa. It's not yet clear whether ISIS extremists actually have Ebola or another disease. Ebola symptoms include fever, vomiting, diarrhea, and unexplained bleeding.

– Jordan's King Abdullah is prepared to personally lead airstrikes against ISIS in retaliation for the execution of a military pilot, according to reports in Arabic-language newspapers. The king, a trained pilot, may personally take part in bombing raids on ISIS strongholds today, according to reports in Arabic-language newspapers. It comes after the former general told members of Congress that he was ready to exact a blistering revenge against the ISIS terror army for the brutal execution of military pilot Moaz al-Kassasbeh—and he quoted a Clint Eastwood movie character to make his point.

– The 18-karat gold version of the Apple Watch Edition will set you back a cool $1,200, TechCrunch reports. The 18-karat gold version of the Apple Watch Edition will be the most expensive of the three new editions of the Apple Watch. – When the Apple Watch goes on sale in April, it will not be an accessory for your iPhone—but it will be an accessory for your iPhone, according to tech writer John Gruber. He predicts that the cost of the Apple Watch will top $10,000, the Telegraph reports. Gruber, who predicted the price of the iPhone 6 when it was released last year, says the cost of the Apple Watch—which will start at $349 for the basic Sport model—will depend on how many people want to buy it and how much they want their iPhone to be an accessory for it. For example, if you want to buy an 18-karat gold Edition model, your iPhone will be an accessory for that model as well, Gruber says. The Telegraph notes that no one knows how much the stainless steel and 18-karat gold Edition models will cost, but beyond that no one knows how far into uncharted water Apple is willing to sail. Authorities say the woman's body was found in a river near the town of Tenochtitln. They haven't released any details about the woman's identity or said where she went missing. She was last seen leaving a party in Tenochtitln on Nov. 6.

– The Washington Post and other major news outlets were fooled by a fake news site posing as Chinese public broadcaster CCTV, reports the AP. Now, 19 years later, she's telling her story publicly for the first time. The 21-year-old from Kent, England, tells the Telegraph that when she was told she had been chosen to play the sun baby on the show, she thought it was a joke. "I was like, 'Oh my God,'" she says. Smith, who is studying to be a nursery school teacher, says she was "thrilled" and "honored" to have been chosen to play the sun baby in the show, which ran from 1995 to 1999.

According to the Salt Lake Tribune, 46-year-old Jason Wright says he was on his way home from a holiday party on Dec. 4 when he stopped at a gas station and asked for a quart of eggnog. He says he drank it first thing in the morning and woke up in the hospital four hours later. "I was like, 'Oh my God,'" Wright tells the Tribune. "I was like, 'I can't breathe. I can't feel anything.'" Wright says he didn't realize what was going on until he woke up in the hospital's intensive care unit. "I was like, 'Oh my God,'" Wright says. "I was like, 'I can't breathe. I can't feel anything.'" Doctors told him to stop drinking the eggnog, and he woke up in intensive care with a pulmonary embolism, which is a blood clot in the lung. – The Secret Service has identified the man who jumped the White House fence and got past a female agent before being tackled by a male agent on Sept. 19 as Omar Mateen, a 28-year-old Florida man with a history of mental illness, the AP reports. A law enforcement source tells the Washington Post that Mateen has a history of mental illness, including bipolar disorder, and has been diagnosed with schizophrenia. The source says Mateen was initially deemed a "person of interest" by the Secret Service after he was found to have consumed alcohol on the day of the incident. The source tells the Post that a search of Mateen's home turned up a number of firearms, including a semi-automatic pistol, as well as "a number of knives, a large knife, and a number of rounds of ammunition."

– Tech blog TechCrunch is out with a report about the Apple Watch that's getting a lot of attention. The site says that inside one of the channels where watch bands slip into place, there's a hidden "diagnostic port" that could be used in the future to interface with "smart band" accessories. "Several sources have confirmed its existence and placement to me," writes David Pogue. "It is very similar to the connector for the Lightning Lightning port for the Apple Watch." The report says the port is currently only used for diagnostic purposes, but it could be used in the future to interface with "smart band" accessories, bringing additional functionality to the watch.

– Rep. Steve Stockman (R-Texas) said on Morning Joe this morning that "we've got ISIS on the other side of the border," referring to the Islamic State. Well, it turns out Homeland Security chief Jeh Johnson isn't buying it. "I don't think that's true," he said on Morning Joe, per CNN. "They're not entering the US through the southern border." Johnson was responding to a claim made by Rep. Steve Stockman (R-Texas), who said on Morning Joe that "we've got ISIS on the other side of the border," referring to the Islamic State. Homeland Security chief Jeh Johnson says ISIS isn't entering the US through the southern border.

– A Utah man is in the hospital after quaffing a quart of eggnog in 12 seconds at an office holiday party. "Everyone knows I'm pretty competitive," Ryan Roche of Lehi, Utah, tells ABC News. "I just decided I was going to win. So I pretty much just opened it up and poured it down my throat." The 33-year-old says he shaved 10 seconds off the previous best time.

– A college student in China is in hot water after he decided to set off fireworks to propose to his girlfriend—only to have the whole thing go up in flames. Dim Xiong Chien, a 22-year-old student at the Liaoning Advertisement Vocational College in Shenyang, apparently wanted to surprise girlfriend Cong Yen with a huge fireworks display this week, but she never showed up. So he decided to set them off anyway, hoping she'd see the huge display. The whole plan literally went up in flames when the fireworks lit the 10-foot-tall grass on fire. Firefighters were called in to put out the 10-foot-tall flames. The school is currently debating how to punish Chien, but they told local reporters that luckily they were insured.

– The wife and son of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi have been detained by the Lebanese army as they tried to cross from Syria into Lebanon, security officials say. A Lebanese newspaper reports that the army detained al-Baghdadi's wife and one of her sons as they crossed from Syria with a fake passport, al-Jazeera reports. The army says it is working with "foreign intelligence apparatus" to track them down.

– Batman v. Superman director Zack Snyder has solved a case of mistaken identity. Bleeding Cool reports that one of the two batmobiles being used in the movie was stolen in Detroit, but Snyder tweeted a photo of himself and JJ Abrams to make fun of the whole thing. "Case closed," reads the caption.

– If you're among the Chinese who prefer to use an English name rather than a Chinese one, you may want to stop reading now. A satirical website that looks a lot like China's state-owned CCTV website has a warning for those considering an alternative English name: Don't pick names that could cause offense, make you look stupid, or just make no sense at all, the Telegraph reports. The tongue-in-cheek "guide to choosing an English name" also warns against words like "dragon," "fish," and "lawyer" that have the potential for sexual innuendo. "Many Chinese people prefer to use an English name, particularly if they conduct business with the West," the Telegraph notes. "But the satirical site suggests people should avoid fictional characters, names with the potential for sexual innuendo, or random words like Dragon, Fish or Lawyer, which could come back and haunt you 'if you want a call.'"

– Some real estate agents really know how to tip. Some real estate agents really know how to tip. A Michigan pizza delivery driver got the shock of his life Thursday after receiving a $2,000 tip for delivering a pizza to a group of realtors, the Detroit Free Press reports.

– The White House says President Obama has approved the use of armed drones to help in the search for ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, who has been believed to be hiding out in the Syrian city of Raqqa. A senior administration official tells the AP that the decision to use drones was made after intelligence indicated that al-Baghdadi was hiding out in the city, which is the capital of the Islamic State group's self-proclaimed capital of Raqqa. The official says the decision to use drones came after intelligence indicated that al-Baghdadi was planning an attack on the US Embassy in Syria.

– ISIS has confirmed the death of American hostage Kayla Mueller, saying in a statement that she was killed when the building where she was being held in Raqqa, Syria, collapsed in an airstrike. Mueller, who was abducted in August while working as a missionary in Syria, is believed to be the first American to be killed while being held by the militant group, the AP reports.

– A gunman opened fire at Canada's Parliament on Wednesday, killing one and wounding six before being shot and killed by a police officer, authorities said. The Conservative Party said in a statement that one member of the public was killed and six others were injured. None of the injuries were believed to be life-threatening. Police said the shooter was wearing body armor and used a high-powered rifle. Parliament Hill was locked down as police investigated the scene.

– A US journalist held by al-Qaeda in Yemen is killed by militants during an operation to rescue him, US and Yemeni officials tell the New York Times. A US journalist held by al-Qaeda in Yemen is killed by militants during an operation to rescue him, US and Yemeni officials tell the New York Times. A US journalist held by al-Qaeda in Yemen is killed by militants during an operation to rescue him, US and Yemeni officials tell the New York Times.

– Batman's Batmobile is missing from the set of Batman v Superman, according to the Hollywood Reporter, which cites "multiple sources." It's not clear what happened to the customized car, which is being used as a prop in the superhero movie.

– Brian Williams took a moment on NBC Nightly News Monday to apologize to meteorologist Mike Seidel for the "wild misinformation" that circulated about him during a live appearance with Lester Holt over the weekend. Seidel had to take off his gloves and redial his phone when he couldn't hear Holt through his earpiece, Williams explained, so he turned his back to the camera, took off his gloves, and redialed his phone to connect for the segment. "That's when the rumors hit the web," he said, explaining that Seidel has lost communication with NBC News. "That's when the rumors hit the web that he was doing a live interview with Lester Holt, and he couldn't hear him through his earpiece." The anchor said social media and some news websites owe Seidel an "apology."

– If you've ever dreamed of being your own boss, now's your chance. The New York Times reports on a company called Hangzhou Xiongjin Technology Co., which has been developing and testing robots for the past two years. It's currently working on a prototype of a self-driving car that can drive itself, and it hopes to have one up and running by the end of the year. According to the company's website, its goal is to build a fleet of robots that can eventually replace human workers in a variety of jobs, and it's already working with a Chinese company on a project to build a fleet of self-driving cars of its own. Hangzhou Xiongjin Technology Co. is currently working on a prototype of a self-driving car that can drive itself, and it hopes to have one up and running by the end of the year. It's currently working on a prototype of a self-driving car that can drive itself, and it hopes to have one up and running by the end of the year. According to the company's website, it's currently working on a prototype of a self-driving car that can drive itself, and it hopes to have one up and running by the end of the year

– Five ISIS militants in Mosul, Iraq, have been burned alive because they were apparently infected with Ebola, an Iraqi health official tells a Kurdish paper. "The Islamic State organization incinerated five militants infected with Ebola to prevent further spread of the disease in Mosul," Faisal Ghazi, who is part of Iraq's Health Committee in its council of ministries, tells Rudaw. "ISIS had proof that these militants were infected with Ebola." Ghazi says the militants were killed on New Year's Eve and their bodies were set ablaze to "prevent further spread of the disease." He adds, "The Islamic State organization incinerated five militants infected with Ebola to prevent further spread of the disease in Mosul." It's not the first time ISIS has shown signs of Ebola.

– The mystery surrounding North Korea's erratic young leader, Kim Jong Un, only deepens by the day. He has not been seen publicly in more than a month. Rumors are flying that Kim is ill with gout, diabetes, even possible problems with his ankles. Now, a group of defectors say they believe Kim's younger sister, Kim Yo Jong, may be running the country while he recuperates. The North Korea Intellectuals' Solidarity, a think-tank run by defectors, says Kim Yo Jong may be at least temporarily leading the government.

– Apple is working on a new version of its MacBook Air with a 12-inch screen and a "radically new design," sources tell 9to5mac.com. The new design will be based on "micron architecture," meaning it will be thinner and lighter than the current 11-inch model, the sources say. The 12-inch screen will have a native resolution of 1920 x 1080. The 11-inch MacBook Air has a resolution of 1366 x 768.

– Looks like Saudi Arabia's state TV may have blurred the face of Michelle Obama during last night's arrival ceremony for the first lady, but Saudi embassy officials say that's not true. "Saudi TV has been showing the total arrival ceremony at the airport and at the Palace and nowhere is anything blurred," an information director at the Saudi Embassy in Washington tells Bloomberg. CNN's Hala Gorani tweeted that the Saudi TV "did not blur Michelle Obama's face."

– Vladimir Putin paid tribute Sunday to Russian soldiers who fought in World War I, but a video of him unveiling a monument to them quickly went viral, the New York Daily News reports. "This tragedy reminds us what happens when aggression, selfishness, and the unbridled ambitions of national leaders and political establishments push common sense aside, so that instead of preserving the world's most prosperous continent, Europe, they lead it towards danger," the Russian president said. "It is worth remembering this today." He was apparently referring to the current political crisis in Russia.

– An audio recording that allegedly captures the gunshots that killed Michael Brown has been released to CNN. On the tape is the voice of a Ferguson man talking during a video chat. KTVI has the audio here.

– The Islamic State has beheaded American journalist Steven Sotloff in revenge for American airstrikes on the militant group's de facto capital of Raqqa, reports the New York Times. Sotloff, who was seized in Mosul in July while working for a news agency, was one of two Americans kidnapped by the Islamic State, the other being James Foley, who was seized in Foley's hometown of Middletown, Conn., last year. Sotloff's body was reportedly found in the back of a truck in northern Iraq on Sunday. The Islamic State has claimed credit for the beheading.

– Police say they've found the body of a 16-year-old boy who was reported missing more than a week ago, and they don't suspect foul play. Authorities say the teen's body was found in a park near the high school where he was a student in the town of Long Beach, Calif., the Los Angeles Times reports. The Long Beach Press-Telegram reports that police found the teen's body after getting a tip that someone had left a "suspicious object" in the park.

– "In Britain, it's not just no-go zones." So declared a Fox contributor in a meme that's gone viral, prompting the network to set up a fake Twitter account last night to "manage and dispel all false facts attributed to us through the #foxnewsfacts trend," the @FoxNewsPress account read, per the Los Angeles Times. "In Britain, it's not just no-go zones," the contributor added, per the New York Daily News. "In America, we call it white suburban sprawl. In Britain, it's swallowed whole by Muslim immigrants." The fake account has since been deleted, but the Daily News has screenshots.

– Amazon is getting into the streaming-video game. The Wall Street Journal reports the company will launch an ad-supported streaming service early next year that will be separate from Amazon Prime, the company's current streaming-video offering. According to the New York Times, the new service will be similar in concept to Netflix's video-on-demand service and Hulu's live-streaming service, both of which are owned by Amazon. It's unclear if the new service will also be offered by other companies.

– Led Zeppelin fans have been clamoring for a reunion tour since Jimmy Page and John Paul Jones agreed to do a "35 dates in three cities" earlier this year. But Robert Plant was having none of it, the Huffington Post reports, and so the band pulled the plug on the tour. "Like a poorly written character in an Aaron Sorkin script, he literally ripped up a contract," writes Matt Cherette. "And like a cure for AIDS, probably, but also the Led Zeppelin thing."

– Before Kim Jong Un took power in North Korea, his father's name was Kim Il Sung—and before he died, his name was officially changed to Kim Jong Un. That's according to an internal document obtained by South Korean TV station KBS and reported by the Guardian. The document, which can be seen in full here, decrees that anyone sharing Kim's name must change it.

– Mexico's attorney general says DNA tests have shown that 28 bodies found in a mass grave are not those of a missing group of students, as 14 more police officers are arrested. Mexico's attorney general says DNA tests have shown that 28 bodies found in a mass grave are not those of a missing group of students, as 14 more police officers are arrested.

– Iraq's Interior Ministry said on Wednesday that a woman detained by Lebanese authorities was not the wife of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, but the sister of a man convicted of bombings in southern Iraq. Iraq's Interior Ministry said on Wednesday that a woman detained by Lebanese authorities was not the wife of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, but the sister of a man convicted of bombings in southern Iraq. Iraq's Interior Ministry said on Wednesday that a woman detained by Lebanese authorities was not the wife of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, but the sister of a man convicted of bombings in southern Iraq.

– Seth Rogen is in talks to play Steve Wozniak in Aaron Sorkin's film about the life of Steve Jobs, according to the Wrap. Christian Bale is already in talks to play the late Apple founder, and Jessica Chastain is also in talks.

– A 35-year-old Bolivian nun who moved to a convent in Italy last year gave birth to a baby boy at the hospital where she was brought in because she was suffering from a stomach ache, the Telegraph reports. An ultrasound confirmed the happy event, and the nun was transferred to an obstetrics unit a few hours after the birth. "No sister gave birth to a child," said the convent's abbess, who denied that the nun had even given birth.

– A photo of a woman holding an array of iPhones has gone viral in China, giving a glimpse into the country's massive app-ranking factory. The woman in the photo appears to be giving out fake ratings to apps, which could affect the top lists of Apple's App Store, reports Tencent Technology. The photo was posted on China's Weibo microblog and has since gone viral.

– Apple's much-anticipated new product, the Apple Watch, was unveiled Tuesday in Cupertino, Calif., but the tech giant did not address one of the watch's major criticisms: the watch's lackluster battery life. Sources tell Re/code that the company will require daily charging, keeping the watch in line with similar smart watches from Samsung and Motorola. "There's a lot of new technology packed into Apple Watch and we think people will love using it throughout the day," an Apple spokesperson says. "We anticipate that people will charge nightly, which is why we designed an innovative charging solution that combines our MagSafe technology and inductive charging." The $349 Apple Watch will be available next month.

– British police have confirmed that a famous street artist was arrested in the UK—but he wasn't Banksy, as was reported. The hoax story, which appeared on US website National Report, claimed that the 35-year-old was arrested in Watford after a "24-hour Anti-Graffiti Task Force" traced him and found "thousands of dollars of counterfeit money along with future projects of vandalism" at his London art studio, the Independent reports. Scotland Yard confirmed that a man was arrested "without bail on charges of vandalism, conspiracy, racketeering, and counterfeiting" but said he was not Banksy.

– Seth Rogen is in talks to star as Steve Wozniak in Sony's Steve Jobs biopic, reports the Hollywood Reporter. Danny Boyle is directing the film, based on Walter Isaacson's book and adapted by Aaron Sorkin, which is one of the most anticipated biopics in recent years. Negotiations have not yet begun, and it's not even clear if Rogen has an official offer, but the producers—Scott Rudin, Guymon Casady, and Mark Gordon—have set their sights on the talent and are in talks.

– Rats have been plaguing the new Vogue headquarters since the beginning of the year, and now the gossip site Gawker reports that they’re “basically holding a Friendsgiving in the fashion closet.” The rats are “chewing away at shoe boxes, noshing on taffeta, and leaving droppings everywhere,” according to the report. Maybe they got in through the vents after Anna Wintour and Condé Nast requested changes to the building prior to its move-in date, the source says. “It sounds like the staffers may be victims of their own highfalutin-design preferences,” the source adds. “Due to architectural changes requested by Anna Wintour and Condé Nast prior to the move-in date, the little suckers may have gotten in through the vents.”

– An Israeli soldier who served in Iraq with the Israeli Defense Forces has been killed while fighting ISIS in northern Iraq. Gill Rosenberg, a 31-year-old Canadian national and former IDF soldier, was killed by a roadside bomb while fighting with Kurdish fighters against the Islamic State, the CBC reports. Rosenberg, who served in Iraq from 2009 to 2011, told Israeli media earlier this month that she traveled to Iraq to help the Kurdish People's Protection Units (YPG) fight off ISIS.

– A small meteorite left a crater 39 feet wide and 16 feet deep in a wooded area near the airport in Nicaragua's capital, the AP reports. Government spokeswoman Rosario Murillo said a committee formed by the government to study the event determined it was a "relatively small" meteorite that appears to have come off an asteroid that was passing close to Earth.

– The fence-jumper who bolted across the White House lawn and got close to the president was able to make it far into the building before he was tackled by Secret Service agents, a law enforcement official tells ABC News. The official says that while Omar Gonzalez made it as far as the East Room, he was tackled by agents before he could get far inside the White House. (Gonzalez made it as far as the North Portico doors before being taken into custody.)

– Amazon is planning to open a brick-and-mortar store in New York City, across from the Empire State Building, in time for the holiday shopping season, the Wall Street Journal reports. The store will reportedly function like a mini-warehouse, with inventory for same-day delivery in New York City, and will also act as a hub for product returns, exchanges, and pickup of online orders. Sources also said that Amazon might use the space to showcase products like its new Kindle

– In North Korea, you can't have the same name as Kim Jong Un—or any other North Korean leader, for that matter. According to a leaked document seen by South Korea's Yonhap News Agency, North Korea banned the use of the name Jong Un in 2011, months before Kim Jong Un took power, the Washington Post reports. According to the leaked document, "all party organs and public security authorities" are required to identify people who share Kim's name.

– DNA tests have confirmed that a daughter and an ex-wife of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi are being held by Lebanese authorities. There have been conflicting reports about the identity of the woman, with an Iraqi official denying on Wednesday she was al-Baghdadi's ex wife. The Telegraph reports that the woman is believed to be the leader's second wife.

– A lawyer for the family of Michael Brown says audio of a man speaking in a video chat at the time of the 18-year-old's shooting death is "irrefutable evidence" that Brown was shot dead. The audio was recorded at the apartment complex where Brown was killed and aired on CNN last night. It features a man speaking in a video chat about unrelated topics ("You are pretty," he says at one point) and at least 10 shots can be heard ringing out over the course of the 12-second clip, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch reports. The family's lawyer, Lopa Blumenthal, says the man is Brown's cousin and was at the apartment complex at the time of the shooting. She says the man, who hasn't been identified, recorded the video at the request of Brown's mother, who was in the apartment complex at the time of the shooting. She says the man told her he was on his way to pick up his things from the store when he heard gunshots. Blumenthal says the audio is an important piece of evidence because "one can clearly hear at least 10 gunshots ring out over the course of the 12-second file—first a group of six shots, then four more." She says

– It's been more than two months since Apple announced its long-awaited Apple Watch, and since then, there's been no official word on when it'll be out—or even if it'll be out at all. But one thing is certain: It's going to be expensive. Bloomberg reports that the price of the stainless steel Apple Watch will be starting at $349, up from the previous estimate of $299. The Wall Street Journal reports that the price is expected to rise further in the coming weeks, possibly as high as $500. The Journal also notes that the watch will be sold separately from the iPhone.

– A US airstrike killed three senior members of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, including Abu Hajar Al-Sufi, an aide to ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, a senior Iraqi security official tells NBC News. Also killed in the strike were an explosives operative and the military leader of nearby Tel Afar.

– It's that time of year again: time for yet another pumpkin spice latte. This time, however, the latte-flavored condom is not a pumpkin spice latte, but a condom made by Durex, Mashable reports. According to a Twitter user, the condoms are inspired by Starbucks' famous pumpkin spice latte. "Because safe sex is important, no matter what season it is," the tweet reads. Durex hasn't confirmed or denied the existence of the condoms.

– Judd Nelson is not dead. That's what a website claiming to be affiliated with Fox News posted Sunday after a report that theBrat Pack actor had been found dead in his condo, the New York Daily News reports. "It was all a hoax," a Fox News rep says. " Judd Nelson is not dead."

– ISIS released a graphic video today showing the beheading of American journalist James Foley, and the group has threatened to kill another US journalist if the US doesn't cease its airstrikes in Iraq, the New York Times reports. The video shows the decapitated body of the 40-year-old, who went missing in Syria in 2012, along with the execution of another American, Steven Sotloff. "I'm back, Obama, and I'm back because of your arrogant foreign policy towards the Islamic State," Foley says in the video. "I'm back because of your arrogant treatment of Muslims." Sotloff, a freelancer who worked for Time and CNN, was kidnapped in Syria last year.

– Apple and HBO are reportedly in talks to team up to offer a stand-alone pay-per-view service that would compete with Netflix and Amazon, reports the Wall Street Journal. The move would put Apple in direct competition with Netflix, which is currently the No. 1 pay-per-view service in the US. HBO, meanwhile, is in direct competition with Time Warner's HBO Now, which is currently the No. 2 pay-per-view service in the US. The move would also put HBO in direct competition with Netflix, which is currently the No. 1 pay-per-view service in the US. HBO Now is currently the No. 2 pay-per-view service in the US.

– Christian Bale has dropped out of Danny Boyle's Steve Jobs biopic, sources tell the Hollywood Reporter. The Christian Bale news comes on the same day it was reported that Seth Rogen was in talks to play Steve Wozniak in the film.

– Glenn Beck thinks al-Qaeda or other extremists in the Middle East could use the 11 fighter jets seized from Moammar Gadhafi's forces in Libya to cause "extraordinary damage" to the US—even if the planes never leave the region. “There’s really two concerns. One, the planes could be used in a similar way that they were used on 9/11 in the United States. And two, Extremists could crash the planes into the oil fields in any of the oil-rich countries on which the US is dependent,” Michele Bachmann said on Glenn Beck's radio show, according to Mediaite. Beck added that the planes could be used "in a similar way that they were used on 9/11 in the United States."

– A photo that purports to show the body of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi is making the rounds on social media, though there's no confirmation from either the White House or the Iraqi government, NBC News reports. The photo, which purports to show al-Baghdadi's body in a pool of blood, has been shared thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter. The White House says it is aware of reports of al-Baghdadi's death and is looking into them. Meanwhile, an Iraqi official tells Al Arabiya that an airstrike near Mosul killed Abu Hajar al-Sufi, an aide to al-Baghdadi, as well as an explosives operative and the military leader of nearby Tal Afar.

– A 7-year-old Iranian girl is in critical condition after being hit by a train while walking on a snowy street in central Tehran, the AP reports. Police say the girl was hit by a train that was approaching from the direction of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard building. According to Iran's semi-official Fars News Agency, the girl was taken to a local hospital, where she was in critical condition.

– Led Zeppelin was supposed to reunite for a tour this summer—but Robert Plant didn't want to do it. The band was about to sign an $800 million contract with Virgin Atlantic billionaire Richard Branson to play a reunion tour, but Plant "pulled the contract to shreds in the final moments" of negotiations, a source tells the Telegraph. The source says Plant wasn't happy with the terms of the deal, which included a co-headlining tour with Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band.

– Amazon will open its first brick-and-mortar store in New York City in time for the holiday shopping season, reports the Wall Street Journal. The temporary store will be located across the street from the Empire State Building and will hold limited inventory for same-day deliveries only. Customers will be able to order items online and pick them up the same day in the store.

– YouTube star Josh Paler Lin, who has more than 700,000 subscribers, decided to try a social experiment: He gave a homeless man $100 and followed him around with a camera so he could see what he would do with the money, the Los Angeles Times reports. The result? The man spent it on booze.

– A photo of what appears to be a pumpkin spice condom went viral over the weekend, causing many to wonder if it was a prank from Durex. But a spokesperson for the condom maker tells BuzzFeed that the supposed product is not, in fact, a pumpkin spice condom. "Durex has heard that people are saying we launched a 'Pumpkin Spice' condom," the spokesperson says. "We can't claim this one, but we do love it when people spice it up in the bedroom."

– A Utah man who chugged a quart of eggnog in 12 seconds to win a restaurant gift card said he was also awarded with a three-day stay in the hospital. A Utah man who chugged a quart of eggnog in 12 seconds to win a restaurant gift card said he was also awarded with a three-day stay in the hospital. A Utah man who chugged a quart of eggnog in 12 seconds to win a restaurant gift card said he was also awarded with a three-day stay in the hospital.

– Two Republican lawmakers told BuzzFeed News Wednesday suspected terrorists have infiltrated the US–Mexico border and as many as 10 fighters have been captured, but Homeland Security officials deny any such thing has happened. Rep. Jason Chaffetz, a Republican from Utah, said four alleged terror suspects were captured on Sept. 10 in Texas. In an interview Wednesday, Chaffetz said the men flew from a Middle Eastern country to Mexico City, where they paid a smuggler to take them to and across the border. From there, the men ended up in a safe house for immigrants. They were en route to New York City, Chaffetz said. But a Department of Homeland Security rep tells BuzzFeed there's "no indication" of such a thing.

– A US Marine nearly died in Afghanistan in 2013 when a Taliban sniper's bullet struck him in the head, but he lived to fight another day thanks to his Kevlar-reinforced helmet, Fox News reports. A fellow soldier's helmet cam captured the incident, which happened during an ambush in the Now Zad District of Helmand Province. "It's a terrifying first-hand look at how close US forces come to disaster each day as wars rage abroad," Fox News states.

– North Korea's state-run media is reporting that Kim Jong Un is in poor health and has been forced to cut short a visit to South Korea, the AP reports. A dispatch from the state-run Uriminzokkiri website says the leader "has had to cut short his trip to South Korea because of the serious health problems he is having." It adds that he is believed to be suffering from "complications related to his mental and physical health as well as his physical health." North Korea's state-run Korean Central News Agency says the report is "groundless" and "aimed at defaming" the country.

– The brouhaha over a Fox News terrorism expert who claimed Birmingham, England, is a "no-go area" for Muslims continues, but this time it's not about Fox News at all. Instead, it's about British Muslims having a good time online, thanks to the #FoxNewsFacts hashtag. "Yes, we wished it were true, too, but no, Fox News are not angrily responding on Twitter to the hilarious #FoxNewsFacts hashtag," quips the Daily Dot. The hashtag was born out of a tweet by a British Muslim calling out Fox's guest, terrorism expert Andrew Napolitano, for his comments. The reaction has been "brilliantly British," notes the Daily Dot. "And then suddenly it looked like Fox News had got rather upset about the hashtag, and started responding from @FoxNewsPress. Except, not really."

– The Apple Watch could be arriving at your local Apple Store by the end of March. That's according to a report from 9to5Mac, which says Apple is training store employees in Cupertino, Calif., and Austin, Texas, in sessions scheduled for Feb. 9 through Feb. 16. The employees who attend will then train employees at their local stores. Apple declined to comment to CNBC Tuesday evening.

– The Islamic State says an American hostage has been killed in a Jordanian airstrike near the northern Syrian city of Raqqa, the group's de facto capital. A statement attributed to the Islamic State group claimed that an American female hostage was killed in the airstrike on Friday on the outskirts of the northern Syrian city of Raqqa, the extremist group's main stronghold, the New York Times reports. The statement said the hostage, identified as Kayla Mueller, was executed in front of her husband and two children. Mueller, who was kidnapped in Syria in 2014, was the last remaining American hostage being held in the country.

– It's official: Christian Bale has dropped out of Aaron Sorkin's Steve Jobs biopic, reports the Hollywood Reporter. The decision comes less than two weeks after Sorkin said Bale would play the late Apple co-founder.

– A Canadian woman says she's "safe and secure" after reports that she'd been captured by the Islamic State while fighting alongside Kurdish fighters in northern Iraq. Gill Rosenberg, an Israeli who'd been volunteering with the anti-ISIS Kurdish force known as the peshmerga, posted on Facebook Monday night that she was "safe and secure" and not captured by ISIS, the New York Times reports. "I am safe and secure and not captured by ISIS," she wrote, adding that she'd been in contact with her family over the weekend and that they'd been in touch with Kurdish authorities. Rosenberg, who was born in Canada and moved to Israel when she was 10, says she'd been volunteering with the peshmerga in northern Iraq since last year and had been told by Kurdish authorities that she was being held by ISIS, the CBC reports.

– The rumors are true: Tiger Woods has been suspended by the PGA Tour for a month, according to a radio interview picked up by the AP. But the tour and Woods' agent insist the suspension is for a mere "difference of opinion" over the golfer's infidelities, and that there is "no basis" for the suspension.

– Macaulay Culkin, perhaps best known for his roles in the Home Alone movies, is dead at age 34, TMZ reports. The news was first reported on a Facebook page set up to honor the actor, who was born in New York. According to the page, "Our beloved actor Macaulay Culkin passed away. He will be missed."

– When Josh Paler Lin handed a homeless man $100, he didn't expect the man to spend it the way he did. But that's exactly what happened, in a video that has now racked up more than 10 million views on YouTube. Lin, a self-described "prankster" who has more than 711,000 subscribers on his YouTube channel, decided to follow the man around to see what he'd do with the money, the Los Angeles Times reports. He gave the man money, then followed him in secret to see what he'd do with it. And sure enough, the man's first stop was a McDonald's.

– An Australian man was on vacation in Bali when a spider got through a scar in his appendix and traveled up his torso, leaving a red scar-like trail from his navel to his chest. Dylan Maxwell was on holidays in the Indonesian island of Bali when the tiny creature borrowed through a small appendix scar and traveled up his torso, leaving a red scar-like trail from his navel to his chest. He was on vacation when a spider got through a scar in his appendix and traveled up his torso, leaving a red scar-like trail from his navel to his chest.
