– The White House has ordered an investigation into reports that ISIS used chlorine gas in an attack on Iraqi security officials last week, the Washington Post reports. According to the Post's sources, 11 Iraqi police officers were rushed to a hospital emergency room in the city of Balad after the attack on Sept. 15. "Some struggled to stand; tears streamed from their eyes," the report says. The attack took place in the town of Duluiyah, where members of the Sunni Jabbour tribe were guarding a line in the north of the country.

– A meteor the size of a small plane would have created a crater 39 feet wide and a ball of flame visible over a wide area if it had traveled faster than the speed of sound, NASA scientists say. The head of Nasa's Meteoroid Environment Office says a meteor capable of creating the crater would have created a ball of flame visible over a wide area

– The baby in the popular children's TV show Teletubbies has finally revaled herself as a university student. Jess Smith, 19, was just nine months old when she became one of the most familiar faces on British television in March 1997. Now she's a first-year student at Exeter University, the Telegraph reports.

– Vox.com, a "brainy news-explainer" site, fell for one of the Internet's many tricks: a fake video of a bird pooping on Vladimir Putin that turned out to be a hoax. The site originally presented the video as real, but compared it to Russian news footage from the event shows it to be a hoax. Putin's unintentionally ironic speech decrying "excessive ambitions in war," though, was very real. Vox explains: "Correction: This post originally presented the video of a bird pooping on Putin as real, but comparison with Russian news footage from the event shows it to be a hoax. Putin's unintentionally ironic speech decrying 'excessive ambitions in war,' though, was very real. Right here is where a media critic generally hammers the offender for naivete, stupidity and a failure to observe reportorial protocol."

– One of the five Guantanamo Bay detainees released in exchange for Army Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl has attempted to return to terrorism, CNN reports, citing US officials. The network says it has learned of an alleged attempt by one of the detainees to return to the Taliban. According to the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, the man had been designated a "low-level" threat by the Taliban at the time of his release. The officials say they don't know if the man actually posed a threat to the US.

– The Washington Post, BBC, and Sky News are all reporting that Mohammed Emwazi, the masked ISIS executioner known as "Jihadi John," has been identified as being from London. The BBC says Emwazi is a 25-year-old computer programmer who grew up in West London; the Post says he's from a "well-to-do" family; and Sky says he's a former student at the University of West London. Police have not confirmed Emwazi's identity, but say they're not "going to confirm the identity of anyone at this stage or give an update on the progress of this live counterterrorism investigation."

– The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS) says it has a new target in its war on terror: scorpions. The extremist group says it has developed a bomb that uses live scorpions as the explosive, the Telegraph reports. The scorpion bomb was first tested last year, but it hasn't been used yet, according to a statement from the group. "The aim of this bomb is to scare the Islamic State's enemies so they will flee the area before it is too late," the statement says.

– Mexican authorities say they've found a mass grave containing the bodies of more than a dozen students who went missing last month after a clash with police, the AP reports. State prosecutors in the country said a man they arrested told them 17 of the missing youths were rounded up and killed, then thrown in pits, where badly charred remains have now been unearthed. Authorities said that the man told them how the students, who went missing after a violent clash on September 26, were marched to the site on the outskirts of Iguala, Guerrero state before their deaths.

– "The urge to create is equally strong in all children. Boys and girls." So reads an open letter included in a select number of Lego doll house products sold in 1974 as a message to parents about gender equality, the Telegraph reports. The letter, which Lego confirmed was authentic, was posted to Twitter and has since been shared thousands of times. "The urge to create is equally strong in all children," it reads. "Boys and girls." The letter was included in a limited number of 1974 Lego products.

– Kim Jong Un is said to be "gravely ill"—but who's to say he won't be around to preside over North Korea's upcoming Workers' Party convention? Kim's sister, Kim Yo Jong, is said to be in charge of the country's day-to-day affairs, the Telegraph reports. The 31-year-old was first introduced to the public in March as a "senior official" of the party's central committee. She is said to be Kim Jong Un's younger sister and has long been rumored to be in line to succeed her father, the late Kim Jong Il. The Telegraph notes that while it's not clear if Kim Yo Jong has actually replaced her father as leader, the fact that she is said to be in charge of the country's day-to-day affairs "suggests she has stepped up to help [Kim Jong Un] manage the daily affairs of leadership while he battles a bout of ill health."

– Turkey's president has said that it was wrong for the United States to deliver military supplies to Kurdish fighters defending the Syrian city of Kobani after some of the weapons ended up in ISIS' hands. In an interview with a Turkish newspaper published Monday, Recep Tayyip Erdogan said the US should not have sent weapons to the Kurds, who are fighting ISIS in Kobani. "They are our brothers and sisters," he told the Hurriyet Daily News. "They are the ones who are fighting in Kobani. They are the ones who have received the weapons from the US." Turkey's president has said it was wrong for the United States to deliver military supplies to Kurdish fighters defending the Syrian city of Kobani after some of the weapons ended up in ISIS' hands. – Militants from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria released a graphic video today showing the beheading of American journalist James Wright Foley, the New York Daily News reports. The video, titled "A Message to America," was posted to social media by an account believed to belong to Foley's captors. At the end of the video, the executioner has what sounds like a British accent and threatens another American journalist.

– A self-styled "guru in bling" in India is in hot water after allegedly ordering 400 of his followers to undergo castrations he said would bring them closer to God, the Telegraph reports. Gurmeet Ram Rahim Singh—known as the "guru in bling"—is being investigated by India's Central Bureau of Investigation for criminal intimidation and causing grievous bodily hurt after the alleged castrations were carried out at his ashram last year.

– Rats have been plaguing the new 1 World Trade Center office of Vogue, and the magazine's editor-in-chief is not happy about it, the New York Daily News reports. According to the New York Post, there are as many as 20 rats in the office, which is located in the same building as the Condé Nast offices. The paper says it's unclear why there are so many of them, but it's not the first time Vogue has had a rodent problem.

– The man believed to have opened fire at Canada's Parliament before being shot dead by police has been identified as Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, a 32-year-old man from Quebec with a criminal record, the CBC reports. Police say Zehaf-Bibeau, who was shot dead by a soldier standing guard near Parliament on Wednesday, had a criminal record in Quebec and British Columbia and was charged with assault, mischief, and unlawful confinement in Quebec, the Globe and Mail reports.

– When the Apple Watch goes on sale in April, it will not be an accessory for your iPhone—but it will be an accessory for your iPhone, according to tech writer John Gruber. He predicts that the cost of the Apple Watch will top $10,000, the Telegraph reports. Gruber, who predicted the price of the iPhone 6 when it was released last year, says the cost of the Apple Watch—which will start at $349 for the basic Sport model—will depend on how many people want to buy it and how much they want their iPhone to be an accessory for it. For example, if you want to buy an 18-karat gold Edition model, your iPhone will be an accessory for that model as well, Gruber says. The Telegraph notes that no one knows how much the stainless steel and 18-karat gold Edition models will cost, but beyond that no one knows how far into uncharted water Apple is willing to sail. A debate between technology and wristwatch experts is under way to determine how far into uncharted water Apple is willing to sail.

– McDonald's is taking a hit in its home turf: Canada. The fast-food giant says it will stop selling McDonald's-branded food in the country effective Jan. 1, the CBC reports. The move follows a series of high-profile defections, including that of CEO Steve Easterbrook, who left the company last month. Easterbrook's departure was followed by the abrupt resignation of President Donald Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner, who had worked at McDonald's for more than a year. The company said in a statement that it "understands the complexity of the regulatory environment in which we operate and has taken steps to ensure our products and services are available to as many Canadians as possible." It said it will continue to sell other types of McDonald's products in Canada.

– Last week we told you about a YouTube prank that saw a homeless man get $100, only to turn around and spend the money on his peers. However, we're hearing reports that Josh Paler Lin's inspiring video may be nothing more than a well-filmed prank! Say it 'aint so! Last week we told you about a YouTube prank that saw a homeless man get $100, only to turn around and spend the money on his peers. However, we're hearing reports that Josh Paler Lin's inspiring video may be nothing more than a well-filmed prank!

– A 31-year-old teacher in Argentina is in hot water after a sex tape she made with a 16-year-old student leaked online, the Independent reports. According to the Daily Mail, Lucita Sandoval, a teacher at a high school in Santiago del Estero, made the sex tape with the student in her classroom and then passed it around on WhatsApp. Sandoval allegedly admitted to police that she'd had sexual relations with the teen in the past. Now she's been suspended from her job as a special education teacher pending an investigation. Gawker points out that most of the stories circulating about Sandoval are false.

– If you own an Apple Watch and you're in the market for a new one, you may want to check out eBay's latest job listing. The listing for a "special projects engineer" suggests that the company is working on a " bespoke Apple Watch app," reports the Wall Street Journal, which notes that the last time an Apple Watch app was put up for sale on eBay, the winning bid was more than $1 million.

– A Chinese couple is trying to raise money for their daughter's cancer treatment by selling her twin brother—on the street, the Telegraph reports. Meng Xiangyan, 29, says she and her husband can't afford live-saving treatment for their 29-year-old daughter, who has a rare form of leukemia. If she doesn't get treatment by the end of the year, Meng says she and her husband are prepared to sell their son to a good home so both could have a shot at life. The couple put him up for sale on a street in Qingdao, China's eastern Shandong province, with a placard offering to sell him to the highest bidder.

– North Korean leader Kim Jong Un had surgery on both of his ankles earlier this month, reports the South Korean newspaper Chosun Ilbo. Kim cracked bones in his ankles after neglecting an injury sustained during field supervisions in June, the Chosun Ilbo said, citing a recent visitor to North Korea it didn't identify. The person said Kim had surgery and is recovering at Bongwha Clinic, an exclusive hospital for high-ranking party members, according to the newspaper. Kim has not been seen in public in almost a month and missed a session of parliament on Sept. 25 for the first time since coming to power almost three months ago.

– An Australian man returning from a trip to Bali was surprised to find a spider had burrowed under his skin. Dylan Thomas says he noticed a mark on his stomach while vacationing on the Indonesian island and went to the hospital, where doctors told him he might have been bitten by an insect, the Sydney Morning Herald reports. He was given medicine and sent on his way, but when he arrived back home, he found the spider had burrowed under his skin under his shirt and under his pants. "It was literally crawling across my body," he says. "It took me a couple of days to figure out what was going on." He says the spider was only a few inches long, but he believes it was a tropical spider, the Telegraph reports.

– When a man in Norfolk, England, brought his ailing goldfish to a local vet's office, he was told it was constipated and would need an operation that would cost about $300. But the man didn't blink at the price, the Independent reports. "At the end of the day they're all pets and everybody does have a commitment to their pet," says the vet at Toll Barn Veterinary Center, where the man's fish was successfully removed. "He had a lump blocking his bottom, rather than because of his diet or any other reason."

– Macaulay Culkin, perhaps best known for his roles as Kevin McCallister in Home Alone and the sequel Home Alone 2: Lost in New York, was the victim of a hoax this week. A fake news story claiming the 34-year-old actor was found dead at his New York apartment appeared on a website and led to an "RIP Macaulay Culkin" Facebook page, the Huffington Post reports.

– A 40-year-old man who tried to rape a teenage girl was so enraged by her screams that he beat her and cut off his genitals with a meat cleaver, the Telegraph reports. Suresh Kumar was found pinning the girl against a wall in a village in India's northwestern Rajasthan state. A lynch mob found him and dragged him to a butchers shop, where they beat him with sticks for an hour before castrating him. Kumar is now in a hospital in critical condition.

– If you're caught with a small amount of marijuana in your possession in New York state, you'll soon be able to skip a court summons and go straight to a police station for fingerprinting. Under a new state law, anyone found with small amounts of pot would be issued with a court summons but would not be handcuffed or taken to a police station for fingerprinting, the New York Times reports. The law, which takes effect Jan. 1, is part of Gov. Andrew Cuomo's plan to make New York the first state in the nation to legalize recreational marijuana use, the Wall Street Journal reports. Under the law, people found with small amounts of pot would be issued with a court summons but would not be handcuffed or taken to a police station for fingerprinting.

– A Massachusetts priest was pronounced dead at the hospital almost exactly 48 hours after he went into cardiac arrest, but his heart started beating again and he was able to be revived, the Boston Globe reports. According to WCVB-TV, the 72-year-old was pronounced dead at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston just after 11pm on Saturday. He was pronounced dead a short time later, but his heart started beating again and he was able to be revived. "He's a miracle man," says a spokesperson for the hospital.

– McDonald's says it will keep serving overweight customers after Jan. 1, despite a fake story on DailyBuzzLive.com that claims the fast-food giant is planning to stop serving overweight customers. McDonald's USA President Steve Easterbrook said in a statement that the company has "heard from many of our customers and partners that we need to do more to make our restaurants healthier." Easterbrook said McDonald's will continue to serve customers who are either healthy-eating or meet the company's nutritional standards. The fake story claimed that McDonald's was planning to stop serving customers who are more than 60 pounds overweight, according to Easterbrook, who said the company has "heard from many of our customers and partners that we need to do more to make our restaurants healthier." He said the company will continue to serve customers who are either healthy-eating or meet the company's nutritional standards.

– HBO is working on a new streaming service that would compete with Netflix and Amazon Prime, the Wall Street Journal reports, citing "people familiar with the matter." The new service would be called HBO Now and cost $15 per month, according to the Journal's sources, who say it's in "preliminary discussions" with Apple. The move would mark the first time HBO would offer its content directly to a third-party streaming service—instead of being tied to a cable provider. Last year, HBO announced that it would finally unbundle its streaming services from cable in 2015, and the HBO Now launch could be signals that HBO is making good on that promise.

– An audio recording purporting to capture the final moments of Michael Brown's life has been verified as authentic, according to a lawyer representing a resident of the Ferguson, Mo., apartment complex where Brown was killed. The resident was using a video messaging app called Glide at the time of the shooting and inadvertently captured the sound of gunfire, the lawyer says. The recording suggests nearly a dozen shots were fired in an altercation between Brown, who was unarmed at the time, and Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson. A previously unverified audio recording that allegedly captures the final moments of Michael Brown's life has been verified as authentic, according to the video streaming application it was recorded on. A resident living in the apartment complex where Brown was killed was using a video messaging app called Glide at the time of the shooting and unwittingly captured the sound of gunfire, according to a lawyer representing the resident, whose identity has not been released.

– It's been more than a month since North Korean Supreme Leader Kim Jong Un's last public appearance, and while he hasn't been seen in public since, there's been no shortage of rumors about his health. In the last 36 days, rumors have swirled, increasing in bizarre factor with each absent day— gout, diabetes, ankle problems, cheese-induced illness, etc. Now, according to South Korea's Chosun Ilbo, the country's spy agency says Kim may have suffered a heart attack during a visit to China. The report says Kim may have had a heart attack while visiting a hospital in the People's Republic of China, which is North Korea's only neighbor to the south. South Korea's spy agency says Kim may have had a heart attack while visiting a hospital in the People's Republic of China, which is North Korea's only neighbor to the south. The country's spy agency says Kim may have had a heart attack while visiting a hospital in the People's Republic of China, which is North Korea's only neighbor. – Nothing tops a vacation in Bali like discovering there is a spider burrowing under your skin. NOTHING tops off a holiday in Bali like discovering there is a spider burrowing under your skin. Bunbury local Dylan Thomas' first trip to Bali last weekend was complete with a visit to the Bali International Medical Center to have a tropical spider pulled out of his stomach.

– The World Health Organization says it has reached out to offer assistance after reports surfaced that ISIS militants in Mosul, Iraq, had contracted the Ebola virus, the New York Times reports. WHO spokesman Gregory Hartl says the organization hasn't been able to confirm the reports, but "we have been in contact with the relevant authorities in Iraq and Syria to offer our assistance in response to this situation." The Times notes that Ebola was first reported in West Africa in 1976 and the last recorded case of the disease in the US was in 1995. According to NBC News, symptoms of Ebola include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, bleeding, and bruising. "If there is disease, spreading in epidemic fashion in Mosul, it may not necessarily be Ebola since... Ebola symptoms— nausea and vomiting, diarrhea, bleeding and bruising—are also similar to those associated with a number of other diseases, including malaria, Lassa fever, yellow fever viruses, and the Marburg virus," says the Times.
– This week, after rat droppings were allegedly found on an editor's computer keyboard, staff of all Conde Nast's titles were issued with a new rule: no eating at your desk

– "He was in his apartment, he was talking to a friend on a video chat, he heard loud noises and at the moment—at the time he didn't realize the import of what he was." So says an attorney for an unidentified man who lives in an apartment building near the site of the Aug. 9 shooting in Washington, DC, that left two police officers dead. The attorney tells CNN that the man, who hasn't been identified, was in his apartment talking to a friend on a video chat when he heard "loud noises." He says the man then heard six shots fired, followed by a pause and then several more shots, the Washington Post reports. "He was in his apartment, he was talking to a friend on a video chat, he heard loud noises and at the moment—at the time he didn't realize the import of what he was," the attorney says. According to the attorney, the man fired as many as 11 shots.

– Henry Jackson, better known as Big Bank Hank of the Sugarhill Gang, died this morning at a New Jersey hospital at age 57 from complications of cancer, the Huffington Post reports. Known for hits "(You Gotta) Fight for Your Right (to Party)!" and "Rapper's Delight," Jackson was also a member of Michael Wonder Mike Wright and Guy Master Gee O'Brien's group. "So sad to hear of our brother's passing," said Wright and O'Brien in a statement. "The three of us created musical history together with the release of 'Rapper's Delight.'"

– Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel says American Luke Somers was killed by militants during an operation aimed at freeing him from his al-Qaeda captors in Yemen. The 33-year-old was captured in 2013 while working as a freelance photographer for al-Jazeera. "I can confirm with the Department of Defense that American citizen Luke Somers was killed during the rescue attempt," Hagel said in a statement, according to Reuters. "I can also confirm that US forces were involved in the rescue attempt."

– American Luke Somers, an American photojournalist being held hostage by al-Qaeda in Yemen, was killed today during a rescue attempt, his sister tells ITV News and the AP. A Yemeni official tells NBC News that 10 militants were also killed in the operation, which was carried out jointly by the US and Yemen.

– A Macedonian man who was dumped by his girlfriend when she told him he was not any good in bed chopped off his penis and threw it in the bin. Police responding to a report of a man with a penis cutting off another man's penis found the other man's penis still attached to the victim's body, reports the Telegraph. The victim, identified only as a 21-year-old man, told police that the other man cut off his penis when he came to the couple's home to pick up his things after he was dumped by his girlfriend, who told him he was not any good in bed.

– A man wanted by police in Newfoundland turned himself in to the Royal Newfoundland Constabulary after promising to do so on Facebook. The police service said in a Saturday post that it was looking for 29-year-old Rodney Constantine in connection with warrants for various charges including assault and some traffic issues.

– A senior official in the Central Public Works Department (CPWD) was on Thursday dismissed from service for unauthorized absence of duty for 25 years. As disciplinary authority, Urban Development Minister Venkaiah... A senior official in the Central Public Works Department (CPWD) was on Thursday dismissed from service for unauthorized absence of duty for 25 years. As disciplinary authority, Urban Development Minister Venkaiah...

– A man accused of trying to rape a teenage girl is in a critical condition after locals hacked off his genitals with a meat cleaver in a butcher shop. A man accused of trying to rape a teenage girl is in a critical condition after locals hacked off his genitals with a meat cleaver in a butcher shop. A man accused of trying to rape a teenage girl is in a critical condition after locals hacked off his genitals with a meat cleaver in a butcher shop.

– The Islamic extremist known as "Jihadi John" has been identified as Mohammed Emwazi, a 25-year-old man from London, the Telegraph reports. Emwazi, who was born in Kuwait and grew up in the UK, is believed to have been the Jihadi John executioner known as "Jihadi John" who was shot dead by police in London last month. "I have no doubt that Mohammed is Jihadi John," a friend of Emwazi's tells the Telegraph. "He was like a brother to me.... I am sure it is him." Emwazi is believed to have served time in prison in the UK for crimes including drug possession.

– Is Kim Jong Un drinking snake wine to improve his sex life with wife Ri Jol-su? The Daily Star reports that the North Korean leader has been guzzling liters of a rare snake wine containing the body of a cobra. Locals believe snake wine helps men get their partners pregnant and improve the size of their manhood. The 31-year-old despot, and his wife Ri Jol-su, are said to be having problems adding to their family because of his weight.

– Michelle Obama is in Saudi Arabia for her first official visit as first lady, but she's making headlines for something else entirely: Her face was blurred by Saudi state television during a meeting with the country's new king, Bloomberg reports. King Salman shook hands with President Obama at the Erga Palace but did not acknowledge the first lady during a brief aside at the funeral for King Abdullah.

– Vanity Fair editor Graydon Carter confirms to the New York Daily News that rats are in the Condé Nast building that houses the magazine's New York offices. "They're rats! What do you think?" he asked when asked if the rats were as gross as previously reported. "And the rodent problem is only getting worse, since the rats spread from Vogue office throughout Condé Nast." Employees are reportedly not allowed to eat at their desks, and the city health department may get involved.

– A ceasefire between Nigeria's government and Boko Haram, an Islamic extremist group that has been terrorizing the country for more than a year, appears to be working, at least according to the country's armed forces chief. President Goodluck Jonathan announced a ceasefire with Boko Haram on Friday, and the group apparently abided by it, the New York Times reports. But on Friday, Boko Haram attacked a town in Adamawa state, capturing 40 women and planting a flag in the town, and beheading six people. On Saturday, Boko Haram also attacked a town in the same state, Reuters reports.

– The Pentagon has confirmed that the leader of al-Shabab, an al-Qaeda-linked organization in Africa, was killed in a US airstrike in Somalia this week. The leader, Ahmed Abdi Godane, was targeted Monday in an airstrike that hit a vehicle and compound in a militant stronghold south of the capital, Mogadishu. Al-Shabab has been linked to a number of attacks in Africa, including the bloody siege at the upscale Westgate Mall in Nairobi, Kenya, in September 2013 that killed 67 people. "Removing Godane from the battlefield is a major symbolic and operational loss to al-Shabab," the Pentagon said in a statement.

– Suspected militant Islamists have shot and slaughtered people in three villages in north-east Nigeria, despite government claims that it had agreed a truce with them, residents say. The militants, who are believed to be from the al-Qaeda-affiliated Boko Haram group, first attacked a village in Borno state last week before moving on to two other villages, the Guardian reports. Residents say at least 20 people were killed in all, including women and children. Nigeria's government says it has agreed a truce with the militants, who are believed to have killed more than 200 people in the country's northeast over the past few months.

– A 280-pound catfish caught by an Italian fisherman might be the biggest ever caught using a generic fishing rod, USA Today Sports reports. According to the San Antonio Express-News, any catfish over 6.5 feet is considered extremely rare. The fish caught by Dino Ferrari was 8.7 feet long and weighed 280 pounds. The biggest catfish ever caught weighed 300 pounds.

– The guy who jumped the White House fence and ran into the Oval Office last week was probably just trying to get inside President Obama's office, not trying to break into the president's residence, a source tells the New York Daily News. The source says the fence jumper, who was caught by Secret Service agents before he could get inside, was probably trying to get inside Obama's office to talk to the president, not try to break into his office.

– If you're looking for a way to lose weight on Jan. 4, you're in luck. According to British astronomer Patrick Moore, at exactly 9:47am PST that day, Pluto will pass directly behind Jupiter, in relation to Earth. This rare alignment will mean that the combined gravitational force of the two planets would exert a stronger tidal pull, temporarily counteracting the Earth's own gravity and making people virtually weightless. Moore calls this the Jovian-Plutonian Gravitational Effect. The event will last for five minutes.

– A Russian TV actor says someone drugged him, stole his testicles, and surgically removed them from his penis, the Telegraph reports. Dmitry Nikolaev, 30, says he was approached by a "young blonde woman" after leaving a Moscow theater. He agreed to go with her for a few drinks, but got up the next day to find himself in a pool of blood. Doctors told him that his testicles have been surgically removed by someone with medical knowledge. It's believed that a gang selling human organs could be involved.

– ISIS fighters in Iraq have tested positive for Ebola, according to a report in the Al-Sabah newspaper, which cites "anonymous sources in a hospital in Mosul." The report says that 26 people in the city have tested positive for HIV/AIDS and two of the fighters have tested positive for the virus, which has killed thousands of people in West Africa. An Iraqi health ministry spokesperson tells the International Business Times that there has been no case of Ebola in Iraq.

– "The life of this American citizen, Obama, depends on your next decision." That was the executioner's message to President Obama in a video that has since been removed from YouTube, BuzzFeed reports. The video was originally posted to a BuzzFeed account, but it was later removed from other YouTube accounts. "YouTube has clear policies that prohibit content like gratuitous violence, hate speech, and incitement to commit violent acts, and we remove videos violating these policies when flagged by our users," a YouTube spokesperson tells BuzzFeed. "We also terminate any account registered by a member of a designated Foreign Terrorist Organization and used in this video."

– The fence-jumper who bolted across the White House lawn with a knife earlier this month actually made it all the way into the East Room, the Washington Post reports, citing "three people familiar with the incident." Secret Service officials had previously told reporters that Omar Gonzalez made it inside the north portico White House doors.

– The Islamic State has released a video showing the beheading of American journalist James Foley, and it has a British accent to boot, reports the New York Times. The video, which has not been verified by the Islamic State, shows a man believed to be a British citizen standing over Foley's body while a gun is held to his head. British intelligence have reportedly identified the man as a British citizen named Jihadi John, reports the Telegraph, which notes that this is the first time the Islamic State has shown a British accent.

– Seth Rogen is in talks to play Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak in an upcoming biopic of Steve Jobs, Variety reports. Christian Bale is reportedly set to play Jobs in Danny Boyle's film, based on a script by Aaron Sorkin. Jessica Chastain is also in talks to play Jobs' ex-wife, Steve Wozniak, according to the Wrap.

– Christian Bale stars as Steve Jobs in the new Jobs movie, directed by none other than Jobs himself, Jobs biographer Walter Isaacson. So who's the real-life Jobs? Vulture rounds up some of the possible candidates: Woody Harrelson: He's the kind of guy who tells you to "stay both hungry and foolish." Garey Busey: He's the real-life version of Steve Jobs. Meryl Streep: She's the real-life version of Steve Jobs. Ashton Kutcher: He's the real-life version of Steve Jobs. Seth Rogan: He's the real-life version of Steve Jobs. For the complete list, click here.

– If you've been dying to watch a rerun of The Mary Tyler Moore Show, well, you're in luck: It's now available on Netflix, reports the Huffington Post. Moore's show has been on the streaming service since 2005, but this is the first time it's been available on a regular basis. It's not clear how often the show will be on Netflix, but the move is part of a trend to speed up TV shows in order to shoehorn more commercials into the mix. "It's a last ditch effort, perhaps, to extract money out of a dying media delivery system before streaming obliterates the advertising model," writes Willa Paskin at Salon. "But is that all there is to it—trying to make more money?"

– Is the Apple Watch getting too expensive for consumers? Not according to one analyst. Keith Bachman of BMO Capital Markets believes Apple will sell 19 million of the devices in calendar year 2015, with more than half of those being sold in the December quarter, reports the Wall Street Journal. That's up from the previous estimate of 18 million, and it would make the watch the second most expensive product ever sold by Apple, behind the iPhone. It would also mark the first time Apple has sold more than 20 million devices in a single year.

– "ISIS is coming across the southern border," Rep. Duncan Hunter told Greta Van Susteren on Fox News last year. "I know that at least 10 ISIS fighters have been caught coming across the Mexican border in Texas." The Texas Republican, who is running for governor, went on to say that "there's going to be dozens more" ISIS fighters caught trying to cross the Rio Grande, the San Antonio Express-News reports. He said he learned of the incident from Border Patrol agents, who "caught them," but "you know there's going to be dozens more."

– It's been more than three weeks since Kim Jong Un hasn't been seen in public, and South Korea's Chosun Ilbo is now reporting that he's in the hospital. The paper says the North Korean leader broke both of his ankles in a fall and had surgery to fix it, reports the AP. The South's Yonhap News Agency adds that Kim is said to be in stable condition, though it didn't provide any other details.

– Is Fidel Castro dead? Yes, but he's not the famous Castro you might be thinking of. The prospect of the Cuban leader's death is circulating on the internet, and Cuba has already denied these rumors, the Inquisitr reports. The Inquisitr also reports that Ian Fleming, the author of the famous James Bond series, helped former President Kennedy hatch a Fidel Castro assassination plot.

– North Korea's official Korean Central News Agency says leader Kim Jong Un has died at the age of 69, reports the AP. The cause of his death is unclear, but the news agency says he passed away "peacefully" in a hospital in Pyongyang. North Korea's state-run media has reported that he died of heart failure.

– The rumor mill is aflutter with news that Christian Bale is in talks to play Steve Jobs in Aaron Sorkin's film about the Apple co-founder, and sources tell the Hollywood Reporter Bale is "on board." Leonardo Dicaprio was also in talks, but those talks fell through, and now Bale is back in the running, the sources say. No word yet on when the film will be out.

– The girlfriend of Michael Phelps has revealed she was born intersex—and lived as a boy until her teens. "I was born with male genitalia with no testicles, but I also have a uterus and no ovaries," Taylor Lianne Chandler, 41, wrote on her Facebook page. She changed her name as a teenager and underwent surgery to become a woman, the New York Daily News reports. Phelps, 29, was not aware of the revelation, according to Chandler.

– The Islamic State militant known as "Jihadi John" has been identified as Mohammed Emwazi from London, the Washington Post reports in an extensive look at the man it says is the "real" ISIS executioner. The 25-year-old was born there and grew up in the London area, according to the Post's timeline of the man's life. In 2010, Emwazi went on a safari holiday in Africa and was detained for "days" by MI5 for questioning, according to a report in the Independent cited by the Post. The report says that while in Africa, Emwazi was radicalized by a man named Muhammad ibn Muazza, who went on to become an ISIS executioner. According to the Independent's report, Emwazi became radicalized after the 2010 safari trip. He is believed to have become an ISIS fighter after the trip.

– Former baseball star Jose Canseco was injured in an accidental shooting at his Las Vegas home today, a neighbor tells KLAS-TV. Police confirm there was an accidental shooting at the address, but would not confirm the former player was hurt. However, records show Canseco owns the home where the shooting happened. His post-playing career has been nothing if not weird and random. Here's hoping he's OK, because weird and random is one thing, tragic is another

– A Republican congressman claimed Tuesday that at least 10 Islamic State fighters have been caught trying to cross the US-Mexico border into Texas, though an administration official denied it. Rep. Steve Stockman of Texas made the claim on CNN's State of the Union, though he later walked it back. He said he was basing it on a report from a local law enforcement official. "I was told that 10 ISIS fighters were caught," he said. "I was told they were trying to cross the border into Texas." The White House has denied the claim.

– The Islamic State militant known as Jihadi John has been identified as Mohammed Emwazi from West London, the Washington Post reports. The 27-year-old is believed to have appeared in a series of shocking videos in which hostages, including British aid worker Alan Henning, are brutally murdered. Emwazi grew up in a well-to-do family in West London and graduated from college with a degree in computer programming, according to the Post's sources, who say he is known to British security services. The Islamic State militant known as Jihadi John has been identified as Mohammed Emwazi from West London. The Islamic State militant known as Jihadi John has been identified as Mohammed Emwazi from West London. The IS frontman is believed to have appeared in a series of shocking videos in which hostages, including British aid worker Alan Henning, are brutally murdered The 27-year-old was named this morning by the Washington Post and it is understood he is known to British security services.

– New York City police will soon be able to issue tickets rather than make arrests for possession of marijuana, according to a report in the New York Times. Mayor Bill de Blasio and Police Commissioner William Bratton are expected to announce the change at a news conference today. Smoking marijuana is still illegal in New York City.

– A cartoon image that appeared on an Instagram account supposedly belonging to Banksy has turned out to be a fake, reports Business Insider. The image, which appears to show a young girl's face superimposed over the face of a dog, first appeared to belong to the street artist himself. But now, according to Banksy's website, the image is "not real" and the account belongs to someone else.

– A new report from an analyst at Piper Jaffray predicts that the most expensive version of the Apple Watch will sell for nearly $6,000. The stainless steel Apple Watch will start at $499, while the 18-karat gold Apple Watch Edition will sell for nearly $6,000, AppleInsider reports. According to Piper Jaffray's Gene Munster, the average consumer will spend around $550 for the Apple Watch, which will be available in three different versions: Apple Watch Sport, Apple Watch Edition, and Apple Watch.

– Matt Taibbi, the CEO of eBay founder Pierre Omidyar's First Look Media, is taking a leave of absence, New York reports. The move comes "after disagreements with higher-ups inside Omidyar's organization," a source tells the magazine, which notes that Omidyar and his Silicon Valley braintrust have exerted control over budgets and vacillated over the journalistic mission of First Look.

– The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria released a graphic video today showing the beheading of American journalist James Wright Foley, reports the New York Times, which notes that the execution is believed to have been carried out by militants who originally threatened to kill Foley if the US didn't end its airstrikes in the country. In the video, a voice claiming to be that of Foley's captors can be heard saying, "This is James Foley, American citizen, because of your arrogant foreign policy towards the Islamic State." The Times notes that the video was recorded in the Syrian town of Kobani, which the Islamic State seized earlier this year.

– The Islamic State militant known as "Jihadi John" in videos showing the beheading of Western hostages has been identified as Mohammed Emwazi of Britain, the BBC reports. Emwazi, who was born in London, was known to British security services as "Adam," though it's not clear whether he was actually born in Britain. ISIS released a video last year showing the beheading of American hostages James Foley, Steven Sotloff, and Kayla Mueller.

– If you're using iOS 8 to reset your iPhone settings, you may want to stop reading now. According to MacRumors, a bug in the latest version of Apple's mobile operating system could delete all of your documents saved in iCloud. As you reset your settings on your iPhone, Apple says "no data or media will be deleted," but people are reporting that the reset wipes all of their iCloud Drive documents.

– An asteroid about 60 feet in diameter missed hitting Earth Sunday by about 25,000 miles, as predicted by NASA's Near-Earth Object program. It did not, contrary to some reports Monday, break off a little piece that landed with a bang in Nicaragua. That story was intriguing to asteroid watchers, including the scientists at the Tucson-based OSIRIS-REx project, who tweeted Monday: #Nicaragua impactor: the second serious impact in as many years that was undetected #chelyabinsk NASA officials, though, are skeptical that the reported explosion and crater near Managua's airport was caused by a space object.

– A 3-year-old girl in China is fighting for her life after a rare and aggressive form of leukemia, and her parents are trying to raise money to pay for her treatment—by selling her twin brother. The girl's parents, who don't have the money to pay for treatment for their critically ill daughter, have gone onto the street to try and raise the money by selling their son who is the girl's twin, reports the South China Morning Post.

– A 7-year-old Russian boy is being hailed as a hero after he played with a soccer ball that ended up on the floor of a Moscow subway station, where he was hit by a train, the AP reports. According to RT.com, Alexander Volochkov was playing with his brother on the subway when the ball went through a gap in the tracks and into the arms of a passing train. Volochkov was hit by the train and fell to the ground, where he woke up on the other side of the tracks. He was rushed to a hospital, where he was treated for injuries to his head, neck, and chest. "I was shocked," Volochkov tells RT.com. "I didn't expect this. I didn't expect it to happen in front of me. I didn't expect it to happen in the middle of the night." He says his brother was injured in the fall. "I was shocked," Volochkov says. "I didn't expect it to happen in the middle of the night." According to RT.com, authorities believe Volochkov was playing with the ball on the subway when it went through a gap in the tracks and into the arms of a passing train.

– On Christmas Day, Joe Riquelme, creator of the successful Videoshop editing app, gave his parents a Christmas to remember. He casually hands his parents an envelope with this present inside. If you're experiencing a bit of a post-Christmas hangover in the warm and fuzzy, feel-good department, look no further—there's a video for that.

– The FBI has identified the second American killed in ISIS-controlled territory in Syria as 19-year-old aid worker Peter Kassig, a US citizen who joined the militant group last year. Kassig, who grew up in Ohio, was one of the first American fighters to join the Islamic State, which seized control of large parts of Iraq and Syria last year. He was killed in the early hours of Sunday near the border with Syria, reports the AP. A spokesman for the FBI's Cincinnati office tells the AP that Kassig was one of several aid workers killed in the fighting. He says investigators are still trying to determine whether other Americans have been killed. Kassig was working for Doctors Without Borders in Raqqa, the capital of the Islamic State's self-proclaimed capital, Raqqa, when he was killed.

– Lucy Somers says she learned of her brother's death from FBI agents, as Yemen claims armed forces freed 'an American hostage' held by al-Qaeda. Somers says she learned of her brother's death from FBI agents, as Yemen claims armed forces freed 'an American hostage' held by al-Qaeda. Lucy Somers says she learned of her brother's death from FBI agents, as Yemen claims armed forces freed 'an American hostage' held by al-Qaeda.

– A South American nun was rushed to the hospital in Macerata, Italy, last week after complaining of severe abdominal pain—and ended up giving birth to a baby boy she didn't even know she was pregnant with, the Independent reports. The unnamed nun, who arrived in the country in June and belongs to an all-female closed order, says she didn't realize she was pregnant until she was admitted to the hospital, where she gave birth to a healthy baby boy. "I was shocked by the fact that I gave birth to a baby boy," she tells Ilre Adriatico. "I had no idea that I was pregnant."

– It's the story that's been shared more than a million times on social media—and it's the story that's getting the most attention. It's the story of 21-year-old Elizabeth Jayne Banks, who was arrested in St. Louis on charges of disorderly conduct and underage consumption of alcohol, reports the St. Louis Post-Dispatch. Banks is accused of getting drunk on a date with a 19-year-old student at the University of Missouri-Kansas City, and the Post-Dispatch has video of her being taken into custody. She's charged with one count each of disorderly conduct, underage consumption of alcohol, and public intoxication.

– Rumors have been swirling that Jordan's King Abdullah II is personally taking part in airstrikes against ISIS, but a government rep says that's "unfounded and baseless" and that he's simply helping his country in its fight against the militant group, the BBC reports. Abdullah, who trained as a pilot before becoming king, has made no secret of his support for the US-led anti-ISIS campaign. "We are waging this war to protect our faith, our values and human principles and our war for their sake will be relentless and will hit them," he said after the death of pilot Moaz al-Kasasbeh.

– A new video purports to show the beheading of American journalist James Wright Foley, who went missing in Syria in November 2012, reports the New York Daily News. The video, which has not been independently verified, begins with text saying "Obama authorizes military operations against the Islamic State effectively placing America upon a slippery slope towards a new war front against Muslims." It then cuts to a clip of President Obama announcing airstrikes against ISIS, and to Foley kneeling in orange, next to a man with his face covered. In it, Foley is forced to read a letter urging Americans to rise up against his "real killer."

– McDonald's has no plans to stop serving overweight customers, according to a report from a website called Daily Buzz Live. The site claims that the fast-food giant will start phasing out serving overweight customers next year in an effort to combat rising obesity rates. McDonald's tells CNNMoney that it is "not about to implement such a policy."

– A Chinese woman says she was stripped naked and beaten by a group of women on a busy shopping street because she slept with another woman's husband. Witnesses say the 38-year-old didn't deserve help because she had slept with another woman's husband, the Daily Mail reports. She was kicked in the groin and breasts as she writhed screaming in agony on the pavement. The police never came. It is only the latest in a number of similar incidents in which it seems there is placid acceptance in Chinese society of such humiliation, as long as the victim is seen as deserving in having caused

– ISIS supporters are circulating images of a child believed to be about 10 years old who they say has become the youngest foreign fighter to be killed in battle for the jihadist group, according to a counter-extremism think tank. The images, which cannot be independently verified, show a young boy believed to be about 10 years old holding guns, posing with a balaclava stretched across his face and standing alongside a man thought to be his father who is reportedly a militant, the Telegraph reports. Those sharing the pictures are paying tribute to the child on Twitter as the youngest martyr from the Arabian Peninsula to have been killed in Syria as ISIS tries to establish a caliphate across swathes of the region.

– A patient being treated for Ebola at a Kansas hospital has tested negative for the disease, the Kansas City Star reports. According to KCTV5, the patient arrived at Research Medical Center's Brookside Campus emergency department Saturday with a fever and abdominal pain. The patient is being treated for Ebola, but the hospital says in a statement that the patient does not have the symptoms of the disease and is not being treated for it.

– First lady Michelle Obama is taking a break from the campaign trail to visit a children's hospital in Chicago, reports the Chicago Tribune. The first lady, who has a book out later this year, won't be stumping for her husband in her first public appearance since he was sworn in as the nation's first black president last month. Instead, she'll be visiting the Children's Hospital of Wisconsin to meet with staffers and patients.

– In the wake of the Charlie Hebdo terrorist attack in Paris, conspiracy theorists have sprung up all over the place—including a fake BBC website. "Doubts raised over Charlie Hebo footage," reads a headline on bbc-news.co.uk, referring to a widely-circulated video showing the killing of a Paris police officer. The site also claims that Western intelligence agencies staged the attack to create a "false flag" operation, the Independent reports.

– Detroit police say the famous Batmobile is "safe and sound" after a rumor spread that it had been stolen. "The Batmobile is safe in the Bat," a police spokesman tells the Detroit Free Press. Bleeding Cool first reported the rumor yesterday, saying that someone had stolen one of the vehicles being used for filming in the city.

– The leader of an al-Qaeda-linked militant group in Syria has been killed in an airstrike near the city of Raqqa, according to the country's state news agency. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says Sunday that Nusra Front leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi was killed in the airstrike, CNN reports. The group claimed responsibility for the airstrike in the eastern city of Deir al-Zor that killed at least 20 civilians. Nusra Front has claimed responsibility for a number of bombings in Deir al-Zor in recent months.

– The US embassy in Tripoli, which was overrun by a militia last month, is back in the hands of the Dawn of Libya group, the Inquisitr reports. The group posted a video on YouTube showing men playing in the embassy's pool. The embassy has been evacuated for a month. The Inquisitr notes that Dawn of Libya is an organization " consisting of militants from several organizations."

– Jihadi John, the masked ISIS militant apparently responsible for the beheading of western hostages, was Thursday named as London man Mohammad Emwazi by the Washington Post and the BBC. Emwazi, a 24-year-old former student at the University of West London, was born in Britain but moved to Syria as a child, reports the Guardian. He is believed to be the same man who was unmasked last week as Jihadi John, the masked ISIS militant apparently responsible for the beheading of western hostages.

– More than 200 girls kidnapped by Boko Haram in Nigeria will be released, according to the country's chief of defense staff. "A ceasefire agreement has been concluded between the Federal Government of Nigeria and the Jama’atu Ahlis Sunna Lidda’awati wal Jihad (Boko Haram)," Air Marshal Alex Badeh said in a statement, per the Independent. "Consequently, I order all members of the armed forces to immediately comply with the order." Badeh said negotiations were under way between the government and the militant group, which seized 276 schoolgirls in April, the BBC reports.

– A Saudi cleric has issued a fatwa against the practice of building snowmen, the Telegraph reports. Sheikh Mohammed Saleh al-Munajjid—who calls the practice "incompatible" with Islam—says it's "against the morals and values of the Islamic religion," and that it's "against the morals and values of the holy month of Ramadan." He says that the practice is "against the morals and values of the Islamic religion," and that it's "against the morals and values of the holy month of Ramadan." A member of al-Munajjid's group of religious scholars tells the Arab News that the fatwa was issued after a member of the group asked whether it was OK for fathers to build snowmen for their children. "The religious scholar, Sheikh Mohammed Saleh al-Munajjid strongly believes that building snowmen isn't an acceptable Islamic practice and it should cease with immediate effect," the group says.

– The Islamic State has released a graphic video purporting to show the beheading of American journalist James Foley, reports the New York Times. The 40-year-old New Hampshire native went missing in Syria in 2012, and the militant group has threatened to execute another US journalist, Steven Sotloff, if President Obama doesn't end airstrikes against the group in Iraq. The graphic video shows Foley, who was kidnapped in Syria, being forced to read a letter in which he urges Americans to rise up against the Islamic State.

– Lebanese army says it has detained second wife of Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi and their eight-year-old son near the Syrian border, the AP reports. Lebanese army says it has detained second wife of Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi and their eight-year-old son near the Syrian border.

– India's Central Public Works Department fired an electrical engineer last week after 35 years on the job—and he only worked the first 10 years of that tenure, Mashable reports. According to a press release issued by the CPWD, the employee stopped showing up for work in 1990, and an inquiry was launched in 1992. The department then seems to have forgotten about it for 13 years: The employee stopped turning up for work in 1990, and an inquiry was launched in 1992.
