– The Islamic State has released a video purporting to show the beheading of American journalist James Wright Foley, who was kidnapped in Syria in November 2012, the New York Times reports. The video also purports to show the beheading of American journalist Steven Sotloff, who has been missing since last August. At the end of the video, another captive is shown holding a knife. The video was posted on Twitter by @mujahid4life, which has since been suspended.

– Islamic State militants in Mosul are displaying symptoms similar to those of Ebola, according to Iraqi media reports of suspected cases at an ISIS-controlled hospital in the city. The World Health Organization has not been able to confirm this but has offered assistance to Iraqi officials

– The World Health Organization says it is investigating reports that ISIS fighters in Iraq have tested positive for Ebola, Mashable reports. Three local media outlets reported this week that a number of militants in Mosul, Iraq, showed signs of the disease and were taken to a hospital for treatment. The WHO says it is trying to reach out to officials in the area to offer help. "We have no official notification from [the Iraqi government] that it is Ebola," a spokeswoman says.

– The Islamic State militant known as "Jihadi John" has been identified as Mohammed Emwazi, a British citizen who grew up in London, the BBC reports. Emwazi, who is believed to be the Jihadi John killer who has appeared in several ISIS beheading videos, was born in London and grew up in a middle-class family, according to the Washington Post, which first reported the news. Emwazi is believed to be 26 or 27 years old.

– Amazon is opening its first brick-and-mortar store in Manhattan this holiday season, the Wall Street Journal reports, citing "people familiar with the matter." The store will be located in the same building as Amazon's other brick-and-mortar locations around the country, including one in Seattle. The Journal notes that Amazon's first brick-and-mortar store was also in Manhattan.

– Batman vs. Superman is in the midst of filming in Detroit, and one of the cars used in the movie has gone missing, according to a post at Bleeding Cool. "The scuttlebutt from sources in Detroit is that one of the Batmobile models being used in the filming of Batman vs. Superman has gone missing, believed stolen," the post reads. "It would not be the first time a Batmobile has been nicked in Detroit."

– A video chat service says it has audio of the moment Michael Brown was shot and killed by Ferguson, Mo., police officer Darren Wilson. A user of the service, called Glide, says he inadvertently recorded audio of the shooting while using the service near the spot where Brown was killed, reports the St. Louis Post-Dispatch. The company says the audio was created at 12:02:14pm on Aug. 9. "A Glide user living nearby was simply using the Glide service at the time Michael Brown was shot and killed," the company said in a statement.

– Christian Bale will play Steve Jobs in Aaron Sorkin's film based on Walter Isaacson's biography of the Apple co-founder, Bloomberg reports. "We needed the best actor on the board in a certain age range, and that's Chris Bale," Sorkin says. The movie will be based on Walter Isaacson's 2011 biography of Jobs.

– A blogger who goes by the name Lena on her blog says she aborted her baby boy because of "bad experiences with men," the Independent reports. In her blog, Lena says she found out she was pregnant in 2012 and describes the father as "the donator." She says she was ready to have a child, but ended up aborting the boy because she found out he was a boy. She also claims to be a feminist, fighting women's rights "to the point of eschewing a career." But from her writing—if what she's saying is actually true—she appears to be something of a misandrist.

– It's the most expensive car in the world, and it's also the most expensive car with a penis drawn on it. So it was a bit of a shock when a photo of a $2.5 million Bugatti Veyron that was parked in Seattle was posted to Instagram this week. But, as the Seattle Post-Intelligencer reports, "it may have not actually been a crime." According to an Instagram post by AndreysMyGov of VG Productions, the car was spray-painted for an upcoming music video. "Yea bro it's for an upcoming music video," Andrey writes.

– Banksy is in trouble with the law—at least in the US. The artist, whose real name is Robert Peston, has been arrested in the UK on suspicion of money laundering, the BBC reports. Peston, who lives in Bristol, is said to be the world's richest street artist, with a net worth of more than $100 million, according to Forbes. The arrest was first reported on the National Report, a US website that bills itself as the "world's most influential news source." The site claims to have tracked Banksy to a police station in south-east England, where he was taken into custody. "Banksy is one of the richest artists in the world, and he's been arrested for money laundering," the site's headline says. "This is the first time in the history of the world that a street artist has been arrested for money laundering, and it is believed to be the first time in the history of the world that a street artist has been arrested for money laundering."

– A group that monitors the Syrian conflict says Iraqi pilots who have joined ISIS are training its members to fly three captured fighter jets, according to a UK-based activist group that monitors the conflict. Iraqi pilots who have joined ISIS are training its members in Syria to fly three captured fighter jets, according to a UK-based activist group that monitors the conflict.

– The video of the beheading of American journalist James Foley was probably staged, experts say, with the murder happening off camera. forensic experts have revealed the video was probably staged, with the murder happening off camera, the Telegraph reports. According to the experts, ISIS released the video—in which Foley is beheaded—without telling the public it was a staged killing. The experts say the video was likely recorded on a camera mounted on a chair, the Independent reports.

– eBay is looking for an iOS engineer/architect who can work on "elegant solutions for the Apple Watch that will complement our core iOS eBay app," according to a job posting spotted by AppleInsider. The listing was first published on eBay's job page in November, but it has been getting more attention thanks to its appearance on LinkedIn this month, according to a report today from AppleInsider. E-commerce companies like Flipkart have developed apps

– Nigeria has reached a ceasefire deal that will include the release of kidnapped Nigerian schoolgirls, in a bid to end the conflict that has claimed thousands of lives. The deal was reached between the government of President Muhammadu Buhari and representatives of the Islamic extremist group Boko Haram, the BBC reports. The schoolgirls were kidnapped in April 2014 from a school in the northeastern town of Chibok. Boko Haram has killed more than 20,000 people in northeastern Nigeria over the past few years.

– Survivors of an Iraqi army regiment in Saqlawiya, near Fallujah, say the radical group used chlorine gas against the besieged soldiers. There were conflicting government statements about whether the gas had been used, the New York Times reports. The siege on the regiment, which consists of nearly 400 soldiers, has created an uproar in Iraq, with Iraqi members of parliament (MPs) on Sept. 21 demanding the government break the siege. The following day, the Anbar Operations Command said it opened the road to Saqlaw. But there were conflicting government statements about whether the gas had been used.

– A mushroom with hallucinogenic properties has been found growing at Buckingham Palace, but no one suspects Queen Elizabeth of cultivating the magic mushroom. The Amanita muscaria was found growing wild in the extensive palace gardens during preparations for a television show.

– When a man in Norfolk, England, noticed that his pet goldfish was having digestive issues, he took it to a vet—and it ended up being a multi-hundred-pound boondoggle. The man, who keeps the fish in his office, took it to Toll Barn Veterinary Center, where vets performed an operation to save it, the Independent reports. The goldfish had been suffering from "some sort of digestive problem," the vet said, and the man had been trying to remedy it with other remedies, but they didn't seem to work. The vet told the man, "If you don't take your pet to the vets, they're not going to be able to help them." So the man took the fish, which he keeps in his tank in his office, to the vet—and it ended up being a multi-hundred-pound boondoggle.

– Anna Wintour is refusing to move into Vogue's new offices in New York City's 1 World Trade Center because they're infested with rats, an employee tells Gawker. The editor-in-chief has reportedly told staffers that rats must be removed before she can enter the building, Gawker notes.

– A loud boom heard Saturday night by residents of Nicaragua's capital Managua was caused by the impact of small meteorite, government officials confirmed on Sunday. The piece of rock, possibly from an asteroid that passed close to Earth on Saturday, landed near a city airport and did not cause any injuries, the AFP reports. However, it did create a 16-foot-deep crater. "I was sitting on my porch and I saw nothing, then all of a sudden I heard a large blast," a resident tells the AP.

– A British fighter who traveled to Iraq to stop the Islamic State claims the terror group fed a murdered kidnap victim to his own mother after she went to their headquarters and demanded to see him. Yasir Abdulla, a security guard from Keighley, West Yorkshire, decided to go to Iraq and fight against ISIS after hearing they came within six miles of taking control of his home village in Kurdistan, which he left in 2000. It has been reported that the 36-year-old bought a set to combat fatigues online for £100 before going to Kurdistan and buying an assault rifle.

– A loud explosion in the Syrian Kurdish town of Kobani last night may have been the result of a chemical weapon being used by the Islamic State, a doctor in the town tells the New York Times. "After a loud explosion, we received some patients with abnormal symptoms," Dr. Walat Omar says. "They had blisters, burning eyes, and breathing difficulties. We don't know if they were from a chemical weapon, a bomb, or something else." The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says ISIS may have used a chemical weapon on the Kurds, who are fighting ISIS for control of the town, which has been under siege for more than two months.

– Tiger Woods' divorce from wife Elin Nordegren is finally official—and it's not a happy one. Nordegren filed for divorce from the golfer on Friday in Florida, citing irreconcilable differences, the AP reports. The couple have a 7-year-old daughter together, and sources tell TMZ that Nordegren wants to move back to Sweden, where she was born. Woods and Nordegren were married for six years and have two children together.

– A meteorite landed "like a bomb" just missing Nicaragua's main airport and raising concerns over scientists' ability to track space objects on potential collision courses with Earth. Officials said they "thanked God" there were no injuries as the rock landed in Managua, a sprawling city of 1.2 million people where it left a crater 12 feet wide and 16 feet deep. The rock was believed to have been a small part of the asteroid 2014 RC, nicknamed "Pitbull," which astronomers had been monitoring as it passed the planet. NASA currently tracks more than 11,000 asteroids that come relatively close to Earth.

– A family of five in the small town of Purdon, Texas, has tested positive for Ebola, according to an Internet post that has since been removed. The post, which appeared on at least one website, claimed that the town had been sealed off by the CDC and local police, Corsicana Daily Sun reports. Officials from the Corsicana/Navarro County Health Department, Navarro County Sheriff Elmer Tanner, and Emergency Management say there is no truth to the post.

– The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS) killed more than 300 soldiers using chlorine gas for the first time in the region of Saqlawiyah, north of Fallujah, Iraqi News reports. MP Ali al-Badri said at a press conference at the parliament building in Diwaniyah that "the terrorist organization ISIS used chlorine gas for the first time in the region of Saqlawiyah after trapping more than 400 troops, resulting in the deaths of many of them due to suffocation while the terrorist gangs detonated car bombs within the brigade." Badri added that ISIS also used live ammunition and anti-tank missiles in the attack.

– A time capsule put in place by Sam Adams and Paul Revere more than 200 years ago has been unearthed at the Massachusetts State House, the Boston Globe reports. The cowhide capsule was placed in a corner stone of the building in 1795. It was replaced with a metal box in 1855, but it wasn't until this week that workers finally removed the copper box. The contents are thought to date back to 1652.

– A story making the rounds on social media suggests that KFC is getting in on the legal marijuana game. The story, which first appeared on the website Racket Report, claims that the fast-food chain is getting in on the marijuana game because profits from the drug are so high that KFC felt compelled to get in on the action. If true, the story says, it would be the first time a major restaurant chain has entered the legal marijuana game. But as the Los Angeles Times reports, there are a few problems with the story. First and foremost, Racket Report appears to be a mostly satirical website.

– The elusive graffiti artist, political activist, film director, and long time fugitive that for years has gone by the pseudonymous name of Banksy, was arrested early this morning by London's Metropolitan Police. The 38-year-old was taken into custody at his home in east London, the BBC reports. Banksy has been on the run since 2009.

– The Weather Channel's Mike Seidel was doing a live report on a North Carolina snowstorm Saturday night when he appeared on camera with his back turned, causing some to speculate that he may have been relieving himself, NBC News reports. "No so, geniuses: Social Media owes our friend Mike Seidel an apology," the Weather Channel tweeted Monday. "The intrepid and fearless Weather Channel Meteorologist was the victim of some wild misinformation when this happened on the news here Saturday night: Lester Holt threw to Mike's live report in a snowstorm in North Carolina. Mike had lost cellphone contact with our control room." On Monday night, NBC Nightly News host Brian Williams took a moment to push back on the misinformation, saying that Seidel had lost his cellphone in the control room. "Mike had lost cellphone contact with our control room," Williams said, adding that social media "owes our friend Mike Seidel an apology."

– A 26-year-old man believed to have been fighting for ISIS in Syria was killed in a Jordanian airstrike on the group's de facto capital of Raqqa, according to a statement posted on an ISIS-affiliated website. The statement says the man was killed by missile strike during bombing raid by Jordanian planes on Syrian city of Raqqa, the AP reports. ISIS has claimed responsibility for the strike.

– Looks like Apple won't be releasing its much-anticipated Apple Watch until January at the earliest. According to a report from Taiwan cited by G for Games, the mass production stage of the Apple Watch won't begin until January at the earliest, and it won't be assembled by two separate suppliers as had been rumored. The source says only one supplier will be making the watch.
– Celebrity Dog Cesar Millan should have died, according to a post on the site noticiasunam.com. But there are many obvious oddities in the post—Viral Inspector shows why it probably is fake.

– The Pentagon has confirmed that an airstrike in Somalia earlier this week killed the leader of the al-Shabaab militant group. Ahmed Abdi Godane was killed in the attack, which targeted an encampment in southern Somalia, the New York Times reports. "The United States works in coordination with its friends, allies, and partners to counter the regional and global threats posed by violent extremist organizations," a Pentagon spokesman said in a statement. Al-Shabaab is linked to al-Qaeda and has claimed responsibility for several attacks on Somali and African Union troops.

– A bear that sings outside a café in Bedfordshire, England, could be hit with an ASBO after residents complained about the noise it was making, the Independent reports. The bear, named Bernard, has been singing his holiday songs outside the Loft café since October. "It seems really silly that someone would moan about a bear when we’re on the high street where there is constant noise from the pubs and traffic," says a store employee. The café's owners say they're working with the council on an "ongoing investigation."

– The investigation into the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., continues, with more than two dozen law enforcement agencies involved—including the FBI, the Broward County Sheriff's Office, the State Attorney's Office, and the US Attorney's Office—now involved, the New York Daily News reports. The Broward County Sheriff's Office is leading the investigation into the shooting, which left six students and one teacher dead, and the Florida Department of Law Enforcement is leading the probe into the shooting's aftermath. The Broward County Sheriff's Office is also investigating the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., which left more than 40 students and one teacher dead on Sept. 26. The Broward County Sheriff's Office is also investigating the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., which left more than 40 students and one teacher dead on Sept. 26. The Broward County Sheriff's Office is also investigating the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., which left more than 40 students and one teacher dead on Sept. 26. The Broward County Sheriff's Office is also investigating the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla.

– If you're one of those people who can't get enough Lester Holt, we've got some bad news for you: He's going to be gone from the Today show by the end of the year. The network says Holt, who has been with the network since 1971, "is no longer with the network," according to a statement on the Today show's website. The network says it has "reached out" to him, but hasn't heard back yet.

– Dylan Thomas got a little taste of what it's like to live in the real world this week when a tiny matchhead-sized insect was removed from his skin, the Los Angeles Times reports. The 11-year-old California boy was playing with friends at his dad's house Monday night when one of his friends noticed a lump on his back. He went to his dad, who called a doctor. The doctor removed the insect, which was about the size of a sesame seed, from under Thomas' skin and sent it away for testing to see if it's a spider, a mite, or some other type of creepy-crawly. It's not clear what it is.

– On Christmas Day, Joe Riquelme, a 25-year-old app developer from New York, surprised his parents by paying off their mortgage. In a video he posted to YouTube, Riquelme presents his parents with an envelope, which reads, "I'm going to pay off your mortgage this Christmas." His parents, who live on Long Island, can be seen in the video crying. "Oh thank you," says Riquelme's dad. "I love you."

– Looks like Samsung is going to be Apple's No. 1 supplier when it comes to the new iPhone 6 and Apple Watch, according to a report from South Korea's BusinessKorea picked up by 9to5mac.com. The site's sources say Apple is looking to Samsung for RAM, flash storage, and batteries for the new iPhone, as well as for the Apple Watch, which is expected to be out this year. Apple has reportedly been trying to reduce its reliance on Samsung in recent years, but this would be a "marked change" from that, says 9to5mac.com.

– The White House says it is "appalled" by a video purporting to show the beheading of American journalist James Foley by militants from the Islamic State. "If genuine, we are appalled by the brutal murder of an innocent American," a spokeswoman says. The White House says it is working with the State Department to verify the video, which purports to show the execution of Foley, who was kidnapped in Syria in 2012, the New York Times reports. The White House says President Obama has been briefed on the video.

– The World Health Organization says there has been no reported case of Ebola in Iraq, despite reports to the contrary by local media, Reuters reports. The WHO says it and the Iraqi health ministry have conducted a full investigation into the reports, which surfaced last week.

– Rapper Sugarhill Gang founder Henry 'Big Bank Hank' Jackson has died at age 57 from kidney complications due to cancer. The rapper was a founding member or Sugarhill Gang, which produced the first mainstream rap hit Rapper's Delight in 1979.

– When Stan Beaton called Virgin Media in December to upgrade his phone service, he thought he'd lost the voicemail message he'd left for his late wife, Ruby, who died of stomach cancer 14 years ago at the age of 63. But engineers were able to access the voicemail, which had been on his line for 14 years, the Telegraph reports. "I cried," said Beaton, 68. "It's been 14 years since she died and I thought I'd lost the message." Virgin apologized and offered to donate to his favorite charities.

– The Islamic State militant known as "Jihadi John" has been identified as Mohammed Emwazi, a Kuwait-born British citizen who grew up in London, the Washington Post reports. According to the Post's sources, Emwazi grew up in a "well-to-do family" in West London and studied computer science at the University of Westminster. He became known as ISIS' executioner for the graphic beheadings of Western hostages, including James Foley.

– Seth Rogen is set to star as Steve Wozniak in an upcoming biopic of the Apple co-founder, according to the Hollywood Reporter. The film will be written by Aaron Sorkin, who won an Oscar for his screenplay for The Social Network. Rogen is best known for his roles in Superbad and Knocked Up.

– A sad story out of Scotland, where an animal welfare group is trying to track down the owner of a young Shar Pei who was found leashed to a rail with a suitcase full of his belongings. The Scottish SPCA is trying to track down the owner of Kai, a young Shar Pei who was found leashed to a rail with a suitcase full of his belongings

– Kim Jong Un hasn't been seen in public for more than a month, but South Korean newspaper Chosun Ilbo thinks it knows why: He fractured both of his ankles. "I heard that Kim Jong Un injured his right ankle in June after pushing ahead with on-site visits and [he] had surgery on both ankles in the middle of September," the source tells the paper, via the Guardian. "I don't know if that's true or not, but I'm sure he'll be back to normal soon."

– Christian Bale is in talks to play Steve Wozniak in a Jobs biopic directed by Aaron Sorkin, the AP reports. Canadian actor in talks to play Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak in Aaron Sorkin-scripted biopic, while Christian Bale is in line to play Jobs himself

– It's official: Fidel Castro is dead, reports AP. The Cuban government today confirmed that the 83-year-old leader died last night at 10:29pm, though it didn't give a cause of death. The news comes after a flurry of rumors in the Cuban-American community that Castro had died, and it comes just days after the death of Kenya's Prime Minister Raila Odinga.

– A woman held by Lebanese authorities is not the wife of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, Iraq's Interior Ministry said Wednesday, injecting further confusion into an already murky situation. A woman held by Lebanese authorities is not the wife of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, Iraq's Interior Ministry said Wednesday, injecting further confusion into an already murky situation. A woman held by Lebanese authorities is not the wife of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, Iraq's Interior Ministry said Wednesday, injecting further confusion into an already murky situation.

– Google is spending $585 million to buy six office buildings near its headquarters in Silicon Valley, sources tell the Wall Street Journal. The deal, Google's biggest ever, is part of the company's plan to boost its Silicon Valley presence by scooping up more office space, the sources say. Google bought the six buildings for $585 million from Starwood Capital Group LLC and Blackstone Group LP, the sources say.

– Texas Rep. Conal O'Rourke says he won't run for re-election in 2018 because he doesn't think he'll be able to raise enough money to defeat Democratic Sen. Ted Cruz, the AP reports. O'Rourke made the announcement in a Facebook post Sunday, a day after Cruz announced that he would seek the Senate seat being vacated by O'Rourke. O'Rourke says he hasn't decided whether to run for re-election in 2020, when his current term is up, or in 2020, when his term is up again. He says he will decide in the next few weeks.

– A 70-year-old priest in Massachusetts was declared dead at the hospital after suffering a heart attack on Sunday, but he was still able to recite verses from the Bible before being revived, the Boston Globe reports. According to WCVB-TV, Rev. Thomas Jay was pronounced dead at Brigham and Women's Hospital, but he was still able to recite verses from the Bible before he was revived. The Rev. Jay had been rushed to the hospital with chest pains and shortness of breath. His heart stopped beating for more than 48 minutes before medics were able to restart his heart.

– An attorney for the family of Michael Brown says a newly released audio recording shows that the police officer who shot the unarmed 18-year-old 10 times paused for at least 10 bullets before shooting him dead, reports the St. Louis Post-Dispatch. Darren Wilson can be heard telling another officer on the tape, "I'm going to get this guy, get this guy, get him on the ground, get him on the ground, get him on the ground, get him on the ground, get him on the ground, get him on the ground and I'm going to shoot him." Brown's family attorney, Benjamin Crump, says the recording doesn't back up the officer's story that he opened fire only because Brown reached for his gun. He tells CNN that Wilson can be heard telling another officer, "I'm going to get this guy, I'm going to shoot him, get him on the ground, get him on the ground, get him on the ground and I'm going to shoot him." Crump tells the Post-Dispatch that the officer is heard telling another officer, "I'm going to get this guy, I'm going to shoot him, get him on the ground, get him on the ground

– A video purporting to show ISIS militants rifling through a supply bundle dropped by US forces near the northern Syrian town of Kobani has gone viral. The video was posted to a YouTube channel associated with ISIS and shows the militants rifling through packages containing dozens of grenades. The supply package was apparently one of many intended for Kurdish fighters who have been battling ISIS militants for control of the strategically important town for weeks. According to the Pentagon, the majority of supplies were safely delivered.

– The Islamic State has released a graphic video showing the beheading of American journalist James Wright Foley, who was captured in Syria 22 months ago. The video, titled "A Message to America," was reportedly made by the same militant who killed journalist Steven Sotloff earlier this month, the New York Times reports. In the video, a masked militant can be seen cutting off Foley's head. The 40-year-old New Hampshire native, a freelance photojournalist, was captured in Syria on Thanksgiving Day 2012.

– At least 10 ISIS fighters have crossed the border from Mexico into Texas, according to Rep. Duncan Hunter, a Republican from California. "I know that at least 10 ISIS fighters have been caught coming across the southern border in Texas," he told Fox's Greta Van Susteren last night, according to Fox News. "It's a serious problem." He said the militants came from ISIS-held territory in Syria, but he didn't say where. "They're coming from Syria," he said. "They're not coming from Iraq or Syria. They're coming from Mexico." Last month, Rep. Jason Chaffetz said the same thing, according to the Washington Post.

– Apple is working on a major redesign of its MacBook line, according to 9to5 Mac, which cites anonymous Apple employees. The site says the new design, expected to be unveiled at an event later this month, will include a thinner, faster version of the 15-inch MacBook line, as well as an improved version of the 17-inch MacBook line. The redesign will also ditch the MacBook's ports, leaving just a single USB-C port, the site says. The new design will also include an improved version of Apple's "Retina Display" technology, which has been used on the iPhone and iPad, 9to5 Mac notes.

– A 71-year-old priest was declared dead after suffering a heart attack on Jan. 29, but he has since been revived—with the help of a high-tech machine. Father John Michael O’neal was rushed to Massachusetts General Hospital after his heart attack, but was declared clinically dead soon after his arrival, the Daily Mail reports. Doctors used a LUCAS 2 machine to keep the blood flowing to his brain, and were able to unblock vital arteries and return his heart to a normal rhythm. O’neal says he went to heaven and met God, which he describes as a "warm and comforting motherly figure."

– A patient at a Kansas City, Mo., hospital is being tested for Ebola after returning from a trip to Nigeria, the Kansas City Star reports. According to KMBC, the patient showed up at Research Medical Center's emergency room Saturday with a high fever and a history of traveling to West Africa. A hospital spokesperson says the patient is not showing symptoms of Ebola, but officials are taking the precaution because of the high-profile nature of the situation. The patient has been isolated, the spokesperson says.

– The FBI has identified James Wright Foley as the man accused of sexually assaulting a 16-year-old female high school student in Arizona, ABC News reports. According to the Arizona Republic, the 16-year-old victim says Foley grabbed her by the throat while she was in his bathroom. The FBI says it is working with the girl's family to bring charges against Foley.

– The fence-jumper who made it through the front door of the White House before being stopped by a Secret Service agent was only stopped after he reached the East Room, a government official confirmed Monday. The official, speaking under condition of anonymity, tells the Wall Street Journal that the unidentified man was stopped only after he rushed past a Secret Service agent inside and was stopped only after reaching the building's East Room. The official says the man, who has been identified as Omar Mateen, made it past a number of security checkpoints before he was stopped.

– A 26-year-old high school teacher in Colombia has been arrested for allegedly having sex with a 16-year-old student, the Independent reports. According to Fox News, Lucita Sandoval was caught on video having sex with the teen at her home. She allegedly didn't know he was recording the encounter on a camera phone and sent it to his friends. Sandoval was charged with sexual relations with a minor and child pornography.

– After months of rumors, it's official: Christian Bale will play Steve Jobs in Danny Boyle's Apple biopic. "We needed the best actor on the board in a certain age range and that’s Chris Bale," screenwriter Aaron Sorkin tells Bloomberg. "He didn’t have to audition. Well, there was a meeting." Bale had been in the running along with Matt Damon, Ben Affleck, Bradley Cooper, and Leonardo DiCaprio.

– A homeless man was given a chance, and he touched an awful lot of surprised people. A viral online video from YouTube prankster Josh Paler Lin tells the story of a homeless man named Thomas and his desire to not let his circumstances keep him from being selfless—by using his newfound money to help not himself, but others.

– The Texas Department of State Health Services says it has "no indication" that a patient at an urgent-care facility in Frisco, Texas, had contact with Ebola victim Thomas Duncan, CNN reports. The patient walked into the urgent-care facility this morning and told health-care workers he had had contact with "patient zero" in Dallas, local officials said in a statement, referring to Duncan, who died yesterday. The Texas Department of State Health Services refuted that claim to CNN, however, saying "no indication" the man had contact with Duncan. It's not known if the patient is one of the 48 being monitored by Texas health officials.

– A mob in Rajasthan, India, cut off a man's genitals and threw them in the street after he allegedly sexually assaulted a teenager, the Telegraph reports. Video of the incident shows the mob throwing the man to the ground and cutting off his private parts as bystanders try to stop it. The woman, who was uninjured, told police that the 40-year-old man had molested her while she was walking home from school. Police say the man has been arrested. The incident is believed to be the latest in a string of high-profile sexual assaults in India.

– A 10-year-old boy fighting for ISIS has been killed in Syria, according to a video posted to YouTube Wednesday. Abu Obadya al-Abassi, also known as Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, is believed to be the youngest member of the terror group to die fighting, the New York Daily News reports. In the video, Abu Obadya is shown holding what appears to be a severed head. "I am Abu Obadya al-Abassi, 10 years old, a soldier of the Islamic State, and I have been killed in the battle of Raqqa," says a voice believed to be that of Abu Obadya in the video.

– Apple is limiting what apps its smartwatch can run in order to ensure it doesn't drain the battery too quickly, sources tell 9to5mac.com. The sources say the company is also limiting the number of apps the watch can access in order to ensure the battery life is not too heavily drained in the initial model, which could tarnish the high-profile launch. Apple is reportedly limiting what Apple Watch apps are capable of doing, ruling out certain features in order to ensure battery life is not too heavily drained in the initial model, which could tarnish the high-profile launch. The sources say the company is also limiting the number of apps the watch can access in order to ensure it doesn't drain the battery too quickly. Apple is reportedly limiting what Apple Watch apps are capable of doing, ruling out certain features in order to ensure battery life is not too heavily drained in the initial model, which could tarnish the high-profile launch.

– McDonald’s is phasing out eight menu items starting next year, including the Big Mac, which is 550 calories and 29g of fat. “Our intent is to have a cleaner menu board that is easier for customers to absorb,” a company spokeswoman said in a statement. “To do so we must simplify our current menu. This means the end of the Big Mac, apple pie, and large size menu items.” McDonald’s has been under fire for years for serving too many calories—and not enough fat—to customers, according to the Huffington Post.

– A ceasefire between Nigeria's military and Islamic extremist group Boko Haram appears to be fizzling, with fresh attacks in the country's northeast just hours after the government announced it had secured the release of more than 200 schoolgirls kidnapped by the group more than a year ago. "Honestly, we are yet to see the fruits of the agreement," a senior army officer tells Reuters, adding that the military has been ordered not to carry out any "major offensives" against Boko Haram. President Goodluck Jonathan, who brokered the ceasefire, says the release of the schoolgirls is the government's top priority. Boko Haram, whose name means "Western education is forbidden," has been terrorizing Nigeria for more than a decade, killing thousands and kidnapping hundreds of schoolgirls.

– A fisherman has caught a giant 8ft 9in long catfish weighing 19 stone—and it could be the biggest ever caught with the humble rod and line. The huge fish was caught off the coast of South Carolina by a man who was using a line he found on the side of the road, the Daily Mail reports. "It's the biggest fish I've ever caught," the man says. "I don't think I've ever caught anything this big before." He says he was using a line he found on the side of a road, but it wasn't clear if it was the same line he was using to catch the fish.

– A woman who claims to be Michael Phelps' girlfriend has revealed she was born with male genitalia—and says she never told the swimmer. Taylor Lianne Chandler also described her “amazing intimacy” with the athlete on Facebook, the Independent reports. The 41-year-old, who is technically “intersex,” was born with both male genitalia and a uterus but had neither ovaries nor testicles.

– Canada's capital was locked down Wednesday after a gunman opened fire at the country's National War Memorial and the Parliament before being shot dead by police, the AP reports. Witnesses say the gunman entered the Parliament building and opened fire with a semi-automatic weapon. He was shot and killed by police as he tried to escape. A Canadian soldier standing at the National War Memorial was shot and killed by a gunman Wednesday before the gunman was shot dead by police as he tried to flee the Parliament building, Reuters reports. The gunman was seen running toward the nearby parliament buildings where more shots were fired.

– A story making the rounds on social media claims that hundreds of thousands of holiday turkeys on a Texas farm may have been infected with Ebola and will have to be destroyed. The "news" site Daily Buzz Live has the "sensationalized but factual news items and outright fiction disguised as news" for this "Ebola Turkey" hoax, according to a post at Boing Boing, which calls the story a "smear campaign" from a "dubious 'news' site." The Texas Department of State Health Services says there has been no reported case of Ebola in the state and there is no indication that any of the 250,000 or so turkeys on the farm have been infected, the Houston Chronicle reports. The story, which features a photo of dead turkeys in a farm shed, was first reported by Boing Boing, which notes that Daily Buzz Live is "a dubious 'news' site called Daily Buzz Live that publishes a combination of sensationalized but factual news items and outright fiction disguised as news. The 'Ebola Turkey' story is an example of the latter."

– British intelligence has identified a suspect in the beheading of American journalist Jim Foley as Abdel-Majed Abdel Bary, also known as "Lyricist Jinn," or "L Jinny," reports USA Today. Bary is a slim, light-skinned rapper from London, according to reports in the British and American media. He is also believed to be a member of the Islamic State, or ISIS.

– The World Health Organization says it has reached out to offer assistance after reports surfaced that an Ebola patient had arrived at a hospital in the Iraqi city of Mosul, which has been under the control of the Islamic State for more than a year. "We have no official notification from [the Iraqi government] that it is Ebola," a WHO spokesman tells the New York Times. "We have reached out to the relevant authorities to offer assistance." The Times notes that pro-government and Kurdish media have largely been behind the reports.

– If you've got an iPhone 6 or 6 Plus, there's a good chance you've just become the latest victim of "Hairgate." The Verge reports that some iPhone 6 and 6 Plus owners are reporting strands of hair being caught between the screen and the aluminum frame of the phone. "The seam on my iPhone 6 where the aluminum meets the glass is definitely catching my hair and pulling it out. #seamgate," tweeted Paul Peavler. "My own hair is quite long and I haven't had any strands get caught within the frame of my iPhone," tweeted another. According to USA Today, some iPhone 6 and 6 Plus owners say their phones are catching their hair while they're using it to take pictures.

– The story that 17-year-old Henry Blodget made $72 million trading the markets while still in high school is being widely disputed. The Wall Street Journal reports that Blodget, a student at the Nantucket High School where he graduated valedictorian, is believed to have made the money by taking advantage of a program that allows students to trade for money at the New York Stock Exchange. Blodget reportedly made the money by taking advantage of a program that allows high school students to trade for money at the New York Stock Exchange. Blodget is believed to have made the money while still in high school. The story making the rounds today of the 17-year-old whiz kid of Wall Street who is rumored to have made $72 million trading the markets, while still in high school, is being widely disputed. The improbable story making the rounds today of the 17-year-old whiz kid of Wall Street who is rumored to have made $72 million trading the markets, while still in high school, is being widely disputed.

– A rat infestation has forced Vogue to close its new offices at 1 World Trade Center—and Anna Wintour is "terrified" of entering her own, the New York Daily News reports. According to Gawker, which first reported the infestation on Friday, rats have been seen in the building's mechanical rooms, as well as in the elevator shafts and on the walls of the fashion magazine's editorial and sales offices. The magazine has been forced to close its offices in the Lower East Side until the problem is fixed.

– The Weather Channel's Mike Seidel has taken a lot of ribbing about what he was doing live on network TV this weekend. But he didn't do what online news sites and YouTubers suggest he did. Seidel was reporting from Sugar Mountain, North Carolina, Saturday where an early season storm dropped 10 inches of snow. NBC Nightly News caught up with him Sunday while he was reporting from a different location in North Carolina.

– North Korea's Kim Jong Un has opened a restaurant in the Netherlands, and now he's considering opening one in Scotland—where whisky is popular, the Telegraph reports. "It would not surprise me at all if they opted to open a restaurant in Scotland," says Michael Madden of the North Korea Leadership Watch group. Madden adds that it would be a "great opportunity" for North Korean defectors.

– Amazon is getting into the streaming game. The company is working on an ad-supported streaming service that would compete with Netflix and Hulu, sources tell the New York Post. The sources say the new service would cost around the same as Netflix and Hulu Plus at $7.99 a month. Amazon could use this new, cheaper streaming service as a way to ease people into its ecosystem so they'll be more likely to eventually make the jump to Prime, while also giving it a way to entice potential customers who don't care about Prime's free.

– Boston is abuzz today over the discovery of a time capsule put in place by Paul Revere and Samuel Adams more than two centuries ago. The capsule was unearthed thanks to a water leak near its resting place inside a cornerstone at the Massachusetts State House, reports the Boston Globe. Revere and Adams buried the capsule in 1795 after warning the British they were coming.

– The Internet is aflutter over a viral video that purports to show a pigeon pooping on Vladimir Putin during a speech in Moscow. The Independent explains that the video is a hoax, but notes that if it had been real, the symbolism would have been spot on. "The 'too good to be true' cliche is especially accurate when it comes to viral news stories on perfectly formed dollops of bird crap," writes Alexander Abad-Santos at Boing Boing. "If it had been real, the symbolism would have been spot on."

– For 14 years, Stan Beaton listened to his late wife's voicemail message every time he called his house. Then, last month, a phone company upgrade caused the recording to be deleted, the BBC reports. "I've always resisted changing companies because whenever I mentioned that my wife's voice was our voicemail message and would it be retained," the 68-year-old says. Beaton's wife, Ruby, died two years before he did in 2003.

– A Massachusetts priest who went into cardiac arrest and was declared dead for more than 48 minutes before medics were able to restart his heart has revealed a shocking revelation about God. In an interview with WCVB-TV, the 72-year-old says he was sitting in his office at the Basilica of the National Shrine of the Assumption of the Virgin Mary on Sunday when he felt a sharp pain in his chest. He was rushed to Massachusetts General Hospital, where he was found to be in cardiac arrest. His heart stopped beating for more than 48 minutes before medics were able to re-start his heart. "I said to God, 'I'm a priest,'" he says. "And he said, 'You're not a priest. You're God.' And I said, 'Yes, God.' And he said, 'You're not a doctor. You're not a judge. You're not a lawyer. You're not a judge.' And I said, 'Yes, I am a judge.' And he said, 'You're a Catholic priest.' And I said, 'Yes, I am a Catholic priest.' And he said, 'Yes, I am a judge.

– A loud boom and a crater the size of a tennis court were felt throughout Nicaragua's capital on Saturday night, but the government says it wasn't a meteorite that caused the damage, the BBC reports. NASA, however, says it can't rule out the possibility of a meteorite, and experts say the lack of eyewitness accounts of a fireball in the night sky suggests it wasn't a meteorite at all.

– An Australian man's story that a spider had burrowed into his abdomen and lived there for three days while he was on vacation in Bali went viral this week—but it turns out the spider wasn't a spider at all. Instead, it was a millipede that was living under his skin, Mashable reports. Dylan Thomas says the spider was a millipede that got stuck in his skin during a routine check-in at a hotel. Thomas says he felt pain in his abdomen and called his doctor, who told him the spider had to be removed. Thomas says the doctor removed the spider's abdomen muscle and stitched up the wound. The doctor told him the spider was probably a millipede that got stuck in his skin during a routine check-in at a hotel. Thomas says he didn't realize the spider had actually burrowed into his skin until he woke up the next day with pain in his abdomen. He says he had to have surgery to remove the spider's abdomen muscle. The doctor told him the spider was probably a millipede that got stuck in his skin during a routine check-in at a hotel.

– When your husband is having sex with your twin, what do you do? You get revenge. That's what one Chinese woman did when she found her husband having sex with his own twin in a parked car, the South China Morning Post reports. Following a phone tracker, Ting Su found her 30-year-old husband, Cheng, in the car with his twin, and they hopped out completely naked. Ting Su then drove off, leaving Cheng and his sister embarrassed and without dignity. "He was banging his fist on the window and shouting," says a witness. " Ting Su jumped in and drove off, leaving Cheng and his sister embarrassed and without dignity."

– What's in a pumpkin spice love glove? That's what some Twitter users are wondering after a photo of what appears to be a pumpkin-flavored Durex glove was tweeted over the weekend, Gawker reports. The photo, which has since been deleted, shows a woman wearing what appears to be a pumpkin-flavored love glove, though it's not clear if it's actually a pumpkin-flavored love glove. According to the New York Daily News, emails from Durex's parent company and a PR company show the company is "playing it cool" by not confirming or denying the existence of a pumpkin-flavored love glove.

– Apple is working on a new slimmest MacBook ever, according to 9to5mac.com, which says the device will boast a single USB port and a 12-inch display. The previous slimmest MacBook was also a 12-inch model, which was released in 2012. The new model will be unveiled at an event later this month, according to 9to5mac.

– A prominent Saudi Arabian cleric has whipped up controversy by issuing a religious ruling forbidding the building of snowmen, describing them as anti-Islamic. Asked on a religious website if it was permissible for fathers to build snowmen for their children after a snowstorm in the country's north, Sheikh Mohammed Saleh al-Munajjid replied, "It is not permitted to make a statue out of snow, even by way of play and fun." Quoting from Muslim scholars, Sheikh Munajjid argued that to build a snowman was to create an image of a human being, an action considered sinful under the kingdom's strict interpretation of the Koran.

– Apple's next big product launch isn't until early next year, but analysts at UBS think the Apple Watch will have a big impact on the smartwatch market within the next nine months. In a survey of 4,000 people across four countries—the US, UK, France, and Italy—17% said they were "very likely" to buy an Apple Watch in the next year, while 10% said they were "very likely," the Wall Street Journal reports. The analysts predict that Apple will sell 24 million watches in the first nine months.

– Rumors have been swirling for a while now that the Apple Watch would be arriving in stores in time for the holidays, but a new one from 9to5mac.com is causing a bit of a stir. According to the site's sources, Best Buy, Walmart, and other big-box retailers won't be selling the watch until after the holidays—and that means you'll have to travel far and wide to get your hands on one. The site's sources say Best Buy and other big-box retailers will only be selling the watch in the US, and that means customers from outside the US will have to travel far and wide to get their hands on one. Apple hasn't commented on the report.

– A loud boom heard in Nicaragua's capital overnight was caused by a small meteorite that left a crater in a wooded area near Managua's airport, the country's president says. The president says the explosion was caused by a rock the size of a tennis court that broke apart in the middle of the night, the AP reports. He says no one was hurt in the blast. Nicaragua's government said Sunday that a mysterious boom heard overnight in the capital was made by a small meteorite that left a crater in a wooded area near Managua's airport, the country's president says. The president says the explosion was caused by a rock the size of a tennis court that broke apart in the middle of the night, the AP reports. Nicaragua's government said Sunday that a mysterious boom heard overnight in the capital was made by a small meteorite that left a crater in a wooded area near Managua's airport.

– The family of Luke Somers, an American who was kidnapped by al-Qaeda in Yemen last year, says it is "grieving over the loss of our beloved son, brother, and uncle." The 33-year-old's mother, Marsha Somers, said in a statement that the family was grateful to the US and Yemen for their efforts to free her son, who was killed during a rescue mission yesterday, the BBC reports. She said the family had been told by US officials that Luke was alive and well and had been moved to a military base for medical care. "We are heartbroken over the loss of our son, brother, and uncle, but at the same time we are thankful to the government of the United States and the people of Yemen for their tireless efforts to save his life," she said. "We ask that you respect our privacy during this difficult time." American officials say they are working to free other American hostages held by al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula country, the New York Times reports.

– Hundreds of Palestinians were evacuated from their homes Sunday morning after Israeli authorities opened a number of dams near the border, flooding the Gaza Valley in the wake of a recent severe winter storm, the Ma'an news agency reports. According to Haaretz, the dam opened near the southern Gaza town of Rafah, as well as in the northern Gaza town of Jabaliya. The flooding is the result of heavy rain and snow that has fallen on the Gaza Strip in recent days.

– Police say a soldier standing guard at the National War Memorial has been by an unknown gunman, the AP reports. Ottawa police confirmed they had a call at 9:52 this morning. According to Member of Parliament Bob Zimmer, the intruder was shot inside the Parliament building. The incident comes just a day after police killed a Muslim convert in Quebec after he had hit two soldiers with his car.

– A small meteorite landed near the international airport in the Nicaraguan capital, Managua, but no one is hurt, government officials say, after residents reported hearing a loud bang. (This video shows the moment.) – It looks like Game of Thrones fans won't have to pay for cable anymore. The International Business Times reports that HBO is launching a stand-alone streaming service called "HBO Now" that will cost $15 per month. That's less than the cost of a cable or satellite subscription, according to the Los Angeles Times. The new service is expected to launch in time for the April 12 premiere of the fifth season of Game of Thrones. According to the International Business Times, Apple is in negotiations to make the Apple TV a launch destination for HBO Now.

– The story of the Harvard Business School professor who flipped out over a $4 bill at a Chinese restaurant took an ugly turn last night. The Boston Globe's free Boston.com site, which first reported the story, posted a follow-up claiming that Ben Edelman had sent a racist email to the restaurant owner—and then replaced the follow-up with an "Editor's Note," explaining that the authenticity of the email couldn't be verified. The Boston Herald has a summary of what went wrong. The original story about Edelman, by Boston.com's Hilary Sargent, had gone viral. The Globe's free Boston.com site, which first reported the story, posted a follow-up claiming that Ben Edelman had sent a racist email to the restaurant owner—and then replaced the follow-up with an "Editor's Note," explaining that the authenticity of the email couldn't be verified.

– ISIS released a new video today in which it claims to have seized a shipment of weapons the US had intended to deliver to Kurdish fighters battling the group in Syria, the New York Times reports. The video shows a militant raking his hands through a crate filled with hand grenades. The US has acknowledged launching one airstrike against ISIS, but it's not clear whether the militant claim is true. The video comes a day after the US acknowledged launching a second airstrike against ISIS.

– Wal-Mart reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings today, but that wasn't enough to soothe investors. The company's stock fell about 2% in after-hours trading, reports the Wall Street Journal. Analysts had expected the company to report earnings of $1.53 per share.

– British rapper Abde Majed Abdel Bary is suspected of being the man who executed American journalist James Foley in a Groton, Conn., hotel room last week, a senior Western intelligence official tells Fox News. The official says Abdel Bary, 23, is a dual citizen of Egypt and the UK and has been living in the US for the past two years. The official says Abdel Bary is believed to have been radicalized in London, where he grew up, and is a member of a radical Islamic group called Al Muhajireen wal-Ansar.

– North Korea's Kim Jong Un has broken both his ankles, and it's all the result of his heavy drinking and overindulgence in Swiss cheese, according to a South Korean newspaper report picked up by the Telegraph. "Kim Jong Un injured his right ankle in June after pushing ahead with on-site visits and ended up fracturing both ankles because he left the injury unattended," an anonymous source was quoted as saying in the Chosun Ilbo.

– Matt Taibbi has taken a leave of absence from First Look Media, the satirical website he was hired to launch for eBay founder Pierre Omidyar's media outlet. According to a post on Taibbi's personal blog, he is taking a leave of absence "to focus on my personal and professional life." First Look Media is a joint venture between Omidyar's eBay and BMG Media.

– Ahmed Abdi Godane, a leader of the al-Shabab terrorist group blamed for the attack on Kenya's Westgate Mall and other atrocities in Somalia, has been killed in an airstrike, the Pentagon says. "Removing Godane from the battlefield is a major symbolic and operational loss to al-Shabab," a Pentagon spokesman says. The death of Godane, who was killed in southern Somalia yesterday, is "a significant blow to al-Shabab," the spokesman says, according to the New York Times.

– Guns N' Roses frontman Axl Rose has been found dead in his West Hollywood home at the age of 52, according to a fake MSNBC report, but the band says he's "alive and hopefully well." The "news" site has no affiliation with the real MSNBC, PopEater reports. "The awful hoax comes from the jerks behind the MSNBC.website URL, which has no affiliation with the real news outlet and tries to fool people into clicking on bogus stories," reads a statement from the band.
– Vladimir Putin was unveiling a World War I monument in Moscow today when... a bird pooped on him. See for yourself in this video, but be warned: It's graphic.

– A gunman opened fire at Canada's National War Memorial in Ottawa today, killing a soldier standing guard, police say. The gunman then ran into the country's Parliament building, where he was shot dead by police, the CBC reports. Police say "a male suspect has been confirmed deceased," but it's not clear whether he was killed inside the Parliament building or elsewhere in Ottawa, the AP reports. Police have asked people to stay away from the downtown area.
– Is the new iPhone 6 causing hair to get caught between the screen and the phone's aluminum back? The hashtag #hairgate saw thousands of tweets overnight. Carson Daly reports at the Orange Room.

– Militants from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria have released a video showing the beheading of American journalist James Wright Foley, reports the New York Times. The graphic video, which has not been independently verified, shows the decapitated body of the 39-year-old, who was seized in northern Iraq in November 2012 while working as a freelance journalist for Time. "I'm not going to dignify the terrorists by posting the video here, you can look it up on your own if you'd like," writes Alex Pareene at Salon.

– A video of a drunk and/or high man attacking a gay man in a Dallas airport has gone viral, with more than 2 million views since it was posted on Raw Story on Saturday. But one person has noticed that one of the men tackling the attacker looks a lot like Paul Rudd, Jezebel reports.

– North Korea leader Kim Jong-un is so fat from eating cheese that he has broken his ankles. North Korea leader Kim Jong-un is so fat from eating cheese that he has broken his ankles. – ISIS has released a video showing the beheading of British hostage David Haines, reports the Telegraph. The video, which comes a day after Haines' family made a public plea for his life, shows the execution of the 44-year-old. "My heart goes out to his family who have shown extraordinary courage and fortitude," said Prime Minister David Cameron in a statement. "We will do everything in our power to hunt down these murderers and ensure they face justice, however long it takes."

– Samsung has scored an important order from Apple: the production of a system-in-a-package for the Apple Watch, reports DigiTimes. The S1 produced by Samsung will combine multiple components, including the processor, mobile flash, and other chips into one package, notes the South Korea-based news site. It's not clear when the watch will be out, but a November report said Apple would be relying heavily on Samsung for the iPhone 6 and the Apple Watch.

– The 276 schoolgirls kidnapped by Boko Haram extremists in Nigeria last month will not be released until all of them have been returned to their home country, Nigerian President Muhammadu Buhari has announced. The leader of the extremist group, which seized the girls last month, has agreed to a ceasefire, but Buhari says the girls will not be released until all of them have been returned to their home country, the BBC reports. "We have reached an agreement with Boko Haram that the girls will not be released to any part of the country until all of them have been returned to their home country," Buhari said in a televised address to the nation. "We have also reached an agreement with Boko Haram that the girls who have not been returned to their home country will be dealt with according to the laws of the country." The leader of a vigilante group set up to fight Boko Haram says the girls will not be released until all of them have been returned to their home country.

– The long-rumored 12-inch Retina MacBook Air is finally here, 9to5Mac reports. The new device will have the same footprint as the current 11-inch model, but will boast a larger display (up to a third larger than the current 11-inch model) and a keyboard that extends from edge to edge, as well as speakers that move to a set of grilles above the keyboard.

– A school trip to Bosnia was supposed to be a fun learning experience for the 28 girls on the trip. Instead, seven of them came home pregnant—and their parents are outraged, the Daily Mail reports via BuzzFeed. The girls were supposed to be touring museums during the five-day trip, but it turns out that wasn't the only purpose of the trip. The parents of the seven pregnant girls say their daughters were on the trip to "excite" their parents, not learn anything, the Daily Mail reports.

– When Dylan Thomas went on vacation to Bali with a friend, his friend noticed a red scar going up the 21-year-old's stomach. At first, doctors told him it was an insect bite, but they later discovered a spider had burrowed itself into Thomas' abdomen, most likely through his recent appendix scar. Thomas posted this on his Facebook page: "Well after running tests and putting things inside my stomach they finally found out it was a spider."

– There are conflicting reports whether Gill Rosenberg, a Canadian-Israeli woman who claims to have joined the fight against the Islamic State, has been captured. UPI reports that there are conflicting reports whether Gill Rosenberg, a Canadian-Israeli woman who claims to have joined the fight against the Islamic State, has been captured. According to the New York Daily News, the 52-year-old's husband, David Rosenberg, says she was captured in northern Syria while trying to cross the border into Turkey. David Rosenberg says he was told by Turkish officials that she was being held by the Islamic State in northern Syria, but Turkish officials deny that and say they are working with the Syrian government to locate her, the Daily News reports. – The Islamic State has claimed that an American hostage held by the group was killed in a Jordanian airstrike on the outskirts of the Syrian city of Raqqa today. The militant group identified the woman as Kayla Jean Mueller and said she was killed during Muslim prayers, which usually take place around midday on Fridays, reports the BBC. No Islamic State militants were killed in the airstrikes, which targeted "the same location for more than an hour," the statement further claimed.

– Mexican authorities say they have found no trace of the 43 students who went missing last month after a confrontation with police in the southern state of Guerrero, the AP reports. Attorney General Jesus Murillo Karam says DNA tests on 28 of the 28 badly burned bodies found in a mass grave on the outskirts of the town of Iguala have confirmed that they are not the missing students. Murillo Karam says tests are continuing on four more graves found last week. State governor Angel Aguirre says some of the bodies could have been found earlier. The whereabouts of the students, who disappeared after a confrontation with police in late September, have been the subject of mass protests in the state. Authorities have been conducting DNA tests on the 28 badly burned bodies found in the graves since discovering them earlier this month. Attorney General Jesus Murillo Karam said tests were continuing on four additional graves uncovered last week.

– ISIS has released a video claiming to show the beheading of American journalist James Foley, reports the New York Times. The executioner, who appears to be a British man, identifies the victim as Steven Joel Sotloff and says the "life of this American citizen is about to come to an end." Sotloff is believed to be a freelancer who went missing in Syria last year. The executioner appears to be the same one who killed Foley in a video earlier this year, notes the Washington Post.

– The sister of Luke Somers, an American photojournalist held hostage by al-Qaeda in Yemen for more than a year, says he has been killed during a rescue attempt. Lucy Somers tells the AP that she was informed of her brother's death by FBI agents today. Earlier this week, al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula issued a video with a message aimed at the US government threatening to kill the 33-year-old.

– The Pentagon is investigating claims by the Islamic State that one of its fighter jets dropped supplies to civilians fighting the group in Iraq and Syria. Video released by the militant group shows what appears to be one of its fighters in the desert with a stack of boxes attached to a parachute, the Telegraph reports. The Pentagon said it was investigating the claim but admitted that one of its airdrops had gone missing.

– Canada's Parliament sergeant-at-Arms is being hailed as a hero after shooting a gunman inside the building this morning. Kevin Michael Vickers, 55, was in his office when gunman Michael Zehaf-Bibeau entered the Parliament building this morning, CTV News reports. "Kevin Vickers came out of his office carrying a gun," says a witness. "I don't know how many shots he fired, but he hit him." Zehaf-Bibeau had entered the Parliament building with a rifle, CTV News reports. He allegedly shot a soldier standing guard at the National War Memorial before being shot by Vickers. "I don't know how many shots he fired, but he hit him," says another witness. "I don't know how many people were in the Parliament building at the time, but he hit him."

– An anonymous source in an Iraqi hospital tells a pro-government newspaper that Ebola has arrived in the northern city of Mosul from "terrorists" who came "from several countries" and Africa, reports Mashable. It's the first time the virus has been detected in an area controlled by the Islamic State, or ISIS, which "doesn't embrace science and modern medicine," observes the Washington Post.

– It's that time of year again: time for the annual debunking of the year's most ridiculous hoaxes. This year, it's the "Zero G Day" hoax, which claimed that on Jan. 4 of last year, a planetary alignment would cause gravity to decrease, allowing you to float temporarily or fall more slowly if you jumped in the air at the right moment, reports Snopes.com, which has the video. "I've decided to update the debunking to include some new links and repost it, hopefully to stem the tide of silliness at year's end," writes the site's editor. "It seems fitting that (hopefully) this is also the last debunking I'll make in 2014."

– She's the "highest paid performer" on YouTube, and she's also a former porn star. That's right, DC Toy Collector is actually a former Brazilian porn star, and she's behind the popular YouTube videos in which she unboxes Disney toys and gives them away, the Daily Dot reports. The woman's real name is Ana Paula dos Reiss, and she was filming both videos in the same Florida home at the time, TMZ reports. DC Toy Collector made nearly $5 million last year unboxing Disney toys.

– Militants fighting for the Islamic State in Iraq have unveiled their latest terror tactic—bombs containing hundreds of live scorpions designed to spread fear among their enemies. The live scorpions are the latest in a long line of terror tactics used by the group, including beheadings, beheadings of prisoners, and beheadings of homosexuals. – A Texas health care worker has tested positive for Ebola, becoming the first person in the US to do so, reports the Dallas Morning News. The worker is undergoing treatment at a hospital in Frisco, about 30 miles north of Dallas. She hasn't been identified, but authorities have identified her as Thomas Duncan, a 31-year-old man who recently moved to Texas from West Africa. The first Ebola case in the US has been reported in New York.

– A viral YouTube video showing a homeless man receiving a $100 gift to buy food for others has raised more than $160,000 for charity, but the man in the video says the whole thing is "bullshit," the Los Angeles Times reports. "Bro, [Lin] drove Thomas to the liquor store," says a man who claims to be the homeless man's cousin. "Bro, [Lin] drove Thomas to the liquor store," the man says. "Bro, [Lin] drove Thomas to the liquor store." Thomas says the whole thing is " bullshit."
– Christian Bale is "in talks" to play Steve Jobs in Sony's biopic of the Apple co-founder, reports Variety. No word yet on when the film will be out.

– There are plenty of ways to make a buck on Apple's App Store, but this one seems to have taken things to a whole new level. In a photo that's gone viral in China, a woman is standing in front of a rack of about 100 iPhone 5Cs, trying to download as many apps as she can, the Telegraph reports. The photo has since gone viral on social media, with many commenters pointing out that the woman in the photo isn't actually trying to download any apps—it's just trying to get into the top 100.

– If you've got an iPhone 6 or 6 Plus, you may want to take care of any issues you're having with the phone before they become an issue. That's according to a report from 9to5mac.com, which cites a Reddit user who says the company has quietly made changes to the iPhone 6 and 6 Plus to make the phones more resistant to bending. The company has not confirmed the report, 9to5mac.com reports. The bending issue has been a big problem for iPhone users, and 9to5mac.com notes that complaints about the phone's responsiveness have also been rising.

– Members of Iraqi Parliament from Diwaniyah Province report that Islamic State militants have killed over 300 soldiers using chlorine gas for the first time in Saqlawiyah, north of Fallujah. It's the first time the militants have used chlorine gas in an actual attack, the Telegraph reports.

– If you're one of the millions of Chinese people who've never heard of "Dumbledore," you're not alone. The country's state-run broadcaster has come up with some tongue-in-cheek suggestions for English-speakers who want to avoid the name, reports the South China Morning Post. Among them: "Don't name your child 'Dumbledore,'" "Don't name your spouse 'Dumbledore,'" and "Don't name your children 'Dumbledore.'"

– The Nigerian government says it has struck a deal with Boko Haram militants to allow the return of 276 schoolgirls kidnapped in April from a school in the country's northeast, the AP reports. The president of the country's Senate says the deal was struck with the militant group's leader, Abubakar Shekau. Officials say the schoolgirls will be returned to their homes under the deal, which still needs to be approved by the country's government and the militant group's leader. The 276 schoolgirls were kidnapped by Boko Haram extremists in April from a school in the town of Chibok.

– Seven schoolgirls in a small town in Bosnia and Herzegovina went on a five-day excursion, and after some time it turned out that seven schoolgirls got pregnant on it. Primary school students from a small town in Bosnia and Herzegovina went to a five-day excursion, and after some time it turned out that seven schoolgirls got pregnant on it. The Telegraph reports that the trip, which was organized by the town's education department, was meant to teach the children about the dangers of extreme weather conditions, but they ended up getting more than they bargained for.

– Seth Rogen, Christian Bale, and Jessica Chastain are all in talks to star in Danny Boyle's Steve Jobs, the Sony Pictures film based on Walter Isaacson's biography of the late Apple co-founder, Variety reports. Rogen will play Steve Wozniak, while Bale will play Steve Jobs himself, according to Aaron Sorkin, who wrote the Facebook drama The Social Network.

– The wife and daughter of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi have been detained by the Lebanese army, security officials say. The woman was described as "one of his wives," while other reports have described her as his "ex-wife," the Telegraph reports. The officials say the woman and her daughter were arrested 10 days ago as they crossed from Syria into Lebanon. A BBC correspondent says a source within the Lebanese Armed Forces has confirmed the woman is al-Baghdadi's ex-wife, Saja Dulaimi.

– The world's most expensive production car, the Bugatti Veyron 16.4 Grand Sport, can hit 60mph in 2.6 seconds—and it has a penis painted on it. Seattle police are looking for a man who painted the organ on the $1.6 million car, the Daily Mail reports. The penis was painted by an amateur psychologist on the side of the Bugatti, which is street legal.

– Jose Canseco is in the hospital after allegedly shooting himself in the hand while cleaning a gun at his Las Vegas home yesterday, the Las Vegas Review-Journal reports. Police say the former baseball star was treated at a hospital before being released. Canseco hasn't tweeted since Monday, when he posted a photo of his dogs.

– An image of a gold Bugatti Veyron graffitied with a drawing of a penis may have upset car lovers—but it turns out the vehicle was included in a YouTube hoax. An image of a gold Bugatti Veyron graffitied with a drawing of a penis may have upset car lovers—but it turns out the vehicle was included in a YouTube hoax. Photos from multiple Instagram accounts have revealed the luxury vehicle wasn't permanently damaged, the Daily Mail reports. Instagram user @andreysmygov uploaded a photo last Friday of the Veyron with a caption that suggested it was painted on as a stunt for TwinzTV.

– The rat problem at Vogue's new office in 1 World Trade Center is so bad that editor-in-chief Anna Wintour has issued a standing order to staff to stay away from the building, Gawker reports. Sources say rats have been spotted on floors 25 and 26 of the office building, which Condé Nast moved into earlier this month.

– Kim Jong Un may be out of sight, but he's not out of mind, according to North Korea watchers. The country's official Korean Central News Agency said today that Kim is "very active" and has been making public appearances over the last few weeks, reports the AP. "He is very active in all matters related to the supreme leadership of the DPRK," said the KCNA, referring to North Korea by its official name, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. The KCNA didn't provide any evidence to back up the claim that Kim is in better health than he has been in a while. The last public appearance Kim made was Sept. 3.

– Apple's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs is just over a month away—and the company is already boasting about the watch's battery life. Apple CEO Tim Cook told CNBC yesterday that the Apple Watch will have a battery life of 19 hours, which is "consistent with our estimate that users will want to charge the device daily," the Wall Street Journal reports. That's in line with Cook's previous estimates, which had the watch's battery life at 12 to 18 hours. The Journal notes that the watch won't be out until later this year, but it's not clear if the company will also release a cheaper version.

– Former baseball slugger Jose Canseco is in the hospital after shooting himself in the hand while cleaning his gun, police in Las Vegas say. Canseco told police he was cleaning his gun in the kitchen when it fired, shooting a finger on his left hand, the AP reports. He was taken to University Medical Center of Southern Nevada. Canseco's fiancee, Leila Knight, tweeted from his account late Tuesday night, saying he was still in surgery and would be OK.

– It's not every day that a suitcase full of puppies is found abandoned at a train station, but that's exactly what happened in the Philippines earlier this month. He's so popular, in fact, that the owner of the cafe is offering a free teddy bear to anyone who comes in contact with him. The bear has been a hit with both kids and adults, the paper notes, and now a local woman says she was threatened by a polar bear who tried to attack him.
