– When Stan Beaton's wife died in 2003, he kept the voicemail message she left for him on her cell phone—but when Virgin Media carried out work on her data network, the message was deleted, the Telegraph reports. "It's just a wonderful, wonderful sound that I thought was lost forever," the 68-year-old tells the BBC. "They've made this old age pensioner extremely happy." The message was recently restored to Beaton's phone.

– Apple's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs hasn't exactly been a rousing success. The company's shares plunged 7.5% in after-hours trading yesterday, wiping out most of the gains it had made since the launch of the Apple Watch last month, reports the Wall Street Journal. The stock has now lost more than a third of its value this year. Analysts say the watch, which costs up to $349, isn't a game-changer for Apple, but the company's share price is still expected to rise in the days to come, reports the New York Times, which notes that this is the first major product launch since the death of the tech giant's founder. Analysts say the watch is unlikely to replace the iPhone as Apple's main product, but it is expected to play a role in the company's efforts to stay ahead of competitors such as Google.

– Tiger Woods' divorce from wife Elin Nordegren may be over, but he's not done with his private island in Sweden. The Los Angeles Times reports the 7-acre property, located near Stockholm, is on the market for $7.1 million. "This island was owned by Tiger Woods, but after his divorce he doesn't need an island in Sweden any more," says Sabine Rollinger of Vladi Private Islands, which is handling the sale. Nordegren has said she and Woods live a 25-minute drive from the island.

– Nicaraguan officials say a meteorite gouged out a crater near the nation's capital city over the weekend, but scientists aren't so sure. A committee formed by the Nicaraguan government determined that a new, 39-foot-wide crater found near the capital Managua's international airport was blasted out by a space rock strike Saturday night, reports the AP.

– A sad story out of Scotland, where a 2-year-old dog was found "tied to railings at Ayr railway station along with a suitcase full of his belongings, which included a pillow, a toy, a food bowl, and food," per a post on the Scottish SPCA's Facebook page. The Shar-Pei cross is microchipped, and his name is Kai, but his owner apparently sold him on Craigslist.

– North Korea is denying a report that its leader, Kim Jong Un, is considering opening a restaurant in Scotland that would serve dog meat. "Not news: A fabricated story coming out of North Korea. News: It's not North Korea doing the fabricating! It's being widely reported that Kim Jong Un is considering Scotland for his next restaurant venture, which will feature dog meat on the menu," North Korea's official Korean Central News Agency tweeted Thursday. "What's not being reported is... well, anyone ever saying that in the first place," the agency continued. "We're here to help you, the reader, mull through all the hot garbage being served up today by telling you exactly what we know, and pointing out the news organizations that are spreading misinformation."

Dmitry Nikolaev, 30, had a drink with a "young blonde woman" who approached him at a bar after he finished a performance at a small Moscow theater, the Daily Mail reports. Flirting with him, she invited him to a sauna, and though he was married, he agreed to go with her. "They kissed and had some more beer and after that the actor remembers nothing," says a friend. Nikolaev's testicles were removed, and police believe the gang included a doctor.

– The Islamic State has unleashed a wave of chemical-weapons attacks on Kurdish peshmerga fighters in northern Iraq, the New York Times reports. According to the Washington Post, at least 11 Kurdish peshmerga fighters were killed by chlorine gas bombs last week in the town of Kobani. A police officer was also killed in the attack. The peshmerga fighters had come to the town to help the peshmerga fight ISIS, the Post reports. ISIS fighters are believed to be using chlorine gas as a weapon because it's illegal under the Chemical Weapons Convention. According to the Post, Kurdish peshmerga fighters are also believed to be using mustard gas because it's legal to use it. ISIS is believed to have at least 2,500 rockets filled with nerve agents that have been degraded at a former chemical weapons production plant in territory seized by the militants. "I was born intersex and named David Roy Fitch," the 41-year-old DC-area woman writes. "I met Michael Phelps on Tinder and fucked him on our first date watching football on TV," she continues. "I was born intersex and named David Roy Fitch." Chandler—who calls Phelps her "best friend" and says she's "in love" with him—tells Radar she was freaked out when the world discovered the truth about her relationship with the 18-time Olympic gold medalist. Instead, he handed the man bags of food—which the man shared with other homeless people in the area. "There's things money can't buy, and I get a happiness out of what I'm doing," the man told Lin. Lin gave the man another $100, and the result was a YouTube sensation.

"Scorpions are robust—even if they are launched a couple of miles, when the canister breaks thousands are flung." ISIS is reportedly using the scorpions as bombs in the north of the country.

– A second patient with Ebola symptoms walked into a Texas clinic today and told medics he had been in contact with first victim Thomas Duncan. The CareNow clinic in Frisco, Texas, was placed in lock-down after the person appeared on Wednesday and was exhibiting signs of the deadly virus. The patient answered yes in a screening questionnaire to a question about travel to West Africa and is said to have contact with Duncan, referred to as 'patient zero,' the Daily Mail reports. Duncan, 42, died on Wednesday morning at Texas Presbyterian Hospital after developing symptoms of the disease almost two weeks ago.

– The US military says it's "not out of the realm of the possible" that some of the weapons and ammunition it dropped on ISIS fighters in northern Syria last week have fallen into the militants' hands, the New York Times reports. A Pentagon spokesman said Tuesday that some of the weapons, including rocket-propelled grenades and anti-tank missiles, "have already fallen into the hands of ISIL," using an alternate name for the group. The spokesman added that the Pentagon is working with local officials to figure out how to get the weapons back to the US.

– The Islamic State's leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, has not been killed as had been reported, according to Iraqi media. A source tells Iraqi media that al-Baghdadi was badly injured in recent US airstrikes near the Tel Afer and Sinjar in northern Iraq, the Independent reports. The source says al-Baghdadi is being treated in the border area of Iraq and Syria.

– An Indian court has ordered the arrest of Dera Sacha Sauda chief Gurmeet Ram Rahim Singh in connection with the alleged forced castration of 400 of his followers in 2000, the BBC reports. The Central Bureau of Investigation says it has filed a case of criminal conspiracy against the Dera chief and his followers for "voluntarily causing grievous hurt with dangerous weapons." The alleged forced castration took place at the Dera Sacha Sauda headquarters in Sirsa, Punjab. Some 400 of Dera Sacha Sauda's followers are said to have been injured in the incident.

– A drone strike in Somalia has reportedly killed a top leader of the al-Qaeda-linked al-Shabab militant group, reports the BBC. The strike reportedly killed Ahmed Godane, who had reportedly trained with the Taliban in Afghanistan. Godane was the group's No. 2 leader and had reportedly been living in an al-Shabab encampment near the town of Bossaso, which is in Somalia's semi-autonomous region of Puntland.

– Who knew Buckingham Palace had mushrooms? TV gardener Alan Titchmarsh discovered spotted toadstool Amanita muscaria while touring the palace garden with an ecology expert, the Telegraph reports. "I won't be eating any of that," Titchmarsh said. Amanita muscaria is a psychedelic mushroom that can cause hallucinations. "It's eaten in some cultures for its hallucinogenic effects," said the expert. "But it also makes people who eat it very."

– If you're a fan of Game of Thrones, you're in for a treat: For the first time in the show's history, Game of Thrones will also feature a live-action version of the show's opening credits, the Guardian reports. The credits debuted during last night's episode, and the live-action version will debut at some point during this week's new episode. The move is part of the show's plan to squeeze in as many commercials as possible before the new season kicks off, according to the Hollywood Reporter.

– On Monday night, ESPN will host a panel discussion on domestic violence, and the only women on the table will be male commentators. "Up to 11 men, all between the ages of 39 and 74 will sit at the table for a domestic violence discussion on ESPN," Esquire quotes an announcement from the network as saying. That's a far cry from the three women on the original list of panelists, which included Jane Goodall, Angela Bassett, and retired Supreme Court justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the New York Daily News reports. The lack of women on the panel "wasn't a mistake," an ESPN VP tells the Daily News. "We wanted to do a panel discussion about domestic violence that would include people from all walks of life."

– Seth Rogen and Danny Boyle have signed on to play Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak, respectively, in an upcoming biopic based on Walter Isaacson's biography of the Apple co-founder, Variety reports. Christian Bale had been set to play Jobs, but he has dropped out of the movie, which will be directed by Boyle.

– An Iraqi official on Wednesday denied that a woman detained in Lebanon is a wife of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the leader of Islamic State group. An Iraqi official on Wednesday denied that a woman detained in Lebanon is a wife of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the leader of Islamic State group. An Iraqi official on Wednesday denied that a woman detained in Lebanon is a wife of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the leader of Islamic State group.

– A prominent Saudi cleric has reportedly issued a fatwa against building snowmen, arguing that the practice goes against Islamic teachings. “It is not permitted to make a statue out of snow, even by way of play and fun,” declared Sheikh Mohammed Saleh al-Munajjid, according to Reuters.

– The wife and child of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi have been detained by the Lebanese military, security officials say. The officials say Sagia Dulaimi, wife of another senior ISIS commander, was detained along with her 9-year-old daughter at a border checkpoint in northern Lebanon last week, the New York Times reports. The officials say the detained women and child could provide valuable information on the activities of al-Baghdadi and his inner circle, or they could be used as "bargaining chips" in the release of ISIS hostages.

– Vice Media CEO and co-founder Shane Smith, whose billion-dollar company was accused of underpaying its employees earlier this year, spent $300,000 on dinner at a Las Vegas hotel last month, the New York Daily News reports. According to the Las Vegas Review-Journal, Smith and his wife spent the night at the Hard Rock Hotel & Casino, where they stayed in the VIP suite. A source tells the Review-Journal the money was spent on food and drinks.

– Is Star Wars: The Force Awakens headed for a summer release? That's what two websites—Ikwiz and Movie Pilot—are reporting, with the latter saying director JJ Abrams is "losing patience" with the "constant stream of plot and image leaks" from the set and wants Disney to move the film's December 2015 release date to this summer.

– Axl Rose is not dead, despite internet reports to the contrary—but that should come as no surprise to fans who by now have surely grown tired of the seemingly endless stream of online hoaxes falsely reporting the death of just about every major celebrity, and plenty of minor celebs as well. Axl Rose is not dead, despite internet reports to the contrary—but that should come as no surprise to fans who by now have surely grown tired of the seemingly endless stream of online hoaxes falsely reporting the death of just about every major celebrity, and plenty of minor celebs as well.

– A time capsule placed in the lion's head of Boston's former State House more than a century ago is set to be unearthed. The Bostonian Society, which runs the building, says Samuel Rogers, the great-great-granddaughter of Samuel Rogers, worked on renovations to the building three years ago and discovered the time capsule buried in the lion's head in 1901, the Boston Globe reports. The society plans to open it this week.

– The fence-jumper who forced his way into the White House last week managed to get past a Secret Service agent before he could get inside President Obama's East Room, the Washington Post reports, citing "multiple sources." The source says the intruder, a former Army soldier with a history of mental illness, managed to get past an agent and into the room, which is used for presidential addresses. (Read the full article here.)

– Apple's next big product launch isn't until later this month, but the company's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs is already generating a lot of buzz. The new Apple Watch will likely come in two models: a standard model that will cost $349 and a high-end model that will cost at least $10,000, the Wall Street Journal reports, citing "people familiar with the matter." The two models will come with different storage capacities: 4GB and 8GB. The 4GB model will likely be the more popular of the two, an analyst tells Cowen and Company, while the 8GB model probably won't be the default configuration. Both Samsung's Gear 2 and Sony's Smartwatch 3 come with 4GB of storage space. The new watch will also likely come with a GPS radio, which is odd since Apple has said it will need to be connected to a cellphone to use the watch's GPS, the Journal notes.

– Amazon's latest line of Kindle Fire HDX tablets will come pre-installed with an app that curates news and photography from the Washington Post, reports Brad Stone at Bloomberg. It's called "Project Rainbow," and it's Jeff Bezos' first move into ties between the two companies since he bought the Post for $250 million last year.

– Apple shares took a nosedive this morning after an analyst predicted the company would miss its revenue forecast for the third straight year, reports the Wall Street Journal. The company's stock fell 7% in the first minutes of trading after it announced that it would delay the release of its Apple Watch until the end of the year to give it more time to work on a cheaper model. The company is expected to release a cheaper model later this year.

– It's not every day that a conspiracy theorist gets the Internet's attention, but that's exactly what happened Thursday night when Macklemore and Ryan Lewis took to Twitter to call out a conspiracy theory that the 9/11 attacks were a hoax. The "#MacklemoreJoinedISS" campaign started with a tweet by conspiracy theorist Alex Jones that read, "9/11 was a fraud perpetrated by the CIA, led by George W. Bush," followed by a photo of a stack of papers that purported to prove the CIA was behind the attacks, the Washington Post reports. The tweet was quickly deleted, but not before it had been retweeted more than 25,000 times and liked more than 10,000 times. In response, Macklemore and Lewis took to Twitter to call out the "smear" and "smear" being directed their way at the so-called 9/11 truther, Fox News reports. "You are a liar," Macklemore tweeted to Jones, calling him a "moron" and a "smear." Lewis, meanwhile, tweeted to Jones: "You are a liar and a smear. You should be ashamed of yourself."

– A Russian lawmaker says Vladimir Putin has told him he's ready to step down as head of the country's FSB security service, the successor to the KGB, reports the AP. Leonid Slutsky, a member of the upper house of Russia's parliament, tells the RIA Novosti news agency that Putin told him "he is ready to step down as head of the country's main intelligence agency." Slutsky says Putin made the announcement in a phone call from his residence in St. Petersburg on Friday. He says the FSB, successor to the KGB, is in charge of the country's anti-terror operations.

– The Islamic State of Iraq and Syria has released a video showing the beheading of American journalist James Wright Foley, who was kidnapped in Syria in November 2012, the New York Times reports. The militant group, which has threatened to kill Foley if the US doesn't end its intervention in Iraq, said the execution was carried out in revenge for American airstrikes against the group. "This is James Foley, an American citizen, who was kidnapped in Syria in November 2012," a voice purported to be that of his captors says in the video. "He demanded the immediate release of any American citizens currently being held in the country." The video, which has been viewed more than a million times on YouTube, shows Foley's headless body.

– Rumors have been floating around for a while now that the Apple Watch is water-proof, but this might be the first time the company has actually confirmed that it's water-proof. According to iGen.fr, an employee at an Apple store in Berlin overheard CEO Tim Cook telling the group that the watch "wears his everywhere, even in the shower." It's not clear if Cook was talking about wearing the watch while taking a shower or while swimming, but iGen.fr notes that the Apple Watch was shown off for the first time last year without being said to be water-proof enough to be worn while swimming or taking a shower.

– If you're an Apple fan who'd like to try on an Apple Watch before you buy it, you'll soon be able to. The Wall Street Journal reports that Apple stores will now accept in-store reservations for the Apple Watch, and employees will even train customers how to choose the best watch for them. The Journal also reports that the high-end Apple Watch Edition will have scratch-resistant gold, which it explains is because Apple mixes the metal with low-density ceramic particles.

– "Theurge to create is equally strong in all children: Boys and girls." That's the message Lego sent to parents in a 1974 letter that's been going viral since a Reddit user posted it over the weekend, i100.co.uk reports. The letter, which Lego says was part of a marketing campaign aimed at girls, reads in part, "Theurge to create is equally strong in all children: Boys and girls." It goes on to say that the company's goal is "to inspire and empower all children to be their best selves." Lego UK and Ireland says the letter was part of a marketing campaign aimed at girls from the 1970s.

– ISIS claimed Friday that a 26-year-old female American hostage was killed in an airstrike in Syria, according to NBC News partners Flashpoint Intelligence. The terrorist group, which has beheaded American Kayla Mueller and threatened to kill the remaining US captives if President Trump doesn't release its prisoners, said the hostage was killed in an airstrike on a building used by the group in Raqqa, reports the AP. Mueller's father, Eric Mueller, says his daughter was taken hostage in August last year in northern Syria by militants who had been threatening to kill her if Trump didn't release their captives. "My daughter is with the Islamic State, she is dead," his father said in a statement. "She is the daughter of American citizens who were kidnapped in Syria by the Islamic State in August of last year. She is the daughter of two American citizens who were held hostage by the Islamic State in Raqqa. She is the daughter of two American citizens who were held hostage by the Islamic State in Iraq. She is the daughter of two American citizens who were held hostage by the Islamic State in Iraq. She is the daughter of two American citizens who were held hostage by the Islamic State in Iraq."

– North Korea's official Korean Central News Agency is reporting that Kim Jong Un's younger sister, Kim Yo Jong, has taken over state duties while her brother receives medical treatment. Kim Yo Jong, the younger sister of North Korean Supreme Leader Kim Jong Un, has allegedly taken over state duties while her brother receives medical treatment. North Korea's official Korean Central News Agency is reporting that Kim Yo Jong, the younger sister of North Korean Supreme Leader Kim Jong Un, has taken over state duties while her brother receives medical treatment. Kim Yo Jong, the younger sister of North Korean Supreme Leader Kim Jong Un, has allegedly taken over state duties while her brother receives medical treatment.

– A Canadian-Israeli woman who was feared kidnapped by the Islamic State over the weekend appears to have posted a message on Facebook debunking reports of her capture. A Canadian-Israeli woman who was feared kidnapped by the Islamic State over the weekend appears to have posted a message on Facebook debunking reports of her capture.

– Kim Jong Un may be missing from the public eye for more than a month, but a South Korean newspaper says he's just recovering from an ankle surgery. The Chosun Ilbo says the North Korean leader, who has been "missing from the public eye" for almost a month, is simply recovering from the surgery, which was carried out on his right ankle last week, the AP reports. The paper says it's not clear whether the surgery was performed on Kim's left ankle, which was also operated on last week, or on his right ankle. North Korea's official Korean Central News Agency didn't comment on the report.

– A ceasefire between Boko Haram and the Nigerian government was expected to lead to the liberation of more than 200 school girls kidnapped by the militants six months ago. That was not the case. The Telegraph reports the girls are still being held by the Islamic extremist group, and it's not clear when they will be released. Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau has said the girls will only be released if the government swaps them for detained militants.

– Christian Bale has dropped out of the Steve Jobs biopic due to "much deliberation and conflicting feelings," according to the Hollywood Reporter. The Batman star had been in talks to play the Apple founder, but "after much deliberation and conflicting feelings," he has decided not to take the role, according to a statement from Jobs' production company. No word yet on who will replace Bale.

– Banksy's real name is Paul Horner, and the artist's publicist has confirmed that a story making the rounds on the National Report is a hoax. The story claims that the 34-year-old is being held "without bail" on charges of vandalism, conspiracy, racketeering, and counterfeiting after a raid on his London studio, the Independent reports. The quotes that accompany the story are exactly the same as those in Banksy's official bio.

– The long-awaited Apple Watch could be out by the end of March. That's according to 9to5Mac.com, which cites "multiple sources" who say the device is on track to ship by the end of March. The site also reports that Apple is planning a "comprehensive testing program" to make sure the watch is up to snuff before it goes on sale.

– A Massachusetts priest says he was dead for 48 minutes before he was revived with the help of a defibrillator, but he's standing by his claim that God is a woman, the Boston Globe reports. Father John O'neal says he went to heaven and met God, who was "a warm and comforting motherly figure." He was pronounced dead at a hospital in Springfield, Mass., on Feb. 3, but he was revived with the help of the defibrillator he was carrying, which was set to go off when his heart stopped beating, the AP reports. O'neal, who says he's a devout Catholic, says he believes God told him he was dead and that his body was taken to heaven and he was greeted by a woman he calls his "sister." "I said to her, 'I'm a priest, and I'm here to serve you,'" he says. "She took my hand and said, 'I am a woman,' and I said, 'Yes, I am a woman.' She took my hand and said, 'I am God.' I said, 'Yes, I am a woman.' She took my hand and said, 'I am God.' I said, '

– Cuban dissidents and Cuban-American media are reporting that Havana is plagued with the most serious rumors in months that former dictator Fidel Castro has died, after the one-year anniversary of Castro's last public appearance transpired without fanfare on Thursday. Castro's last public appearance occurred without fanfare on Thursday, the one-year anniversary of Castro's last public appearance. Cuban dissidents and Cuban-American media are reporting that Havana is plagued with the most serious rumors in months that former dictator Fidel Castro has died, after the one-year anniversary of Castro's last public appearance transpired without fanfare.

– A US airstrike killed the leader of a Somali terrorist group Monday, the Pentagon confirmed Friday. Al-Shabab head Ahmed Abdi Godane—who was considered one of the world's most wanted men—was the 'the principal target' of the attack, officials said Tuesday when they announced the strike.

– An Italian nun was rushed to the hospital with stomach pains—and soon after, she gave birth to a baby girl. The unnamed nun from the all-female convent in Macerata didn't realize she was pregnant until she was taken to the hospital for an ultrasound, reports the Local via Corriere Adriatico.

– First #bendgate, now #hairgate. Twitter users are complaining that the new iPhone 6 causes them to lose their beards and hair, the Los Angeles Times reports. "If you buy an iPhone 6, you better be totally bald #HairGate," tweeted @redletter. Users are using hashtags like #beardgate and #hairgate to voice their complaints.

– Casey Dean and Eduard Nitz were just 14 years old when they stopped off at a McDonald's in Adelaide, Australia, to pick up a Quarter Pounder with cheese they'd bought for another kid. The kid never showed up, so they didn't eat the burger. "We're pretty sure it's the oldest burger in the world," Dean tells ABC News Australia. The men have since become men, and the burger is now 20 years old.

– Libya's prime minister says a plane that went missing over the weekend may have been brought down by a "terrorist act." Seif al-Islam Gadhafi made the comment in an interview with al-Jazeera, a day after the crash of an Airbus A320 en route from Paris to Tripoli. The plane is believed to have been brought down by a rocket-propelled grenade fired from a hole in the ground at Tripoli's airport. The prime minister says the plane may have been brought down by "a terrorist act or an accident," but he didn't give any further details. He said the investigation is ongoing. The plane is believed to have been brought down by a rocket-propelled grenade fired from a hole in the ground at Tripoli's airport.

– Rumors have been swirling that the Batmobile from Batman V. Superman: Dawn of Justice may have been stolen, but it turns out they were just as ridiculous as they sounded, reports the Detroit Free Press. It turns out that the movie's production company, Warner Bros., has no idea what happened to the iconic car, which was last seen in action in a scene from the third Batman movie.

– British intelligence has identified a man believed to have been involved in the beheading of James Foley as 23-year-old Abdel-Majed Abdel Bary, also known as Jihadi John, reports the Guardian. Bary, a former rapper who left his London home last year to fight for the Islamic State in Syria, is believed to be from the same London suburb as Foley's killer. He has an English accent and was photographed wearing a black hood and military camouflage earlier this month.

– Daiane DeJesus is a 29-year-old native of Brazil who now lives in California with her husband, Messias Credido, and their two children. She's also a former porn star who now runs a wildly popular YouTube channel called DC Toys Collector, which has more than 5 million subscribers and is reportedly the highest-paid YouTube creator with an estimated $5 million in earnings in 2014, the Daily Mail reports. It's not clear why DeJesus has kept her identity a secret, but the New York Daily News notes that her channel's success "could explain why the mega-successful Youtuber has chosen to stay anonymous despite months-long digging from numerous media outlets covering her channel's surprising popularity."

– "It is with this issue that Muslims here in America are obligated to find a way to solve conflicts and disputes according to the principles of Islamic Law and its legal heritage of fairness and justice in a manner that is reasonable and cost effective." So reads the website for Breitbart Texas, which reports on the existence of an Islamic tribunal in Texas that will make judgments in accordance with Sharia law. “It is with this issue that Muslims here in America are obligated to find a way to solve conflicts and disputes according to the principles of Islamic Law and its legal heritage of fairness and justice in a manner that is reasonable and cost effective,” the site continues. The tribunal would not do things like cutting off hands of offenders, but would focus on civil Sharia law.

– In India, government jobs are considered to be for life, and one executive engineer was recently fired after nearly 25 years on the job—even though he'd last appeared for work in December 1990. AK Verma, an executive engineer at the Central Public Works Department, was fired after last appearing for work in December 1990. The Times of India reports that in a country where government jobs are considered to be for life, Verma argued that his government pension was too low and that he should be allowed to retire early. "I am not a rich man," he said. "I am a poor man's man. I am not rich. I am not a rich woman's man. I am not a rich man's son. I am not a rich daughter-in-law. I am not a rich brother-in-law. I am not a brother-in-law. I am not a brother-in-law. I am not a brother-in-law. I am not a brother-in-law. I am not a brother-in-law. I am not a brother-in-law. I am not a brother-in-law. I am not a brother-in-law. I am not a brother

– A TV weatherman was caught with his trousers down—literally—when a news report cut to him "using the bathroom." NBC Nightly anchorman Lester Holt in the New York studio cut to an outdoor weather forecast, but his man in the field was busy having a wee in the bushes. Weatherman Mike Seidel obviously thought he had enough time to have a quick tinkle before presenting his segment, but when a cameraman shouted for him to look lively he just turned round, muttering, "why?" The video (WARNING: LANGUAGE) is in the gallery.

– A picture of what appears to be a penis-shaped graffiti drawing of a Bugatti Veyron has gone viral after it was posted on Reddit this week. The image, which is thought to have been taken in Seattle, prompted a mixed response from online users, the Independent reports. One person said: "The spray paint is almost an improvement," while another wrote: "If you can afford a Bugatti, you can afford to park it in a secure lot." But others condemned the graffiti artist for vandalism. "This hurts me to look at. You never f***ed me," said one Reddit user.

– An Australian man visiting Bali says he felt a "searing sensation" around his abdomen before a spider crawled all the way up to his sternum, the Age reports. Dylan Thomas Bunbury says he was on vacation when he felt a "searing sensation" around his abdomen near his old appendix scar. He says he went to his doctor, who told him there was a spider in his body and that he needed to see a specialist. The doctor confirmed the spider was indeed in his body and that it had crawled all the way up to his sternum. Thomas says he didn't realize the spider was there until he woke up the next day. "I was in shock," he tells the Age. "I was inconsolable." According to the Sydney Morning Herald, there have been no reports of spiders crawling up to people's sternum in the past.

– Amazon is getting into the streaming-video game. The company will launch an ad-supported video service early next year, reports the New York Post, which cites "sources." The service will be separate from Amazon's $99-a-year Prime membership, which includes a video service.

– Tom Brokaw wants Brian Williams' "head on a platter" at NBC, sources tell the New York Post. "He is making a lot of noise at NBC that a lesser journalist or producer would have been immediately fired or suspended for a false report," one source says. Williams has admitted that he was in a helicopter that was hit by a rocket-propelled grenade while reporting on the Iraq war in 2003. "He is making a lot of noise at NBC that a lesser journalist or producer would have been immediately fired or suspended for a false report," the source says. "He is not going to be suspended or reprimanded in any way," an NBC employee tells the Post.

– When Jess Smith was nine months old, she filmed a monster in the sky and didn't tell anyone—until now. The 19-year-old is a first-year college student at Canterbury Christ Church University in England, and she says she didn't tell anyone because "I thought I may as well tell them as I’m going to be spending the next three years with that monster." Smith says she filmed the part when she was 9 months old and didn't tell anyone because she didn't think anyone would believe her. "I thought I may as well tell them as I’m going to be spending the next three years with that monster," she tells the Telegraph.

– Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, the man believed to have opened fire at Canada's Parliament yesterday before being shot dead by security forces, was a 32-year-old Canadian citizen born in 1982, CBS News reports. The network says Zehaf-Bibeau's name is in the city of Montreal's court database three times, and he has been arrested twice for drug possession. "Arrested twice for drug possession in Feb 2004 (marijuana and PCP)," CBS reporter Domenic Fazioli says. Witnesses say Zehaf-Bibeau was wearing a black coat with blue jeans throughout the shootings, while his weapon of choice was a double-barrel

– A Canadian-Israeli woman who joined Kurdish fighters against the Islamic State has been kidnapped by the militants, Israeli media are reporting. Gill Rosenberg, a 41-year-old mother of two, was seized in northern Iraq on Saturday, according to the Jerusalem Post and Ynet, Israel's largest and most popular news website. Rosenberg had traveled to Iraq from her home in Israel earlier this month to join Kurdish fighters against the Islamic State. She was seized near the Iraqi border.

– The gunman who attacked Canada's Parliament and a soldier standing guard outside it before he was fatally shot has been identified as Michael Zehaf Bibeau, a 32-year-old from Quebec, the CBC reports. Police say Zehaf Bibeau, who used to work for the Canadian embassy in Washington, DC, had a criminal record and served time in prison in Canada for drug-related offenses. He was also convicted of assault with a weapon and mischief in the US in 2006, according to the Canadian Press. Police say Zehaf Bibeau used to live in Ottawa, where he used to own a building that overlooked Parliament, the National Post reports.

– If you thought NBC meteorologist Mike Seidel peed in the snow on live TV last night, well, we have some bad news for you: He didn't. In fact, he did not "write his name in the snow" in urine, says Brian Williams, who took time out of last night's broadcast to set the record straight. Seidel was reporting on a winter storm in North Carolina when he lost communication with the station, so he took his gloves off and dialed his phone, Williams explained. (Some reports said he peed in the snow and wrote his name in urine.) He did not, however, "write his name in the snow" in urine, Williams says.

– A 38-year-old woman accused of cheating on her husband was savagely beaten by a group of women in broad daylight as passers-by watched. It's the latest in a string of copycat attacks in China, including one a month ago when a half-naked woman was stamped on by a stiletto-wearing rival. Locals say such scraps go ignored because there is an acceptance that love cheats are deserving of a beating having caused a man to cheat on his partner. In this latest incident, accused Lin Yao Li was ambushed by four women as she walked home from shops in Puyang, in eastern China.

– A worker at a Texas turkey farm has tested positive for Ebola, making him the first person in the US to be diagnosed with the disease this year. The worker, a male who recently traveled to West Africa, is under quarantine and not showing symptoms, the Texas Department of State Health Services said in a statement. The department said it is working with the CDC to identify and track down anyone else who may have come in contact with the worker, the AP reports. More than 250,000 holiday turkeys have been affected by the disease at the Texas turkey farm, according to health officials.

– ISIS released a graphic video today showing the beheading of American journalist James Foley, and two US officials tell the AP that they believe it is indeed him. The video also shows the execution of Steven Sotloff, a US aid worker who was kidnapped in Syria earlier this year. Foley's family confirmed his death in a statement posted on a webpage that was created to rally support for his release.

– ISIS militants in Syria say that US-led coalition air strikes have killed Kayla Jean Mueller, an American aid worker who was being held hostage by the group, the Telegraph reports. According to social media sites used by the group, the 26-year-old was killed in coalition air strikes on the ISIS stronghold of Raqqa, a city in northern Syria.

– Two Italian brothers have pulled in a monster of a fish—and now they've got a new Guinness World Record to add to their collection. The brothers, Dario and Dino Ferrari, pulled in a 348-pound, 11-foot-long, 27-inch-wide catfish on Feb. 19 in the province of Mantua, the Telegraph reports. The previous record-holder was a 344-pound, 15-inch-wide catfish caught in the same area in 2013. The brothers, who live in the town of Cremona, say they caught the catfish while fishing along the river Po, the Local reports. "It's the first time we've ever caught a catfish that big," says Dario. "It's also the first time we've caught a catfish that long." The brothers, who also claim a world record for catching the longest freshwater fish, plan to release the catfish into the river next week.

– Tiger Woods' agent responded Monday to inflammatory allegations made by little-known pro Dan Olsen, who said on the Mad Dog in the Morning radio show last week that Woods is serving a suspension for a failed drug test. Woods' agent responded Monday to inflammatory allegations made by little-known pro Dan Olsen, who said on the Mad Dog in the Morning radio show last week that Woods is serving a suspension for a failed drug test. Woods' agent responded Monday to inflammatory allegations made by little-known pro Dan Olsen, who said on the Mad Dog in the Morning radio show last week that Woods is serving a suspension for a failed drug test.

– A video purporting to show Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau laughing off reports that the Nigerian government has reached a ceasefire with the terrorist group over the kidnapping of more than 200 girls from a school in the town of Chibok has set off a wave of outrage in the country and beyond. The video was posted to YouTube by a man claiming to be a member of the militant group, the BBC reports. In the video, Shekau is seen laughing off reports that the Nigerian government has reached a ceasefire with Boko Haram and that the girls kidnapped six months ago are close to being released. "We have reached a deal with the government to release the girls," Shekau says in the video. "The girls who were kidnapped in Chibok are still in the hands of our Allah and the government has assured us that they will be released soon." A spokesman for Nigeria's Department of State Services tells the BBC that the government has not yet received a response from Boko Haram on the video.

– The Islamic State has been flying fighter jets over areas it has captured in Syria for the first time, and now the group is training its pilots to do the same, Reuters reports. According to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, three Iraqi pilots have been training ISIS fighters to fly three captured F-16 fighter jets. "This is the first time in the history of the Islamic State that they are training their pilots to fly fighter jets," a spokesman for the monitoring group tells Reuters.

– Taylor Lianne Chandler, the 21-year-old girlfriend of swimmer Michael Phelps, has revealed in a Facebook post that she was born a boy. "David Roy Fitch was born a boy," she writes. "I went on testosterone blockers and had my name changed and then, in my early twenties, underwent corrective surgery to get rid of my male genitalia." She calls herself "humbled" and says she's "grateful for all the love and support" she's received.

– A doctor in Kansas City, Mo., has tested negative for Ebola after being exposed to the virus while treating a patient in West Africa, the Kansas City Star reports. Dr. Craig Spencer, the first person in the US to have tested positive for the disease, showed symptoms consistent with Ebola after returning from Liberia, where he had been treating a patient with the disease. Spencer was admitted to a hospital Saturday and tested negative for the disease Sunday. The World Health Organization has since confirmed that Spencer was not infected with Ebola. Spencer's wife and two children have been placed in quarantine as a precaution.

– Apple is working on a new version of its MacBook Air, 9to5Mac reports, citing "sources inside Apple." The site says the new device will have a 12-inch screen and be about the size of the 11-inch MacBook Air with reduced bezels on all sides. " Possibly even cooler than that is the computer is said to be an actual thing, not like the iPad Pro we keep hearing about," 9to5Mac writes. "The new-look MacBook is also lighter than the existing MacBook Air," the site adds. " Aside from sporting a larger screen and lighter design, there are several other interesting nuances, here."

– The Islamic State terrorist known as "Jihadi John" has been identified as Mohammed Emwazi from London, the Telegraph reports. Emwazi, who is believed to be 26 or 27 years old, grew up in west London and was known to British security services as " Mohammed Emwazi," according to Sky News. He is believed to have served in the UK armed forces. Emwazi was born in Kuwait but moved to the UK when he was eight years old, according to the BBC. He is believed to have been radicalized in the UK by extremists. ISIS has claimed Emwazi, who is believed to have killed at least four people in Iraq and Syria, is a "Jihadi John."

– Is the Apple Watch water resistant? Apple CEO Tim Cook reportedly told employees at an Apple Store in Berlin that he wears his watch "even in the shower," according to a report on French site iGen picked up by AppleInsider. The problem is that the report is hearsay, and we don't really know which version of "water resistant" Apple has come up with.

– The 18-time Olympic gold medal-winning swimmer's girlfriend has revealed that she is intersex—a fact she has not previously revealed to Phelps, the New York Daily News reports. In a Facebook post, Michael Phelps' longtime girlfriend, Nicole Johnson, says she was born "intersex" to a man and a woman. "I'm taking this time to be open and honest," Johnson writes. "It's been an amazing journey and I'm glad I've been able to share it with you." Johnson says she and Phelps, who has a 15-month-old baby together, are "in love" and "in love with each other for the rest of our lives." She says she has no plans to come out to Phelps.

– If you're using iOS 8 to reset your iPhone settings, you may want to stop reading now. According to MacRumors, a bug in the latest version of Apple's mobile operating system could delete all of your documents saved in iCloud. As you reset your settings on your iPhone, Apple says "no data or media will be deleted," but people are reporting that the reset wipes all of their iCloud Drive documents.

– The Internet is aflutter with rumors about the release date of the much-anticipated Star Wars: The Force Awakens, but one thing is certain: It won't be coming to theaters until December 18, 2015. That's according to the Hollywood Reporter, which cites "multiple sources." The original release date was set at Dec. 18, 2015.

– The World Health Organization said Tuesday that there has been no reported case of Ebola in Iraq, despite reports to the contrary in Iraqi media in the past week, Reuters reports. The WHO said in a statement that "despite the recent media reports, there have been no reported cases of Ebola in Iraq, and there is no reason to believe that this is the case." Iraqi media reported last week that four people had tested positive for Ebola, but the country's health ministry denied that and said it was working to contain the outbreak.

– Canada's Parliament sergeant-at-arms, Kevin Vickers, is being hailed as a hero today after reportedly shooting and killing a gunman inside the building, the Telegraph reports. "This is Canadian Sergeant-at-Arms Kevin Vickers who reportedly shot & killed one assailant," tweeted Prime Minister Stephen Harper. "Ex-Mountie. Still got it."

– In the wake of the Charlie Hebdo terror attack in Paris, a street artist has offered up a tribute that's gaining traction on social media. The image shows a giant balloon with the words "Je Suis Charlie" (I Am Charlie) over a giant image of the magazine's cover with the words "Je Suis Charlie" (I am Charlie). The image has been shared more than 50,000 times as of this writing. It was apparently created by Banksy, who tells the Guardian, "I wanted to show my support for the French people and the people of Charlie Hebdo." The image has been shared on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter.

– It's not every night that a pizza delivery driver gets a $2,000 tip. But that's what happened to one in Ann Arbor, Mich., on Thursday. Pizza House delivery manager Brian LeFevre said he received a call Thursday morning from a man who said they wanted one pizza delivered to the Sheraton Hotel in Ann Arbor. "They said they wanted it at 2:20pm on the dot," LeFevre said. I gave it to our delivery driver and he went down there and took it to the front desk."

– If you've tried to use the Tor anonymity tool to keep your identity hidden from prying eyes, you're in for a rude surprise from Comcast: The company has blocked access to the tool, Gawker reports. "Users who try to use anonymity, or cover themselves up on the Internet, are usually doing things that aren’t so-to-speak legal; we have the right to terminate, fine, or suspend your account at anytime due to you violating the rules—Do you have any other questions?" a Comcast rep said in a transcript of a conversation between the customer and the company obtained by Gawker. The NSA has been using Tor to help it gather information on foreign spies, and Comcast's move is likely an effort to block further use of the tool, Ars Technica notes. "Users who try to use anonymity, or cover themselves up on the Internet, are usually doing things that aren’t so-to-speak legal; we have the right to terminate, fine, or suspend your account at anytime due to you violating the rules," the rep said. "Do you have any other questions?"

– KFC is getting into the marijuana business in a big way in Colorado. The fast-food chain has gotten an Occupational Business License to sell marijuana to employees at its restaurants in the state, reports the Denver Post. The move is a way for the company to get a leg up on competitors McDonald's and Burger King in the legal marijuana market, notes the Wall Street Journal.

– ISIS released a new video today in which it claims American-made weapons it says were intended for Kurdish forces fighting the militants actually ended up in the hands of the militants, the New York Times reports. In the video, the group says one bundle of weapons dropped by the US was meant for the Kurds, but it ended up in the hands of the militants. The US says it's working to figure out how the weapons ended up in the hands of ISIS.

– The next generation of Apple's MacBook Air will come with a Retina display, according to a report at 9to5mac.com. The site also claims that Apple will be releasing a 12-inch MacBook Air with a Retina display later this year.

– The FBI has identified the second American killed in ISIS-controlled territory in Syria as 19-year-old aid worker Peter Kassig, a US citizen who joined the militant group last year. Kassig, who grew up in Ohio, was one of the first American fighters to join the Islamic State, which seized control of large parts of Iraq and Syria last year. He was killed in the early hours of Sunday near the border with Syria, reports the AP. A spokesman for the FBI's Cincinnati office tells the AP that Kassig was one of several aid workers killed in the fighting. He says investigators are still trying to determine whether other Americans have been killed. Kassig was working for Doctors Without Borders in Raqqa, the capital of the Islamic State's self-proclaimed capital, Raqqa, when he was killed.

– A devoted fish owner in Norfolk, England, took his constipated fish to the veterinarian, only to learn that a lump near its backside was the cause. A devoted fish owner in Norfolk, England, took his constipated fish to the veterinarian, only to learn that a lump near its backside was the cause. A devoted fish owner in Norfolk, England, took his constipated fish to the veterinarian, only to learn that a lump near its backside was the cause. A devoted fish owner in Norfolk, England, took his constipated fish to the veterinarian, only to learn that a lump near its backside was the cause.

– The Secret Service has beefed up security at the White House in the wake of the fence-jumper incident, with Secret Service agents and Capitol Police officers patrolling the area around the White House, the Washington Post reports. According to the Post's sources, the increased security is due to the fact that former Navy SEAL Omar Gonzalez, who scaled the White House fence three times in less than 24 hours, may have been planning to harm either President Obama or members of his family.

– New York City will no longer arrest people for possessing small amounts of marijuana, sources tell BuzzFeed. Instead, offenders will be issued violation summonses that will require them to appear in court and pay a fine. An official with one of the city's five district attorneys says the change "is happening."

– In what would be the first known use of chemical weapons by the Islamic State, the group is believed to have attacked Kurdish fighters in the northern Syrian city of Kobani, reports the New York Times. The Times spoke to several journalists on the ground who say they're aware of reports of a chemical attack, but that doctors don't have the necessary equipment to properly diagnose victims. The victims said they had difficulty breathing, and many had burns on their skin, teary eyes, and swollen lips.

– In the wake of the Ray Rice controversy, the NFL and ESPN have agreed to a joint investigation into the league's handling of domestic-abuse scandals, the AP reports. ESPN will conduct its own probe, while the NFL will conduct its own, Esquire reports. The investigation will look into how the league handled the cases of Rice and other players, as well as whether there's any truth to claims that the league knew about the abuse before the games in which they were involved. The investigation will include interviews with current and former players, as well as experts in the fields of criminal justice, law enforcement, and sports medicine.

– Pope Francis has a message for all the animals in the world: "paradise is open to all of God's creatures," he told a young boy in St. Peter's Square last week as he consoled a boy whose dog had died. The pontiff's comments were met with applause from animal-rights groups, the New York Times reports. "paradise is open to all of God's creatures," he told the boy. The Humane Society called them a "remarkable repudiation" of conservative Catholic theology.

– At least 11 planes are missing from a Tripoli airport in Libya, but there's no evidence they've been stolen or diverted to other countries, according to a fact-check report by the Washington Post. The missing planes include three Boeing 737s and two Airbus A321s, but there's no evidence they've been stolen or diverted to other countries, according to the report.

– The Islamic State militant known as "Jihadi John" has been identified by British security services as Mohammed Emwazi, a British national from London, the Telegraph reports. Emwazi, who has appeared in several ISIS beheading videos, is believed to have been born in Britain but has lived in Syria for the past few years. He is believed to be in his mid-20s. British security services have not confirmed the identity of the man in the black balaclava who has seemed to have been beheaded several foreign hostages in ISIS videos.

– If you're willing to shell out $7.1 million, you can live on a 62-acre island in Sweden that's owned by one of the richest athletes on the planet. That's right: Tiger Woods is selling his private island near Stockholm, the New York Daily News reports. According to the Wall Street Journal, the 62-acre island, which is on a golf course but has its own private beach, is "one of the most beautiful places on Earth." The property, which has been owned by Woods since 2009, is "one of the most exclusive and private islands in the world," the Journal reports. According to the Journal, the property includes a private beach, tennis court, private pool, sauna, lounge, restaurant, and stables. It's also "one of the few private islands in the world with direct access to the ocean," the Journal reports. Woods, who is expected to make his 2015 debut later this month, is listed as the buyer.

– The Department of Homeland Security has weighed in on the conspiracy theory that ISIS fighters tried to cross the US-Mexico border—and it says it's "categorically false" and "not supported by any 'credible intelligence,'" Politico reports. According to the right-wing media conspiracy theory, which has been making the rounds in recent weeks, ISIS fighters have been captured at the border. But in a statement, the Department of Homeland Security says the rumor is "categorically false" and "not supported by any 'credible intelligence,'" Politico reports.

– It's that time of year again: time for yet another hoax about a so-called "planetary alignment" on Jan. 4 that will cause partial weightlessness and decrease gravity for five minutes. The hoax has been around since the 1970s, when British astronomer Patrick Moore told a radio audience that the alignment would result in a gravitational pull that would make people lighter at 9:47am local time, reports Time. The Huffington Post rounds up more fake planetary alignment stories here.

– A video that purports to show the moment Michael Brown was shot dead by police has been verified by a video texting service, reports the Erik Wemple blog at the St. Louis Post-Dispatch. A rep for the service, called Glide, says that because the service is "the only messaging application using streaming video technology," each message is simultaneously recorded and transmitted so the exact time can be verified to the second. "In this case, the video in question was created at 12:02:14pm CDT on Saturday, August 9th," writes Chaim Haas. "In this case, the video in question was created at 12:02:14pm CDT on Saturday, August 9th."

– A soldier standing guard at Canada's National War Memorial was shot to death today by a gunman who then stormed the building and tried to attack other soldiers inside, police say. The soldier, identified as 24-year-old Nathan Cirillo, was shot in the chest and died later in the hospital, the Ottawa Citizen reports. The gunman, identified as Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, then fled in a car and was shot dead by police. Police say they don't believe there is any connection between Zehaf-Bibeau, who was shot dead by police, and other attackers. Cirillo was a reservist with the Canadian Armed Forces, the Telegraph reports.

– Judd Nelson, best known for his role as John Bender in The Breakfast Club, has been found dead at age 55, TMZ reports. Police responded to a 911 call for an unconscious man at Nelson's Los Angeles condo last night and carried out his body on a stretcher.

– Conal O'Rourke says he was fired from his job as a Comcast customer service rep because he complained about the company's billing practices—and now he's suing Comcast and its controller for defamation, the Philadelphia Inquirer reports. According to O'Rourke's lawsuit, controller Lawrence Salva told an executive at PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) that O'Rourke's complaints about Comcast's billing practices were "unfair" and "disparaging" to the company. O'Rourke says Salva, who used to be an executive at PWC's Philadelphia office, went on to tell other PricewaterhouseCoopers employees that O'Rourke's complaints were "unfair" and "disparaging" to the company. O'Rourke says he was fired after he complained to Comcast's Philadelphia office about the company's billing practices, which he says violated federal regulations on overbilling and poor service. He says he was told he'd be fired if he didn't resign by Oct. 14, and he set a deadline for Comcast to respond to his demands, which included a full apology and a monetary settlement. Instead, the company issued a half-assed apology, and O'Rourke filed his lawsuit two days after the deadline.

– A photo showing how Chinese workers manipulate the App Store rankings has gone viral in China, the Verge reports. The photo shows a worker standing in front of a rack containing hundreds of iPhones. "It's Hard Being a Top App Worker," reads the headline on a Chinese micro-blog that shared the photo. "The exposé, shown in the picture, displays a 'Top App list worker' in their work place, which features a simple shelf containing hundreds of iPhone 5Cs."

– ISIS militants tricked a mother into eating meat from her dead son's body, according to a report in the Telegraph. The mother, who has not been named, says she went to a hospital in northern Iraq last week to collect her son, who had died of a heart attack, when she was told he had been killed by militants. Instead of taking her to the hospital, she says she was taken to a house in Mosul—the Islamic State's de facto capital—where she was told her son's body had been cooked and she could eat it. "They told me the body was cooked and I could eat it," the mother says. "I couldn't believe it." She says the militants told her they would kill her son if she didn't accept their demands. "They said if I didn't accept their demands, they would kill me," the mother says. "They told me they would kill my son if I didn't accept their demands." She says the militants told her they would kill her husband if she didn't accept their demands, but she refused because she didn't want to give up her son to the militants. "They told me they would kill my husband if I didn't accept their

– A homeless man who became a YouTube sensation after he spent a $100 donation on food for his beggar friends has received a surprise meal, makeover, and hotel stay in a new video released amid claims it is a hoax. The short film posted by'serial prankster' Josh Paler Lin shows Thomas, a man living on the streets of California, being taken to a sushi restaurant before staying in a hotel room complete with a hot tub on Christmas Eve. After a night's sleep the filmmaker then takes him to a hairdressers for a haircut and then to a mall where he buys a new suit.

– At least 80 Palestinian families have been evacuated from their homes in the Gaza Valley due to flooding, Al Jazeera reports. According to the Gaza Ministry of Interior, more than 40 homes were flooded and 80 families are currently holed up in shelters.

– JJ Abrams isn't happy about leaked photos from the set of Star Wars: Episode VII, so he's asked Disney to push the release date up a few months, iKwiz reports. The director made the request while addressing the 2015 Visual Effects Society Awards, according to iKwiz. It's not clear when the movie will be out, but the site states that Disney is taking the request "very seriously."

– Apple's first major foray into the smartwatch market isn't going so well. Sources tell the Wall Street Journal that the company has asked its suppliers in Asia to make between 5 million and 6 million units of the Apple Watch in the first quarter of this year. That's less than 1% of the watch's total production capacity, but it's enough to make up for the fact that the company hasn't been able to keep up with demand. The Journal's sources say the watch is expected to be released in April.

– eBay is looking for an engineer to design and implement "elegant solutions" for the Apple Watch "that will complement our core iOS eBay app," according to a job ad spotted by AppleInsider. The ad was originally posted to eBay's careers webpage in November, but was spotted by LinkedIn this week. The company's New Technology Group, which employs more than 200 engineers in product development in Portland, Ore., is looking for an engineer who "will design and implement elegant solutions for the Apple Watch that will complement our core iOS eBay app," according to the ad.

– The Department of Homeland Security says a congressman's claim that at least 10 ISIS fighters were captured trying to cross the Mexico border into Texas is "categorically false." Rep. Duncan Hunter, a Republican from California, told Fox News that he learned of the story from the Border Patrol, saying "they aren't flying B1 bombers bombing American cities, but they are going to be bombing American cities coming across from Mexico." He said the Border Patrol "caught them," but "you know there's going to be dozens more that did not get caught by the Border Patrol." A senior Department of Homeland Security official tells the Los Angeles Times the claim is "categorically false."

– It's the kind of thing you don't want to hear about during the dog days of summer—a condom flavored like pumpkin spice, of course. Durex, the maker of such condoms, has confirmed to the New York Daily News that it's not actually a pumpkin spice condom. Instead, it's a regular condom that's been tweaked to look like a pumpkin spice latte, complete with a pumpkin-shaped penis. (It's not the first time a pumpkin-themed condom has made the rounds.)

– It's official: Fidel Castro is dead, reports the AP. The Cuban government confirmed the 80-year-old's death to the country's official news agency early Saturday, though it didn't provide any further details. The news comes after President Raul Castro publicly confirmed his brother's death for the first time. Castro hasn't been seen in public in months.

– If you're using the Tor browser for Internet anonymity, you may want to stop reading on. Comcast says it's not denying service to users of the anonymity-boosting browser, the Los Angeles Times reports. In a blog post, the company says it "is not asking customers to stop using Tor, or any other browser for that matter." In fact, "We have no policy against Tor, or any other browser or software," Comcast says. The company says customers are free to use any other browser or app on Comcast's Internet service.

– A Kansas City apartment building was sealed off Saturday when a man became seriously ill, WIBW reports. The man's Kansas City apartment building was sealed off when the man became seriously ill. According to KMBC, the man is not being treated for ebola.

– Mexican authorities have discovered six hidden graves that may contain the bodies of more than 40 university students who went missing a week ago after clashing with local police in the violent state of Guerrero. The semiofficial National Human Rights Commission said Sunday that experts will conduct DNA tests in an attempt to identify bodies found in the graves. It was not yet clear how many bodies were present. Mexican police enter La Parota colony on the outskirts of Iguala, Mexico, where a mass grave was found Saturday. (European Pressphoto Agency) Guerrero state Health Minister Lazaro Mazon said nine bodies, burned beyond recognition, were recovered from the muddy grave.

– The NYPD will stop arresting people for low-level marijuana possession and will instead simply issue a summons, sources tell the New York Daily News. Mayor de Blasio and the NYPD are prepared to initiate a change in the law that will allow them to issue a summons rather than arrest people for low-level marijuana possession, sources say. Police will stop arresting people for low-level marijuana possession and will instead simply issue a summons, sources say.

– A man wanted on outstanding warrants in Newfoundland and Labrador has turned himself in to police. Rodney Constantine, 29, had told police via a Facebook post on Sunday that he would attend headquarters Monday morning.

– A man in Macedonia has had his penis reattached after he cut it off with a razor blade in an act of revenge for being dumped by his girlfriend. – A South American nun says she didn't even know she was pregnant when she was rushed to the hospital with severe stomach pains—and ended up giving birth to a baby boy. The cloistered nun, who belonged to an order in Macerata, in the eastern Italian region of Le Marche, says she was supposed to be pregnant when she arrived at the convent in June, the Daily Mail reports. She says she didn't realize she was pregnant until she was admitted to the hospital, where she gave birth to a baby boy.

– Macklemore is known for his charitable work and his willingness to help those in need, but he may have just joined ISIS. That's according to a series of fake tweets that surfaced Thursday, the New York Daily News reports. The tweets claimed the rapper had joined the terrorist group, along with the hashtags #MacklemoreJoinedISIS and #ISISEroticism. The backlash was swift. "In shock that #MacklemoreJoinedISIS I think I'm in denial," one person tweeted. – Apple is holding an event in San Francisco today to announce new products, and one name in particular is getting a lot of attention: the Apple Watch. The Wall Street Journal reports that the watch is expected to be the main focus of the event, which is being held on the same day Daylight Savings Time starts in the US. The event is being held at the Re/code tech conference, which is being held at Apple's headquarters in San Francisco.

– The wife of a British aid worker being held hostage by ISIS released a statement on Tuesday—the second within a week—following new video put out by the terror group where they threaten another British hostage. The wife of British aid worker Alan Henning, who is being held by the Islamic State of Iraq and al-Sham, or ISIS, released a statement on Tuesday—the second within a week—following new video put out by the terror group where they threaten another British hostage, reports the Telegraph. "My husband was a taxi driver before he went to Syria in December 2012," says the statement from Barbara Henning. "He was taken hostage while on his way back to his base after completing his work. We have no idea when he was taken or how he got into the country, but we know he is a vulnerable man and we are all very worried for his safety." – Tiger Woods has been suspended for a month from the PGA Tour for failing a drug test, according to one of his fellow golfers. Dan Olsen told a radio station that his sources are telling him that Woods is currently serving a one-month suspension for failing a drug test, Deadspin reports. "Tour players that are exempt," Olsen said.

– Six months after more than 200 girls were kidnapped from their school in Chibok, Nigeria, the country's military says it has agreed a ceasefire with Boko Haram, the BBC reports. The country's chief of defense staff, Alex Badeh, says the ceasefire will hold until the girls are released. Boko Haram has not made a public statement on the ceasefire, but the group has been fighting an insurgency since 2009, with some 2,000 civilians reportedly killed this year.

– Apple is working on a way to extend the battery life of its smartwatch, reports 9to5mac.com. The new feature would be called "Power Reserve," and it would allow the watch to run on low energy while only displaying the time. The site notes that the watch's battery life is expected to last only a day, putting it at the bottom of the pack for smartwatches.

– Police in Carlisle, England, are on the hunt for a middle-aged man who they say has been slapping people on the head if they've sneezed. In what they describe as "very unusual behavior," the man smacked a woman around the head after she sneezed on Monday and then slapped an 82-year-old woman around the head after she did the same on Tuesday, the Daily Mail reports. Police say the man is in his mid-to-late 50s and was wearing a baseball cap.

– The Pentagon says US officials have confirmed the death of the leader of the al-Shabaab terror group in a US airstrike on Monday. The Pentagon says US officials have confirmed the death of the leader of the al-Shabaab terror group in a US airstrike on Monday. The Pentagon says US officials have confirmed the death of the leader of the al-Shabaab terror group in a US airstrike on Monday.

– The BBC has identified the Islamic State terrorist known as Jihadi John as Mohammed Emwazi, and the Washington Post says Emwazi was killed in a drone strike last week. The BBC tweeted a court document from a case involving another suspected militant and British Home Secretary Theresa May, in which Emwazi is named as an associate. The BBC says another "core member" of Emwazi's group, Bilal Berjawi, was killed in a drone strike in Somalia.

– The price of a new Apple Watch may be on the rise. Citing an anonymous source, the French website iGen.Fr reports that stainless steel versions of the Apple Watch will retail for $500 while the gold models may retail for as high as $5,000. The report is based on an anonymous source.

– The FBI has questioned a man who says he recorded gunfire at the time Michael Brown was shot by Ferguson, Mo., police on Aug. 9, the man's attorney tells CNN. The attorney says his client, who has not been named, told the FBI he was on his cell phone recording gunfire at the time of Brown's shooting by Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson. The attorney says the FBI has also asked the man what he was doing at the time of the shooting and whether he had a cell phone with him. – Mexican authorities say none of the 28 bodies found in a mass grave near the town of Iguala in the southern state of Guerrero belongs to the 43 students who went missing on Sept. 26. Attorney General Jesus Murillo Karam said at a press conference yesterday that investigators have determined that none of the bodies belong to the missing students, who are believed to have been massacred by police in league with gang members, the AP reports. Murillo Karam said investigators have determined that the victims were killed on Sept. 26, the day the students were last seen, the BBC reports.

– A homeless man who was filmed living on the streets of California was given a new suit and haircut, a $100 donation to buy food for his friends, and a hotel stay—all in the name of charity. But a witness says the whole thing was a hoax, the Telegraph reports. The man, identified only as Thomas, was filmed by serial prankster Josh Paler Lin, who posted the video online. In the video, Thomas is seen eating at a sushi restaurant before being taken to a hotel room with a hot tub and treated to a new suit and haircut. But Thomas insists the whole thing was a hoax, despite the fact that witnesses say the whole thing was a set-up.

– Boko Haram has agreed to a cease-fire with Nigeria's military, the country's defense chief announced today, but it's not clear yet how long the truce will last or whether any of the 219 schoolgirls kidnapped by the Islamic extremist group in April will be freed, the AP reports. The chief of staff of Nigeria's military says all military units have been instructed to abide by the deal, but the president's chief of staff says the agreement only applies to Boko Haram "wherever the girls and women are taken," the BBC reports.

– Nikolai Kryaglyachenko, a 12-year-old Russian boy, was walking home one day when he leaned against a lamp post that was live from a faulty wire, and was blasted across the pavement by the shock. The next day, Nikolai discovered that metal objects stuck to him like glue. “I found some coins that had been lying on the mattress had stuck to my body,” he tells the Telegraph. “It was like a magnet. I could feel them sticking to my body.” Nikolai’s grandmother tells the paper that the boy’s injuries were not life-threatening, and that the metal objects were simply stuck to his skin, not his body. “It’s possible that they got stuck in his bones,” she says. “But it’s more likely that they got stuck in his arms and legs.” Nikolai’s grandmother adds that the boy’s injuries are similar to those suffered by Magneto in the X-Men movies. The Telegraph reports that Nikolai’s powers of metallic attraction are similar to that of the X-Men villain, Magneto. “I found some coins that had been lying on the mattress had stuck to my body,” Nikolai says.

– Hell hath no fury like a woman scorned. Hell hath no fury like a Macedonian man who chopped off his penis and threw it in the dustbin after he was dumped by his girlfriend for the lack of bedroom skills. The saying came true for a Macedonian man who chopped off his penis and threw it in the dustbin after he was dumped by his girlfriend for the lack of bedroom skills. The 22-year-old man, whose name has not been released, told police that he had been in a relationship with a woman for two years before she dumped him last month, the Telegraph reports. He said that after she left him, he decided to cut off his penis and throw it in the trash because he didn't have enough bedroom skills. He said that after he cut off his penis, he went to his mother's house and told her he was going to throw it in the trash because he didn't have enough bedroom skills.

– Rumors have been swirling for a while now that Apple would be holding a special event in February to announce new products, and according to French website iGen, that event may actually be held in February. The site's sources say the event could take place last week, possibly on Tuesday, Feb. 24. If true, that would mean the company would be debuting the Apple Watch in April and the 12-inch MacBook Air in March, 9to5Mac reports.

– A rumor that parts of Texas are under Islamic law appears to be a hoax, the Houston Chronicle reports. Breitbart.com published an article this week claiming that an Islamic tribunal had been established in the Lone Star State and that an attorney claimed "it's an organization that's dedicated to Sharia law." But, as the Chronicle notes, "some users and other blogs went along with the story but apparently misinterpreted its premise."
– Canada's Parliament Hill has been locked down after shots were fired inside the building this morning, CTV News reports. There are also reports of shots being fired inside Parliament Hill.

– A video purporting to show Vladimir Putin pooping during a speech opening a World War I monument has gone viral, but Reddit users are pointing out that the footage doesn't actually show the Russian leader pooping. Instead, it appears to be an edited version of the speech, in which Putin doesn't appear to poop at all.

– It's not every day you get the chance to quit your job and make a lasting statement, but that's exactly what one iPhone game developer did, Mashable reports. In his game Electric Boogie, the man managed to sneak in a few hidden animations of the game's characters banging each other, something that would be banned by Apple. He then sent a letter of resignation to his "s---ty" boss. "It's basically the single greatest letter of resignation ever...only it's not a letter at all, it's a hilarious," the Verge states.

– A gunman opened fire at Canada's Parliament in Ottawa Wednesday, killing one person and wounding several others before he was shot dead by police, authorities said. The Canadian Press is reporting that a second person is in custody. Witnesses said the shooter was dressed all in black and wearing a black shirt, jeans, and a black hat. He reportedly ran from the Parliament building toward the National War Memorial, where he fatally shot a female employee of the House of Commons before being shot dead by police. Witnesses said the shooter was dressed all in black and ran from the Parliament building toward the National War Memorial, where he fatally shot a female employee of the House of Commons before being shot dead. Witnesses said the shooter was dressed all in black and ran from the Parliament building toward the National War Memorial, where he fatally shot a female employee of the House of Commons before being shot dead.
