– Don Lemon debuted what he says is audio of the gunshots that killed 18-year-old Michael Brown on CNN Tonight last night, Mediaite reports. The audio reportedly comes from a man who claims to have recorded at least 10 shots fired by Ferguson, Mo., police officer Darren Wilson. In the recording, the man is heard talking about unrelated matters, and at least two gunshots can be heard.

– The latest Apple Watch will come in 18-karat gold, and it will set you back a whopping $4,999. That's according to analyst John Gruber of Daring Fireball, who tweeted a picture of the watch with the caption, "Guess what? The Apple Watch Edition will come in 18-karat gold/sapphire to boot." Gruber thinks it's a good bet the watch will sell for that much, according to 9to5mac.com.

– The Internet is abuzz this week over a picture of what appears to be a penis spray-painted onto a $2 million Bugatti Veyron, the Telegraph reports. According to Reddit, the image was taken in Seattle, the BBC reports. The penis appears to have been painted by YouTube pranksters TwinzTV.

– Apple CEO Tim Cook said last month that the company was working on a "smart" watch that would incorporate facial recognition technology. Now, a report in the Wall Street Journal says the watch will have a built-in facial recognition system. The Journal says it has obtained a prototype of the watch, which is expected to be released later this year. The report says the watch will have a "secret data connection port," which the Journal calls "previously undisclosed by Apple." According to the Journal's sources, the facial recognition system will allow the watch to identify people in photos. The report says it's not clear if the watch will be sold as a stand-alone device or as part of a larger Apple Watch collection. Apple has not responded to the Journal's report.

– A gunman opened fire in front of Canada's parliament today, wounding a soldier before he was shot dead by police, reports the CBC. The soldier suffered non-life-threatening injuries, and the shooter is in custody. The incident took place just a few feet from Canada's parliament building, and witnesses say the gunman ran toward nearby government buildings before being shot dead by police.

– Apple's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs isn't expected until later this year, but the company's smartwatch is already causing a fuss. According to a post at 9to5mac.com, the $349 Apple Watch will be priced at $500 for the mid-tier steel model and up to $5,000 for the top-end gold Edition. That's a number much higher than previous estimates, the Wall Street Journal reports. The Journal says it's based on "a source familiar with the company's plans." Apple hasn't commented on the rumor.

– Batman vs. Superman is currently shooting in Detroit, and one of the Batmobiles used in the film has gone missing, reports the Detroit Free Press. It's not clear if the car was stolen from the lot of a local auto shop or if it was taken elsewhere.

– A man who lives near the spot where Michael Brown was shot to death by Ferguson, Mo., police says he was recording a video chat with a friend when gunfire rang out in the background, reports CNN. The man's lawyer, Lopa Blumenthal, says he has been interviewed by the FBI about the recording, in which you can hear six shots being fired.

– A woman in China gave birth to a healthy baby boy—but when a nurse went to check on him the next day, she found the mother trying to eat him, the Sun reports. The 24-year-old, identified only as Li Zhenghua, had been found with her jaws tightly around the infant's arm. The nurse tried to pull the baby free, but Li wouldn't let go, and doctors had to use an implement to get her off the child before giving her a sedative. "The cannibalistic attack happened at a hospital in the city of Shenzhen in southern China’s Guangdong Province, where the woman had been discovered heavily pregnant and in labor," reads a report from the South China Morning Post. "The doctors used an implement to prize her off the child before administering a sedative."

– Apple may be planning to hold a media event in late February to showcase the final version of its upcoming Apple Watch, and also debut a newly redesigned MacBook Air, potentially with a Retina display, according to a new report. Apple may be planning to hold a media event in late February to showcase the final version of its upcoming Apple Watch, and also debut a newly redesigned MacBook Air, potentially with a Retina display, according to a new report.

– North Korea's Kim Jong-un has piled on so much weight that he has fractured both his ankles and remains in hospital after an operation, it was reported today. The leader of the impoverished nation is estimated to have ballooned to 20 stone as a result of fine wining and dining—putting enormous pressure on his feet and legs.

– Iraq's deputy prime minister says ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi has not been killed in an airstrike but is "martyred," the AP reports. No official confirmation has been given, but a photo circulating on social media appears to show a bloodied al-Baghdadi, who was said to have been killed in the same airstrike that hit the headquarters of the Nusra Front in Syria on Saturday. A spokesman for Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi says the prime minister has been told that al-Baghdadi was killed in an airstrike, but no further details were given.

– A fake report that a family in the town of Purdon, Texas, has got the Ebola virus and the town was quarantined is fake. It was posted on the National Report, a satirical website. A report that says a family in the town of Purdon, Texas, has got the Ebola virus and the town was quarantined is fake. It was posted on the National Report, a satirical website.

– An Iraqi official denied that a woman detained in Lebanon is a wife of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the leader of the Islamic State group, adding that she is the sister of a terror suspect being held in Iraq. An Iraqi official denied that a woman detained in Lebanon is a wife of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the leader of the Islamic State group, adding that she is the sister of a terror suspect being held in Iraq. – The Islamic State has released a graphic video showing the beheading of American journalist James Foley, who was seized in Syria in 2012, reports the New York Times. The militant group, which released a video of the beheading of Steven Sotloff earlier this month, says Foley was killed because he refused to pay a ransom. The 33-year-old, who grew up in Rochester, NY, had been working as a freelance photographer in Syria when he was seized.

– Canada's Parliament sergeant-at-arms Kevin Vickers is being hailed as a hero after shooting and killing a gunman inside the Parliament this morning. Vickers, 58, a 29-year veteran of the RCMP, was praised by politicians, journalists, and the public for saving lives, the CBC reports. He told the CBC this afternoon that he is safe and OK. Vickers' younger brother, John, tweeted that his thoughts are with him and that his family is being contacted by media around the world. During his nearly three decades with the RCMP Vickers, who is now 58, rose to the rank of chief superintendent, often serving as the face of the national police.

– An Iraqi airstrike on Thursday killed Abu Hajar al-Souri, a top aide to ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the Iraqi Ministry of Defense said. An Iraqi airstrike on Thursday killed Abu Hajar al-Souri, a top aide to ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the Iraqi Ministry of Defense said. An Iraqi airstrike on Thursday killed Abu Hajar al-Souri, a top aide to ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the Iraqi Ministry of Defense said. An Iraqi airstrike on Thursday killed Abu Hajar al-Souri, a top aide to ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the Iraqi Ministry of Defense said.

– The Islamic State is unleashing live scorpions on the Iraqi people in an "act of madness," according to an ex-military official. The former head of chemical and biological weapons for the Army and NATO tells the Mirror that ISIS militants are using improvised devices to launch the scorpions, which are launched into the air by a canister that breaks apart after a couple of miles. Thousands of scorpions are believed to have been killed in the process. "They are promoting the fact that they are doing it, which in turn is creating panic," the ex-military official says.

– A man was dragged away by a mob of angry locals who beat him for an hour, then cut off his penis with a meat cleaver and dumped it in the middle of the road, the Daily Star reports. The vigilantes decided to take the man to a butcher's shop after he allegedly tried to rape a woman, the Mirror reports. "They beat him with sticks for an hour, then they cut off his penis with a meat cleaver and dumped it in the middle of the road," said a local official.

– Apple's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs isn't going so well, according to a new report from the Wall Street Journal. The company has halted production of the Apple Watch over concerns about its lithium-ion battery's ability to power the device for up to 24 hours. Apple CEO Tim Cook said in a letter to employees that the watch's batteries "have degraded to the point where they are no longer able to power the device" and that production has been halted "until we can figure out a way to make the battery life of the Apple Watch as long as possible." The Journal notes that the watch, which is due out next month, is Apple's first major new product since the death of its CEO in 2011.

– When Dylan Thomas awoke one morning in Bali to find a red scar-like trail on his stomach, the 21-year-old Australian thought he'd been bitten by an insect. Instead, he found a tropical spider that had burrowed under his skin and traveled up his chest, the Telegraph reports. Thomas, who was given antihistamine cream to treat what doctors thought was an insect bite, was sent to see a dermatologist, who discovered the small spider and removed it. Doctors say the spider had burrowed through a small scar left by a previous trip to Bali.

– Kim Jong Un may be missing, but he's not dead—at least according to South Korea's biggest newspaper. The Chosun Ilbo reports that the North Korean leader is recovering from two broken ankles caused by a strain of his expanding waistline, the Telegraph reports. According to the paper's sources, Kim has been drinking a lot of cheese from Switzerland—specifically, Emmental—since becoming North Korea's leader. The North Korean leader has reportedly gained more than 100 pounds since taking over from his father and grandfather, leading to rumors of a coup.

– A helmet camera has captured the incredible moment a US Marine was shot in the head by a Taliban sniper in Afghanistan—and lived to tell the tale. The three-minute video, shot from a helmet camera, shows three elite amphibious infantrymen from the US Navy as they take part in a joint helicopter raid in Now Zad, Helmand Province, in 2013. After hearing insurgent gunfire, the trio go to investigate, pausing for cover in the exit of a tunnel. It is at this moment that the marksman strikes, a bullet from his high-powered weapon ricocheting off the helmet of the second Marine in the patrol with the video, filmed from a helmet camera, can be seen here.

– "33 people got married during Same Love. Amazing to be apart of that movement. Just kidding bitch, I'm in ISIS now." That's what Macklemore tweeted last night, leading to the hashtag "#MacklemorejoinedISIS" trending on Twitter, Mashable reports. The rapper has no affiliation with ISIS, the Huffington Post notes, but he's known for conspiracy theories in the past. In 2013, he tweeted, " 911...bush knocked down the towers. And on a song called Bush Song."

– The Pentagon says ISIS militants managed to seize one of 28 bundles of weapons and medical supplies dropped to Kurdish forces in northern Iraq on Monday, the Wall Street Journal reports. Army Col. Steve Warren, a Pentagon spokesman, says that two of the bundles went astray.

– It's not your run-of-the-mill restaurant: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is set to open a state-backed restaurant in Scotland serving North Korean delicacies such as dog meat soup and pine-nut gruel, the Telegraph reports. Kim Jong Un is "delighted" to open the restaurant in Aberdeen, according to a statement from North Korea's embassy in London. The statement says the restaurant will be the first of its kind in the UK.

– The fence-jumper who forced his way into the White House earlier this month overpowered a Secret Service officer and ran through much of the main floor before he was taken into custody, the Washington Post reports, citing "three people familiar with the incident." The sources say the unidentified man, who has not been identified, made it as far as the North Portico doors before he was taken into custody by Secret Service agents. The sources say he made it as far as the Executive Office Building before he was taken into custody.

– The Islamic State militant known as "Jihadi John" has been identified as Mohammed Emwazi, a British citizen born in Kuwait who is believed to have traveled to Syria in 2012. Emwazi was known to British security services but they chose not to disclose his name earlier for operational reasons, the Telegraph reports. He is believed to have traveled to Syria around 2012 and later joined the Islamic State, or Isil, the group terrorising Iraq and Syria. Jihadi John first appeared in a video last August, when he appeared to kill the American journalist James Foley. The Washington Post describes Emwazi as Kuwaiti born and in his mid-20s. He was apparently raised in a middle class neighborhood and occasionally prayed at a mosque in Greenwich.

– It may feel like winter is slowly squeezing all the sunlight out of your day, but if you see any news stories claiming Earth is headed for "Six Days of Total Darkness" then don't start stocking up on the tins of beans and torches just yet. In fact, if you see any news stories claiming Earth is headed for "Six Days of Total Darkness" then don't start stocking up on the tins of beans and torches just yet.

– Robert Plant’s publicist has called a report that he turned down a massive Led Zeppelin reunion deal “rubbish.” The Mirror reported that Richard Branson had offered Plant, Jimmy Page, John Paul Jones, and Jason Bonham—the son of Bonham’s Led Zeppelin drummer John Bonham—a $700 million deal to tour in 35 cities. But Plant’s publicist tells the Guardian the story is “absolute rubbish.”

– George Zimmerman's wife has filed a motion to dismiss the second-degree murder charge against her husband, arguing that the state failed to prove he acted in self-defense, reports the Los Angeles Times. The judge in the case has ordered a competency hearing for the 28-year-old. Zimmerman's defense team has argued that he acted in self-defense when he shot and killed a man outside a Florida home last year.

– A teacher is facing the sack after she was secretly filmed having sex with one of her pupils—and the video ended up on a porn site. Argentinian beauty Lucita Sandoval was unwittingly recorded having sex with a 16-year-old pupil who switched camera phone on after asking the teacher to turn around, the Telegraph reports.

– A Saudi religious scholar has issued a fatwa against building snowmen, saying the practice is not acceptable in Islam. Mohammad Saleh Al Minjed, a professor of Islamic studies, said making snow models of lifeless things like buildings and ships is acceptable in Islam, Gulf News reports. "God has given people space to make whatever they want which does not have a soul, including trees," Minjed said. "It is not permitted to make a statue out of snow, even by way of play and fun," he said. "God has given people space to make whatever they want which does not have a soul, including trees."

– ESPN is hosting a panel discussion on the NFL's domestic violence problem tonight, and the Week calls it a "remarkable showing of the exact flavor of dumb meathead that ESPN is so adept at that it should trademark." The panel will be comprised of 11 men and zero women. "A domestic violence panel involving 11 men and 0 women when women constitute the vast majority of domestic violence victims is neither good nor informative," says the Week's headline. "ESPN is so adept at that it should trademark."

– The FBI has identified the second American killed in ISIS-controlled territory in Syria as 19-year-old aid worker Peter Kassig, a US citizen who joined the militant group last year. Kassig, who grew up in Ohio, was one of the first American fighters to join the Islamic State, which seized control of large parts of Iraq and Syria last year. He was killed in the early hours of Sunday near the border with Syria, reports the AP. A spokesman for the FBI's Cincinnati office tells the AP that Kassig was one of several aid workers killed in the fighting. He says investigators are still trying to determine whether other Americans have been killed. Kassig was working for Doctors Without Borders in Raqqa, the capital of the Islamic State's self-proclaimed capital, Raqqa, when he was killed.

– If Bali belly, dengue fever, and dangerous drinks have not been enough to put you off taking a holiday to Bali—perhaps the story of "spiderman" will. The island nation's tourism board has announced that the much-anticipated movie Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark will be released in theaters on Oct. 17, reports the Jakarta Post. The film, which has been in the works for years, is based on the Marvel comic book series of the same name.

– The internet is buzzing this morning with news that country icon and legend Willie Nelson has died. One big problem is that the buzz is kind of pointless since the country crooner isn't dead at all.

– Five ISIS militants in Mosul, Iraq, have been confirmed to have tested positive for Ebola, an Iraqi health official tells Al Jazeera. "The Islamic State organization incinerated five militants infected with Ebola to prevent further spread of the disease in Mosul," he says. "ISIS had proof that these militants were infected with Ebola." It's not clear whether the militants died from the disease or were killed and incinerated by the group.

– The brouhaha over Brian Williams' admission that he was on a helicopter that was hit by a rocket-propelled grenade while in Iraq is far from over—and Tom Brokaw isn't happy about it. In an open letter to NBC News President Deborah Turness, Brokaw writes that he's "furious that Brian Williams is still in the anchor chair after he sheepishly admitted he hadn't traveled on a helicopter hit by enemy fire" and that the network's handling of the situation is "shameful," reports the Daily Beast. "You know you're in trouble when Tom Brokaw is out for your blood," he writes in the letter, which was obtained by the Daily Beast. "This is not the kind of leadership we should be giving to our young people. This is not the kind of leadership NBC should be giving to its senior leaders. This is not the kind of leadership you should be giving to someone who is supposed to be your role model. This is not the kind of leadership you should be giving to someone who is supposed to be your friend. This is not the kind of leadership you should be giving to someone who is supposed to be your mentor. This is not the kind of leadership you

– If you're a freshman at Elon University in North Carolina and want to call yourself a freshman, you're out of luck. The school's website now uses the term "first-year" instead of "freshman," reports the Winston-Salem Journal. But the school isn't actually banning the use of the word, just making sure it's used correctly, says an Elon VP. "We're just trying to make sure that our students understand what we're trying to communicate," he says. "We don't want them to think that they're being banned from using the word freshman."

– A 16-member activist group called Raqqa Is Being Slaughtered Silently has released images it says show a US Predator drone hovering over the Syrian city of Raqqa, the capital of the Islamic State, the Washington Post reports. According to the New York Times, the drone can be seen in a video uploaded to YouTube Sept. 6. RIBSS says it's the first time a US drone has been spotted in Raqqa. According to the Post, the US has been conducting airstrikes against the Islamic State in Syria.

– It's been a big year for Apple and Samsung, with the two tech giants announcing plans to team up to create the world's most powerful smartphone. Now, the Wall Street Journal reports that the two companies are in talks to team up to create the world's most powerful tablet computer—a move that could have a major impact on the smartphone market. "This could be a game-changer," says one analyst. "It could mean the death of the smartphone as we know it." The idea is to create a tablet that would compete head-to-head with the likes of Google's tablet, currently the No. 2 smartphone in the world, and Apple's own tablet, currently the No. 4. "This could be a game-changer for the smartphone industry," says another analyst. "It could mean the death of the smartphone as we know it."

– Libyan strongman Moammar Gadhafi has ordered an investigation into the crash of at least 11 civilian airliners over the past two years, including two that went missing from Tripoli's airport, the Washington Free Beacon reports. Senior editor Bill Gertz, who broke the story on WMAL radio in Washington, DC, Wednesday morning, says the investigation could take up to a year. He says the investigation will focus on whether the planes were shot down by surface-to-air missiles or brought down by a bomb.

– A Macedonian man who thought his small penis was to blame for his girlfriend's decision to break up with him apparently didn't think so. The man sliced off his own dick and threw it away after his girlfriend broke up with him, citing dissatisfying sex, reports every site in the tabloidosphere. The man believed his small penis was to blame for the failed relationship, reports every site in the tabloidosphere.

– If you've got an iCloud Drive on your iPhone, iPad, or iPod Touch, you may want to think twice about using iOS 8's "All Settings" option. According to MacRumors, iOS 8's "All Settings" option could delete files stored in the cloud—including those related to iWork—the way it's supposed to. When you use iOS 8's "All Settings" to reset your iPhone or iPad's settings, iOS will tell you that no data or media will be deleted. But in iOS 8, this isn't working.

– First came #BendGate. Now comes #HairGate. A 9to5Mac community post reveals that iPhone 6 customers are complaining on social media that their new phones keep ripping out chunks of their hair when they hold them up to their ear to take a call. Twitter users claim that the seam between the glass screen and aluminium back of the iPhone 6 is to blame, and it's that gap that their hair is getting caught in.

– It's not every day that an atheist website wins an "Oscar" for best blog, but that's exactly what happened with Patheos Atheist last night. The site took home the top prize for "blog of the year" at the South by Southwest festival, thanks in large part to a post by Richard Patheos, who writes that he's an agnostic and that he doesn't believe in creationism. Patheos also posted a video of himself giving his acceptance speech, which you can watch here.

– A photo purporting to show the body of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi is making the rounds on social media—and it's causing a lot of confusion. The image, which purports to show al-Baghdadi's body after he was said to have been killed in a US airstrike, has been shared thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter, Iraqi News reports. The White House has yet to confirm or deny the photo's authenticity.

– When a 26-year-old woman in China got dumped by her boyfriend, she decided to take a week off from her job to mourn the loss—at a KFC. "I hadn't planned on staying there long, I just wanted some chicken wings," Tan Shen tells Yahoo. "But once I got in there and started eating, I decided I needed time to think." She called in sick to work at a 24/7 KFC in Chengdu, where she chowed down on chicken wings, hamburgers, and fries, the Huffington Post reports. "I just wanted some chicken wings," she says. "But once I got in there and started eating I decided I needed time to think."

– If you've been dying to get your hands on an Apple Watch, you're in luck: Research firm Strategy Analytics predicts that Apple will sell 15 million of the devices in 2015, making it the world's No. 1 smartwatch vendor, the Wall Street Journal reports. That's 55% of the global smartwatch market share, and it will "instantly make Apple the number one smartwatch vendor," according to the report.

– Rumors have been swirling that the iconic Batmobile has gone missing from the set of Batman vs Superman: Dawn of Justice, but the Detroit Free Press reports that police have confirmed it's not missing. The car was spotted cruising the set in Detroit last week.

– Batman V. Superman: Dawn of Justice is in the midst of filming in Detroit, and social media is abuzz with rumors that someone has stolen the iconic Batmobile from the set, reports the Detroit Free Press. “Does this person—if the rumor is true (we don’t know how credible the source is)—think that he or she can just go cruising around in this car no one will notice?” asks CBS Detroit in their report.

– British and US intelligence have identified British rapper Abdel-Majed Abdel Bary as a prime suspect in the murder of James Foley, who was killed by Islamic State militants in November. Bary, whose real name is Abdel Bary Khaled el-Hussein, is an Egyptian-born British citizen who lives in London, the Telegraph reports. He has been in custody since last year on suspicion of conspiring with the Islamic State.

– A 21-year-old Australian man's photo of a spider's red trail through his stomach has gone viral after he posted it to Facebook last week. Dylan Thomas says the spider was living under his skin in Bali, Indonesia, for three days before it managed to get out, the Telegraph reports. "They finally found out it was a tropical spider that's been living inside of me for the last 3 days, managed to get it out," he says. Thomas says he took a selfie of the spider's trail and posted it to Facebook, where it has been shared more than 100,000 times as of this writing. According to the Telegraph, Thomas says the spider was about the size of a puppy. Experts say the spider likely got into Thomas' stomach through a hole in a surgery scar, the Independent reports.

– You may have seen a clever Banksy illustration of broken pencils being shared far and wide on social media. It's a powerful message about optimism and rebuilding after facing adversity. But it's not by Banksy. The illustration is actually by Lucille Clerc, a London-based illustrator. After being posted on an Instagram account purporting to be associated with Banksy, the image has been shared over 130,000 times. There are a lot of fake Banksy accounts on social media, but the one that scraped Lucille Clerc's image has over a million followers, which explains its wide reach.

– Is the iPhone 6 ripping out hair? Maybe. Photo: Courtesy of Apple By now, you've probably heard about #hairgate, which has people chattering about an unintended problem with the iPhone 6. According to a forum post on 9to5Mac, Apple's latest phone traps hair in the seam between the glass and aluminum. "When you try to free it out, it hurts," the poster laments. "#hairgate." But is there any actual evidence of the iPhone 6 ripping out hair?

– Game of Thrones is coming to your TV. HBO is launching a stand-alone streaming service called HBO Now in April, and sources tell the Wall Street Journal it's in talks with Apple to make Apple TV one of the launch partners. The Journal's sources say HBO Now will launch in tandem with the fifth season premiere of Game of Thrones on April 14. The standalone service will be the first time consumers will be able to subscribe directly to HBO for the first time, rather than through a cable, satellite, or telco TV distributor.

– Talk about an amazing Christmas surprise—Joe Riquelme, an entrepreneur who created the iPhone app Videoshop, paid off his parents' mortgage for the ultimate holiday gift. Joe caught the moment he gave his parents the gift on video and the clip shows his parents cuddled around him on the couch as he gives them an envelope containing the special note. "Your house is paid off. Merry Xmas.—Joe," the note reads along with a check list featured "raising kids," "college loans," and "mortgage" all checked off.

– Batman v. Superman is set to hit theaters next month, but the Batmobile is missing from a Detroit parking lot, the Detroit Free Press reports. According to a report on Jalopnik, the customized car, which was used in a promotional video for the movie, has gone missing from a lot on the city's east side. It's believed to have been stolen. "If this is true I could only imagine seeing it driving down 696 in rush hour," writes Matt Miller on Jalopnik's site.

– Canada's Parliament is on lockdown after reports of shots fired inside and outside the building this morning, the CBC reports. According to CTV News, a soldier standing guard at the country's War Memorial was shot this morning, and witnesses say multiple shots have been fired inside Parliament Hill, which is located in the heart of Ottawa. The soldier was reportedly transported to a local hospital with non-life-threatening injuries.

– The Nigerian government says it has reached a ceasefire deal with Boko Haram militants that will result in the release of more than 200 schoolgirls kidnapped by the group earlier this year, the Guardian reports. "I wish to inform this audience that a ceasefire agreement has been concluded," Nigeria's chief of defense staff said at the end of a three-day security meeting between Nigeria and Cameroon. "It appears as though the 219 school girls that are being held captive by Boko Haram will be released." The chief of defense said negotiations had been held in neighboring Chad.

– When a man in Norfolk, England, took his pet goldfish to a vet, he didn't just bring it in for a check-up. Instead, he paid the vet more than $400 to have two tumors removed, the Independent reports. The man, who hasn't been named, tells the Norfolk Messenger that the fish had been drinking from its tank for about a year. The vet, Faye Bethell, found two tumors—one on the fish's anus and one on its dorsal fin—and decided to remove them all. She says the man paid her $300 to have the tumors removed because he was "so fond of his constipated office goldfish."

– Rumors have been flying that the Apple Watch will run you up to five hours on a single charge. But according to a new report from TechCrunch, the watch will actually take two hours to charge and will only deliver all-day battery life with normal on-and-off usage. That's in contrast to a previous report from 9to5mac that said the watch would deliver all-day battery life and run you up to five hours on a single charge. The new report says the watch will only deliver notifications while in contact with skin and will stop delivering them when the battery reaches 10% or lower in an effort to conserve power.

– Condé Nast's new headquarters are located in New York City's 1 WTC—the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere, per the New York Daily News—and the publishing house's editors have been complaining for months that rats are hanging around the place. A source tells the New York Post that rats have been spotted "all over" the place, and that Vogue editor Anna Wintour is "definitely not thinking about rats" at the moment.

– A 2-year-old dog is recovering after being found tied to a railing and stuffed into a suitcase at a Scottish train station, the Guardian reports. According to the Scottish Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, the male shar-pei crossbreed was discovered Jan. 2 at the Ayr railway station in South Ayrshire. The suitcase was filled with items, including a pillow, a toy, a food bowl, and food, the SPCA says. Officials were able to track down the last registered owner, who has since been found.

– Macaulay Culkin has once again died—at least, according to a death hoax spreading online. The troubled actor, who at one point was reportedly entrenched in heroin addiction that friends feared he had only months to live, is once again the subject of a hoax claiming that he was found dead in his Manhattan apartment. News that Macaulay Culkin had allegedly died spread quickly on Facebook and Twitter, with users linking to a story on something called MSNBC.website.com (which is entirely separate from the real MSNBC).

– "The urge to create is equally strong in all children. Boys and girls. It's the imagination that counts. Not skill. You build whatever comes into your head, the way you want it. A bed or a truck. A dolls house or a spaceship. A lot of boys like dolls houses. They're more human than spaceships. A lot of girls prefer spaceships. They're more exciting than dolls houses. The most important thing is to put the right material in your head." So begins a letter from a box of Legos sent to parents in the 1970s that's been going viral since it was posted on Reddit this week. "To Parents. To Parents," the letter reads. "The urge to create is equally strong in all children. Boys and girls. It's the imagination that counts. Not skill. You build whatever comes into your head, the way you want it. A bed or a truck. A dolls house or a spaceship. A lot of boys like dolls houses. They're more human than spaceships. A lot of girls prefer spaceships. A lot of girls prefer spaceships. They're more exciting than dolls houses. The most important thing is to put the right material in your

– The internet is abuzz with the story of an elderly priest who died and had a conversation with God—and a female God. The story has been dancing around on Facebook, Twitter, and Reddit since the priest's death, according to WCVB. Now, the Archdiocese of Boston has weighed in, and it's not happy about it. The story is "not true," the archdiocese says in a statement to the Boston Herald. The priest "did not receive any financial support from the Archdiocese of Boston or any of its agencies." The statement goes on to say, "The Archdiocese of Boston does not condone this kind of behavior."

– A woman who says she was dumped by her boyfriend decided to make up for lost time by chowing down on chicken wings at KFC—for a week. The unidentified woman posted a photo of herself chowing down on wings in the fast-food chain’s chicken wing-eating contest on Instagram last week, along with the caption, “My boyfriend dumped me for a week so I decided to chow down on chicken wings at KFC.” The post has since gone viral, with thousands of likes and retweets, the Daily Mail reports.

– A soldier standing guard at Canada's National War Memorial was shot to death today before he was shot dead by a gunman inside the country's Parliament, authorities say. The gunman, identified as 32-year-old Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, then ran into Parliament where he was shot dead by a member of Parliament, the CBC reports. Parliament Sergeant-at-Arms Kevin Lamoureux says Zehaf-Bibeau exchanged fire with two members of Parliament before he was shot dead by the sergeant-at-arms. The soldier, identified as 24-year-old Nathan Cirillo, was standing guard at the National War Memorial when Zehaf-Bibeau shot him, authorities say. Cirillo's father tells the CBC that his son was standing guard when Zehaf-Bibeau shot him multiple times. "I'm just so proud of my son, he's a hero," he says. "I'm just so proud of all the men and women who put their lives on the line every day." Canada's governor-general says it's too early to say whether Zehaf-Bibeau's actions were terror-related, the AP reports.

– For the second time this year, Macaulay Culkin has been the victim of an online death hoax. This time, the Home Alone star's reps confirmed to the Hollywood Reporter that the 34-year-old is very much alive. A Facebook memorial page announcing the actor's death sparked the rumors, according to fact-checking site Snopes.

– Henry Jackson, aka Big Bank Hank of the pioneering rap group Sugarhill Gang, has died of cancer at the age of 63, reports TMZ. The group, whose hits included "(You Gotta) Fight for Your Right (to Party)!" and "(You Gotta) Fight for Your Right (to Party)," was formed in the late '60s in New York City, notes Fox News. The group's manager confirms Jackson's death to the network.

– For the second time this year, Macaulay Culkin has been the victim of an Internet hoax. This time, the Home Alone star was found dead in his Manhattan apartment, according to the latest hoax, which was quickly picked up by Twitter and Facebook users, the Huffington Post reports. The 34-year-old actor has been in and out of rehab for drug and alcohol addiction, according to the Daily Mail.

– A 22-year-old Macedonian man says his small penis is to blame for his girlfriend breaking up with him, Metro reports. Oliver Ilic allegedly sliced off his penis and threw it in a trash can after his girlfriend broke up with him due to lack of skills in the bedroom. Ilic called emergency services after he could not stop the bleeding and was taken to a hospital in the east Macedonian town of Kocani. Police searched his house and found the severed organ in a dustbin after it had been sliced off using a razor blade

– When Meng Xiangyan's 29-year-old daughter was diagnosed with a rare and aggressive form of breast cancer, her parents couldn't afford the treatment her twin sister needed. So the Chinese mother took to the streets of Qingdao in eastern China, holding a street auction to raise money for her daughter's care, the Sun reports. The twins are one and the same, but Meng Xiangyan had to sell one of them to pay for her daughter's care, so she put him up for sale with a sign reading, "My son is for sale to the highest bidder," the Daily Mail reports. Photos of the auction have gone viral since they were posted on Chinese social media last week.

– When the New Yorker profiled 17-year-old Mohammed Islam in its September issue, it said the Stuyvesant High School student had made $72 million from the stock market since he was 8 years old. Well, Mohammed tells CNBC that's not quite right. "The attention is not what we expected—we never wanted the hype," he says. "This was about friends trying to make something exciting together." He says the money is probably in the "few million" range, not $72 million.

– The recording of the gunshots that killed Michael Brown may or may not be authentic, according to two experts. CNN law enforcement analyst Tom Fuentes and former Los Angeles police officer David Klinger told Mediaite this morning that they initially believed the recording to be a hoax. "I’ve told your producers that for all I know this is something that one of Howard Stern’s punk people have been doing... I don’t have a high degree of confidence in it," Fuentes said. He added that he has seen the recording and it sounds "very different" from what he has heard on the radio. "I don’t have a high degree of confidence in it," Klinger said.

– One of the five Taliban members freed in exchange for Army Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl has reportedly tried to return to terrorist activity, trying to reconnect with Islamic extremists near Qatar, according to CNN. One of the five Taliban members swapped by the Obama administration in exchange for Army Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl has reportedly tried to return to terrorist activity, trying to reconnect with Islamic extremists near Qatar, according to CNN.

– Joe Riquelme, creator of the popular iPhone video editing app Videoshop, surprised his parents on Christmas by revealing that he had paid off their mortgage. Riquelme, who goes by "Joey," took to YouTube on Thursday to share the touching footage of his parents reacting to his generous gift, the Washington Post reports. In the clip, Riquelme and his parents are cuddled on a couch when he casually tells them he has one more gift. He then pulled a folded enveloped sweatshirt and presented it to his mom. "It has to be a nice present," she says while opening it.

– It's one of the most annoying aspects of modern air travel—kicking off shoes and removing belts to get through security without setting off the scanner. One frustrated traveler clearly decided the only answer was to strip off altogether, much to the surprise of security guards.

– The man believed to have opened fire at Canada's National War Memorial yesterday before being shot dead by police has been identified as Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, a 32-year-old Canadian soldier who served two tours in Afghanistan. Zehaf-Bibeau was shot dead by an Ottawa police officer as he tried to enter the memorial with a weapon, reports the CBC, which identifies him as Zehaf-Bibeau's roommate. Police say Zehaf-Bibeau, who was shot in the leg, is a "person of interest" in the attack but has not been charged, the AP reports.

– Tom Brokaw is not happy about Brian Williams' admission that he lied about being in a helicopter that was shot down during the Iraq war. The NBC anchor, who has long claimed that he was in a chopper when it was shot down, apologized on Meet the Press today. "I have to admit that when I was in Iraq, I was in a helicopter that was shot down," he said, adding that he was "deeply, deeply sorry" for what happened. "I was in the helicopter with other members of the NBC News team," he said. "I was in the control tower. I was in the cockpit. I was in the helicopter with other members of the NBC News team when it was shot down. I was in the helicopter with other members of the NBC News team when it was shot down, and I was in the helicopter with other members of the NBC News team when it was shot down." Brokaw said he was "deeply, deeply sorry" for what had happened and that he was "saddened" by Williams' admission, the AP reports.

– Comcast is threatening to cut off your internet service if you don't stop using the Tor browser, reports Deepdotweb. Tor is a type of anonymous web browser that, in theory, makes your internet activity private. The software routes traffic through a series of other connected internet users, making it difficult for governments and private companies to monitor your internet usage. Up to 1.2 million people use the browser, which became especially popular after Edward Snowden leaked information showing that the NSA was spying on US citizens.

– A huge crater in the Nicaraguan capital of Managua may or may not have been caused by a meteor, according to NASA scientists. The space agency says it's looking into whether the 40-foot-wide crater was caused by a rock that broke off from an asteroid as it passed between the Earth and the moon, the Los Angeles Times reports. The Nicaraguan government initially said the rock was a meteorite, but NASA scientists say there aren't any eyewitness accounts to back that up, and the timeline of the asteroid's closest approach to the Earth in 2014 doesn't sync up with the crater's appearance, the Washington Post reports.

– A 3-year-old boy in China was auctioned off on the streets of Beijing this week to raise money for cancer treatment for his twin sister, the Telegraph reports. The boy's mother says she was told her daughter would die without urgent treatment for acute leukemia, so she and her husband took to the streets to sell the boy to the highest bidder. "We thought we had everything we could need with a wonderful little boy and a wonderful little girl who are twins," she says. "But all that changed."

– Seth Rogen will play Steve Wozniak in Danny Boyle’s Steve Jobs, the film based on Walter Isaacson’s biography of the late Apple co-founder, Variety reports. Christian Bale will play Steve Jobs’ right-hand man, according to the Hollywood Reporter, which notes that the film will be divided into three long scenes.

– The NHL's trade deadline is just two weeks away, and rumors are flying that one of the biggest names on the market will be dealt before then. Evander Kane of the Winnipeg Jets—the 23-year-old who scored 30 goals last year—is a restricted free agent at the end of the season, and the team is said to be looking to move him before the March 2 deadline, reports the Chicago Sun-Times. The big question, of course, is whether the Jets will deal him for a first- or second-round pick. If they do, it's a safe bet that at least one team will get a first- or second-round pick in return, notes ESPN.

– A West Australian man who developed a mysterious mark on his skin during a trip to Bali said doctors found a tropical spider had burrowed under his skin, UPI reports. The man, whose name has not been released, was in the Indonesian island for a hunting trip when he noticed a black mark on his back. He returned to Bunbury, in the state of West Australia, the next day, where he consulted a doctor, who told him the mark was likely caused by a tropical spider that had burrowed under his skin. The doctor confirmed that the spider was indeed a spider from the island of Bali, and that it had likely burrowed under the man's skin while he was on a hunting trip, the BBC reports. The man's wife, who was also on the trip, says she believes the spider ate something from her husband's skin while he was on the hunting trip.

– The Islamic State has released a video showing the beheading of American journalist James Foley, reports the New York Times. The militant group, which calls itself the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, says the killing is a message to the US to end its intervention in Iraq. The video also shows Time reporter Steven Sotloff, who was kidnapped in Syria two years ago.

– A Lego pamphlet from 1974, unearthed and posted on Reddit this weekend, has some advice for parents that rings true 40 years later: True then, true now. Lego spokesman Roar Rude Trangbk confirmed to Quartz that the document is real, and was included with a series of Lego dollhouses. (If the dollhouse figures look a little strange in the photo above, it's because Lego's iconic "minifigure" wasn't invented until 1978.)

– In the wake of the Charlie Hebdo terror attack in Paris, Banksy is offering a message of hope. The street artist, whose real name is Banksy, posted a drawing on Instagram that appears to show him holding a sign reading "Je Suis Charlie"—"I Am Charlie"—and linking it to a Facebook page that many believe is associated with Banksy, the New York Daily News reports.

– Apple's next big product launch isn't until later this month, but the company's first major product launch since the iPad's debut in 2011 is already generating plenty of buzz. The new Apple Watch, which CEO Tim Cook has described as the company's "most ambitious product launch ever," is expected to include a variety of new features, including a stainless steel display with a 24-karat gold finish, the Wall Street Journal reports. In addition to the watch, the company is also expected to offer a cheaper version of the iPhone 6 and a new iPod Touch. The Journal notes that while Apple hasn't confirmed the new features, they are expected to be included in a "mainstream" version of the watch that will include 512 megabytes of RAM and a "mainstream" version with 4 gigabytes of internal storage.

– It's not every day you get the chance to pick up a 20-year-old McDonald's Quarter Pounder with Cheese, but that's exactly what happened to two friends in Kansas. They were at a local McDonald's 20 years ago when one of their friends asked them to pick up the burger for him, but he never showed up to eat it, 9 News reports. So the friends decided to keep the burger for 20 years as a joke, and posted a YouTube video of it on Feb. 16.

– The Nigerian government's claim that Boko Haram has agreed to a ceasefire and will release more than 200 schoolgirls taken from their school last month is just wishful thinking, the militants say. Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau says the girls have been married off and converted to Islam since they were taken, the BBC reports. He says the group will only release the girls if the government swaps them for detained Boko Haram members. Shekau says the girls were taken from their school in a raid on April 14. He says the militant group is willing to negotiate the girls' release, but only if the government swaps them for detained Boko Haram members.

– In the wake of journalist James Foley's beheading by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, President Obama says the US will do "whatever is necessary" to protect American citizens and will not change course in Iraq. In an address to the nation last night, the president said the US "will do what is necessary to protect our people, our embassy in Baghdad, and our personnel, but we will not change the course of action in Iraq," the Washington Post reports. "We will continue to stand by the people of Iraq," he said. "We will work with the government of Iraq to bring the killers to justice, and we will do everything in our power to support the people of Iraq and the government of Syria, as well as the Iraqi people, as they seek to rid their country of the hatred and violence that has plagued their country for a long time." The president said Foley's execution was an "outrage" and said the US condemns it in the strongest possible terms, the AP reports. "This barbaric act is an outrage to the entire world," he said. "The entire world wasappalled by this act, but we will not change course in Iraq."

– Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb has claimed responsibility for the killing of hundreds of Iraqi soldiers in the western province of Anbar, the AP reports. The terrorist group said in a statement that the soldiers were killed in an attack on a military base. Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb has claimed responsibility for a number of attacks in Iraq and Syria in recent months.

– A college football player in China set off a huge explosion when he got down on one knee to ask his girlfriend for her hand in marriage, the New York Daily News reports. Dim Xiong Chien, a junior at Lanzhou University, set off fireworks in the school's football stadium Saturday night. The smoke was so powerful he could see through the windows of nearby buildings, according to the Daily News. Chien's girlfriend Cong Yen, who is also a junior at the university, got down on one knee and said yes. Chien then set fire to the hall where the proposal took place, the Daily News reports.

– A meteor may have struck near the Nicaragua-Mexico border just hours before an asteroid is set to pass by—and experts say the two events are likely related. Asteroid 2014 RC is set to pass within 20 miles of the Earth's surface on Sunday, according to NASA, which says the flyby will be the closest an asteroid has ever come to Earth. Experts say a meteor may have struck near the border Saturday night just 13 hours before the asteroid was set to pass by, the Los Angeles Times reports. The closest an asteroid has come to Earth was in 1908, when a 20-mile-wide meteor hit near the Nicaragua-Mexico border, according to NASA.

– "Most people think I'm joking when I say the gold ones are going to start at $5,000," John Gruber writes in a blog post at Daring Fireball. "I couldn't be more serious." Gruber says the 18-karat gold Apple Watch Edition could sell for as much as $4,999. The $349 Apple Watch Sport may start at a mere $349, but "the product line's price point could well soar from there," Gruber writes.

– The FBI has identified the second American killed in ISIS-controlled territory in Syria as 19-year-old aid worker Peter Kassig, a US citizen who joined the militant group last year. Kassig, who grew up in Ohio, was one of the first American fighters to join the Islamic State, which seized control of large parts of Iraq and Syria last year. He was killed in the early hours of Sunday near the border with Syria, reports the AP. A spokesman for the FBI's Cincinnati office tells the AP that Kassig was one of several aid workers killed in the fighting. He says investigators are still trying to determine whether other Americans have been killed. Kassig was working for Doctors Without Borders in Raqqa, the capital of the Islamic State's self-proclaimed capital, Raqqa, when he was killed.

– British security services have reportedly identified the British member of the Islamic State who is suspected of murdering American journalist James Foley. According to the London-based Sunday Times newspaper, the British intelligence services MI5 and MI6 have identified the British member of the Islamic State who is suspected of murdering American journalist James Foley as a British citizen named Jihadi John.

– A video making the rounds on Reddit and YouTube shows a young man handing his parents an envelope on Christmas. Inside is a note that reads, in part, "You've paid off your mortgage." Needless to say, the reaction from the parents is priceless. "I'm not crying, you're crying," one can be heard saying. "You're the baby."

– An Australian man claims he had a tropical spider surgically removed from his body after discovering it had burrowed into his stomach, but some commentators have cast doubt on his version of events. An Australian man claims he had a tropical spider surgically removed from his body after discovering it had burrowed into his stomach, but some commentators have cast doubt on his version of events. An Australian man claims he had a tropical spider surgically removed from his body after discovering it had burrowed into his stomach, but some commentators have cast doubt on his version of events.

– North Korea's official news agency says leader Kim Jong Il has ordered all members of the country's ruling Workers' Party to take part in a massive military parade next month to mark the 70th anniversary of the armistice that ended the Korean War. The KCNA news agency says the order was issued in a "secret document" obtained by South Korea's KBS TV station, according to the South's Yonhap News Agency. The news agency says it has seen the document, which states that "all party, army, and police officials" are to take part in the parade. The parade is expected to draw hundreds of thousands of people.

– A lawyer for the man who says he recorded Michael Brown before he was shot to death by Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson says his client has turned over the tape to the FBI, CNN reports. "He heard loud noises, and at the time he didn't even realize the import," Lopa Blumenthal tells anchor Don Lemon, who played the tape for viewers. She says the FBI has already interviewed her client, and that he told her he was on the phone with a friend at the time of the shooting and that he didn't realize Brown had been shot until he heard multiple gunshots. CNN says it has not independently verified the tape's authenticity.

– The Islamic State has taken a big step in its fight against Bashar al-Assad: The group has trained its own pilots to fly fighter jets, the New York Times reports. According to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, the first group to report the development is the US-led coalition, which says it has been aware of ISIS' efforts to train its pilots for some time. The group says it has been in contact with the Iraqi government, which has agreed to allow the training to take place in a base near the ISIS stronghold of Raqqa, Syria.

– The Syrian military has captured three fighter jets—believed to be MiG-21 and MiG-23 jets—from the Islamic State, and a watchdog group says the militants are learning to fly them, the Times of Israel reports. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says the former pilots for Saddam Hussein's regime are training ISIS fighters to fly the planes, which the group says are being kept at an air base in Raqqa, Syria. "They are learning how to use the planes," a spokesman for the monitoring group tells the Wall Street Journal. "They are not learning how to fight. They are learning how to fly the planes."

– Ahmed Abdi Godane, the leader of al-Shabab, the militant group behind last year's attack on a mall in Kenya, has been killed in a US airstrike, a source in al-Shabab tells NBC News. "Removing Godane from the battlefield is a major symbolic and operational loss to al-Shabab," a Pentagon spokesman says. "The United States works in coordination with its friends, allies, and partners to counter the regional and global threats posed by violent extremist organizations."

– Well, this is one way to spend $100. YouTube star Josh Paler Lin decided he'd give $100 to a homeless man named Thomas and then follow him around to see how he'd spend the money, the Los Angeles Times reports. Paler Lin—better known for his sex in bathrooms and mafia gags—set out to capture the simple social experiment on video. Days before Christmas, Internet prankster Josh Paler Lin set out to capture a simple social experiment on video.

– Mexican authorities have found at least 15 charred bodies near where 43 students disappeared after a deadly police shooting last week. The burial pits were found Saturday on a hill in a community outside Iguala, Southern Mexico, the town where the students were last seen. Witnesses claimed that they had last been seen being led away by police. Twenty-two police officers were arrested in Guerrero today, accused of killing two students during the clashes last week. Mexican authorities are investigating a mass grave discovered on the outskirts of Iguala, the same city where 43 students have been missing for a week

– The owner of a Texas plumber's truck says he's been receiving death threats after a photo surfaced of him being driven by ISIS militants in Syria. Mark Oberholtzer tells CBS News that his Ford F-250 pickup truck, complete with the Mark-1 Plumbing company decals, has been converted into an anti-aircraft vehicle. The Ansar al-Deen Front of ISIS militants posted the photo on Twitter with a man standing in front of it.

– The World Health Organization is investigating reports that ISIS militants have been showing up at an Iraqi hospital with Ebola, the Daily Mail reports. According to three media outlets an undisclosed number of militants displaying signs of the disease attended a hospital in the ISIS-held city of Mosul, 250 miles north of Baghdad. While the reports, from Kurdish and pro-Iraqi sources, remain unconfirmed, a WHO spokesperson says the group are trying to reach out to officials in ISIS-held areas to offer help.

– If you've ever wondered what it's like to work at Vogue, well, you're in luck: The magazine's new offices are filled to the brim with... furry, furry employees, the Huffington Post reports. According to staffers who work at the iconic fashion bible, Anna Wintour-helmed Vogue's brand-new offices at the Freedom Tower in downtown New York are full of furry little friends—and no one thinks it's chic at all.

– A blast that filled Nicaragua's 1.2 million capital Managua with dismay on Sunday night is most probably a meteorite that left a 12-meter crater near the city's airport, reports the Nicaragua Times. (See a photo of the crater here.) No one was injured in the blast, which the Times describes as "a huge blast that shook the city and caused a lot of damage to buildings."

– "I am the sun from Teletubbies." That's how 19-year-old Jess Smith describes herself in a Facebook post announcing her secret: She's transgender. "I used to hide it but after a lot of encouragement from my friends at university, I've gained the confidence to come out with it," she writes. "I am the sun from Teletubbies. I am the sun from Teletubbies. There has been quite a few people pretending to be 'the sun' but I am the sun." Smith, a first-year dance education student at the University of Exeter, says she decided to come out after friends encouraged her to do so. "There has been quite a few people pretending to be 'the sun' but I am the sun from Teletubbies," she writes.

– The town of Purdon, Texas, is not being quarantined because of Ebola, according to Snopes. The satirical news site NationalReport.net shared a story about the Texas town being quarantined after a family of five tested positive for Ebola, the Houston Chronicle reports. Snopes debunked the story after it was shared more than 79,000 times in nine hours.

– A video that went viral over the weekend shows a Chinese woman trying to sell her two-year-old son to raise money for her daughter's cancer treatment. The Daily Mirror reports that Meng Xiangyan, who says she's from a poor family, was forced to sell her son to pay for the girl's care after her parents couldn't afford it themselves. In the video, posted on YouTube, Meng can be seen trying to sell her son to a man who claims to have a relative who can help with the child's care. The man offers to pay for the child's care, but she refuses. The video has been viewed more than a million times since it was posted on Saturday.

– One of the five Guantanamo Bay prisoners released in exchange for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl has apparently gone back to militant activity in Qatar, according to CNN's Barbara Starr. Starr says one of the "Taliban Five" has been reaching out to militants over the last few months, and the Obama administration is now concerned that he may once again be a threat. The US released the prisoners in exchange for Bergdahl, who was held for five years by the Taliban.

– The leader of Nigerian extremist group Boko Haram says the group has not signed a ceasefire or agreed to release kidnapped schoolgirls, as the country's government has claimed. Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau tells the AP that the group is still holding hundreds of girls and young women as sex slaves, and that they will not be released until all of them are returned to their parents. He says some of the girls are still being held in Boko Haram camps in neighboring countries. "They are still in our hands, but we do not want them to go back to their parents," he says. Nigerian President Goodluck Jonathan said yesterday that Boko Haram had agreed to "cease fire" in exchange for the release of the girls, who were taken from their home in Nigeria's remote northeastern town of Chibok in April.

– Parliament's sergeant-at-arms shot and killed a gunman inside the Parliament building today, reports Fox News. One other gunman remains at large. The first gunman ran into the Parliament building before he was shot dead by Kevin Vickers, the sergeant-at-arms, reports the Canadian Press.

– The Pentagon is confirming that ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi was killed in a US airstrike, but it's not saying much else. The news comes via Iraqi News, which reports that three senior ISIS members were also killed in the airstrike, which took place in the city of Mosul. A photo that appears to be al-Baghdadi's body has been making the rounds on social media, according to the Washington Post, which notes that the Pentagon hasn't confirmed the death yet, though any ISIS leaders "inside troop formations they are likely to be killed."

– Big Bank Hank, a member of the early hip-hop group the Sugarhill Gang, has died of complications from cancer at age 57. The group were responsible for one of the most popular rap songs of all time, Rapper's Delight. The musician died Tuesday at a hospital in Englewood, New Jersey, according to David Mallie, a business manager for two former members of the group, and Aree Booker, a funeral director with Eternity Funeral Services. Big Bank Hank, whose real name was Henry Jackson, was born in the Bronx borough of New York. He was a part of the Sugarhill Gang in 1979 when it had its biggest hit, "Rapper's Delight."

– A 21-year-old Australian man was on vacation in Bali, Indonesia, when his body was invaded—by a spider that had burrowed under his skin. – When Stan Beaton lost his wife a decade ago, she left a voicemail message for him that he never heard—until this week, when a team of 10 employees at a British radio station heard about his story and decided to bring it back, the BBC reports. "That's her," he says as he hears the message. "Wonderful. Wonderful."

– The Scottish SPCA is appealing to the public for any information related to a dog that was found abandoned at a railway station along with a suitcase full of its belongings. In a Facebook post, the organization says the dog, which has yet to be named, was found "scared and whimpering" on the floor of a train station in Aberdeen on Sunday, per the Guardian. "It is believed that this is a pit bull who has been abandoned and is likely to have died as a result," the post adds, per the BBC. "If you see this dog, or any other abandoned animal, please get in touch with us."

– Jordan's King Abdullah ibn al-Hussein, who has trained as a pilot, may fly a bomber himself on Thursday in the country's retaliation against the ISIS. Jordan's King Abdullah ibn al-Hussein, who has trained as a pilot, may fly a bomber himself on Thursday in the country's retaliation against the ISIS, reports Reuters. The move comes after the country's air force dropped two F-16 fighter jets on ISIS targets in northern Iraq.

– The Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi probably isn't dead, but no one who's in a position to know for sure is saying anything. That's according to the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, which claims al-Baghdadi is still alive and planning to set up a new headquarters in the northern Syrian city of Raqqa, the capital of his "caliphate." A spokesman for the militant group, which has seized control of large parts of Iraq and Syria, told the AP on Sunday that the leader is still alive and planning to set up a new headquarters in Raqqa. The spokesman didn't provide details on when the leader is believed to have been killed or where the headquarters would be located. The Islamic State of Iraq and Syria leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi probably isn't dead, but no one who's in a position to know for sure is saying anything.

– If you've got an iPhone 6 Plus, you may want to put it in your pocket—but if you don't, you may not be able to bend it. That's according to the folks over at Gizmodo, who say they've tested the new iPhone 6 Plus, and they're pretty sure it's as bendable as the old one. The good news is that the new iPhone has a special case that allows it to be bendable without damaging the phone. The bad news is that the case is only half as bendable as the old one, so if you're planning on using the new phone while on the go, you may want to put it in your pocket.

– The discovery of a species of magic mushroom in the grounds of one of Britain's most famous stately homes has left a TV gardener stunned. Alan Titchmarsh was filming a Christmas special at Buckinghamshire's Buckingham Palace when he came across the mushroom, which he described as looking like a "fairytale mushroom," the Telegraph reports. "I've never seen anything like it in my life," said Titchmarsh, who described the mushroom as looking like a "fairytale mushroom from a children's book." "I've never seen anything like it in my life."

– Kim Jong Un may be the most famous man in North Korea, but he's apparently not the only one. The country's official Korean Central News Agency announced today that anyone named Kim is banned from "sharing the name" of the country's leader with the rest of the world, Yonhap News reports. According to the report, the ban applies to "any person with the name Kim Jong Un," including "any person with the name Kim Jong Un" as well as "any person with the name Kim Jong Un." Yonhap notes that the name Kim is "one of the most common in both Korean states and the given name Jong Un is also popular."

– The sister of Luke Somers, an American photojournalist held hostage by al-Qaeda in Yemen for more than a year, says the 33-year-old was killed during a rescue attempt this morning. Lucy Somers tells the AP that she learned of her brother's death from FBI agents at 5am. "We ask that all of Luke's family members be allowed to mourn in peace," she says. Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula had been threatening to kill Somers if the US didn't free its citizens in the country, the BBC reports.

– "All of God's creatures have a shot of ending up in heaven when they die." That's Pope Francis' take on a heartbreaking story out of Argentina, where he consoled a young boy after his beloved dog died, the Telegraph reports. The boy's father had taken the 4-year-old to see the pope in St. Peter's Square, but the visit was cut short when the boy's dog died on the way home from the park. The pope, who had seen the boy play with the dog before its death, consoled the boy by saying, "All of God's creatures have a shot of ending up in heaven when they die," per the Telegraph.

– A huge wels catfish has been caught in Britain's Po Delta, which is known for having the perfect living conditions for giant wels to flourish, the Independent reports. According to a British wels catfish website, they have hundreds ofvelcro-like teeth used to hold prey before passing food to "crushing pads" at the back of the throat.

– An Indian spiritual guru and multi-millionaire has convinced up to 400 followers that they should cut off their own testicles, Metro reports. Gurmeet Ram Rahim Singh, 47, said the castrations would bring the men closer to God. The painful procedures were carried out at a hospital owned by Singh, who is worth $40 million. He also has around 50 million followers worldwide. Singh has been dubbed the "Guru in Bling." The men were castrated around the year 2000 but the cases are only now coming to light as Singh is accused of grievous bodily harm.

– A group of Russian explorers went looking for Bigfoot in the foothills of Russia's Caucasus Mountains—and came back with more than they bargained for, the Daily Beast reports. According to the Mirror, the group shot a video that appears to show a big, hairy creature walking through a snowy, wooded area. Key details about the incident are missing, but the visuals are remarkable.

– The FBI has identified the second American killed in ISIS-controlled territory in Syria as 19-year-old aid worker Peter Kassig, a US citizen who joined the militant group last year. Kassig, who grew up in Ohio, was one of the first American fighters to join the Islamic State, which seized control of large parts of Iraq and Syria last year. He was killed in the early hours of Sunday near the border with Syria, reports the AP. A spokesman for the FBI's Cincinnati office tells the AP that Kassig was one of several aid workers killed in the fighting. He says investigators are still trying to determine whether other Americans have been killed. Kassig was working for Doctors Without Borders in Raqqa, the capital of the Islamic State's self-proclaimed capital, Raqqa, when he was killed.

– When it comes to the English language, it's all about the alpha and the omega, writes Jonathan Chait in the New York Times. The omega is the alpha, the omega is the alpha, the omega is the omega. And when it comes to the English language, it's all about the alpha and the omega. Chait recounts a story about a young woman in China who told him, "You can call me 'Easy.' That's my English name." He paused, thought for a moment, and then said, "You might want to consider changing your name." She thanked me for the tip. "I'm going to go and change my name now," she said. Click for Chait's full column.

– The US Geological Survey says a meteorite that crashed into the Pacific Ocean off the coast of Washington state was probably a "relatively small" one that "appeared to have come off an asteroid that was passing close to Earth," the AP reports. The USGS tweeted a photo of the meteorite, which was about the size of a grain of sand, along with the message: "A meteorite has crashed into the Pacific Ocean off the coast of Washington state." A spokeswoman for the USGS says the agency has determined it was a meteorite that "appears to have come off an asteroid that was passing close to Earth."

– The gunman who opened fire inside Canada's Parliament on Monday was shot and killed by an armed sergeant-at-Arms after he charged the building, police say. Kevin Vickers, 52, was shot several times as he tried to enter the Parliament building Monday morning, but he was brought down by the sergeant-at-Arms, who was armed with an assault rifle, the Globe and Mail reports. Witnesses say Vickers was wearing body armor at the time of the attack, which left one person dead and two others injured. "I'm just so thankful that the sergeant-at-Arms came to my aid," a woman who was in the Parliament building at the time of the attack tells the CBC. "I'm just so thankful that he was able to take the coward out."

– A 13-year-old girl in Bosnia has become the latest victim of the country's rampant underage pregnancy problem. The girl's mother says she was on a school field trip when she had sex with an 18-year-old man, then returned home to find herself pregnant at age 15, the Telegraph reports. "It is worrying that girl 13 years old to have sex, but that is the trend," says a local gynaecologist. The number of underage pregnancies is on the rise in the Balkans country, which has been wracked by war since the end of the 1990s. The government has set up a special committee to look into the issue. "It is worrying that girl 13 years old to have sex, but that is the trend," says another local gynaecologist.

– The FBI has identified the second American killed in ISIS-controlled territory in Syria as 19-year-old aid worker Peter Kassig, a US citizen who joined the militant group last year. Kassig, who grew up in Ohio, was one of the first American fighters to join the Islamic State, which seized control of large parts of Iraq and Syria last year. He was killed in the early hours of Sunday near the border with Syria, reports the AP. A spokesman for the FBI's Cincinnati office tells the AP that Kassig was one of several aid workers killed in the fighting. He says investigators are still trying to determine whether other Americans have been killed. Kassig was working for Doctors Without Borders in Raqqa, the capital of the Islamic State's self-proclaimed capital, Raqqa, when he was killed.

– A resort in Austria is set to open its doors to the public on Friday—and it's already got a pretty impressive opening date. The Saalbach-Hinterglemm ski resort, located in the state of Salzburg, says it's managed to save tons of snow from last year's brutal winter and is on track to be fully operational by the end of the month, the AP reports. The resort had originally planned to open in December, but bad weather forced it to push the opening date back to March. The resort's marketing director says the decision to delay the opening was based on the poor weather and the fact that most of the resort's lifts were still buried in snow from last year.

– Superman v. Batman: Paths of Glory is currently being filmed in Detroit, and rumor has it one of the movie's Batmobiles has been stolen, reports Bleeding Cool. No word yet on who took it, but if true, it's a shame.

– If you've got at least $500 burning a hole in your pocket, you may want to consider getting the new Apple Watch Edition. A French website is reporting that the 18-karat gold version of the watch will sell for up to $5,000, which works out to about $400 more than the standard Apple Watch and Apple Watch Sport will cost, CNNMoney reports. The watch will be available Feb. 14, according to Apple's website.

– A 46-year-old man who pinned a teenage boy to the wall in Rajasthan, India, ended up with his penis chopped off and dumped in the middle of the road, the Daily Star reports. According to the Hindu, the teen tried to rape Suresh Kumar in public, so the man pinned him. Then he saw his penis chopped off and thrown on the road. He was reportedly beaten with sticks for more than an hour at a butcher shop before being dumped in the middle of the road. Kumar was left bloodied and bruised, with no one helping him.

– Kim Jong Un may be North Korea's leader, but he's not above having a little fun with the people who name their children after him. According to a leaked government document, officials have been instructed to make sure no one is named Kim Jong Un and to "train" anyone who doesn't agree to the policy to change it, the Telegraph reports. Anyone with the name would be forced to have official documents, identity cards, and even school certificates altered. And birth certificates for the name would be rejected. The "administrative order" was leaked to South Korean news station KBS TV, according to Sky News.

– Militants from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria released a video today purporting to show the beheading of American photojournalist James Foley, who has been missing in Syria for 636 days, the Independent reports. The video, which has not been verified yet, claims that the killing is "a message to the US," according to the Telegraph.

– Rumors have been swirling that the Apple Watch will be able to withstand liquids for a long time to come, and the Wall Street Journal reports that Tim Cook has finally spilled the beans on the watch's supposed ability to do just that. In a Q&A session with employees at an Apple store in Berlin, Germany, Cook was asked about the watch's ability to withstand liquids like water, salt, and pepper, according to 9to5mac.com. "I don't know," he said when asked if the watch would be able to do that. "I don't know. I don't know what it is. I don't know what it can't do. I don't know what it can't do."

– Nigerian officials announced a ceasefire with Boko Haram two weeks ago, saying they had secured the release of more than 200 schoolgirls kidnapped by the militant group in April. But in a video released yesterday, Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau says there's no such deal, the New York Times reports. "Don't you know the over 200 Chibok schoolgirls have converted to Islam?" he asks in the video. "They are now married off." He says the girls were taken from a school in Chibok, Nigeria, in April and converted to Islam in the custody of Boko Haram, the BBC reports.

– Shane Smith, the CEO and co-founder of Vice Media, has won $1 million at the Bellagio casino in Las Vegas and spent $300,000 of his winnings on a meal for more than 30 employees and business partners, the Telegraph reports. According to the New York Daily News, Smith won the no-limit Texas Hold 'em game on Saturday and spent the rest of his winnings on a three-course meal for more than 30 employees and business partners at the hotel-casino. Smith, who is also a co-owner of the Las Vegas Review-Journal, is the latest in a long line of high-rollers to win big in Las Vegas.

– A video purporting to show the final moments of a French police officer's life has sparked a debate over whether the officer's death was a hoax. The video, which has been viewed more than a million times on YouTube, appears to show the officer's body just before he is shot and killed, the Independent reports. Police say the officer was shot in the head as he sat in his car outside a police station in the town of Evreux, south of Paris. The officer's body is blurred in the video, which has been viewed more than a million times, but a forensic expert says the lack of blood spatter suggests the killing was a close-range shooting, the Independent reports. "If the video shows events as they actually occurred, then in my opinion it is most likely that the firearm shown is discharging," the expert says. The officer was shot in the head as he sat in his car outside a police station in Evreux, south of Paris.
