– The Internet is abuzz today with the news that JJ Abrams, director of the upcoming Star Wars: The Force Awakens, has been arrested in connection with a sex tape that surfaced earlier this year. The New York Daily News reports that the 35-year-old is suspected of having sex with a 15-year-old girl while he was filming the movie in the back seat of his car. The tape was reportedly shot in the back seat of a car driven by the girl's 17-year-old friend, who is also suspected of having sex with the director. The driver of the car was also arrested. The Daily News notes that the sex tape was reportedly shot in the back seat of a car driven by the girl's 17-year-old friend, who is also suspected of having sex with the director.

– One of the most popular Instagram accounts in the world is paying tribute to the journalists killed in the Charlie Hebdo terror attack in Paris. Banksy's Instagram account posted a photo of the French newspaper with the message, "Je suis en terrasse Charlie Hebdo," or "I am Charlie Hebdo"—a play on the phrase "Je suis en terrasse," or "I am Charlie"—which has been widely interpreted to mean "I am Charlie" in French, the Guardian reports.

– The New York Post is reporting that the World Health Organization is looking into whether ISIS fighters have contracted Ebola. The Post's sources say that the WHO is investigating whether any of the group's fighters have contracted the disease, which has killed more than 11,000 people in West Africa. ISIS fighters are no match for Ebola, according to the Post's sources.

– A Canadian-Israeli woman who has joined the ranks of the Kurdish militias fighting Islamic State in northern Syria has been taken captive by ISIS fighters, blogs and Islamist websites thought to be close to the militant group, the New York Times reports. The woman, identified as 31-year-old Raveena Aulakh, is believed to be the first Westerner taken captive by the militants, who have seized large swaths of northern Iraq and Syria. Aulakh, who was born in Israel and moved to Syria with her family when she was 12, is believed to be a computer science student at the University of Calgary, the CBC reports.

– A recording that purports to be President Trump's call to Vladimir Putin during last year's G20 summit has surfaced, and it's a doozy. In it, Trump can be heard telling the Russian leader that "I love you, I love your country, I love your leadership, I love your people, I love your wives, I love your mothers, I love your wives." He adds that he's "very, very proud" of his country and that he "loves Vladimir Putin just as much as I love America." The White House has not confirmed the authenticity of the recording, which was made during Trump's meeting with Putin in Russia last year, but a senior administration official tells the New York Times that the president has been "very clear" that he doesn't approve of Putin's actions. The official says Trump was also "very clear" that he didn't approve of his national security adviser, Michael Flynn, who is accused of leaking classified information to Russian officials. Flynn has said he believes he was fired.

– Rats are so bad at the new 1 World Trade Center office for Vogue that editor-in-chief Anna Wintour is not happy, the New York Post reports. According to the paper’s sources, there are as many as 20 rats in the office, which is located in the same building as the Condé Nast offices. The paper also says there are rats in other parts of the building as well. The Conde Nast offices are currently undergoing renovations, according to the New York Daily News.

– Jose Canseco is in the hospital after accidentally shooting himself in the foot this morning at his Las Vegas home, 8 News Now reports. The injury is not life-threatening, and Canseco is expected to make a full recovery.

– When a Chinese couple found out their 29-year-old daughter had leukemia, they decided to do something about it: They sold their son to pay for her treatment, the Telegraph reports. Meng Xiangyan's twin brother was supposed to pay for his twin sister's treatment, but the family couldn't afford it, and so they decided to sell the 29-year-old to the highest bidder, according to the Daily Mail.

– A panel discussion on domestic violence that was supposed to air on ESPN's Monday Night Countdown last night has been canceled, reports the Los Angeles Times. The network said in a statement that the discussion, which was supposed to air as part of a two-part special, "did not take place as planned." The statement didn't elaborate, and it's not clear whether the panel discussion was specifically mentioned in the statement.

– Is the Apple Watch Edition going to be the next big thing? That's the question tech writers are asking today after the company unveiled its new line of watches last night. Here's what they're saying: The Apple Watch Edition is the most expensive of the bunch, but it's "relatively lovely on tiny female forms," writes Henry Blodget at Business Insider. "But how much might it cost?" he asks. "All Tim Cook offered last week was that the watches—the cheapest presumably being the sporty ones you'll sweat all over—are the cheapest presumably being the watches you'll leave us naked." Blodget's take: "It's going to cost a lot more than we thought. But it's not going to be the most expensive watch in the world. It's not going to be the smartest watch in the world. It's not going to be the most stylish watch in the world. It's not going to be the most functional watch in the world. It's not going to be the most beautiful watch in the world. And it's not going to be the most useful watch in the world. It's going to be a waste of time and money

– Apple's first major product launch in two years was supposed to be a resounding success. Instead, the company's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs has turned out to be a complete disaster, reports the Wall Street Journal. First-day sales of the $349 Apple Watch were so dismal that Apple CEO Tim Cook had to be removed from a meeting to discuss the watch's first-day sales. Analysts say the watch's biggest drawback is that it doesn't have enough battery life to run the phone or the computer. The first-day sales of the $349 Apple Watch were so dismal that Apple CEO Tim Cook had to be removed from a meeting to discuss the watch's first-day sales. Apple crushed its introduction of the Apple Watch yesterday in Cupertino, but while Kevin Lynch and Jony were waxing poetic about the design of watch and its revolutionary UI, there was one feature everyone steered clear of: battery life.

– A man in Norfolk spent more than $400 to save his constipated goldfish, the Telegraph reports. The man took the fish to a vet's office in North Walsham after he noticed it wasn't getting rid of waste as well as it should. The vet found the fish was constipated and euthanized it. The man, who has not been named, says he is "devoted" to his pet and the decision to euthanize the fish was "the right one."

– What do you call a condom that tastes like pumpkin spice? That's what Durex is banking on with its new pumpkin-spice-flavored condom, which has gone viral on social media since it was announced over the weekend, the New York Daily News reports. According to the condom's website, it's "made from 100% natural ingredients, like pumpkin spice, cinnamon, nutmeg, and ginger" and "injected with just the right amount of pumpkin spice to give it that extra kick." Durex claims the condom, which retails for $32, is the "world's first pumpkin spice condom," according to the Daily News.

– A St. Louis County grand jury has decided not to indict Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson in the shooting death of Michael Brown, reports the St. Louis Post-Dispatch. The decision means that the 28-year-old will not face criminal charges for the death of the unarmed 18-year-old. The newspaper says it has audio of Wilson telling Brown to stop resisting arrest just before shooting him six times. The St. Louis County medical examiner has said Brown was shot at least 18 times, including in the back, neck, and chest.

– Tiger Woods has been suspended from the PGA for a month, and ex-pro golfer Dan Olsen isn't taking it lightly. "I've heard that he's suspended," he said on an AM radio show. "And it's kind of a strong witness. It's a credible person that's telling me this. It's not testosterone but it's something else. I think when it's all said and done that he's gonna surpass Lance Armstrong with infamy." Olsen, who played on the PGA team that won the 1997 Masters, said he was told by a source that Woods is on a month-long suspension. "I think when it's all said and done that he's gonna surpass Lance Armstrong with infamy," he said.

– A South American nun suddenly started experiencing sharp pains, and not long after being rushed to the hospital, she gave birth to a baby boy. Now, the nun is claiming she had no idea she was pregnant.

– The FBI has identified James Wright Foley as the man accused of sexually assaulting a 16-year-old female high school student in Arizona, ABC News reports. According to the Arizona Republic, the 16-year-old victim says Foley grabbed her by the throat while she was in his bathroom. The FBI says it is working with the girl's family to bring charges against Foley.

– Rumors are flying that a massive explosion in Nicaragua on Saturday was caused by a meteorite. A 40-foot-wide crater was found in the woods near the capital of Managua, according to some reports, but Phil Plait at Slate isn't so sure. "I'm unconvinced," he writes. "Reports are still a bit sketchy, but my biggest doubts come in two." The explosion was detected by seismic detectors in the area, and residents reported hearing a large bang Saturday evening. According to some reports, the explosion was caused by a space rock slamming into the ground at high speed. But Plait writes, "I'm unconvinced. Claims are being made that this was a meteorite impact, a space rock a meter or so across slamming into the ground at high speed."

– The Islamic State militant known as "Jihadi John" has been identified by the BBC and the Washington Post as Mohammed Emwazi. Emwazi is believed to be a Kuwaiti-born British man who was known to British security services, who chose not to disclose his name for operational reasons. Jihadi John has appeared in videos showing the killings of US journalists James Foley and Steven Sotloff, US medic Abdul-Rahman Kassig, and Britons David Haines and Alan Henning.

– A Singapore woman was caught on camera having sex with her husband's mistress in an underground parking lot, the Straits Times reports. The woman, identified only as Ting Su, was spotted having sex with Cheng, 30, in the lot by a surveillance camera. Ting used a tracking device on Cheng's phone to find him and alerted the police, who arrested him and charged him with cheating on his wife. According to the New York Daily News, it's believed to be the first time a cheating husband has been caught on camera having sex with his mistress.

– "Working for you is a living hell." That's what the lead developer of smartphone game Electric Boogie wrote to his boss in a letter that appeared on a YouTube video yesterday, Gawker reports. The "secret ending" to the "not-at-all-popular" game appears to have been filmed in a meeting between the developer and the game's general manager, according to the Huffington Post. "Working for you is a living hell," the letter reads. "You have your head so far up your ass, it's time to go."

– A parody Twitter account affiliated with Fox News is threatening legal action against anyone who mocks the network, reports the Washington Examiner. The "@FoxNewsPress" account emerged over the weekend in response to a hashtag that made fun of a recent segment on the network. The segment involved author Steve Emerson, who writes books on terrorism, claiming that there are certain "no-go" zones for non-Muslims in Europe, including Birmingham, which he wrongly claimed is a "totally muslim" zone.

– The next generation of Apple’s MacBook Air will boast a 12-inch screen, a thinner and smaller footprint, a faster Intel chip, and maybe even a spot in Space Grey, according to 9to5mac.com. The site predicts that the new MacBook Air will be available this summer. “The next MacBook Air will sport a 12-inch screen, a thinner and smaller physical footprint, a cleaner chassis with one combined power connector and USB port, faster Broadwell chipsets from Intel, and it might even come in Space Grey,” writes Marc Gurman.

– A small meteorite crashed into a wooded area near the Nicaraguan capital's airport Saturday night, the BBC reports. Residents reported hearing a loud bang, and the crater left by the meteorite measured 40-feet wide and 16-feet. No one was hurt. Astronomer Humberto Saballos said the meteorite could be part of an asteroid that passed by Earth Saturday night. International experts have been asked to help local scientists in the investigation.

– New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio is expected to announce a major change to the NYPD's controversial stop-and-frisk policy today, the New York Times reports. According to the New York Daily News, police officers will no longer stop and frisk people on the street for drugs, alcohol, or weapons. Instead, they'll be required to do so as part of a criminal investigation. The policy has been heavily criticized for its use of stop-and-frisk, which has resulted in thousands of undocumented immigrants being stopped and frisked by police. According to the Daily News, de Blasio is expected to announce a major change to stop-and-frisk today.

– When Georgy Myakinkin, a 31-year-old airport worker in the Russian city of St. Petersburg, decided to strip down to his birthday suit for work, he didn't think he'd be caught on camera. But that's exactly what happened, the Telegraph reports. According to the Siberian Times, Myakinkin was working a shift at the city's main airport when he decided to strip down to his birthday suit and strip down to his boxers. He was caught on video by security guards, who watched in astonishment as he stripped down to his birthday suit and performed oral sex on one of them. The video has since gone viral, and Myakinkin—who says he was just trying to celebrate his 31st birthday—is now getting death threats.

– It's not every day that a bullet bounces off a Marine's helmet, but that's exactly what happened in this YouTube video, Fox News reports. The clip, shot in Afghanistan, shows three Marines searching a building for gunfire when a bullet bounces off one of them and hits a nearby door. The Marines don't realize it at the time, but the bullet is still ricocheting off their helmets.

– A drunk gay basher being tackled by travelers at the Dallas Fort-Worth International Airport grew a little more shocking with rumors that one of the citizen heroes was Paul Rudd. A shocking viral video of a drunk gay basher being tackled by travelers at the Dallas Fort-Worth International Airport grew a little more shocking with rumors that one of the citizen heroes was Paul Rudd.

– Batman vs. Superman is set to hit theaters next year, but you won't be able to catch a glimpse of the Batmobile in it. That's because Cosmic Book News recently reported that the iconic vehicle had been stolen from the set of the Batman vs. Superman movie in Detroit, according to the Hollywood Reporter. It turns out the story was a hoax, and director Zack Snyder responded by posting a mash-up of the new Batmobile and another version of the car from Star Wars: The Force Awakens.

– Is the iPhone 6 causing hair to tear out of people's beards? The Daily Mail reports some iPhone 6 owners are complaining about a seam between the aluminum and glass screen that's catching hair and tearing it out. Twitter users have been posting about the issue under the hashtags beardgate, seamgate, and hairgate.

– Police in the United Kingdom have arrested a street artist who they say was Banksy's "most wanted man," the Telegraph reports. Banksy, real name Robert Peston, was arrested Sunday at his home in Bristol after police received a tip from a member of the public. According to the BBC, the 47-year-old was believed to be Banksy's most wanted man because he hasn't been seen in public in more than a decade. Police say he was found with a large amount of marijuana, opiates, and cash.

– The US says it has spotted ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi in the Syrian city of Raqqa, the capital of the Islamic State group's self-proclaimed "caliphate." A senior US military official tells the AP that the military has been monitoring al-Baghdadi's movements in Raqqa for some time, and that American drones have been flying over the city in an effort to track him down. The official says the military has been in contact with local Syrian fighters who have renounced ISIS and are fighting the group in Raqqa, and that they have been informed of al-Baghdadi's location.

– President Obama and Michelle Obama are in Saudi Arabia today for a meeting with King Salman bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud, and the White House has released a video of the couple receiving the Order of Abdulaziz, the nation's highest honor. In the video, the Obamas can be seen shaking the king's hand, but there's a big blur in the middle of them where Michelle's hair is exposed. MSNBC's Chris Hayes was the first to report the apparent censorship of the first lady's hair, using the coinage "censorka" to describe the apparent censorship of the First Lady's exposed hair. "There's a big ol' ovoid blur where Michelle Obama should be," Hayes tweeted.

– ISIS militants fed a desperate mum the mutilated remains of her son—after telling her it was cooked meat and rice. The worried mum had bravely visited the terror group's headquarters in a bid to free her son, who had been beheaded by militants, the Sun reports. "They told me it was cooked meat and rice," the woman says. "I said, 'That's not meat and rice, it's a body,' and they said, 'It's a body,' and they said, 'It's your son,' and they said, 'He's been cooked and you can eat it.'" The woman's son had been beheaded by militants last month.

– The Islamic State today released a video that appears to show the beheading of American journalist James Foley, reports the New York Times. In the video, a man believed to be Foley kneels next to an armed man and says: “For what will happen to me is only a result of their complacency and criminality.” He goes on to criticize the US government. “I wish I had more time. I wish I could have the hope of freedom of seeing my family once again.” Foley was kidnapped in Syria in 2012.

– Amazon will open its first brick-and-mortar store in New York City in time for the holiday shopping season, the Wall Street Journal reports. The store, which will function more as a warehouse than a big-box store, will have a limited supply of items available for same-day delivery and will process returns, exchanges, and pickup orders. Amazon did not immediately say how long the experimental store would remain open, or whether it was preparing to open similar physical locations elsewhere in the country.

– Just a week after it was announced that Christian Bale would be playing Steve Jobs in Aaron Sorkin's film, it appears Seth Rogen will be taking on the role of Steve Wozniak, Variety reports. The film will be based on Walter Isaacson's biography of Jobs, and Sony did not respond to Mashable's request for comment about the casting report.

– "We have never been prouder of our son Jim. He gave his life trying to expose the world to the suffering of the Syrian people." So reads a statement from his mother, Diane Foley, in the wake of the execution of her son, James Foley. "We implore the kidnappers to spare the lives of the remaining hostages," the statement continues. "Like Jim, they are innocents. They have no control over American government policy in Iraq, Syria, or anywhere in the world. We thank Jim for all the joy he gave us. He was an extraordinary son, brother, journalist and person." The Islamic State, which released a video showing the execution of the 40-year-old journalist, has now threatened to kill the remaining hostages if the US doesn't free them, reports the New York Times. "We have never been prouder of our son Jim. He gave his life trying to expose the world to the suffering of the Syrian people," the statement continues. "He was an extraordinary son, brother, journalist and person. Please respect our privacy in the days ahead as we mourn and cherish Jim."

– Apple's first wearable device was supposed to help the company keep tabs on its workers and customers, but the company is now saying it won't be making such a thing. The Wall Street Journal reports that Apple CEO Tim Cook said in a letter to employees that the company has "paused" work on the Apple Watch "out of respect for our customers, employees, and regulators"—and that the watch won't be out until next year at the earliest. The Journal notes that Cook's letter doesn't say why the watch won't be out this year, but it does note that the company has "struggled to keep pace" with competitors such as Samsung, which has a well-established presence in the wearable-tech arena. In designing its first wearable device in the Apple Watch, Apple looked to incorporate a variety of highly advanced health functions with an eye on creating a holistic monitoring device, but ultimately scrapped those plans due to technological and regulatory hurdles.

– The Wall Street Journal is out with a report on the original health features of the Apple Watch, and they're not pretty. For one thing, the idea of tracking health and fitness data was a big one for Apple. The company began working on the watch about four years ago, with a focus on health and fitness, but the project proved to be a "particularly challenging" one, insiders say. For one thing, there were so many different sensors—10 of them, to be exact—to track health and fitness data that it was difficult to keep track of them all, the sources say. The Journal also notes that the watch's "heart rate monitor and fitness tracker" didn't work as well as expected, and it's not clear whether the company will bring back those features. Before the Apple Watch was unveiled last year, reports indicated the device would come with 10 sensors to track health and fitness data, leading some healthcare professionals to find the unveiled Apple Watch's health features disappointing.

The girls, who attend a school in Banja Luka, Bosnia-Herzegovina, were on a five-day educational trip to the Bosnian capital that was meant to focus on the country's history, but they ended up getting more than they bargained for while they were away from home, the Telegraph reports. – North Korea's state-run media hasn't reported on Kim Jong Un's whereabouts since the 31-year-old attended a concert with his wife on Sept. 3, and now a source with access to the secretive North's leadership tells Reuters that Kim hurt his leg while inspecting military exercises. The source says Kim is "in firm control" of his government, but the injury is not believed to be life-threatening.

– An attorney for the man who says he was video-chatting with a friend when he recorded police shooting Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., tells CNN that he has a "very, very disturbing" tape of the shooting that the FBI is now investigating. The attorney, Lopa Blumenthal, says the tape shows that officer Darren Wilson had a "point of contemplation" before firing the final shots, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch reports. The FBI is looking into the tape, which Blumenthal says was recorded by the unidentified man while he was video-chatting with a friend. On the tape, you can hear what sounds like at least 10 shots fired, with a significant pause separating the shooting into two segments, CNN reports.

– A newly released video shows Michael Brown's final moments before he was shot to death by Ferguson, Mo., police officer Darren Wilson. In the video, a man who appears to be Brown can be seen talking to a friend on a video-chatting app when the sound of gunshots can be heard in the background, CNN reports. The man turned the video over to the FBI as evidence. A forensic audio expert tells CNN he detected six shots, followed by four more after a brief pause.

– A vacation in Bali turned into a nightmare for an Australian tourist when he discovered a spider had burrowed under his skin. Dylan Thomas, 21, was sent away with antihistamine cream after suffering an allergic reaction to an insect bite, but three days later, when the red mark on his stomach began to blister, he knew something was wrong, the Telegraph reports. He went back to the medical center to see a dermatologist, who discovered that a tropical spider had burrowed underneath his skin.

– The 22-year-old girlfriend of Olympic swimmer Michael Phelps has revealed that she was born "intersex." Taylor Lianne Chandler says she was given the name David Roy Fitch at birth, the Telegraph reports. Intersex is "a general term used for a variety of conditions in which a person is born with a reproductive or sexual anatomy that doesn’t seem to fit the typical definitions of female or male," according to the Intersex Society of North America.

– A man claiming to be Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau said more than 200 girls kidnapped by the militant group six months ago had been "married off" to its fighters, contradicting Nigerian government claims they would soon be freed. Nigeria's military says it killed Shekau a year ago, and authorities said in September that they had also killed an imposter. Now, a man claiming to be Shekau says the girls are still being held, the BBC reports. "Boko Haram has married off the 219 girls taken from Chibok," the man says, referring to the town in Nigeria's northeast where the girls were kidnapped. "They are still in the custody of Boko Haram." He says the girls are being held in the extremist group's stronghold of Sambisa Forest. He says the group's leader, Abubakar Shekau, was killed a year ago.

– The Mexican town of Iguala has been wracked by violence for years, but things took a turn for the worse this week when four people were killed—including two police officers—in a car crash on a busy highway, the AP reports. The bodies of the two officers were found in the back seat of the vehicle, which was hit by a car driven by a man believed to be a drug trafficker, according to local media reports. The driver of the car also was killed. The cause of the crash isn't clear, and it's not clear whether the driver was killed by a pedestrian or by a car driven by a gang member, the Los Angeles Times reports.

– The explosion that rocked Nicaragua's capital on Saturday night was so powerful it left a crater more than a mile wide and was felt throughout Managua—but there were no reports of injuries. Nicaraguan authorities believe it was a piece of the small asteroid known as 2014 RC, which passed very close to Earth yesterday and was estimated by astronomers to be about 20 meters big, or the size of a house. "We are convinced that this was a meteorite," a spokesman for the country's meteorological agency tells the AFP. "It was a very powerful explosion." The asteroid passed very close to Earth yesterday and was estimated by astronomers to be about 20 meters big, or the size of a house.

– A female passenger at DC's Dulles International Airport was spotted yesterday wearing a hazmat suit, complete with full-body gown, mask, and gloves, the Daily Caller reports. The woman was waiting for a flight. Ebola patient Thomas Duncan had a layover at Dulles last month. Health officials have said that passengers at the airport were not at risk for exposure to Ebola because Duncan was not

– Kim Jong Un is apparently a big fan of pickled cobras. So much so that he wants to send them to his palace in North Korea in a gift of snake wine, reports the Daily Star in an article picked up by the Telegraph. Legend has it that snake wine has medicinal properties and can both increase fertility in women and improve virility in men. Kim and his wife, Ri Jol-su, are reportedly having trouble conceiving due to health problems from Jong-un being overweight.

– Another nun who had no idea that she was pregnant surprised her mother superior and sisters as she gave birth to a baby boy recently, according to the Daily Mail. The unnamed nun, who has not been named, gave birth to a baby boy recently, the Daily Mail reports. She had no idea she was pregnant until the baby was born.

– Weather forecaster Mike Seidel obviously thought he had enough time to answer a quick call of nature, but clearly he was wrong. In a video uploaded to YouTube by Kris Tatum, NBC Nightly news reader Lester Holt cuts to Seidel ready for the forecast. Holt says: 'Let's bring in Weather Channel meteorologist Mike Seidel he's in Sugar Mountain, North Carolina. Hi Mike.' But then there is an awkward pause until Seidel eventually says, 'Why?'" Holt adds, 'Well, obviously Mike's not ready for us.'"

– Big Bank Hank, aka Henry Jackson, has died of cancer at the age of 57. The rapper, whose real name was Henry Jackson, formed the Sugarhill Gang with Michael "Wonder Mike" Wright and Guy "Master Gee" O'Brien in the 1970s, and they were the first rap act to score a hit with their song "(You Gotta) Fight for Your Right (to Party)." TMZ reports that he died at a New York City hospital early Tuesday.

– When Pope Francis recently sought to comfort a distraught boy whose dog had died, the pontiff took the sort of pastoral approach he is famous for—telling the youngster not to worry, that he would one day see his pet in heaven. See the video here.

– It's that time of year again: time for pumpkin spice-flavored condoms to hit the shelves. Yes, that's right, they're here, in time for Halloween, reports the Los Angeles Times. Yes, it's that time of the year again: time for pumpkin spice-flavored condoms to hit the shelves. – MGM Resorts International unintentionally outed Vice Media CEO Shane Smith's ridiculously expensive $300,000 dinner at the Bellagio casino's Prime Steakhouse in January. Asked yesterday about spending levels at the company's casinos, MGM CEO James Murren bragged about the tab to Nomura analyst Harry Curtis: "$300,000 for dinner at Prime. That's a pretty good check. You would have liked the wine, Harry." Murren didn't identify the person who ran up the six-figure bill, but Bloomberg reporters quickly connected the dinner to Smith, who at the time of the meal was in the midst of a hot run at the blackjack tables

– A drone strike in Somalia may have killed the leader of al-Shabab, a militant group allied with al-Qaeda, the New York Times reports. Ahmed Abdi Godane was the group's No. 2 leader, and his death would be a "very significant blow" to al-Shabab, according to the Pentagon, which says it is still assessing whether an airstrike hit an encampment where Godane was believed to be hiding, Reuters reports. Godane was killed in a raid last month.

– North Korea's official Korean Central News Agency says Kim Jong Un's younger sister has taken over "important state duties" from her brother as he recuperates from a mysterious illness. Kim Yo Jong, believed to be around 20 years old, is North Korea's No. 2 leader and a member of the ruling Workers' Party Central Committee, the Yonhap News Agency reports, citing state media. The younger sister of North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un has taken over important state duties from her ailing brother, as he recovers from a mysterious illness, it has been reported. Kim Yo Jong is believed to be around 20 years old. The younger sister of North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un has taken over important state duties from her ailing brother, as he recovers from a mysterious illness, it has been reported.

– They're called K5s, and they're part of a fleet of robots testing out security at a Microsoft campus in Silicon Valley. The 300-pound, 5-foot-tall robots, which can "see" license plate numbers and analyze faces, aren't equipped with weapons and can't run or get in someone's face, but they do have onboard alarms and sirens to alert people if something bad is going on, reports the Mercury News. If they spot something that a person should handle, they can call a human security guard over.

– Police in Carlisle, England, are looking for a man who they say slapped a woman because she sneezed. The middle-aged man is believed to have assaulted a woman on Monday after she sneezed, the BBC reports. Police say it was "very strange behavior." They're now trying to track down the man.

– The fence-jumper who bolted across the White House lawn with a gun last week made it further into the building than previously reported, according to CBS News. The network says Omar Gonzalez made it 70 yards across the White House lawn before entering the North Portico doors, where he was stopped by a Secret Service officer with a gun. He then made it through the front doors to the White House's Cross Hall.

– Christian Bale will not be playing Steve Jobs in Sony's biopic of the Apple founder, sources tell Variety. Bale had been in talks with director Danny Boyle about the role, but a deal never came to fruition.

– If you've been dying to know when Star Wars: Episode VII—The Force Awakens will be out, well, you'll have to wait a little longer. Director JJ Abrams told the Visual Effects Society Awards last night that he's considering releasing the much-anticipated film this summer instead of next winter, io9 reports. "Instead of winter he may move his film down the line for a summer release!" the Verge quotes Abrams as saying. "This is an extremely brave move (if true) as it puts Star Wars into a new era."

– An American journalist held for more than a year by al-Qaeda's affiliate in Yemen was killed during a rescue attempt by United States commandos late Friday, a senior United States official said. – Christian Bale has dropped out of Aaron Sorkin's upcoming Steve Jobs biopic after just one week, reports the Hollywood Reporter. Sorkin said last week that Bale was "the best actor in a certain age range" to play Jobs, and that he'd agreed to the part without an audition. But Bale is "not right for the part," he tells the Reporter.

– Michael Phelps is out of rehab and back in the pool, but his off-the-rails life is far from over. The world's greatest swimmer has been linked to a 29-year-old porn star. Sources tell TMZ that Phelps, 22, has been seeing 24-year-old porn star Taylor Lianne Chandler since August, when he was already in a relationship with a 24-year-old porn star. The sources say Phelps, who is in the midst of a six-month rehab stint for alcohol abuse, has been seeing Chandler since at least July, when she was still a student at the University of California-San Diego. Phelps has been photographed with a woman believed to be Chandler multiple times since August.

The company says the change will apply to both men and women, though children will still be able to eat at McDonald's as long as they're under the legal weight limit for adults. McDonald's CEO Steve Easterbrook says the move is part of the company's "long-term plan to improve the health and well-being of our customers." The company says the change will apply to both men and women, though children will still be able to eat at McDonald's as long as they're under the legal weight limit for adults. – A 71-year-old Massachusetts priest who was declared dead by doctors 48 minutes after suffering a massive heart attack woke up and said he went to heaven and met God, the Huffington Post reports. Father John Michael O'neal was rushed to a hospital after suffering a massive heart attack. His heart was restarted and he said he went to heaven and met God, who he claimed to be a warm and Motherly figure.

– A Chinese woman was so fed up with her husband and twin sister cheating on her that she decided to take matters into her own hands—by following them around a shopping center, the Telegraph reports. According to the Daily Mail, 29-year-old Ting Su used a tracking device on her phone to follow her husband and twin sister, both in their 30s, as they shopped at a mall in the city of Luohe. She even posted photos of them on her Facebook page. "They cheated on me, so I followed them," she says. "I even called the police, but they couldn't help me because they didn't have any records of the crime. So I decided to take matters into my own hands." According to the Mail, Ting Su told the police her husband and twin sister had been using her phone to text each other, and when they were at the mall, she used a tracking device on their phone to follow them. The police were unable to help her because they didn't have any records of the crime.

– A dog was found abandoned at a Scottish train station next to a suitcase filled with it's belongings and now the local animal welfare charity are looking for tips into who is the neglectful owner. – North Korea's state-run media says Kim Jong Un has broken his ankle after eating too much cheese. South Korea's Yonhap News says the North Korean leader broke his ankle after he put on extra weight from eating imported cheese, according to state media. North Korea's official Korean Central News Agency says Kim broke his ankle while walking near his residence in Pyongyang on Sunday. The North Korean leader is expected to make a full recovery, according to the report.

– North Koreans who want to name themselves after Kim Jong Un are out of luck. The country's leader has banned the use of his moniker, and ordered those who already have it to be "trained" to change it, the Telegraph reports. According to state-run media, Kim has told officials to "resolutely" prevent anyone from using his name, and those who already have it will be "trained" to change it.

– You may have seen the amazing story today about the high school kid who made $72 million trading stocks. But now CNBC is reporting that the figure is totally bogus. Mohammed Islam, a 17-year-old high school kid in New York, was profiled as a Wall Street whiz kid who was raking in millions. The New York Magazine piece implies that his wealth ($72 million or not) largely came from trading. Mo got into trading oil and gold, and his bank account grew. Though he is shy about the $72 million number, he confirmed his net worth

– Is Axl Rose dead? That's the question everyone is asking today, after a TMZ reporter tweeted that the Guns N' Roses frontman had died in West Hollywood at the age of 52. But a rep for Axl Rose confirms to the Los Angeles Times that the singer "is not dead," and a TMZ reporter adds that Axl's longtime manager confirmed the news to him. Axl's ex-wife, Rose's fellow Guns N' Roses singer Slash, also denied the rumors to TMZ.

– An Australian man's trip to Bali was "ruined" when he had a horrifying run-in with a tropical spider. Twenty-one-year-old Dylan Thomas' horror story trip began while he was sleeping one night at his hotel: that's when a tropical spider climbed into his bed, burrowed through his appendix scar, crawled under his skin, and tunneled into his sternum. An initial visit to a doctor on Sunday saw him diagnosed as having been bitten by an insect and sent away with antihistamines. He spent another day with the insect tunneling inside of him before going to a hospital.

– The FBI has identified the second American killed in ISIS-controlled territory in Syria as 19-year-old aid worker Peter Kassig, a US citizen who joined the militant group last year. Kassig, who grew up in Ohio, was one of the first American fighters to join the Islamic State, which seized control of large parts of Iraq and Syria last year. He was killed in the early hours of Sunday near the border with Syria, reports the AP. A spokesman for the FBI's Cincinnati office tells the AP that Kassig was one of several aid workers killed in the fighting. He says investigators are still trying to determine whether other Americans have been killed. Kassig was working for Doctors Without Borders in Raqqa, the capital of the Islamic State's self-proclaimed capital, Raqqa, when he was killed.

– Harvard Business School professor Ben Edelman is in hot water after a story on Boston.com claimed that he sent an email with "racist overtones" to a Chinese restaurant. The story claimed that Edelman sent the email to Sichuan Garden because he was upset that a restaurant owned by a Chinese citizen was named after a slave-owning ancestor of one of the restaurant's owners. The story has since been taken down, but you can read the original here. Edelman denies sending the email and calls the story "ridiculous." "I have never sent an email with racist overtones," he tells the Harvard Crimson. "I have never sent an email with racist overtones to anyone."

– When Dylan Thomas of Australia went on vacation in Bali last week, he woke up with a nasty mark on his stomach that kept growing. "I started to feel a burning sensation like a searing feeling," he tells his local paper, the Bunbury Mail, via ABC Australia. A dermatologist at Bali International Medical Center determined the cause was a tropical spider that had burrowed into Thomas' skin through an old appendix scar.

– Militants have stolen several commercial jetliners in Libya, raising concerns about 9/11-style terror strikes as the 13th anniversary approaches, some reports say. The theft of the Boeing jets, which were parked at a Tripoli airport, was first reported by a passenger who was on one of the planes, according to al-Jazeera. The plane's whereabouts are unknown.

– Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, the man believed to have fatally shot a soldier standing guard at Canada's Parliament before being shot by police, was a Canadian citizen born to Syrian parents who had converted to Islam in recent years, sources tell the Globe and Mail. The sources say Zehaf-Bibeau, 32, had been under surveillance because of his possible links to radical Islam, and that his passport had been seized by authorities, the AP reports.

– First there was bendgate... now brace yourself for hairgate. Fresh from the online uproar over whether the shiny new iPhone 6 bends when carried around in pockets, Apple has been hit by a new complaint—that the handset traps users' hair or beards when they make calls, reports Reuters. The new iPhone has been in wide circulation since its debut last week, but now a small number of users are complaining that it traps their hair or beards when they make calls, reports the Telegraph. One woman tells the paper that when she tried to make a call from her iPhone 6 last week, her hair "came out of my ear" and she "felt like I was trapped in a trap." A spokesman for Apple says the company is aware of the issue and is working to fix it.

– Legendary country singer Willie Nelson was found dead today at the age of 81 in his Maui home, reports Hawaii News Now. The cause of death hasn't been officially determined, but police say there was no evidence of drug abuse or alcohol and there was no sign of foul play. "There was no evidence of drug abuse or alcohol and no signs of foul play," says a police spokesman. Nelson was found by a groundskeeper who was performing yard maintenance, reports AP.

– A video that claims TBS speeds up its Seinfeld reruns by 7.5% in order to squeeze in two extra minutes of commercials has been making the rounds on Reddit for a few months now, but over the weekend it recirculated, gathering a lot of attention. The video, which purports to show the real-life effects of the network's decision to cut back on reruns in order to squeeze in two extra minutes of commercials, was first posted on Reddit back in March, according to the Hollywood Reporter.

– North Korea is denying reports that Kim Jong Un is planning to open a restaurant in Scotland, the Guardian reports. According to the Telegraph, North Korean experts had speculated that Kim, who presides over a chain of restaurants known as Pyongyang, would like to open a branch in Scotland because it's "a natural target for expansion." But an official with the country's Ministry of Foreign Affairs calls the reports "a nonsense."

– When FXX took over the syndication rights to The Simpsons last year, one of the stipulations was that older episodes with longer run-times be edited to the modern standard of 22 minutes in order to fit in the now normal 8 minutes of advertising found within half-hour programming. Not every network is so keen on trimming whole scenes to make run-times work for older shows, but that doesn't mean they're immune to tricks of their own. That's reportedly what's happening over at TBS. Thanks to one crafty viewer, it seems to have been discovered that TBS has been running syndicated episodes of Seinfeld for years that were cut to fit in the now normal 8 minutes of advertising found within half-hour programming.

– When Dim Xiong Chien, 22, went to buy fireworks for his girlfriend's 22nd birthday, he had no idea he'd end up burning down his college's sports hall in the process. The Daily Mail reports Chien bought three large boxes of fireworks and planned to set them off as he got down on one knee and proposed to girlfriend Cong Yen, also 22. But when Yen didn't show up, he set the fireworks off anyway—and the entire sports hall on campus was on fire.

– A Western Australia man says he was bitten by a spider while visiting Bali for the first time—and now scientists say the story may not be true. The unnamed man says he was bitten by a black widow spider while walking on a beach on the first day of his visit to the Indonesian island last month, the BBC reports. "I was walking on the beach when I was bitten by a black widow spider," he tells the Bunbury Mail. "I was in shock. I didn't know what was going on." He says the spider burrowed into his abdomen and he didn't realize it was a spider until it was out of his skin and he started convulsing. "I was in shock for a couple of minutes and then I realized it was a spider," he says. "I didn't know what was going on." A doctor who examined the man says he was bitten on the right side of his body and the bitten spider didn't appear to be a black widow spider. – It's not every day that a 21-year-old wakes up to find a trail of red dye stretching up his stomach, but that's exactly what happened to Dylan Thomas last weekend in Bali. The English student was on vacation with friends when he woke up to find a red trail stretching up his stomach, reports the Telegraph. It's not clear what the trail was, but it's enough to make Thomas think he's a real-life Spider-Man.

– A story making the rounds on social media claims to have caught the attention of the world's most famous graffiti artist: Banksy. The story, which appears on the news website National Report, says that the "real" artist was arrested in Watford, England, after being tracked by a "24-hour Anti-Graffiti Task Force." But the BBC reports that the story is "particularly ridiculous," noting that there's no evidence to back it up and that Banksy isn't from Liverpool.

– Boko Haram is holding a German hostage, the militant group's leader says in a video obtained by AFP. In the video, Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau says his group is "holding your German hostage." Shekau also denies reports that Boko Haram has reached a ceasefire with the Nigerian government, the BBC reports. Shekau says the ceasefire was a "lie" from the Nigerian government.

– Tiger Woods' ex-wife, Elin Nordegren, is selling the 62-acre Swedish island they shared before their marriage fell apart, the Daily Mail reports. The property, on Lake Mlaren, features a villa, a hunting lodge, its very own landing strip for propeller planes, six golf holes, a custom-made golf hole, and of course, Nordegren's favorite hobby: hunting. It's for sale for $3 million.

– There are unconfirmed reports that jihadists fighting for the Islamic State have contracted Ebola. Local media outlets reported that cases of Ebola have showed up at a hospital in the IS-controlled city of Raqqa in Syria, the Wall Street Journal reports. "There are unconfirmed reports that jihadists fighting for the Islamic State have contracted Ebola," a spokesman for the Nusra Front, an al-Qaeda-affiliated group, said in a statement. "The Nusra Front has never had any cases of Ebola and there is no reason for us to believe that this is the case."

– A 31-year-old Canadian-Israeli woman who traveled to Iraq to join the Kurdish fight against the Islamic State group reportedly has been abducted by the group. A 31-year-old Canadian-Israeli woman who traveled to Iraq to join the Kurdish fight against the Islamic State group reportedly has been abducted by the group, the New York Daily News reports. According to Haaretz, the woman—whom the paper identifies only as Dov Dov—is believed to have been taken by militants from the Islamic State in the northern city of Kirkuk on Sunday.

– The Islamic State appears to have unleashed a chemical attack on Kurdish fighters defending a Syrian border town, the BBC reports. A Kurdish official says ISIS fighters fired a crude chemical weapon at the Kurdish forces defending Kobani last night, causing people to lose their eyesight, blistering on the skin, and respiratory problems. Testing on victims has not taken place because of the intensity of the fighting there, but a Kurdish doctor in the town, who was also injured by the strike, says he is '75%' sure it is a chemical weapon.

– Boko Haram has reportedly agreed to a cease-fire with the Nigerian military as well as the release of hundreds of schoolgirls who were abducted by the terrorist group earlier this year, officials said Friday. Boko Haram has reportedly agreed to a cease-fire with the Nigerian military as well as the release of hundreds of schoolgirls who were abducted by the terrorist group earlier this year, officials said Friday.

– A Utah man has set a new world record by chugging down a carton of eggnog in 12 seconds. Ryan Roche beat the previous record of 22 seconds by downing a carton of the creamy holiday drink at an office party, reports the Salt Lake Tribune. (See the video here.) The 34-year-old says he was pressured into the contest and ended up with an infection in his lungs.

– The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS) now controls about a third of the country's Anbar province, which includes the cities of Mosul and Tikrit, the New York Times reports. The militants seized the provincial capital of Tikrit last week and have since forced thousands of residents to flee their homes. In Mosul, meanwhile, the government has declared a state of emergency after an outbreak of several diseases, including Ebola, HIV, and measles, the Times reports. According to Iraqi officials, 26 people have been diagnosed with HIV in the city, and two people have died from Ebola, the Independent reports. The government has also declared a state of emergency in six other towns and villages in the province, including Qadhimeya, Baiji, and Dohuk, the Times notes. ISIS controls about a fifth of the territory it seized in northern Iraq, including Mosul, the country's second-largest city.

– Pope Francis has given hope to gays, unmarried couples and advocates of the Big Bang theory. Now, he has endeared himself to dog lovers, animal-rights activists and vegans. The pontiff has given hope to gays, unmarried couples and advocates of the Big Bang theory. Pope Francis has given hope to gays, unmarried couples and advocates of the Big Bang theory. Now, he has endeared himself to dog lovers, animal-rights activists and vegans.

– A photo posted to Twitter on Monday by the Ansar al-Deen Front, an Islamic extremist brigade seemingly comprised largely of Chechen fighters, shows the Ford F-250 with a militant standing in the bed firing the anti-aircraft gun. A photo posted to Twitter on Monday by the Ansar al-Deen Front, an Islamic extremist brigade seemingly comprised largely of Chechen fighters, shows the Ford F-250 with a militant standing in the bed firing the anti-aircraft gun. – Apple's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs hasn't gone as well as the tech giant had hoped. The company's shares fell more than 5% in after-hours trading Tuesday, reports the Wall Street Journal. The stock has lost about a quarter of its value this year. Apple CEO Tim Cook said at the company's annual shareholder meeting that the company had "a lot of work to do" before its smartwatch went on sale later this year. Analysts had expected Apple to announce a cheaper version called the Apple Watch later this month.

– A man dubbed the " guru in bling" allegedly convinced up to 400 men to cut off their own testicles so it would bring them closer to God. Ouch. A man dubbed the " guru in bling" allegedly convinced up to 400 men to cut off their own testicles so it would bring them closer to God. Ouch. A man dubbed the " guru in bling" allegedly convinced up to 400 men to cut off their own testicles so it would bring them closer to God. Ouch.

– Apple's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs is scheduled for next week, and the tech giant's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs has been leaked. Sources tell the Wall Street Journal that the Apple Watch, which is expected to be unveiled at an event next week, will have a stainless steel case with an 18-karat gold band. The Journal's sources say the case, which can be opened using the watch's built-in app, is about the size of a credit card. Apple has not confirmed the leak.

– Mexican authorities say they've found a mass grave in the southern city of Iguala that may contain the bodies of 43 students who went missing after police clashed with protesters last week, the AP reports. Security forces discovered the grave on the edge of town on Saturday. Guerrero Gov. Angel Aguirre says the victims had been "savagely slaughtered." He says the victims' throats were cut and their heads were cut off. Relatives of the missing students from a teacher's college say they believe police killed them and dumped their bodies in the grave. "We cannot say anything. We are very nervous, but until they inform us, there is nothing," the father of one of the missing students tells the AP.

– A blast near the Nicaraguan capital city of Managua on Saturday night was most likely caused by a meteorite plummeting to Earth, creating a 40-foot-wide crater. A 40-foot-wide crater. A blast near the Nicaraguan capital city of Managua on Saturday night was most likely caused by a meteorite plummeting to Earth, creating a 40-foot-wide crater. (See a photo here.) – An attorney for Michael Brown's family says a police audio recording of the shooting that killed the unarmed 18-year-old contains "disturbing" and "graphic" evidence. The recording, which CNN says it has obtained, shows officer Darren Wilson telling Brown to put his hands up before shooting him multiple times in the back, the New York Daily News reports. In the recording, Wilson can be heard telling Brown, "I'm going to kill you." Brown's father, Michael Brown Sr., tells the Daily News that the recording is "disturbing" and "graphic." He says his son was trying to get his hands up when he was shot. "I don't know what to make of it," he says. "He was trying to get my son's hands up. I don't know what to make of it." The recording comes as Brown was laid to rest today, the same day CNN aired an audio recording in which the gunshots that killed Brown can be heard in the background.

– Apple's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs is just over a month away, and the company is already feeling the heat. The Wall Street Journal reports that the company had to cut many of the health-tracking features that were supposed to be included with the Apple Watch before it releases it in April. According to the Journal's sources, the company originally planned for the Apple Watch to have a whole range of exciting health-tracking features, but it had to cut many of them before its anticipated release.

– Fidel Castro hasn't been seen in public for more than a year, but that didn't stop the Internet from going wild last night with rumors that the Cuban leader is dead, reports the Los Angeles Times. Twitter went wild with speculation about the 88-year-old leader's health after a Spanish newspaper reported that he had been admitted to a hospital in Mexico for respiratory problems. "Felipe Castro is dead," read one tweet. "His eyes are closed. He doesn't walk. He doesn't eat. He doesn't drink. He doesn't listen to the radio. He doesn't speak. Is he dead?" A spokesman for Castro's brother Raul told the AP that the rumors are baseless and that the elder Castro is recovering from intestinal surgery.

– New York City officials are considering issuing tickets for possession of small amounts of marijuana instead of arresting people, officials said. The new guidelines would allow people with low-level marijuana possession to be issued a court summons rather than requiring them to get handcuffed, arrested, and brought into the precinct for finger-printing, the New York Times reports. Police arrested some 50,000 people a year on minor marijuana charges during the administration of former Mayor Michael Bloomberg. Numerous states and localities have decriminalized marijuana for medical or recreational use in recent years.

– An alarm box near the front entrance of the White House designed to alert guards to an intruder had been muted at what officers believed was a request of the usher’s office, the New York Daily News reports. According to the Washington Post, the White House usher’s office asked for the box to be muted on Friday, the same day a suspicious package was sent to the White House. The box was supposed to alert the Secret Service if a suspicious person was spotted near the front entrance. The package turned out to be harmless.

– In a video uploaded to YouTube, prankster Josh Paler Lin gives $100 to a homeless man and secretly follows him to find out how it was spent. – A Western Australia man's bizarre tale of a spider that apparently burrowed into his abdomen while he was on vacation in Bali has gone viral—but now scientists say it may not have been a spider at all. Dylan Thomas says he suffered "a really burning sensation like a searing feeling" in his abdomen while on vacation in Bali earlier this month. He says a specialist dermatologist was called in and he was able to remove what was believed to be a spider with tweezers, the BBC reports. But scientists in Perth say there may not have been a spider at all. "There is no evidence that a spider was present in the abdomen of Mr. Thomas," they write in a report published in the West Australian. "There is no physical evidence that a spider was present in the abdomen of Mr. Thomas." The scientists say it's possible that a spider could have crawled into Thomas' skin while he was on vacation in Bali, but they don't believe it was a spider of any kind. "It's possible that a spider could have crawled into Mr. Thomas' skin while he was on vacation in Bali, but we don't believe it was a spider of any kind," one of the scientists tells the BBC.
