– A homeless man in California got a big surprise when YouTuber Josh Paler Lin handed him $100—and followed him around to see what he did with it. The video shows Thomas walking into a liquor store, buying bread, and then heading over to a park, where he handed out food to other homeless people, the Washington Post reports. Lin says he was moved by Thomas' story. He says he lost his job to take care of his sick parents and couldn't afford food. He quit his job to care for his parents, only to lose his home. Lin says he wanted to see how Thomas was doing after getting the money and decided to follow him around to see what he would do with it.

– It's not every day that a meteorologist makes headlines for relieving himself on-air, but that's exactly what happened to Mike Seidel of NBC's Today show on Wednesday, reports the Los Angeles Times. (See the video here.) It's also not every day that a TV news anchor gets called out on social media for doing just that. But that's exactly what happened to Brian Williams of NBC's Today show on Thursday, reports the New York Daily News. (See the video here.) It's not clear whether Seidel actually did relieve himself on-air, but it's clear that his co-anchor, Matt Lauer, didn't see it. (See the video here.)

– Cesar Millan, better known as the "Dog Whisperer," has died of a heart attack at the age of 45, according to a report on a Spanish news agency's website. The website, ProcesoMX, said Millan died at a hospital in Malaga, Spain, the BBC reports. Millan, a Mexican-American, became famous in the 1990s for his work with dogs on the Discovery Channel's Cesar Millan: Life After Dog. He also starred in the National Geographic Channel's Cesar Millan: Life After Dog: A Dog's Tale.

– Newt Gingrich was back on the campaign trail Tuesday night for the first time since he dropped out of the race for the GOP nomination, and he didn't exactly have a great night. The former House speaker, speaking at a rally in Mobile, Ala., was heckled and booed by the crowd as he took the stage, CNN reports. "You're fired," he told the crowd. "You're fired." At another point, he told the crowd, "You're fired. You're fired." Gingrich was booed again when he addressed the crowd after his speech, saying, "You're fired. You're fired. You're not going to be president of the United States. You're not going to be president of the United States." At another point, he told the crowd: "You're fired. You're not going to be president of the United States." Gingrich was booed again when he addressed the crowd after his speech, saying, "You're fired. You're not going to be president of the United States." He told the crowd: "You're fired. You're not going to be president of the United States."

– KFC has no plans to open a marijuana restaurant, according to a story making the rounds on the website Racket Report. The story claims that the fast-food chain is in talks to open a pot restaurant in Colorado as a way to boost sales of the drug, which is legal in the state, the Denver Post reports. A KFC spokesperson tells the Post that the company is "not in a position to comment on rumors or speculations."

– A lawyer for the family of Michael Brown says he has audio of the gunshots that killed the unarmed 18-year-old at the hands of Ferguson, Mo., police officer Darren Wilson. The lawyer, Lopa Blumenthal, tells CNN that the man who lives near the scene of the shooting recorded the shots accidentally. He says he heard six shots and a pause, then several more. Blumenthal says the man, who hasn't been identified, is a friend of Brown's who was standing near the police cruiser at the time of the shooting. He says he didn't realize until he heard the gunshots that they were coming from Wilson's gun. A private autopsy commissioned by Brown's family found that he was shot six times, including twice in the head.

– A satirical website went viral over the weekend with a story claiming that Boston Marathon bombing suspect Dzhokhar Tsarnaev had been attacked in prison and left blind and paralyzed. The story, posted on Empire News, claimed that Tsarnaev had been found lying in a pool of blood in his cell at Massachusetts' Ft. Devens Detention Center. According to the New York Daily News, thousands of people shared the story on Facebook and other social media. But, as the Daily News notes, the incident never happened, and Tsarnaev is still safe in his cell awaiting trial.

– An 85-year-old woman in Waco, Texas, has been arrested for allegedly kidnapping her neighbors' cats and making them into fur coats, the Waco Tribune-Herald reports. According to the World News Daily Report, some local residents hired a private investigator to figure out what was going on. The investigator caught the woman on tape stealing a neighbor's cat. The woman admitted in court that she tried to raise her own cats, but became too attached to them. Prior to being caught on tape, the woman denied all allegations.

– The Islamic State militant known as "Jihadi John" in videos showing the beheading of Western hostages has been identified as Mohammed Emwazi from London, the Washington Post reports. Emwazi, believed to be 27 or 27, was known to MI5 as a "person of interest" in 2011, but his name was not revealed for "operational reasons," according to the BBC. One of Emwazi's friends was quoted as saying his name was not revealed at an earlier stage for "operational reasons."

– Banksy has been busted—in a hoax. The artist was arrested during a raid on his studio in London, according to a report on nationalreport.net. The site, which describes itself as "America's No.1 independent news source," claimed that a man named Paul Horner from Liverpool was arrested during the raid, the BBC reports. The report said that a "London police chief" held a press conference to announce the arrest.

– The Ebola patient being treated in a Kansas City-area hospital is not being treated for the virus, officials say. An assistant vice president at HCA Midwest, which is caring for the man, says the patient does not have the symptom profile of Ebola and is being treated appropriately for his condition, the Kansas City Star reports. The man, whose name has not been released, was rushed to the hospital Saturday after becoming ill. He is being treated in the hospital's isolation unit.

– Two Republican lawmakers told BuzzFeed News Wednesday suspected terrorists have infiltrated the US–Mexico border and as many as 10 fighters have been captured, but Homeland Security officials deny any such thing has happened. Rep. Jason Chaffetz, a Republican from Utah, said four alleged terror suspects were captured on Sept. 10 in Texas. In an interview Wednesday, Chaffetz said the men flew from a Middle Eastern country to Mexico City, where they paid a smuggler to take them to and across the border. From there, the men ended up in a safe house for immigrants. They were en route to New York City, Chaffetz said. But a Department of Homeland Security rep tells BuzzFeed there's "no indication" of such a thing.

– Militants from the Islamic State have released a video showing the beheading of American journalist James Wright Foley, who went missing in Syria in 2012, the Telegraph reports. In the video, a masked executioner says the killing is in retaliation for US airstrikes against the militant group in Iraq. "The life of this American citizen, Obama, depends on your next decision," the executioner says. "I'm back, Obama, and I'm back because of your arrogant foreign policy towards the Islamic State." The State Department says it is "sickened" by the video and is working to authenticate it.

– The US has been dropping bombs on ISIS targets in Iraq and Syria for more than a month now, and one of the biggest screw-ups came last week when a B-52 bomber crashed into a building in northern Iraq that was being used as a training ground for Kurdish fighters, reports the New York Times. No one was hurt in the crash, but the Pentagon is calling it an "unintentional" accident and says the bomber was on the wrong side of the runway. It's not clear what caused the crash, but Kurdish fighters were using the building as a base from which to launch attacks on the US.

– Mark Olberholtzer and his family near Houston have received hundreds of phone calls with questions and threats after a Chechen-led group tweeted a photo of the black Ford F-250 in action near Aleppo. Olberholtzer and his family have received hundreds of phone calls with questions and threats after a Chechen-led group tweeted a photo of the black Ford F-250 in action near Aleppo. Mark Olberholtzer and his family near Houston have received hundreds of phone calls with questions and threats after a Chechen-led group tweeted a photo of the black Ford F-250 in action near Aleppo.

– AK Verma hasn't been to work as an executive engineer at India's Central Public Works Department since December 1990. That's not bad for a guy who was found guilty of "wilful absence from duty" in 1992 and had to be kicked off the job again 22 years later, reports the Times of India. The government blames Verma's long absences on "seeking extension of leave, which was not sanctioned, and defied directions to report to work." It's not the first time such a thing has happened, though the Times notes that such cases are rare.

– Police in England are on the hunt for a man who slaps people in the head right after they sneeze. According to the Mirror, an 82-year-old woman was hit in the head by a man in Carlisle on Monday after she sneezed, and police believe the same man attacked an 82-year-old woman on Tuesday after she sneezed, the Independent reports. "It is believed that the same man is responsible for both incidents and we are following up several leads," a police spokesman says. The man in the first incident is believed to be in his mid to late 50s, the Daily Mail reports.

– Bad news for Pumpkin Spice lovers: Durex says it won't be releasing a pumpkin-flavored condom in the near future, BuzzFeed reports. "Rumors that Durex was working on a pumpkin-flavored condom have been greatly exaggerated," the company said in a statement. "We have no plans to introduce a pumpkin-flavored condom in the near future."

– A woman at DC's Dulles Airport was spotted yesterday wearing a rain poncho, medical gloves, and a protective mask, reports the Daily Caller, which calls the outfit a "hazmat suit." It's not clear why she was wearing it, but Dulles is one of five US airports that have implemented "enhanced screenings" for travelers from Liberia, Sierra Leone, and Guinea. (Ebola patient Thomas Duncan passed through Dulles on his way to Texas from Liberia.)

– A horrific story out of Iraq, where a mother says ISIS militants fed her her son's mutilated remains—after telling her it was cooked meat and rice. The mother, identified only as Sajida, says militants arrived at her home in Mosul last week and showed her her her son's body, which had been cut in half and covered in blood, the Telegraph reports. "They said it was cooked meat and rice," she says. "I couldn't believe it." She says the militants told her they had taken her son from his mother's house and killed him before feeding him the rice and meat. "I was so angry," she says. "I couldn't believe it." The mother says she was able to identify her son's body using his bloodstained clothes. She says the militants told her they had taken him from his mother's house and killed him before feeding him the meat and rice. "I was so angry, I couldn't believe it," she says. "They said they had taken my son from his mother's house and killed him. I couldn't believe it." She says the militants told her they had taken her son from his mother's house and killed him before feeding him

– Russian President Vladimir Putin unveiled a World War I monument in Moscow last Friday, ahead of the centennial of the start of the "Great War." Sometime on Saturday, a video popped up on YouTube purporting to show a bird staging a form of protest—defecating, to be specific, on Putin. See it here.

– Militants in Libya have posted pictures online of themselves posing with some of the 11 commercial jets that went missing last month after their takeover of Tripoli airport. US officials fear that these planes could now be used to carry out 9/11-style attacks in the region on the anniversary of the tragedy this month, the Telegraph reports. The militants from the group Libyan Dawn can be seen climbing on to the wings of commercial jets while smiling and waving for the camera. US officials fear that these planes could now be used to carry out 9/11-style attacks in the region on the anniversary of the tragedy this month.

– A man who tried to rape a teen in Rajasthan, India, was so enraged by the incident that he had his penis cut off by an angry mob, the Daily Star reports. The 40-year-old man, identified only as Suresh Kumar, was dragged away by the mob and his penis was then thrown on the street. Photos of the incident were posted online.

– In the wake of this week's horrific attack on Israeli soldiers in the West Bank, the Washington Post takes a look at what it calls the "flood libel," a term coined in the 1980s to describe accusations of anti-Semitism that have been hurled at journalists over articles they've written. In this case, it refers to an article by Jonathan Weisman at the Jewish Daily Forward that was, in the words of the Post's editor-in-chief, "riddled with errors, misstatements, and outright fabrications." And it's not just Israeli soldiers who are at fault, writes Weisman. "There are moments when biased coverage of Israel goes beyond mere opinion," he writes. "Last year, the good folks at Vox, a notoriously error-ridden site, declared the existence of the 'flood libel.'" Read his full column here.

– The FBI has identified James Wright Foley as the man accused of sexually assaulting a 16-year-old female high school student in Arizona, ABC News reports. According to the Arizona Republic, the 16-year-old victim says Foley grabbed her by the throat while she was in his bathroom. The FBI says it is working with the girl's family to bring charges against Foley.

– Hundreds of people in the Gaza Strip have been forced to evacuate after Israel opened the gates of several dams on the border with the Gaza Strip, and flooded at least 80 households. Palestinian officials say hundreds of Gazans were forced to evacuate after Israel opened the gates of several dams on the border with the Gaza Strip, and flooded at least 80 households. The flooding is the result of torrential rains caused by El Nio, one of the hottest summers on record, the AP reports.

– Brian Williams says he's sorry for his on-air behavior that's come under fire in the wake of the Brian Williams controversy, and he's asking for an apology from social media critics who've been belittling him. "I want to apologize to my colleagues, to the millions of people I have worked with over the years, and to the entire NBC family," he said at a news conference Monday night, per the New York Daily News. "There has been no urinating on Brian Williams' airwaves, and I want to make it clear that I am not the same person. I apologize to my colleagues, to the millions of people I have worked with over the years, and to the entire NBC family." Williams, who apologized last week for being "inartful" about being on the plane that was shot down in Iraq in 2003, says he's "deeply sorry" for what he calls an "error in judgment," the AP reports. He says he was on a flight from New York to California when the plane was shot down.

– Lego may have come a long way since the 1970s, when a leaflet accompanying a set encouraged parents to let their kids build whatever they want instead of forcing them to go down specific gender lines, the Independent reports. Now, however, the company has come under fire for apparently reversing this policy—and it's not for lack of trying. An image of the 1970s letter, which was uplodaded by reddit user fryd_, was uplodaded by a few people, who called into question its authenticity.

– Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, the man believed to have shot a soldier outside Canada's Parliament yesterday before being shot dead by police, has been identified as the gunman, reports the CBC, which notes that Zehaf-Bibeau "appeared to have no online presence." That's because, as of this writing, there's only a single photo on the Internet that appears to show Zehaf-Bibeau, and it comes from an account linked to ISIS.

– The heartwarming video of a homeless man buying food for friends with $100 he had been given was viewed more than 25 million times on YouTube—but there's a twist: The man in the video, identified only as "Thomas," is actually a con artist, his brother tells CBS Los Angeles. Thomas' brother says he was told by a friend that the video was real and that he should donate the money to a homeless shelter. But Josh Paler Lin, the YouTube personality who posted the video, says that's not the case. He says he gave the money to a homeless shelter in Huntington Beach, Calif., and it's being used to buy food for other homeless people. Thomas' brother says his brother is being scammed. Meanwhile, an eyewitness to the filming also believes the video is real.

– North Korea's Kim Jong Un is so fat that his ankles have fractured, according to a report in a South Korean newspaper. Sources tell Chosun Ilbo that the 31-year-old leader has put too much strain on his ankles while touring the country and had to have an operation to fix the problem. The sources say Kim's failure to attend a recent session of the Supreme People's Assembly is also to blame, the Telegraph reports.

– If you're in Colorado and craving a fried chicken with a side of weed, KFC has just the place for you. The fast-food chain has been granted a license to sell legal cannabis in the state, reports the Denver Post, which notes that nearly half of the chain's Colorado franchises have already started selling cannabis. "In order to be successful, a deep understanding of the market is critical to success," a KFC spokesperson says in a statement. "It's all about evolution and we are ready to serve the needs of the people of Colorado." Customers who want to buy cannabis with their genetically modified fried chicken will still need to prove that they are at least 21 years of age, with a valid government issued ID.

– The World Health Organization is investigating reports that ISIS militants have been showing up at an Iraqi hospital with Ebola. According to three media outlets an undisclosed number of militants displaying signs of the disease attended a hospital in the ISIS-held city of Mosul, 250 miles north of Baghdad.

– Saudi Arabia's King Salman met with President Obama in Riyadh on Tuesday, and while the meeting was live-streamed on state TV, there was a bit of a kerfuffle over whether the first lady was blurred out, reports the Wall Street Journal. Video clips circulated online Tuesday that purported to show that Saudi state television blurred out Michelle Obama at a meeting between President Obama and the new Saudi king. However, observers of the live broadcast—including a Wall Street Journal reporter in the country—say that there was no blurring of Mrs. Obama, and that the broadcast showed her shaking hands with King Salman.

– A Canadian woman reported missing by her family last week has been found alive in northern Syria, her brother tells the CBC. Gill Rosenberg, a 31-year-old mother of two, was reported missing by her family on Oct. 6 after she failed to return from a trip to Turkey. Her brother says she was found in the Kurdish town of Kobani, which has been under attack by Islamic State militants. "She's alive," his brother, Craig Rosenberg, says. "She's in good health." Sources in the Kurdish underground in Syria denied Sunday night that Rosenberg had been in the Kobani region, as claimed by Islamist and Palestinian websites that reported she was captured by ISIS during the fighting in that area.

– A Led Zeppelin reunion tour, backed by an astonishing amount of money put up by British billionaire Richard Branson, will never happen—because singer Robert Plant ripped up a contract that would have paid him about $300 million to play 35 concerts with the legendary band in just three cities. A Led Zeppelin reunion tour, backed by an astonishing amount of money put up by British billionaire Richard Branson, will never happen—because singer Robert Plant ripped up a contract that would have paid him about $300 million to play 35 concerts with the legendary band in just three cities. A Led Zeppelin reunion tour, backed by British billionaire Richard Branson, will never happen—because singer Robert Plant ripped up a contract that would have paid him about $300 million to play 35 concerts with the legendary band in just three cities.

– A 600-pound woman has given birth to a 40-pound baby at Perth's King Edward Memorial Hospital, a record breaking weight that could possibly make the newborn the largest baby ever born, reports the Western Australian Herald this morning. The baby, who weighed in at 40 pounds, 7 ounces, is believed to be the largest baby ever born in Australia.

– A man accused of attempting to rape a teenage girl was set upon by a vigilante group who hacked off his genitals with a meat cleaver. These horrifying pictures show Suresh Kumar, 40, after he was beaten with sticks for an hour before being castrated in the city of Ganganagar in India, reports the Telegraph.

– A US airstrike hit two vehicles carrying al-Shabaab militants near the Somali town of Barawe last night, killing at least six, an al-Shabaab spokesman tells the AP. The spokesman wouldn't say whether the group's top leader, Ahmed Abdi Godane, was among the six killed, but a witness described ground-shaking explosions after the strike.

– Apple's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs hasn't exactly been a roaring success. The company's latest gadget, a smart watch called the Apple Watch, has had mixed reviews, with some saying it's too expensive and others saying it's too little, too late, reports the Wall Street Journal. The Journal notes that the $349 price tag for the base model of the watch—which will be available next month—is a big increase from the $199 price tag for the iPhone 6. Apple CEO Tim Cook has said the watch will be "the most expensive product in the company's history," though he hasn't said how much the company plans to spend on it.

– Stephen Strasburg's three-year contract with the Washington Nationals is up at the end of the month, and the 21-year-old phenom isn't saying whether he'll sign a new one, reports the Washington Post. "We'll see," he said earlier this week when asked about the possibility of a new deal. "We'll see what happens." The Nationals are in the middle of a contract dispute with the players' union, and if a new one isn't reached by the end of the month, Strasburg is expected to walk away without a deal.

– It's unofficially Fall, which means you'll see the word "pumpkin" trotted out even more often than the phrase "Apple product launch" this month. Brands like Starbucks do not seem to have heeded the "enough with the pumpkin stuff!" warning; as friend of the site Dave Armon of Critical Mention wrote in one of those rare comments worth reading: "Like it or not, Starbucks is killing it with this story. We spotted 75 airings on US TV and radio stations today, through 5:45pm ET. Personally, I'll wait until I can see my breath before ordering anything."

– A 17-year-old New York City high school student known for spending his lunch breaks flipping stocks has reportedly amassed a $72 million fortune. So much for idle millennials: a 17-year-old Stuyvesant High School student known around campus for spending his lunch breaks flipping stocks has reportedly amassed a $72 million fortune. – American photojournalist Luke Somers, who was being held by al-Qaeda militants in Yemen since he was abducted in September, was killed during a failed rescue attempt early Saturday, according to his sister. American photojournalist Luke Somers, held by al-Qaeda militants following his abduction in Yemen's capital, Sanaa, in September last year, was killed during a failed rescue attempt early Saturday, according to his sister. – David Haines, the British singer-songwriter best known for hits like "You've Lost That Lovin' Feelin'" and "(You've Lost That) Love," has died at the age of 69, reports the BBC. Haines, who gained fame in the 1980s with songs like "You've Lost That Lovin' Feelin'" and "(You've Lost That) Love," died of complications from pneumonia in a hospital in London, reports the Independent.

– A 62-acre Swedish island once belonging to Tiger Woods and his then-wife, Elin Nordegren, is now for sale, the San Jose Mercury News reports. Located on Lake Mlaren, the 62-acre Vladi Private Islands island features a villa, hunting lodge, private ferry boat, horse stables, landing strip for propeller planes, and six tee-off locations for the golfer, who used to live there with Nordegren before their marriage went down the tubes in 2010. The price for the island, which also features a private ferry boat and horse stables, is $7 million.

– A homeless man holding a sign asking for money from a freeway offramp in Orange County, Calif., spent the $100 he received from a local liquor store on food and other items for others in need, the Los Angeles Times reports. Josh Lin, an amateur filmmaker, decided to film the homeless man as he entered a liquor store to see how he'd spend the gift of $100. Lin watched as the man bought food and walked to a local park, where he gave it to others in need. "I was shocked," Lin tells the Orange County Register. "I thought he was going to spend it on himself." Lin posted his video to social media, where it's been viewed more than a million times.

– A 1795 time capsule buried by Paul Revere and Samuel Adams in the cornerstone of the Massachusetts State House has been removed and will soon be on display, the Boston Globe reports. The contents of the box—believed to have been placed by Adams, then governor of Massachusetts, and Revere, a soldier who helped lead the revolt against British rule—will be on display "for the foreseeable future," according to Massachusetts Secretary of State William Galvin. Galvin tells CNN that the contents of the box, which was dug up and reburied in 1855 during repairs to the building, will be on display "as soon as the cornerstone is removed from the cornerstone."

– A neighbor tells 8 News NOW former baseball star Jose Canseco was hurt in an accidental shooting Tuesday afternoon at his house on the eastside of the Las Vegas valley. Canseco was hospitalized in stable condition.

– The Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) killed at least 300 Iraqi soldiers by using chlorine gas in an attack on a military base in Fallujah, an Iraqi lawmaker said today. MP Ali al-Budairi, from the Shia-dominated National Iraqi alliance in the Iraqi Parliament, told a press conference that the attack was carried out by the ISIS-affiliated al-Sham Front, the New York Times reports. It's unclear when the attacks took place. There are reports that ISIS militants used chlorine gas before.

– The New York Post is reporting that the World Health Organization is looking into whether ISIS fighters in Iraq have Ebola. Yes, that's two catastrophes combined. And it's not just the Post, Mashable had a piece earlier this week about reports from the Iraqi media that ISIS militants have contracted the disease. Their report, however, does contain some response from people with knowledge of whatever's going on. Firstly, a WHO spokesperson told them they've had "no official notification" from the Iraq government about the cases. – A 40-year-old man who tried to rape a teenage girl in India was beaten to death by a mob and his manhood was cut off with a meat cleaver, the Telegraph reports. Police say the mob caught Suresh Kumar trying to rape the girl in a dark area of the northern city of Ganganagar. He was also dragged to a butcher's shop and a meat cleaver was used to cut his manhood off. The girl's mother says her daughter was on her way to school when she was attacked by a group of men. "She was screaming for help but the men couldn't stop them," she says. "They beat him to death and then cut off his manhood with a meat cleaver," she says. "I was in shock when I saw his manhood cut off," she says. "I asked them to stop, but they kept on beating him." Kumar has been charged with rape and attempt to rape and is being held in a jail in the state of Uttar Pradesh, the BBC reports. – Twitter is abuzz with rumors that Cuba's former communist leader Fidel Castro has died, although the timing is suspiciously close to the death of another high-profile person who shares his name. – Islamist militias in Libya took control of nearly a dozen commercial jetliners last month, and western intelligence agencies recently issued a warning that the jets could be used in terrorist attacks across North Africa. – A 19-year-old woman in Colombia has become the first person in the world to die because she ate a genetically modified food, reports the World News Daily. The woman, identified only as Carolina, ate what doctors say was a "biological material" from the lab that had been altered to make it "more nutritious, tasty, and safe." She died of acute intoxication after eating it, and her autopsy will be performed today. It's not clear what the "biological material" is, but the Colombian government has approved genetically modified foods for public consumption.

– It's not the kind of thing you'd expect to see on an anonymous blog, but that's exactly what's happened in the case of an anti-Muslim video that's gone viral on YouTube. The video, which purports to show a Muslim reciting verses from the Koran while wearing a headscarf, has been viewed more than 11 million times since it was posted Wednesday, according to BuzzFeed, which says it's the most popular video on the site so far. The video has been called "chilling," "despicable," "cowardly," "horrible," and "shameful" by some, while others have called it "sickening," "reprehensible," "cowardly," and "shameless," BuzzFeed reports. According to BuzzFeed, the video was shot in the parking lot of a mall in Manchester, England, and was recorded by a man who claims to be a 22-year-old Muslim. In the video, the man's voice can be heard saying, "You are a terrorist." The video was posted to an anonymous blog that was set up on the same day the video was published, according to BuzzFeed, which reports it's been viewed more than

– When Texas plumber Mark Oberholtzer traded in his old truck for a new one last year, he didn't expect it to end up in the hands of Syrian rebels. That's exactly what happened, the Houston Chronicle reports, after a militant group tweeted a photo of Oberholtzer's old truck and said it was being used to transport an anti-aircraft gun. "I was like, 'Oh my God,'" Oberholtzer tells the Chronicle. "They're taking my truck and they're going to kill me." He says he's been getting death threats since the photo was tweeted by Jabhat Ansar al-Din, a Syrian rebel group.

– As the US steps up airstrikes against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, some Republicans are starting to worry that the militants may already be crossing the border into the US, the New York Times reports. Rep. Duncan Hunter, a Republican from California, said on the House floor yesterday that "it's possible" ISIS fighters are already crossing into the US, according to the Los Angeles Times. "I'm not saying it's not possible, but I'm not saying it's a certainty," he said. "I'm just saying it's a very real possibility." Hunter's comments echo those of Texas Gov. Rick Perry, who said in August that there was a "very real possibility" ISIS fighters had already crossed into the US.

– Christian Bale is in talks to play Steve Jobs in an upcoming biopic being produced by Sony, reports Variety. Leonardo DiCaprio was originally in talks to play Jobs, but withdrew from negotiations earlier this month.

– Kim Jong Un has reportedly been drinking snake wine in an attempt to boost his love life with his wife. According to the Daily Star, the North Korean leader has been guzzling liters of rare snake wine with the body of a deadly cobra inside. The Daily Mail reports the snake wine was delivered to Kim's palace.

– "That must have cost a fortune!" says Stan Beaton of the three days it took Virgin Mobile UK to retrieve a long-lost message from his late wife's cell phone. Beaton, 68, saved the "leave a message after the beep" recording that his wife, Ruby, made after she died in 2003, the Telegraph reports. But when Virgin Mobile carried out some technical work, the message was lost. BBC Radio Leeds was able to retrieve it, and a video of Beaton's reaction has gone viral.

– North Korea's state-run Korean Central News Agency is reporting that Kim Jong Un has had ankle surgery and will be out of the public eye for a while, the AP reports. The report is based on an interview with an unnamed official who says the surgery was performed on Kim's right ankle. The official says the North Korean leader will be out of the public eye for "a while," but he is expected to make a full recovery. Kim hasn't been seen in public for more than a month.

– In the wake of the Charlie Hebdo massacre in Paris, Banksy has taken to the streets of the French capital with an image of the magazine's cover. The artist, who has never shied away from drawing satirical caricatures, posted the image on his website, along with the message, "Je Suis Charlie," or "I Am Charlie," reports the Telegraph. (See it here.) The image has been shared thousands of times on social media.

– The World Health Organization has yet to confirm reports that ISIS militants in Iraq have contracted the Ebola virus, but an International Business Times article confirms that three Iraqi news outlets reported that Ebola showed up at a hospital in Mosul, a city 250 miles north of Baghdad which has been under ISIS control since June 2014.

– Twitter is abuzz with rumors that Cuba's former communist leader Fidel Castro has died, although the timing is suspiciously close to the death of another high-profile person who shares his name. – Rats are apparently a thing. The New York Post reports that staffers at Condé Nast’s new 1 WTC digs in New York City are still seeing them, even though the building is still under construction. The paper notes that rats have been spotted in other Condé Nast buildings, including the new headquarters for Vogue, which is moving from Paris to New York later this year.

– In North Korea, it's not unusual for people to have to give up their names. But in the case of Kim Jong Un, it's not unusual at all. According to a report by a South Korean TV station cited by the Wall Street Journal, North Korean authorities ordered people to give up their names when Kim Jong Un took over from his father, Kim Jong Il. The directive was reportedly issued in 2011.

– If you're using iOS 8, you may want to stop reading now. According to a report from 9to5mac.com, iOS 8's "All Settings" feature deletes data stored in iCloud Drive. The report says the feature was included in iOS 7 but not included in iOS 8, which was released last week. The "All Settings" feature can be used to wipe a user's data from iCloud Drive, according to 9to5mac.

– When NBC meteorologist Mike Seidel got caught on camera peeing in the woods during a live weekend appearance with Lester Holt, NBC News decided Brian Williams needed to discuss it on NBC Nightly News last night. "It's come to this. Yes, it's come to this," Williams said on last night's edition of NBC Nightly News. "When a report went viral that NBC meteorologist Mike Seidel got caught on camera peeing in the woods during a live weekend appearance with Lester Holt, NBC News decided Brian Williams needed to discuss it on NBC Nightly News tonight." (See the video here.)

– Rapper Big Bank Hank, whose real name was Montel Williams, has died at the age of 69, reports TMZ. The performer, whose real name was born Montel Williams Jr., was a member of the Sugarhill Gang, a hip-hop group based in Southern California. He was best known for the song "(You Gotta) Fight for Your Right (to Party)." He was also known as "the grandmaster with 3 MCs that shock the house for the young ladies," according to his website.

– A heartwarming video is going viral, and it's all thanks to a YouTube user. JoeyTrombone posted the video to his channel on Christmas Day, and when his parents opened the envelope to see that their mortgage had been paid, they were just as moved as you would imagine. "I mean, these people were cuddling on the couch even before they got the news," writes Daniel D'Addario on Reddit. "I have no specifics on how he pulled it off, but of course the first YouTube comment is everything you need to know about YouTube commenters."

– A 31-year-old Canadian woman says she is "alive and well" after reports that she had been kidnapped by the Islamic State, or ISIS, in northern Iraq, the CBC reports. Gill Rosenberg, a member of the Kurdish peshmerga fighting force, was said by ISIS to have been seized near the Turkish border on Saturday. According to the New York Daily News, ISIS was said to be debating whether to execute her or try to negotiate her release in a prisoner swap. But Rosenberg, who joined the peshmerga this year, posted to Facebook yesterday that rumors of her capture are untrue. "I am alive and well," she wrote. "Please be patient until I have more information." Rosenberg has been posting regularly on Facebook since joining the peshmerga.

– If you're a fan of the MacBook Air, you're in for a treat: Apple will be releasing a 12-inch version of the laptop this year, making it its biggest product to date, the Wall Street Journal reports. The 13-inch MacBook Pro will be the company's biggest product to date, while the 15-inch MacBook Air is currently Apple's smallest. The 12-inch MacBook Air will be available in stores next month.

– There's a story making the rounds about an Australian man who, upon returning from a trip to Bali, discovered that a spider burrowed under his skin and traveled up to his chest. Freaky? Yes, but it's also not plausible. Rest easy, arachnophobes. You do not have to worry about Charlotte weaving her web beneath your flesh. The supposed story goes like this: Dylan Thomas (a 21-year-old man, not the dead poet) was on vacation in Bali and woke up one morning to discover a red "trail" of irritation running from his navel to his chest.

– Depressed, 26-year-old Tan Shen stopped off at a KFC in China's Chengdu for some chicken wings. "I just wanted some chicken wings," she tells the Daily Mail. "But once I got in there and started eating I decided I needed time to think. "I didn't want to eat the rest of the wings." She spent a week in the fast-food joint, eating 35 wings a day. "I was walking around feeling miserable and decided to stop off at the KFC at the train station," she says. "I hadn't planned on staying there long, I just wanted some chicken wings. But once I got in there and started eating I decided I needed time to think."

– A married TV actor who met a young woman and kissed her in a sauna woke up to find his testicles had been stolen. Dmitry Nikolaev, 30, is believed to be the target of a gang—including a doctor—that may be harvesting organs to sell on the black market, the Telegraph reports. According to Russian media, Nikolaev met the woman in a bar, kissed her in a sauna, and woke up in the middle of the night to find his penis and testicles had been stolen.

– Amazon has warehouses—hundreds of them, miles of them. It has lockers and pop-up shipping containers. But it's never had a true, physical retail store, at least not until now. The Wall Street Journal is reporting that Amazon plans to open its first physical store, and that it will be located in midtown Manhattan, right in the heart of New York City. It'll be located on 34th Street, right between the flagship Macy's store and the Empire State Building. In a way, the store will reportedly be just an extension of what Amazon already does in its physical spaces.

– A video purporting to show a US marine being shot in the head by an Afghan sniper in 2013 is going viral, BuzzFeed reports. The video was uploaded to YouTube on Sept. 26 by Sam Arnold, who has been described as an Afghanistan veteran. In the video, the marine can be seen being hit in the head by an unknown sniper during a raid in the Now Zad district of Helmand Province. After being hit, the marine tells his colleagues he's fine and has a ringing in his ears.

– Militants from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria say they've executed American journalist James Foley, reports the New York Times. The militant group released a video yesterday showing the execution of the 40-year-old, who went missing in Syria in November 2012, and said it would kill him if the US didn't cease airstrikes in Iraq. Politico's Blake Hounshell was the first to report on the news on Twitter, saying the militant group is threatening to kill another reporter in retaliation for US strikes on their forces in Iraq: Foley had been missing since November 22, 2012 when he disappeared in Syria.

– North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's younger sister Kim Yo-Jong has taken over the running of the country and is making all the important decisions in her brother's absence, according to a think tank in Seoul formed by North Korean defectors. – A man was arrested in London yesterday for allegedly posting a picture of himself on Facebook with the caption "I'm on my way to the Carnival," the Telegraph reports. The man's photo has since been taken down, but the Telegraph notes that it bears a "striking resemblance to a hoax that went around last year."

The piece, by Jessica Pressler, is headlined "Mohammed Islam Is a billionaire, but He's Not a Millionaire," and it's based on an interview with the 17-year-old, who says he made $72 million last year from the stock market. I'm just a high school senior, and I made a lot of money." He says the Observer story is based on an interview he gave to a friend last year, when he was still in middle school, and he says he didn't tell anyone at the time because he didn't want them to think he was rich. – Kim Jong Un hasn't been seen in public for more than a month, but South Korea's National Intelligence Service told lawmakers in a closed-door meeting that the North Korean leader had a cyst removed from his right ankle between May and June, CNN reports. The cyst may have caused muscle or nerve damage, and may have led to ankle surgery between September and October. South Korea's National Intelligence Service told lawmakers that "European experts" handled the surgery for tarsal tunnel syndrome, which is caused by compression on the ankle.

– If you've been using iWork on your iPhone, iPad, or iPod Touch since iOS 8 was released last week, you may want to stop reading now. According to MacRumors, an iOS 8 bug could erase iWork documents stored on your iCloud drive. If that happens, you may not be able to access any of your iWork documents, reports Digital Trends.

– If you're an Apple fan who'd like to try on an Apple Watch before you buy it, you'll soon be able to. The Wall Street Journal reports that Apple stores will now accept in-store reservations for the Apple Watch, and employees will even train customers how to choose the best watch for them. The Journal also reports that the high-end Apple Watch Edition will have scratch-resistant gold, which it explains is because Apple mixes the metal with low-density ceramic particles.

– When a Comcast customer called to complain about shoddy service, the company's reputation took a hit—but it's not because of customer service. It's because of what Consumerist calls the company's "satanic glory." The employer of the man who made the call fired him after he complained, and now Comcast is reaping the benefits. "If reports this week are accurate, Comcast has continued to shine as an innovator in the competitive field of corporate terribleness," writes James Surowiecki at Time. "It got a customer’s employer to fire him for complaining about shoddy customer service." Surowiecki's take: "The full story in all its sadistic glory is at Consumerist."

– The World Health Organization says it has no indication that members of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria are suffering from Ebola, Mashable reports. According to Iraqi media outlets, ISIS fighters in the northern city of Mosul have tested positive for the virus, which has killed thousands of people in West Africa. The WHO says it has reached out to Iraqi officials to offer help, but there is "no official notification" that ISIS members are suffering from Ebola, Mashable reports. Iraq's Ministry of Health also says it has no indication that ISIS members are suffering from Ebola.

– When YouTuber Josh Paler Lin gave $100 to a homeless man in Anaheim, Calif., he expected the man to spend it on alcohol. Instead, he got a surprise when the man, identified only as Thomas, went into a liquor store and left with enough food to feed everyone around him, reports the Daily Dot. Lin posted the story on his YouTube channel, and it's been viewed more than a million times.

– Batman vs. Superman is set to hit theaters next month, but the Batmobile—the centerpiece of the movie—has gone missing from a Detroit parking lot, the Detroit Free Press reports. According to a report on CBS Detroit's website, the customized car, which was used in the Batman v. Superman trailer, is "presumed stolen." No word on how the car got away.

– Rats have taken over Conde Nast's new offices at One World Trade Center, and editor-in-chief Anna Wintour "doesn't even want to go in the building anymore," a source tells the New York Daily News. Vanity Fair editor Graydon Carter, meanwhile, tells Confidenti@l that the rodents are "snooty" and "relentless," and that they're causing a lot of damage to the drywall.

– President Obama has condemned the execution of American journalist James Foley by the Islamic State, saying the militant group "has no place in the 21st century." In a statement the White House issued after the release of a video purporting to show Foley's beheading, Obama said the US "will continue to work with partners around the world to degrade and ultimately destroy" the group, which he said "has no place in the 21st century." The president said the US "will continue to work with partners around the world to degrade and ultimately destroy" ISIS, which he said "has no place in the 21st century." (Read Obama's full statement here.)

– The Islamic State is training its fighters to fly captured fighter jets in the hopes of eventually establishing an air force in Syria, the Independent reports. According to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, the militants are testing out the planes at the captured al-Jarrah military airport east of Aleppo. The planes were captured from the Syrian military, and Iraqi pilots who were officers in Saddam Hussein's air force have been trained to operate them, the Telegraph reports.

– The internet is in a tizzy over a photo that purports to show Vladimir Putin with his penis on display. The image, which surfaced on Reddit yesterday, appears to show the Russian leader with a horse in what appears to be a photo taken during his 2012 inauguration, the Daily Dot reports. It's not clear if the penis in the photo is actually Putin's, but if it is, it's sure to spark a lively debate on Reddit and elsewhere. The Daily Dot notes that this isn't the first time Putin's penis has made the rounds on Reddit.

– A touching tribute to the victims of last week's Charlie Hebdo shooting in Paris has been shared more than 100,000 times on Instagram—but it's not from Banksy, the Independent reports. "We can confirm this is not by Banksy," says a rep for the street artist. "Several fake Banksy social media accounts have attracted thousands of followers, however the artist has confirmed on his official website that he is not on Facebook or Twitter."

– Is Anna Wintour's reign as editor-in-chief about to come to an end? According to Radar's sources, rats have taken over Wintour's new office in New York City's Freedom Tower. "The office is over-run and the Vogue staff is secretly whispering that the rats could be cosmic," says one source, who adds that the rats have made their way into Wintour's accessories closet, leaving behind "an abundance of rat droppings all over their pricey couture, computers, and desks." Click for more.

– The World Health Organization said last week that it was investigating reports that militants with the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria may have contracted the Ebola virus, which has killed thousands of people in West Africa. But while the WHO hasn't confirmed that militants in Mosul, Iraq, are showing symptoms—including fever, vomiting, and abdominal pain—the current evaluations at a hospital there "are prompting concerns that the fringe extremist group ISIS may in fact be able to obtain a biological weapon unlike anything the world has seen before," reports the Daily Beast. Iraq's health ministry, however, denies that ISIS militants have contracted Ebola.

– As a 9-month-old, Jess Smith was one of the most familiar faces on British television in the 1990s. At the age of nine months, Jess Smith was selected to be the giggling Baby Sun who looks over Teletubbyland. Sources say that in the initial phase, only retail stores will be allowed to sell the watch, and that Apple won't even be sending the watch to its resellers. The sources say that this will make it easier for Apple to dominate the market for smart watches. The sources say that at least in the initial phase will be the SmartWatch reserved exclusively for retail stores to monopolize the market and to create additional admissions in the Apple Stores. – A bikini-clad woman was dragged to her death by a falling tree branch in Pacific Shores, Calif., on Sunday. Police say the woman was pronounced dead at the scene, and a witness tells the Los Angeles Times that the tree branch fell as the woman was getting into her car. The Pacific Shores Police Department tweeted a photo of the woman's body Monday, adding that the investigation is ongoing.

– Police are investigating after a hand grenade was found in a safe above an old sweet shop in Shortlands. “We have been told a hand grenade has been found in a safe directly above the old sweet shop," an estate agent tells the News Shopper. "Everything here has just come to a stand still."

– A member of the Sugarhill Gang, whose pioneering hit "Rapper's Delight" brought hip-hop to mainstream audiences 35 years ago, died Tuesday of complications from cancer. – If you've got an iPhone 6, there's a good chance your hair is going to get caught in the seam between the glass screen and the aluminum back of the phone, 9to5mac.com reports. Twitter users say their hair is getting caught in the seam between the glass screen and aluminum back of the iPhone 6 when they hold the phone up to their ear to take a call.

– Apple has finally released a video preview of the Apple Watch, and it's a doozy. The video, which you can watch in the gallery, shows a woman wearing the watch looking at the screen. It's not clear exactly what she's looking at, but it's clear that she's not wearing the watch, the Telegraph reports. It also doesn't appear that the woman is wearing the watch at all, but that's probably because she's carrying it around in her pocket. The Apple Watch will be unveiled March 9 at an event in San Francisco.

– Apple's first major new product since the death of Steve Jobs isn't expected to boost the company's profits any time soon: A new report from investment firm Piper Jaffray predicts that selling prices for the Apple Watch will fall to as low as $550 by the end of the year, the Wall Street Journal reports. That's because consumers will be able to use the watch as a case or as an internal storage option, according to the report, which notes that the $349 price tag for the basic Apple Watch isn't going to cut it for most consumers. The report says the $349 price tag for the basic Apple Watch doesn't take into account the watch's various options, including the possibility of pairing it with an iPhone, the Journal reports. The report predicts that Apple Watch prices will fall to $575 to $600 for the basic Apple Watch, $575 to $600 for the Apple Watch Sport, and $600 to $600 for the Apple Watch Edition, according to 9to5mac.com.

– The FBI has identified the second American killed in ISIS-controlled territory in Syria as 19-year-old aid worker Peter Kassig, a US citizen who joined the militant group last year. Kassig, who grew up in Ohio, was one of the first American fighters to join the Islamic State, which seized control of large parts of Iraq and Syria last year. He was killed in the early hours of Sunday near the border with Syria, reports the AP. A spokesman for the FBI's Cincinnati office tells the AP that Kassig was one of several aid workers killed in the fighting. He says investigators are still trying to determine whether other Americans have been killed. Kassig was working for Doctors Without Borders in Raqqa, the capital of the Islamic State's self-proclaimed capital, Raqqa, when he was killed.

– The Islamic State has released a video that purports to show the beheading of American photojournalist James Wright Foley, who has been missing in Syria since 2012, the New York Times reports. The video also claims to show the beheading of another American journalist, Steven Joel Sotloff of World Affairs and Time. In a separate video, the militants threaten to kill Sotloff as well if President Obama doesn't intervene to save his life. Foley, a 39-year-old freelance photographer, was working for Agence France-Presse when he disappeared.

– A school trip to the Serbian capital of Banja Luka turned into a nightmare for seven 13- to 15-year-old girls when their parents discovered they were expecting. The girls, who are all from the same family, went on the five-day trip to Belgrade last month, but when they returned home, their parents discovered they had been on a school trip to the capital and discovered they were pregnant, the Telegraph reports. "I was shocked," one of the girls says. "I didn't expect anything like this. We went on a school trip and our parents didn't expect us to go on such a trip. We didn't expect them to get pregnant." Police say the parents have been arrested and are being held on suspicion of "adultery, immoral behavior, and neglect," the Independent reports.

– For the first time ever, a human has died because he ate a genetically modified food, doctors at a Madrid hospital announced today. Juan Pedro Ramos, a 31-year-old man, died early this month after suffering an allergic reaction to tomatoes he ate at lunch, the Telegraph reports. Experts at the hospital determined that the man's death was caused by the tomatoes, which had "fish genes" added to them.

– David Haines, the British singer-songwriter best known for hits like "You've Lost That Lovin' Feelin'" and "(You've Lost That) Love," has died at the age of 69, reports the BBC. Haines, who gained fame in the 1980s with songs like "You've Lost That Lovin' Feelin'" and "(You've Lost That) Love," died of complications from pneumonia in a hospital in London, reports the Independent.

– A school field trip to Sarajevo, Bosnia-Herzegovina, turned into a nightmare for seven teenage girls and their parents when one of them got pregnant during the five-day trip. The girls, all between the ages of 15 and 17, were on a school trip to the Bosnian capital when one of them got pregnant during a bathroom break, the Telegraph reports. "I was so angry that I could not sleep at night," says the mother of one of the girls. "My daughter told me that she felt like she was being made to give birth in front of the whole world. I was so angry that I could not sleep at night." The parents, who say the trip was supposed to be fun, were furious when they found out about the pregnancy. "I was so angry that I could not sleep at night," says the mother. "My daughter told me that she felt like she was being made to give birth in front of the whole world. I was so angry that I could not sleep at night." The parents, who say the trip was paid for by the school, have filed a police report.

– A patient in Kansas City, Mo., is being treated for Ebola, but officials say he doesn't have the disease's typical symptoms and is being treated appropriately, KCTV reports. The patient, a male in his 50s, was rushed to a hospital Saturday and diagnosed with Ebola-like symptoms, including fever, vomiting, and abdominal pain, reports the Kansas City Star. He was transferred to a hospital in Kansas City, Mo., and is now in stable condition. The patient has not been identified.

– The rat problem at One World Trade Center has apparently reached a fever pitch—and Anna Wintour is the latest high-profile person to be affected. The Vogue editor-in-chief was spotted Friday without her trademark Chanel sunglasses as she left the magazine's new headquarters at One World Trade Center, which has reportedly been overrun with an infestation of rats, the New York Daily News reports.

– A schoolboy who was almost killed when he was knocked out by a massive electrical shock claims he now has superpowers like those of Marvel's Magneto. MGM Resorts International revealed Tuesday that an unnamed guest dropped $300,000 on a meal at the Jean-Georges Vongerichten-designed restaurant during the week of CES in January, Business Insider reports. A spokesperson for the company tells Bloomberg that most of the check was spent.

– The gunman who opened fire at Canada's Parliament this morning has been shot dead by security forces, reports the CBC. The first sergeant-at-arms to confront the gunman, Kevin Vickers, was also shot but is expected to survive. “I am safe & profoundly grateful to Sgt at Arms Kevin Vickers & our security forces for selfless act of keeping us safe,” said Julian Fantino, Canada's minister of Veterans Affairs, via Twitter. “To all in Ottawa, stay safe & strong. Thank God for Sgt at Arms Kevin Vickers & our Cdn security forces. True heroes...” added Minister Peter MacKay.

US District Judge Nancy Gertner ruled that the 14th Amendment to the Constitution grants black women the same rights as white women when it comes to choosing their children's names, according to the Detroit News. "It is unconstitutional for African-American women to be deprived of the same rights as white women when it comes to choosing their children's names," Gertner wrote in her decision. "The Constitution does not protect black women from the burden of choosing their children's names." Gertner said that under the 14th Amendment, black women have the same rights as white women when it comes to choosing their children's names, but under the 21st Amendment, they have no such rights when it comes to choosing their own children's names. – Amazon.com will open its first brick-and-mortar store in New York City in time for the holiday shopping season, the Wall Street Journal reports, citing "people familiar with the plans." The store, set to open on Manhattan's busy 34th Street, would mark an experiment by Amazon to connect with customers in the physical world.

– On the same day Michael Brown was buried, a Ferguson man released what he claims to be new evidence in the case. CNN reports that audio from a man who says he was having a video chat with a woman when shots rang out has been analyzed by a forensic audio expert, who says he detected at least 10 gunshots—a cluster of six, followed by four.

– A group of real estate agents in Ann Arbor, Mich., decided to show their appreciation for a pizza delivery man Thursday by giving him a $2,084 tip, MLive.com reports. "All I did was deliver pizza," the man, identified only as Rob, said on video as agents from Keller Williams Realty stood behind him. He received a Visa gift card, lottery tickets, and letters of encouragement.

Emwazi is believed to have joined ISIS in Syria in 2012 and is the masked man who has beheaded several hostages. "I have no doubt that Mohammed is Jihad," a friend says. Emwazi grew up in West London and graduated from college with a degree in computer programming. He is believed to have traveled to Syria around 2012 and have later joined the Islamic State, the group whose barbarity he has come to symbolize.

– If you're looking for an Apple Watch that can tell you when it's time to go out and have a drink, the company has just the thing for you. Sources tell the New York Times that Apple is working on a "power reserve" feature for the watch that will allow it to tell you when it's time to go out and have a drink, even if you're not wearing it. The feature is expected to be included in an update to the watch later this month. "It's a departure for Apple, whose mobile devices haven't had these kinds of features," a source tells the Times.

The World Health Organization says the Ebola outbreak there has now killed 3,069 people.

The MQ-1 Reaper drone has a distinct V-shaped tail, and it doesn't appear to be carrying any missiles, the Independent reports. According to the Independent, this suggests the drone is being used for surveillance purposes, rather than as a "hunter-killer type mission."

– A former Comcast customer says the company got him fired after he complained about billing and accounting issues. The problem? Comcast learned where Conal was employed. It just happened to be a company that does business with Comcast. Consumerist reports that Conal claims he never named the company when he was on the phone with various customer service reps—he believes Comcast must've looked up the information somehow. Nonetheless: At some point shortly after that call, someone from Comcast contacted a partner at the firm to discuss Conal. This led to an ethics investigation and Conal's subsequent dismissal from his job

– An official in India's Urban Development Department who has been on furlough for the past 25 years has been fired for "unauthorized absence of duty," the Times of India reports. The official, AK Verma, was dismissed from the Central Public Works Department on Thursday. According to the Indian Express, Verma had been working in the department for more than 30 years and was promoted to the rank of joint secretary in 1993. He was on furlough for the past 25 years due to various reasons, the Times of India reports. He was fired for "unauthorized absence of duty" on Thursday.

– Batman v. Superman: Dawn of Justice is currently shooting in Detroit, and there were rumors last week that one of the movie's Batmobiles had been stolen. Turns out, that's not true, the Detroit Free Press reports. Bleedingcool.com reported Friday that one of the vehicle's models was "believed stolen," but police have since confirmed with the movie's producers that that's not the case.

– "ESPN has a problem with women." That was Esquire's headline on a scathing piece written by news editor Ben Collins on the network's "problem with women." The piece focused on the suspensions of Bill Simmons and Stephen A. Smith, but Collins also revealed details about the network's upcoming coverage of Monday Night Football—specifically, a panel discussion on domestic violence. "All men. Our bold emphasis has been added," Collins wrote. "On Monday night, a panel on a two-hour pregame show for Monday Night Football will, among other things, feature 11 different voices. All men. Our bold emphasis has been added." The piece has since gone viral.

– The World Health Organization has confirmed there are no suspected cases of Ebola in Iraq as of Jan. 5, after reports emerged last week suggesting members of ISIS had contracted the disease. The confirmation comes after the Islamic State, which has seized control of large swaths of northern and western Iraq and is believed to have carried out at least one suicide attack in the country last week, claimed members of the militant group had contracted the disease.

– The leader of Nigeria's Islamic extremist group Boko Haram has denied agreeing to any cease-fire with the government and said more than 200 kidnapped schoolgirls all have converted to Islam and been married off. In an interview with the AP, Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau also said the group is negotiating with the government to free the girls, who were kidnapped last month from a school in the town of Chibok. Shekau said more than 200 schoolgirls have converted to Islam and been married off.

– Sons of Anarchy fans, you're not going to see the show on the big screen. That's because a fake article on Empire News says creator Kurt Sutter will be making a movie with Charlie Hunnam and Brad Pitt, reports the Huffington Post. The article, which has since been taken down, even has a disclaimer: “Empire News is a satirical and entertainment website. We only use invented names in all our stories, except in cases when public figures are being satirized. Any other use of real names is accidental and coincidental.”

– Gillian Rosenberg, a Canadian-Israeli woman fighting ISIS with Kurdish forces in Syria, has updated her Facebook page to say that, contrary to reports, she has not been captured by militant forces. In a post that has been shared more than 5,600 times, Rosenberg says she has been "falsely reported kidnapped" by the Islamic State and that "I have not been kidnapped by the Islamic State or any other terrorist organization." She says she has been fighting alongside Kurdish forces against ISIS in northern Syria since August and that they are her "only hope for a peaceful, democratic, and safe transition of power in Syria," the BBC reports.

– Cesar Millan's wife announced the celebrity dog trainer's death at a press conference Monday in California, per a report at Unam Noticias, which has since been taken down. The report claims Millan died of a heart attack at a Santa Clarita hospital, per the Los Angeles Times, but a rep for the Cesar Millan Network says the TV personality "did not die of a heart attack," nor was he hospitalized. The rep adds that Millan's wife did announce his death at the press conference, but did not give a cause of death.

– The leader of Nigerian extremist group Boko Haram says the more than 200 schoolgirls kidnapped last month have been converted to Islam and married off, reports AFP. "Don't you know the over 200 Chibok schoolgirls have converted to Islam? They have now memorized two chapters of the Koran," says Abubakar Shekau in a video released last night. "The issue of the girls is long forgotten." He adds that the group has agreed to a ceasefire with the Nigerian government in exchange for the girls' release.

– A Texas plumber says his company's work truck ended up in the hands of Islamic extremists in Syria, where the black Ford F-250 with the logo for Texas City's Mark-1 Plumbing emblazoned on the door appeared in a tweet posted Monday by the Ansar al-Deen Front, a jihadist group operating near Aleppo. In the photo, a man fires an anti-aircraft gun mounted to the bed of the truck, presumably where plumbing equipment used to sit, the Houston Chronicle reports. "I don't know how it ended up in the hands of these people," Texas City's Mark-1 Plumbing president tells the Chronicle. "I don't know how they were able to get it." The Ansar al-Deen Front, a jihadist group operating near Aleppo, tweeted the photo Monday. Chechen Jaish al Muhajireen wal Ansar using plumbing truck against regime in #Aleppo."

– The FBI has identified James Foley as the second American hostage to be killed in Syria, NBC News reports. The body of 19-year-old aid worker Kayla Mueller, who was kidnapped in Aleppo in October, was found yesterday in a field in northern Syria, according to a statement from the US Embassy in Damascus. Foley, who served time in prison in the US in the late 1990s for crimes including sexually assaulting a minor, was identified as the second American hostage killed in Syria by al-Qaeda. Earlier this month, American aid worker Peter Kassig was killed.

– Kim Jong Un's latest venture: a North Korean restaurant in the UK, the Daily Star reports. If it happens, it'll be the second such restaurant in Europe (the first was opened in Amsterdam in 2012) and the third in the world (there are currently two in China and one in South Korea). The North Korean government-run eateries have been popping up all over Asia, and the Star notes that 30% of the money from the restaurants goes to the North Korean government.

– A witness has given the FBI a recording he says shows Officer Darren Wilson opening fire on Michael Brown in broad daylight in Ferguson, Mo., reports CNN. The man, who hasn't been identified, claims to have recorded the events before and after Wilson shot the unarmed 18-year-old dead. He says he was standing behind Brown when Wilson opened fire. The FBI is reviewing the tape to see if it corroborates his story, but experts say it's too early to tell whether it will help or hurt Wilson's case. At least 10 shots are heard ringing out in the background of the tape, with a pause between the first seven shots and the last four, reports the Daily Mail.

– Amazon will soon offer a free, ad-supported video service separate from its $99 Prime Instant Video service, the New York Post reports. The move is said to be an attempt to boost the company's video share against Netflix and thus lure more people into its Prime memberships. The Wall Street Journal first reported the rumor back in March, but Amazon denied it at the time.

– Kim Jong Un hasn't been seen in public since early September, but according to South Korea's Chosun Ilbo, the reason may be more mundane than meets the eye: The country's official Korean Central News Agency says the North Korean leader had surgery to repair two broken ankles, reports the AP. The report doesn't specify when the surgery took place or what kind of injury the leader is said to have suffered.

– What sounded like a bomb went off over the Nicaraguan capital Saturday night—and scientists aren't sure what it was. Residents of Managua say they heard a large blast and thought it was a bomb because they felt an "explosive wave," the Telegraph reports. "I was sitting on my porch and I saw nothing, then all of a sudden I heard a large blast," says one resident. "We thought it was a bomb because we felt an expansive wave." Experts from around the world are trying to figure out whether the blast was caused by a meteorite that broke off from an asteroid passing by, the Independent reports.

– The wife and daughter of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi have been arrested in Lebanon, according to the country's interior minister. Saja al-Dulaimi, an ex-wife of al-Baghdadi, was traveling with two sons and a daughter when she was arrested, Lebanese interior minister Nouhad Mashnuq told Lebanese MTV last night. "Dulaimi is not Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi's wife," Mashnuq said, according to Reuters. "Dulaimi is the daughter of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi." DNA tests have confirmed that the girl is Baghdadi's child, Mashnuq said.

– Canada's capital was locked down today after a gunman opened fire near the country's parliament and a soldier standing guard at the nation's war memorial, the BBC reports. The soldier was being treated by paramedics and police rushed to the scene. Witnesses told CBC News that the suspected shooter was carrying rifle. The Canadian parliament building was reported to be in lockdown following the shooting. Police have cordoned the area and blocked access to Parliament Hill. Other reports said shots were fired inside the parliament.

– One of the five Taliban fighters exchanged for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl is trying to make contact with the Taliban once again, Fox News reports. One of the five Taliban fighters traded last year for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl is trying to make contact with the Taliban once again, Fox News has learned.

– A fisherman in Italy may have just caught the biggest catfish ever caught with a rod and reel. The wels catfish, which can reach up to 62 inches long, was caught by Dino Ferrari in the Po Delta, the Independent reports. If the 19 stone fish is confirmed to be the biggest wels catfish caught with a rod and reel, it would best the current record-holder, which was 22st and 2.78m long.

– Eleven commercial jetliners have gone missing from Libya's main airport in Tripoli, raising fears that militants could use them in terrorist attacks to mark the 13th anniversary of 9/11 next week. Reports that 11 commercial jetliners are missing from the main airport in Libya's capital of Tripoli are raising fears that militants could use them in terrorist attacks to mark the 13th anniversary of 9/11 next week.

– New York City has rolled out a new policy that will make it easier for people found in possession of small amounts of marijuana to avoid arrest, the New York Times reports. Under the new guidelines, which go into effect Jan. 1, possession of less than an ounce of pot will no longer result in a criminal conviction, and possession of up to an ounce will no longer result in a arrest. The new guidelines were approved by Mayor Bill de Blasio's administration and the city's Board of Health, the Wall Street Journal reports. The board's president says the new guidelines "strike the right balance between keeping marijuana out of the hands of minors and maintaining public safety."

– He may have been a few hours late, but a Newfoundland man who vowed to police over Facebook that he would turn himself in has kept his promise. Newfoundland police said over Twitter Monday afternoon that Rodney Constantine had "kept his word" and turned himself in to authorities after saying he would so in a Facebook comment—to police.

– A prominent Saudi cleric has whipped up controversy by issuing a religious ruling forbidding the building of snowmen, described them as anti-Islamic, Reuters reports. " snowmen are an insult to Islam," said Sheikh Abdul Aziz bin Hamad al-Sudairi, who is also the country's minister of information. "Building snowmen is an insult to Muslims." According to the ruling, snowmen are "insulting" and are "against the morals and values of Islam."

– ISIS released a new video today claiming it has seized weapons dropped by the US military intended for Kurdish forces defending a Syrian city near the Turkish border, the AP reports. In the video, a man claiming to be an ISIS fighter claims the weapons dropped by the US on Sunday were actually intended for Kurdish forces fighting ISIS in the city of Kobani. The video also claims ISIS fighters are now in control of the city.

– Comcast is denying a rumor that it's threatening to cut off service to customers who use the anonymity-providing Tor browser, the Wall Street Journal reports. According to DeepDotWeb, which first reported the rumor, Comcast agents have contacted customers using Tor and told them they'll be cut off if they don't change their password. But Comcast says the rumor is "wildly inaccurate," and that there's no evidence it's happening.

– The World Health Organization dismissed reports of Ebola cases in Iraq as "rumor" today, saying that all sources have " negated the existence of any suspected cases." The WHO said it and the Iraqi health ministry conducted a full investigation and "further confirmed that the laboratory facilities in Mosul do not have the necessary capabilities to diagnose" the disease, Reuters reports.

– ESPN has decided against an all-male panel discussion on domestic violence that was supposed to air on Monday Night Football, the New York Daily News reports. The move comes after an Esquire blog post suggested that an all-male panel would discuss the issue during a pre-game show. "There was never a panel discussion about the topic planned for tonight," ESPN says in a statement. "An all-male panel discussion was never planned."

– McDonald's is getting rid of the "fresh" part of its name in favor of the more familiar "mushrooms and french fries" in an attempt to boost sales. The chain says it will start phasing out the "fresh" part of its name by the end of the year, reports the Wall Street Journal, which notes that the name change is part of a major overhaul of the company's logo in recent years. McDonald's has been trying to boost sales by emphasizing the health benefits of its french fries, which are more popular than other fast-food offerings.

– A game developer for Electric Boogie apparently had such disdain for the person he worked for that he decided to ridicule them in a rather creative way. As the Daily Dot reports, this game note was posted to the company's Facebook page last week and has since gone viral. The note, which can be seen in full here, begins, "This game note is for your boss I quit anymore if this game note is to be believed." It then proceeds to list all the ways in which the person he worked for had such disdain for him that he decided to ridicule them in a rather creative way.

– Country music legend Willie Nelson is alive and well, despite a hoax that went viral over the weekend, Inquisitr reports. The 81-year-old singer was supposedly killed in a car crash in Florida on Saturday, according to the website MSMBC. The site's initials are exactly the same as MSNBC's, and the headline reads "Willie Nelson Dead at 81." People around the world started checking their social media accounts to see if they'd been affected by the news, and many were surprised to find out it wasn't true, Inquisitr reports.

– The most expensive version of the Apple Watch will set you back $10,000, according to an analysis by Grail Watch. That's mostly because the watch's frame is made from 18-karat gold, which is very expensive, notes the blog. If you want a larger version, you'll have to shell out $8,300. That's assuming the watch case is made from solid gold, not gold-plated.

– Apple hasn't actually announced any prices for the Apple Watch yet, but a French blog is reporting that the stainless steel version will start at $500 and the gold version at $4,000, MacRumors reports. The base price for the base model of the Apple Watch is $349, but the iGen blog reports that the stainless steel version will have a starting price of $500 and the gold version will have a starting price of $4,000. The iGen blog has been reliable in the past, correctly predicting the size of the iPhone 6 and 6 Plus.

– The Nigerian government has declared a state of emergency in the country's northeast after an attack by Boko Haram extremists left at least eight people dead, the AP reports. Boko Haram, whose name means "Western education is forbidden," has been terrorizing Nigeria's northeast for more than a decade. The extremist group has killed more than 1,000 people this year alone, mostly in attacks on villages near the border with Niger. The state of emergency was declared after gunmen believed to be Boko Haram fighters attacked two villages and a town near the border with Niger, killing at least 8. The militants are believed to have taken advantage of a recent ceasefire between the government and Boko Haram.

– North Korea's leader may be making good on his promise to open a restaurant in Scotland.
