– A giant catfish caught in an Italian river was so big it could swallow a person whole, the Telegraph reports. The 20-pound, 127-pound fish was caught by twin brothers Dino and Dario Ferrari in the Po River in northern Italy. "It looks big enough to swallow a person whole," says a fisherman who caught the fish with his brother. "It has a big mouth, a big hole in the side, and it swallows a lot of fish."

– A British anti-ISIS fighter who joined the fight against the Islamic State says militants fed a woman searching for her kidnapped son some meat and rice—and then told her she had just eaten her son, according to a British man who joined the fight against ISIS. The woman was searching for her son in the ISIS stronghold of Raqqa when she was approached by militants who told her they had kidnapped her son and were going to feed him to them, the New York Daily News reports. "They fed her some meat and rice and then told her she had just eaten her son," the man, who joined the fight against ISIS in Syria and Iraq, tells the Daily Mail. "I've never seen anything like this before."

– A video released by the Islamic State on Tuesday allegedly shows a stray weapons bundle from the United States that missed its target in Kurdish-controlled areas near Kobani, Syria and instead fell into the hands of ISIS (ISIS or ISIL), reports the AP. The video, which can be seen here, shows a US military helicopter firing on what appears to be ISIS fighters in northern Syria. ISIS fighters then appear to grab the bundle, which they say is a rocket-propelled grenade launcher, reports the New York Times.

– The Apple Watch will start at $349 when it hits stores next month, according to a report on French website iGen.fr picked up by 9to5mac.com. The site also claims that the stainless steel and gold versions of the watch will start at $399 and $499, respectively. Apple hasn't confirmed the report, 9to5mac.com notes.

– The Islamic State militant known as "Jihadi John" has been identified as Mohammed Emwazi, a 25-year-old computer programmer from London, the Washington Post reports. Emwazi grew up in London and graduated from college with a degree in computer programming. He is believed to be the " Jihadi John" who has appeared in several ISIS beheading videos. Emwazi is believed to have moved to Syria in recent years.

– A schoolboy who was almost killed when knocked out by a massive electric shock now claims the accident gave him superpowers like those of X-Men's Magneto. – The FBI has identified the second American killed in ISIS-controlled territory in Syria as 19-year-old aid worker Peter Kassig, a US citizen who joined the militant group last year. Kassig, who grew up in Ohio, was one of the first American fighters to join the Islamic State, which seized control of large parts of Iraq and Syria last year. He was killed in the early hours of Sunday near the border with Syria, reports the AP. A spokesman for the FBI's Cincinnati office tells the AP that Kassig was one of several aid workers killed in the fighting. He says investigators are still trying to determine whether other Americans have been killed. Kassig was working for Doctors Without Borders in Raqqa, the capital of the Islamic State's self-proclaimed capital, Raqqa, when he was killed.

– Sen. Lindsey Graham says the Taliban detainees released from Guantanamo Bay in exchange for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl have been in touch with members of the al-Qaeda-linked Haqqani network. In an interview with CNN's Brian Stelter, the Republican senator from South Carolina says the detainees have been in contact with members of the al-Qaeda-linked Haqqani network, which is linked to al-Qaeda and the Taliban. "They're in touch with members of the al-Qaeda-linked Haqqani network," Graham says. "They're not in contact with the Taliban."

– A worker at a Texas turkey farm has tested positive for Ebola, making him the first person in the US to be diagnosed with the disease this year. The worker, a male who recently traveled to West Africa, is under quarantine and not showing symptoms, the Texas Department of State Health Services said in a statement. The department said it is working with the CDC to identify and track down anyone else who may have come in contact with the worker, the AP reports. More than 250,000 holiday turkeys have been affected by the disease at the Texas turkey farm, according to health officials.

– Christian Bale has dropped out of Danny Boyle's Steve Jobs biopic after deciding the film wasn't right for him, reports the Hollywood Reporter. "Sources say Bale, after much deliberation and conflicting feelings, came to the conclusion he was not right for the part and decided to withdraw." No word yet on who will replace him.

– It's not every day you get the chance to chop off your own penis, but that's exactly what happened to Yang Hu, a 23-year-old man from Taiwan who was apparently fed up with not having a girlfriend and decided to do just that, reports the Daily Mail. He cut off his own penis—which he had no real use for—and posted the video on YouTube.

– Apple's first major product launch since the death of Steve Jobs is just over a year away, and the company is already working on modifications to make the Apple Watch last longer on a charge, sources tell Business Insider. Right now, the watch has a one-day battery life, but the sources say Apple is working on modifications to make the watch last longer on a charge before its 2015 launch. Analysts say that while the watch is a promising new product, a lot of other smartwatches run on components meant for smartphones and aren't properly optimized for wrist-worn gadgets. "A lot of smartwatches run on components that are meant for smartphones and aren't properly optimized for wrist-worn gadgets," an analyst with Canalys Insight tells Business Insider.

– The man believed to have opened fire at Canada's Parliament today before being shot dead by a security guard has been identified as Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, officials tell CBS News. Zehaf-Bibeau, a 32-year-old Canadian citizen living in the US, is believed to have first shot a soldier standing guard at the nation's War Memorial before entering Parliament's Center Block and opening fire, the Epoch Times reports. He was shot dead by a security guard before entering the Center Block. At least three other people were injured in the attack.

– A 7-year-old boy in Omsk, Russia, says that when he doesn't want anything, everything appears—even glass. "Once I even pulled glass. He moved on his own. Practically I think to become a superhero," Nicholas Kruglyachenko tells 12 Channel. Touching the boy may even affect others and pass them superpowers.

The source says disagreements with higher-ups inside Omidyar's company have led to the leave of absence.

He said one of the young men told him that the militants had been feeding the desperate mother a meal of meat and rice before revealing she had eaten her own son. – The FBI is investigating a possible audio recording that purports to capture the shooting of Michael Brown by Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson, the New York Times reports. In the recording, a man who has not been identified is heard saying, "I don't know what to do, I don't know what to do, I don't know what to do, I don't know what to do." A series of gunshots can be heard in the background. The recording was first reported by CNN, which says it has not independently confirmed that the gunshots on the tape are from the shooting.

– It's official: Fidel Castro is dead. The revolutionary leader's nephew, Raul Castro, confirmed to the AP that the 88-year-old has died, though he didn't give a cause of death. Raul Castro says his uncle had been ill for some time, but didn't give any further details. The Miami Herald, however, reports that Castro died at a hospital in Santiago, Cuba, where he had been staying in ill health, with his younger brother Raul by his side.

– A new report from an analyst at Piper Jaffray predicts that the most expensive version of the Apple Watch will sell for nearly $6,000. The stainless steel Apple Watch will start at $499, while the 18-karat gold Apple Watch Edition will sell for nearly $6,000, AppleInsider reports. According to Piper Jaffray's Gene Munster, the average consumer will spend around $550 for the Apple Watch, which will be available in three different versions: Apple Watch Sport, Apple Watch Edition, and Apple Watch.

"I think that is fabricated, it's nonsense," says a spokesman for the embassy. The Daily Record, however, quoted an expert who said it "would not surprise me at all if they opted to open a restaurant in Scotland."

– If you've ever watched the popular children's show Teletubbyland, you've probably seen the baby's face superimposed over the sun—and if you haven't, you may want to stop reading now. A new study finds that people who have watched the show at least once are more likely to have a positive attitude about children in general, and parents in particular, than people who haven't watched at all, the Los Angeles Times reports. The study, which was published in the journal Pediatrics, found that children who watched the show at least once were twice as likely to have a positive attitude about children in general and parents in particular as children who hadn't watched at all. The study also found that children who watched the show more than once were twice as likely to have a positive attitude about children in general and parents in particular as children who hadn't watched at all.

– "Ex-ter-min-ate!" is the security robot shout-out coming from Microsoft's new campus in Silicon Valley. The 300-pound, 5-foot-tall robot—nicknamed K5 for its resemblance to the Daleks from Doctor Who—is part of a team of five security guards from Knightscope, reports the San Jose Mercury News. The guards use cameras and sensors to look for suspicious activity on the Microsoft campus.

– Rumors have been swirling that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is seriously ill or even dead, but a source with access to the secretive North's leadership says Kim hurt his leg while inspecting military exercises. The source tells Reuters that the 31-year-old leader is in firm control of his government but has hurt his leg while inspecting military exercises. The source says that Kim hurt his leg while inspecting military exercises.

– A video of an airport worker stripping naked to go through a security scanner in protest at heavy-handed security guards has gone viral. Georgy Myakinkin, 31, who works at the airport in the city of St Petersburg in northwestern Russia, had finished his shift and was going home when he remembered he had left his keys at work.

– This morning on CNN's New Day, Don Lemon tried to defend the network's airing of a tape purported to capture the shooting of Michael Brown. Lemon said that CNN could not verify the tape's authenticity, Mediaite reports, and noted that CBS News had received the same audio earlier in the week from the attorney who claims to have given it to her, but didn't run it because it couldn't be verified. Mediaite points out that the same audio was also purported to capture the shooting of Eric Garner, but CBS didn't run it.

– New York City police are set to announce a major change in their approach to marijuana possession: Instead of arresting people for small amounts of the drug, they'll be issuing tickets, the New York Times reports. The new guidelines will allow cops to issue tickets instead of arrests for possession of up to an ounce of pot, which currently carries a maximum punishment of two years in jail and a $5,000 fine. The change could have a big impact on New York's black and Hispanic communities, the Times notes.

– When it comes to customer service, it's all about the recorded run-arounds. But when it comes to live customer service reps, it's all about actually reaching out to the person on the other end. That's according to a new study out of the University of Virginia's Center for Business and Economic Research, which found that live customer service reps actually outperform recorded run-arounds when it comes to resolving issues, the Washington Post reports. According to the study, recorded run-arounds were responsible for 40% of customer service complaints in 2013. Live customer service reps actually have a better success rate than recorded run-arounds when it comes to resolving issues, the study found. The study also found that live customer service reps have a higher success rate than recorded run-arounds when it comes to getting a product or service to the customer, the Post reports. Haines, who gained fame in the 1980s with songs like "You've Lost That Lovin' Feelin'" and "(You've Lost That) Love," died of complications from pneumonia in a hospital in London, reports the Independent.

– A Texas plumber is getting death threats after his old truck—still bearing his name—was tweeted on the front line by Islamic jihadists in Syria, the Houston Chronicle reports. Mark Oberholtzer's former Ford F-250 pickup truck, still bearing his name, was tweeted on the front line by Islamic jihadists in Syria. "I'm getting death threats," Oberholtzer tells the Chronicle. "I don't know who they are. I don't know what they're trying to do, but they're trying to kill me."

– A Canadian soldier standing guard at the nation's war memorial was shot dead last night by a man believed to have been on a terror watchlist. Michael Zehaf-Bibeau then ran into Canada's parliament, where he was shot dead by a member of parliament. Cirillo, a 25-year-old who had planned to become a border guard, was a "devoted family man and a career soldier who planned on becoming a border guard," writes the Telegraph. "The young soldier killed in a terror attack on the Canadian parliament last night was a devoted family man and a career soldier who planned on becoming a border guard," it adds. "It was chance that brought the two men together, when Zehaf-Bibeau launched his attack as Corporal Nathan Cirillo, 25, stood guard at Ottawa's war memorial, just metres away from the national parliament."

– American journalist Luke Somers has been killed during a rescue attempt for him by militants in Yemen, reports Reuters. The militant group al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula had been threatening to kill the 33-year-old if the US didn't pay a ransom within 24 hours.

– A school trip to the Serbian capital of Banja Luka turned into a nightmare for seven 13- to 15-year-old girls when their parents discovered they were expecting. The girls, who are all from the same family, went on the five-day trip to Belgrade last month, but when they returned home, their parents discovered they had been on a school trip to the capital and discovered they were pregnant, the Telegraph reports. "I was shocked," one of the girls says. "I didn't expect anything like this. We went on a school trip and our parents didn't expect us to go on such a trip. We didn't expect them to get pregnant." Police say the parents have been arrested and are being held on suspicion of "adultery, immoral behavior, and neglect," the Independent reports.

– The Department of Homeland Security is denying a congressman’s assertion that fighters with the militant group Islamic State, also known as ISIL or ISIS, have been caught crossing the southwestern border, the New York Times reports. Rep. Mike Rogers, R-Mich., said Sunday that ISIS fighters had been caught crossing the border from Mexico into Arizona. But a DHS rep tells the Times that Rogers’ claim is "not true." "There have been no recent reports of ISIS fighters crossing the border into Arizona," the rep says. "There have been no recent reports of fighters crossing the border from Mexico into Arizona."

– The FBI has interviewed a man whose video chat with a friend picked up audio of the gunshots that killed Michael Brown, the man's lawyer tells CNN. The FBI has allegedly interviewed a man whose video chat with a friend picked up audio of the gunshots that killed Michael Brown, the individual's lawyer tells CNN. What attorney Lopa Blumenthal claims is the sound of Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson firing at the unarmed 18-year-old can be heard in two distinct bursts—at least six shots, a pause, and an additional four shots, according to a forensic audio expert. “It’s the pause that gives most concern in a police shooting, especially with an unarmed victim, because at this point Mr. Brown is defenseless,” Blumenthal says.

– Fidel Castro has not been seen in public for months, and rumors of his death spread fast on social media Friday, but there was no sign that the reports were true, even if the 88-year-old former Cuban leader has not been seen in public for months. By Friday, Cuba-related Twitter accounts were ablaze with speculation, fueled in large part by reports on news websites such as Diario de Cuba and Diario las Americas that Cuba had scheduled a news conference, possibly to discuss Castro's health, the AP reports.

– This weekend, a photo of what appears to be a Durex pumpkin-spice-flavored condom made the rounds on social media, BuzzFeed reports. "Because safe sex is important, no matter what season it is," reads the tweet, which has since been deleted. According to the New York Daily News, the photo was posted to a Durex Facebook page, where it was accompanied by the message, "This is not how we do things at Durex." The post has since been deleted, but a screenshot was posted to Twitter, where it has since been retweeted more than 10,000 times.

Kassig, who grew up in Ohio, was one of the first American fighters to join the Islamic State, which seized control of large parts of Iraq and Syria last year. He was killed in the early hours of Sunday near the border with Syria, reports the AP. A spokesman for the FBI's Cincinnati office tells the AP that Kassig was one of several aid workers killed in the fighting. He says investigators are still trying to determine whether other Americans have been killed. Kassig was working for Doctors Without Borders in Raqqa, the capital of the Islamic State's self-proclaimed capital, Raqqa, when he was killed.

– Kim Kardashian and Kanye West may not be allowed to attend future Grammy Awards—but they're still eligible to win a Grammy. That's according to World Wide Interweb, which reports that West and Kardashian have been "forever banned" from future Grammy shows, but that they're still eligible to win a Grammy anyway, PopEater reports.

– A video purporting to show yeti footage in western Russia is renewing the debate over whether the animal is real. The video was shot by a group of Russian researchers who traveled to the Adygeya Republic after reports of yeti sightings in the area, the Daily Mail reports. The team interviewed witnesses at a local mountainside lodge who claimed to have seen the yeti, but some say the video is a publicity stunt and others say the yeti is real. The yeti was spotted just an hour's drive away from the city of Adygeisk.

– A time capsule placed in Boston's Old State House by abolitionist Harriet Tubman more than a century ago was unearthed this week, Reuters reports. According to the Boston Globe, the time capsule was placed in a bronze lion statue on the side of the building by Tubman in 1898. It was supposed to last until 2029, when it was to be replaced by a wooden box with a red hardcover book. On Thursday, historians opened up the time capsule and found the book. "It's a bit of a surprise," says Harriet Tubman's great-great-granddaughter. "I didn't think we'd ever find a time capsule like this." Tubman, who founded the Harriet Tubman Foundation for Women's and Children's Health, put the time capsule in when she visited Boston in 1898 to mark the 200th anniversary of her arrival in the US. It was supposed to be replaced with a wooden box by 2029, but it was replaced with a copper one the following year.

– If you're an American living in China, you may want to consider changing your name. The country's official Xinhua news agency has run a tongue-in-cheek report on the matter, complete with advice to Chinese on how to choose their English names, the AP reports. "Your English name should be 'Zhanzi' or 'Xinzi,'" the report reads. "If you want to be called 'Zhanzi' or 'Xinzi,' then your name should be 'Zhanzi.' But if you want to be called 'Xinzi,' then your name should be 'Xinzi.' But if you want to be called 'Zhanzi,' then your name should be 'Xinzi.'"

– Rep. Duncan Hunter, a Republican from California, made headlines this week when he claimed that at least 10 ISIS fighters had been caught trying to cross the US-Mexico border. On Fox News last night, Greta Van Susteren asked him about it. "You say that they are coming in the southern border, which changes all the dynamics," she asked him. "They are going to be bombing American cities coming across from Mexico," said Hunter. "I mean, stop for one second," said Van Susteren. "They are going to be bombing American cities coming across from Mexico," said Hunter. "You say that they are coming in the southern border, which changes all the dynamics?" asked Van Susteren. "I don't know what you're talking about," said Hunter.

– They must be the nattiest rats in all of New York City. Journalists at the fashion bible Vogue have been forced to delay their move into swanky new offices on the site of the Twin Towers because of an infestation of rodents. According to the New York Daily News, the rats were found in the basement of Vogue's new offices on 42nd Street. The paper reports the infestation was so bad that Vogue had to delay the move to a new building on the site.

– A rock the size of an orange crashed into the Pacific Ocean off the coast of Nicaragua on Saturday, killing two people and injuring at least seven others, Xinhua reports. According to local media, the rock—believed to be a piece of a meteorite—hit the shore near the town of Salinas, some 100 miles west of the Nicaraguan capital of Managua. Nicaraguan authorities are now trying to determine whether the rock came from a meteorite that crashed into the Pacific or was part of a larger one that broke apart and landed in the area.

– Dera Sacha Sauda chief Gurmeet Ram Rahim Singh is in custody after a court in northern India found him guilty of raping two of his female followers, reports the Times of India. The court also ordered a Central Bureau of Investigation probe into the alleged forced castration of the followers at his ashram in Sirsa, Punjab. Singh, who has been in custody since last year, was on Friday sentenced to 20 years in prison by a court in the town of Dera Sacha Sauda, where his followers say he forced them to perform sex acts.

– "If you really want to protect Americans from ISIS, you secure the southern border—it's that simple," Rep. Duncan Hunter says. The California Republican says US Border Patrol "sources" told him that "at least 10 ISIS fighters have been caught coming across the Mexican border in Texas," the Los Angeles Times reports. "They caught them at the border, therefore we know that ISIS is coming across the border," he says. "If they catch five or 10 of them then we know that ISIS is coming across the border." Hunter, who says he's been told by Border Patrol "sources" that there are up to 150 ISIS fighters on the Mexican side of the border, has introduced a bill to make it a federal crime to attempt to join ISIS, the San Diego Union-Tribune reports.

– A US Marine was nearly killed by a Taliban sniper during a joint helicopter raid in Afghanistan yesterday, the New York Daily News reports. The incident took place in southern Helmand province, where US and Afghan forces have been battling the Taliban for more than a year. According to the Daily News, the Marine was on his way to assist other forces with a firefight when he came across a Taliban sniper. The Taliban quickly claimed responsibility for the incident.

The woman and the man, who is believed to be al-Baghdadi's son with his first wife, were found in a house in the southern city of Daraa, close to where al-Baghdadi is believed to have spent time as leader of the Islamic State in Iraq and Greater Syria, al-Jazeera reports. A security official tells the AP that the woman and al-Baghdadi's son were found in the same house. The security official says the plot to kill al-Baghdadi was in the works for some time. The woman and al-Baghdadi's son have not been identified.

– When Tim Cook announced the "Spring 2015" launch date for the Apple Watch back in September, he called it "the oh-so-vague 'Spring 2015.' Now, 9to5Mac reports that the Apple Watch will actually ship in the US by the end of March, with Apple Store retail training scheduled for mid-February.

– Jordan's King Abdullah is on a US visit, but he's cutting it short in the wake of the execution of pilot Muath al-Kaseasbeh and the country's vow to exact revenge. "I have decided to cut short my visit to the United States," he said at a press conference today, per the New York Times. "I want to assure the American people that the government and the people of Jordan are behind the king and the people of Jordan in this difficult situation." The king, a former military pilot himself, had been scheduled to meet with President Obama today.

– Apple is limiting the number of apps developers can create for its new smartwatch in an effort to make sure the device has the best possible battery life, insiders tell Business Insider. "I think Apple is taking a similar approach with the Apple Watch and iPhone, saying to themselves, 'We don't have an option to fail on this,'" Sumit Mehra, CTO of app studio Y Media Labs, says. "Apple is only going to allow developers to do the basic stuff to just get the Apple Watch out there, because either it's not ready, or they don't know what the implications of something like this could be." Developers say they've been told they can't create apps that can take advantage of the watch's bells and whistles, including charging capabilities, GPS, and Bluetooth. "I think they're limiting what apps are going to be able to do early on in order to ensure a smooth launch and maintain battery life," Mehra says.

– First people complained that their new iPhone 6s were bending. Now owners of the new Apple gadget have said when they make a phone call, it is ripping out their hair. The new controversy, branded by social media users as 'hairgate,' follows allegations people are getting their beard or head hair'snagged' when the phone is held against their face. Chad Coleman was one of the first people to raise the issue on Twitter after complaining that hisscruff' was being ripped. Scott Bilsky blamed the seam where the aluminium meets the glass on his hair being pulled out.

– The price of an Apple Watch may be going up, and not in a good way. The Wall Street Journal reports that the price of the stainless steel and gold versions of the watch, which went on sale in the US in early September, could be as much as $500 more than the $349 price tag for the non- stainless steel version. That would mean the watch would cost more than twice as much as the cheaper stainless steel version of the Apple Watch, which is expected to go on sale in China next month. The Journal also notes that the price of the gold version of the watch, which is expected to go on sale in the US next month, could be as much as $5,000 more than the $349 price tag for the non- stainless steel version.

The 55-year-old actor, who has been forced to confirm that he is alive and well after rumors swept the internet on Sunday morning that he had died overnight, said in a statement to E! Online that he is "happy to confirm that I am alive and well." – A Texas plumber says he's been getting hundreds of phone calls and faxes since an extremist group in Syria tweeted a photo of his pickup truck, along with his name and phone number. Mark Oberholtzer isn't an Islamic fighter in Syria. He's never been there, and he certainly would never willingly aid fundamentalist rebels. So it's hard for him to understand how his Ford F-250 pickup truck—including his logo for Mark-1 Plumbing and his phone number—ended up being in a photo posted on Twitter by the extremist Ansar al-Deen Front from the front lines of the war in Syria, the BBC reports.

– Canada's Parliament Hill was locked down today after shots were fired inside the building and a soldier standing guard at the National War Memorial was shot, the Globe and Mail reports. Witnesses say an armed man with long black hair emerged from the Parliament building, fired about four times, and a guard went down. The gunman then ran toward Parliament Hill. The shooting victim was taken to hospital in an ambulance. Police locked down Parliament and Ottawa Police tactical officers arrived, pointing guns at journalists and ordering them to the ground.

– Lebanon says it has arrested the wife of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi in the country's north. The BBC reports that the woman's name is Samira Abu al-Baghdadi, and she is the second wife of the militant group's leader. Security officials say she was arrested 10 days ago in northern Lebanon and is now in military detention. It's unclear whether she was fleeing the self-proclaimed caliph of the extremist Sunni group or if she remains loyal to Baghdadi and was simply in hiding, experts say.

– When Jess Smith was nine months old, she filmed a monster in the sky and didn't tell anyone—until now. The first-year college student at Canterbury Christ Church University in England tells Uproxx that she didn't tell anyone outside of her family until a game with her university friends "where they all had to say something about themselves that no one else would guess." That game? She played the monster.

– Breakfast Club star Judd Nelson is alive and well, his agent tells the Los Angeles Times, after a report that he had died turned out to be false. "Reports of Judd Nelson's death were greatly exaggerated," Gregg Klein wrote in an email to the Times. "He is, and has always been, a very happy and healthy person." Klein even provided the Times with a photo of Nelson holding up a copy of the paper with the note, "Reports of Judd Nelson's death were greatly exaggerated."

In audio released by the network, Tiffany Mitchell and DeRay Mckesson say they saw the 18-year-old Brown and officer Darren Wilson wrestling in the doorway of the police car before Brown was shot. Mitchell and Mckesson say they saw Wilson open fire on Brown, who was running away, after he had been shot five times from behind and six times face-to-face, the Los Angeles Times reports. The women, who were in the police car with Brown when the shooting occurred, say they saw Brown running away and Wilson shooting him after he turned around with his arms in the air. Both women say they saw Brown and Wilson wrestling in the doorway of the police car before Brown ran away and was shot at from the back. Then, they say, Brown turned around with his arms. – In 1795, Paul Revere and Samuel Adams placed a time capsule in the cornerstone of the Massachusetts Statehouse. A 1795 time capsule. Bostonians may have just discovered a new real-life national treasure. A time capsule from 1795 in the form of a small copper box was unearthed in Massachusetts statehouse in Boston Thursday. The container was first placed in the cornerstone of the building on Beacon Hill by revolutionary war hero Paul Revere and the then-governor of Massachusetts, Samuel Adams. The cigar-box-sized capsule will be x-rayed over the weekend and its contents revealed next week. The artifact is believed to be one of the oldest time capsules in Massachusetts.

– A 6-foot mechanical polar bear that's been making a bit of a splash in a small town in the UK may have to find a new home. A local newspaper reported that the Central Bedfordshire Council was about to issue an anti-social behavior order (Asbo) to the bear named Bernard, who's been a hit with passers-by outside a local cafe. But a council press officer tells i100.co.uk that the story was "embellished" and that there was "absolutely no mention of an Asbo or a gagging order, or anything like that."

– An Australian man is recovering from a nasty spider bite after a spider burrowed into his skin from where his appendix had been removed. Dylan Thomas, 21, says he woke Saturday morning to a 2-inch red trail rising up from his stomach. Later that day it had risen two or three inches higher up his body, he says. When he first went to doctors on Sunday they told him it was an insect bite and gave him some cream, NT News reports. By Monday morning the trail had started to blister. Then Thomas saw a dermatologist, who told him the spider had burrowed itself into his skin through a scar from where his appendix had been removed.

– Militants from the Islamic State have seized a cache of weapons dropped by the US-led coalition in northern Syria, the AP reports. The weapons included hand grenades, ammunition, and rocket-propelled grenade launchers, according to a video uploaded by a media group loyal to the militant group. The weapons were intended for Kurdish militiamen fighting ISIS in the border town of Kobane, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights.

– North Korean despot Kim Jong-un has been guzzling pint after pint of'snake wine'—with the body of a dead cobra in the bottle—in a vain attempt to restore life to genitals he may not have seen for years due to his vast bulk, the Telegraph reports. – "Even animals have a place in heaven." So said Pope Francis to a little boy during a public appearance in St. Peter's Square earlier this month. The Vatican's official news agency has since clarified that the pontiff was talking about animals—not humans—and that the boy was just trying to comfort him, the AP reports.

– A new survey from UBS finds that 10% of consumers are "very likely" to buy an Apple Watch in the next 12 months. That's good news for Apple, because the investment firm thinks it will sell 24 million of the devices in their first nine months on the market, the Wall Street Journal reports. That's a gross profit of $3.4 billion, according to the poll of 4,000 people.

– An Israeli-Canadian woman has reportedly been captured by the Islamic State as she tried to join Kurdish forces fighting the militants in northern Iraq. Gill Rosenberg, a 31-year-old civil aviation pilot, reportedly reached out to the Kurds on Facebook, asking them to let her join their forces in the fight against ISIS in the Syrian town of Kobani, the New York Times reports. The Islamic State has not confirmed the report. Rosenberg joined the Israeli army's search-and-rescue unit before being extradited to the US in 2009 on charges of scamming people out of tens of thousands of dollars, the Times notes.

– The fence-jumper who bolted across the White House lawn and got close to the president may have actually made it further into the building than previously reported, the Washington Post reports. The Secret Service had said Omar Gonzalez overpowered a agent and ran through most of the building's main floor before he was apprehended.

– A group of 14-year-old girls in Bosnia have been arrested for having sex with a 15-year-old boy while on a school trip, UK MailOnline reports. The incident took place during a school trip to the Croatian town of Vranovce. According to the Telegraph, the girls were on a cultural trip to Croatia when they met a 15-year-old boy on the trip. They allegedly had sex with him while he was on the trip.

– If you're going to judge someone based on what they look like, don't do it on the basis of their appearance. That's the message from a new ad for Levi's that's going viral, the Los Angeles Times reports. The ad shows a young man in a baseball cap, jeans, and a white T-shirt standing next to a woman with the words, "I'm Levi's." The message is clear: "This is what you look like when you're not wearing a shirt," says the man, who appears to be in his early 20s. "You know that tendency we have to judge people by what they look like? Yeah, that's why you shouldn't do that." The campaign's tagline: "It's You, It's Me, It's For Them, It's For Them, And It's For Them All The Way." It's not the first time the ad has gone viral.

– The Islamic State has released a video showing the beheading of British hostage David Haines, the third Westerner to be killed by the group. The video, which has not been released by the militant group, shows the severed head of Haines, who was seized in Syria in March last year, along with the dismembered body of James Foley, a US journalist who had been held hostage in the same country. Haines is the first British hostage to be killed by the Islamic State, which is also known as ISIS, al-Jazeera reports.

– The FBI has identified the second American killed in ISIS-controlled territory in Syria as 19-year-old aid worker Peter Kassig, a US citizen who joined the militant group last year. Kassig, who grew up in Ohio, was one of the first American fighters to join the Islamic State, which seized control of large parts of Iraq and Syria last year. He was killed in the early hours of Sunday near the border with Syria, reports the AP. A spokesman for the FBI's Cincinnati office tells the AP that Kassig was one of several aid workers killed in the fighting. He says investigators are still trying to determine whether other Americans have been killed. Kassig was working for Doctors Without Borders in Raqqa, the capital of the Islamic State's self-proclaimed capital, Raqqa, when he was killed.

– North Korea's state-run restaurant chain has a branch in Amsterdam, and now Kim Jong Un is considering opening a restaurant in Scotland, the Telegraph reports. Madden says Scotland's rejection of independence "grew Scotland into the North Korean elite's thoughts." "Despite voting 'No' they'd consider left-leaning Scotland to be more suitable to deal with than England," he says. "Plus, North Koreans love their food."

A North Korean government source tells Reuters that the 31-year-old leader, who became North Korea's youngest leader last year, injured his leg while on a flight from Pyongyang to the South Korean border city of Panmunjom last week. The source says Kim Jong Un is believed to be recovering from the injury, though it's not clear whether he will be able to continue in his role as leader. – Google is spending $585 million to buy six office buildings near its headquarters in Silicon Valley, sources tell the Wall Street Journal. The deal, Google's biggest ever, is part of the company's plan to boost its Silicon Valley presence by scooping up more office space, the sources say. Google, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., bought the six buildings for $585 million from Starwood Capital Group and Blackstone Group, the sources say.

– Tiger Woods has been hit with a two-year ban from the PGA Tour over allegations that he used performance-enhancing drugs, the tour said in a statement today. "The PGA Tour does not condone the use of performance-enhancing drugs in any capacity by anyone, including, but not limited to, Tiger Woods," the statement said. "This is a matter for the PGA to resolve internally." According to the statement, Woods was suspended after a "comprehensive drug test" conducted by the tour's chief medical officer turned up "no adverse effects from human growth hormone, steroids, or other performance-enhancing drugs." Woods' agent, Mark Steinberg, told ESPN last week that the golfer "has never used performance-enhancing drugs in his life." Journeyman golfer Dan Olsen retracted claims Tiger Woods had been suspended by the PGA Tour for using performance-enhancing drugs after both the PGA Tour and Woods' agent, Mark Steinberg, vehemently denied the claims.

– Judd Nelson, the actor best known for his roles in The Outlaw Josey Wales and Barefoot in the Park, has died at the age of 83, reports the Los Angeles Times. The cause of his death isn't clear, but he had been in failing health for some time. Nelson was found dead at his home in Woodland Hills, Calif., early Sunday morning. He was reportedly suffering from pneumonia and heart failure.

– Mexican authorities say they've found a number of unmarked graves with bone remains on the outskirts of Iguala, the town where 43 students went missing after a violent confrontation with police last week. The chief prosecutor for the state of Guerrero, where the bodies were found, says it's "hard to be sure that it's the missing students because we must conduct expert tests and find similarities with the people being searched," the AFP reports via an anonymous state police agent. Police say they're working to identify the bodies.

– A self-styled "guru" who says he has some 50 million followers around the world convinced some 400 of his followers to cut off their own testicles to "bring them closer to God." Gurmeet Ram Rahim Singh, who heads the Dera Sacha Sauda sect in the Punjab province of India, says he was inspired by Michelangelo's David, who cut off his own penis to "bring them closer to God," the BBC reports. Singh, who claims to be the world's 10th-richest man with a fortune said to be in the tens of millions of dollars, says the procedure was carried out in his hometown of Dera Sacha Sauda's headquarters in the town of Zakariya, Punjab. He says the penises were removed with the permission of God.

– Lebanese officials say they've detained the wife and child of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, but an Iraqi official tells the AP that the woman in custody isn't al-Baghdadi's wife. The woman is an Iraqi national named Saja Abdul Hamid al-Dulaimi, and she traveled to Syria before arriving in Lebanon, the Iraqi official says. Earlier reports claimed that Lebanese officials had captured the wife and child of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi. An Iraqi official told the AP that the woman detained in Lebanon was not the wife of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi. The report noted that al-Baghdadi has two wives.

But when he went to a doctor, he learned the scratch was actually the result of a spider that had burrowed through an appendix scar and traveled up into his torso, leaving a red, scar-like trail, Australia's ABC News reports. The spider survived for three days. Maxwell, who has since returned to Australia, was dubbed "Spider Man" by local media after a photo of his scar went viral on social media.

– Big Bank Hank, aka Henry Jackson, has died of kidney complications at the age of 57, TMZ reports. The rapper, real name Henry Jackson, was a member of the Sugarhill Gang, which was the first hip-hop act to score a mainstream rap hit with 1979 track Rapper's Delight.

– The bodies of 43 students who went missing in the late 1970s and early 1980s have been found in a mass grave near the site of a high school massacre in Connecticut. The Hartford Courant reports that police discovered the graves after getting a tip from the mother of one of the students who went missing. The bodies of the students, who ranged in age from 13 to 17, were found buried near the site of the Sandy Hook massacre, which occurred in the Hartford Courant's coverage of the massacre last year. The Courant says it's the first time such a grave has been found at the site.

– Christian Bale is in talks to play Steve Jobs in a new movie based on Walter Isaacson's biography, sources tell the New York Daily News. Danny Boyle will direct, and Aaron Sorkin will write the script, according to the Hollywood Reporter.

The paper reports that Kim's younger sister, Kim Yo Jong, is "closer to the leader" than her father, Kim Jong Il, and is believed to be able to handle the country's day-to-day affairs more effectively than her father, according to the paper, which says it has seen "proof" that the younger Kim is capable of running the country. Haines, who gained fame in the 1980s with songs like "You've Lost That Lovin' Feelin'" and "(You've Lost That) Love," died of complications from pneumonia in a hospital in London, reports the Independent.

He says the man in the video appears to have been killed by a rocket-propelled grenade while on a mission to capture a Taliban leader.

– The good news: Banksy has not been arrested. The bad news: The news is, yet again, a hoax. If you woke up this morning to a Twitter feed filled with recycled "OMG BANKSY WAS ARRESTED/WTF BANKSY WAS NOT ARRESTED" exclamations, here's why. Banksy has not been arrested. Let's not bury the lede here, people. The news of his incarceration is, yet again, a hoax. If you woke up this morning to a Twitter feed filled with recycled "OMG BANKSY WAS ARRESTED/WTF BANKSY WAS NOT ARRESTED" exclamations, here's why.

– A US airstrike in Somalia may have killed the leader of the al-Qaeda-linked al-Shabab terrorist group. Pentagon spokesman John Kirby says drones and manned aircraft bombed a gathering of al-Shabab commanders in a camp in south-central Somalia on Monday, the BBC reports. "US special operations forces using manned and unmanned aircraft destroyed an encampment and a vehicle using several Hellfire missiles and laser-guided munitions," he said. Kirby confirmed that the attack was aimed at leader Ahmed Abdi Godane, also referred to as Abu-Zubayr, and that the bombs definitely hit the meeting of Shabaab chiefs. But he said it was unclear whether Godane was killed.

– Apple hasn't actually announced any prices for the Apple Watch yet, but a French blog is reporting that the stainless steel version will start at $500 and the gold version at $4,000, MacRumors reports. The base price for the base model of the Apple Watch is $349, but the iGen blog reports that the stainless steel version will have a starting price of $500 and the gold version will have a starting price of $4,000. The iGen blog has been reliable in the past, correctly predicting the size of the iPhone 6 and 6 Plus.

– Newt Gingrich was back on the campaign trail Tuesday night for the first time since he dropped out of the race for the GOP nomination, and he didn't exactly have a great night. The former House speaker, speaking at a rally in Mobile, Ala., was heckled and booed by the crowd as he took the stage, CNN reports. "You're fired," he told the crowd. "You're fired." At another point, he told the crowd, "You're fired. You're fired." Gingrich was booed again when he addressed the crowd after his speech, saying, "You're fired. You're fired. You're not going to be president of the United States. You're not going to be president of the United States." At another point, he told the crowd: "You're fired. You're not going to be president of the United States." Gingrich was booed again when he addressed the crowd after his speech, saying, "You're fired. You're not going to be president of the United States." He told the crowd: "You're fired. You're not going to be president of the United States."

– If you're going to spend $2 million on a sports car, you might as well put some thought into where you're going to leave it. That's apparently what happened in Seattle, where the hood of a Bugatti Veyron—one of the world's most expensive sports cars—was spray-painted with what appears to be a man's genitals, the Telegraph reports. It's not clear who spray-painted the car, but Stef Stivala of the Seattle Post-Intelligencer tweeted a photo of the "brilliantly simple penis" along with the caption, "If you've spent £1.5 million on a Bugatti Veyron you probably should put a bit of thought into where you leave it." Reaction on Twitter has been mixed, with some calling the penis "brilliantly simple" and others bemoaning the fact that the car is worth so much.

– When a 2-year-old girl in St. Peter's Square watched Pope Francis lead a procession for her dog, Assisi, who had recently died, she thought it was the end of the world. It wasn't. Instead, the pontiff spoke to the boy and his mother, telling them there was a place at the Vatican for all creatures who share our lives. "There is a place in hell for the evil one, but there is also a place in heaven for the good one," he said, per the Telegraph. Assisi, it turns out, was a dog by the name of St. Francis of Assisi, a 16th-century friar who specialized in animals. The pope's visit to the boy's house was the first of its kind by a pontiff since the dog's death, and it's being hailed as one of the most moving moments of his young life.

– A 19-year-old college student from Laguna Beach, Calif., says she's the sun from the children's show Teletubbies—and she wants the world to know about it. "I am the sun from Teletubbies," Jess Smith tells the Mirror. "There has been quite a few of them." Smith, a dance education student at Canterbury Christ Church University, says she got the idea for the character from the children's show when she was watching it on TV with her mom, reports the Los Angeles Times. "She was like, 'I want to be on the show,'" Smith says. "I said, 'I want to be in the show,' and she was like, 'No, I don't want to be in the show.'"

– In a historic change, the NYPD will stop arresting people on low-level marijuana charges and issue tickets instead, sources tell the New York Daily News. The NYPD’s old strategy for combating pot possession is going up in smoke. Sources say officers will stop arresting people on low-level marijuana charges and issue tickets instead.

– The Pentagon confirmed Friday the death of the leader of the al-Shabab terror group, Ahmed Abdi Godane, who was the target of a US airstrike Monday in Somalia. The strike killed the leader of the al-Shabab terror group, Ahmed Abdi Godane, who was the target of a US airstrike Monday in Somalia. The strike killed the leader of the al-Shabab terror group, Ahmed Abdi Godane, who was the target of a US airstrike Monday in Somalia. The Pentagon confirmed Friday the death of the leader of the al-Shabab terror group, Ahmed Abdi Godane, who was the target of a US airstrike Monday in Somalia.

– It's not Banksy, it's Lucille Clerc. The artist's Instagram post showing what appeared to be the work of the famous graffiti artist was widely shared on social media this week, but it's not Banksy's, BuzzFeed reports. BuzzFeed was one of several media outlets to mistakenly credit the image to Banksy, though it now says it was Clerc's work, not Banksy's.

– ISIS says it has killed American hostage Kayla Jean Mueller, who was being held by the militant group in Syria for more than a year. The group released a video last month in which she said she would be killed if the US didn't pay a multimillion-dollar ransom for her release, the BBC reports. "The news that an American citizen has been killed during the operations against the Islamic State in Raqqa has been confirmed by the Islamic State," a statement from the group said. "The fate of the remaining American hostages is now in the hands of the United States government." Mueller, 26, was seized by militants while on a humanitarian mission in Raqqa in October 2015 and is the last US hostage held by ISIS. Jordan has been conducting airstrikes against the militant group in an effort to drive it out of the Syrian capital.

– Yetis have been roaming the forests of Siberia for thousands of years, and now they've made their way to the town of Adygeysk. The Siberian Times reports that locals have been posting videos of the creatures on social media in an attempt to prove they're real—and that they're not scared by humans. One video shows a Yeti walking in front of a car, and another shows a young boy who appears to be a Yeti walking in front of a house. The town's mayor says it's the first time a bighorn sheep has been seen in the area since the 19th century, according to the BBC.

– A plumber in Texas is trying to figure out how a company name and phone number ended up on the back of a pickup truck that was photographed being fired on by ISIS militants, CBS News reports. Mark Oberholtzer's Mark-1 Plumbing Company put a black F-250 pickup truck up for auction more than a year ago, according to the Houston Chronicle. The company lost track of the truck after selling it to a dealership in Houston last year.

– "At least 10 ISIS fighters have been caught coming across the Mexican border in Texas," California Rep. Duncan Hunter told Fox News' Greta van Susteren yesterday, adding that he got the information from a border patrol source. The Republican has been pushing the "ISIS At the Border" line so hard he may now be hearing things.

– Militants from the Islamic State in Iraq have beheaded American journalist James Foley and are threatening to kill another hostage, US officials say. The video shows the decapitation of Foley, who was seized by militants in northern Iraq in 2012 while working as a freelance journalist for Time, the New York Times reports. The Islamic State, which controls a third of Iraq and Syria, has threatened to kill another American hostage, Steven Sotloff.

– ISIS says it has killed American hostage Kayla Mueller, who was being held by the militant group in Syria, reports the AP. A statement released on behalf of the militant group, which calls itself the Islamic State, says Mueller was killed during a Jordanian airstrike near Raqqa. Mueller, 26, had been taken hostage in August 2013 by the militants, who had threatened to kill her if the US didn't pay a ransom. US officials haven't confirmed her death.

– A video posted online Tuesday purportedly shows an Islamist extremist beheading James Foley, an American journalist kidnapped in Syria more than 18 months ago. A video posted online Tuesday purportedly shows an Islamist extremist beheading James Foley, an American journalist kidnapped in Syria more than 18 months ago. James Foley went missing in November 2012 A video posted online Tuesday purportedly shows an Islamist extremist beheading James Foley, an American journalist kidnapped in Syria more than 18 months ago.

– New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio is expected to announce a new policy Monday that would decriminalize the possession of small amounts of marijuana, the New York Times reports. According to the Wall Street Journal, de Blasio is expected to announce that possession of less than an ounce of marijuana would be punishable by a ticket instead of a jail term. The new policy would apply to people with a first-time offense and would largely affect black and Latino residents, who make up 86% of marijuana possession arrests in the city this year.

– A Russian lawmaker says Vladimir Putin has told him he's ready to step down as head of the country's FSB security service, the successor to the KGB, reports the AP. Leonid Slutsky, a member of the upper house of Russia's parliament, tells the RIA Novosti news agency that Putin told him "he is ready to step down as head of the country's main intelligence agency." Slutsky says Putin made the announcement in a phone call from his residence in St. Petersburg on Friday. He says the FSB, successor to the KGB, is in charge of the country's anti-terror operations.

– A video purporting to show US military aid being dropped on ISIS fighters defending the Syrian city of Kobani was released by a pro-Isis news agency yesterday, the New York Times reports. The video, which purports to show military aid being dropped on ISIS fighters in Kobani by US forces, has been viewed more than a million times since it was posted online last night, according to the Times.

– Henry "Big Bank Hank" Jackson, the rapper best known for the 1979 hit "Rapper's Delight" with the Sugarhill Gang, has died of cancer at the age of 57, reports the Los Angeles Times. Jackson, who was born in New York, was a member of the original Sugarhill Gang, which included Guy "Master Gee" O'Brien and Henry "Big Bank" Young, according to the New York Daily News. "His voice served as a call to action, an echo that continues today whenever a kid bellows the word 'hip hop' into a microphone," writes Jon Caramanica at the Times. "It was in Henry 'Big Bank Hank' Jackson's lyrical wobble, the way he rapped through the Sugarhill Gang's 'Rapper's Delight,' the singular hit that propelled a movement when it was released in 1979."

– Is Fidel Castro dead? The Cuban government says there's "no truth" to rumors of the 88-year-old's death and it has no plans to hold a press conference to address the rumors, AFP reports. A spokesman for Cuban President Raul Castro says the ex-leader is recovering from intestinal surgery and remains in good health. Castro has not been seen in public since July, when he appeared in public for the first time since ceding power to his brother Raul.

– Apple's much-anticipated Apple Watch won't be out until early next year, an analyst tells CNBC. "There's really no right time of the year for this product to come out because really hasn't existed yet," says Brian Blair of Rosenblatt Securities. "It is kind of a strange period, but the more production gets pushed back, the later it's going to launch. It looks like right now February is the best shot they have." The Wall Street Journal reports that the delay is due to production problems.

– The Nigerian government says it has reached an agreement with the extremist group Boko Haram that will see the release of more than 200 kidnapped schoolgirls, the AP reports. The deal was announced Friday by Nigerian President Muhammadu Buhari, who says Boko Haram has agreed not to carry out any "major offensives" against the country until the girls are released. Boko Haram, which wants the girls released as slaves, has been terrorizing Nigeria for more than six years.

– ISIS released a new video today in which it claims American-made weapons accidentally fall into the hands of the militants, reports the Daily Beast. The video shows a bundle of weapons that ISIS says were supposed to go to Kurdish fighters fighting ISIS in the Syrian city of Kobani. Instead, the weapons appear to have fallen into the hands of the militants.

– A man says Comcast contacted his employer and got him fired after he called to complain about the company's service. A man says Comcast contacted his employer and got him fired after he called to complain about the company's service. The Consumerist reports that a man known as Conal complained to Comcast after he was billed for services he didn't actually have. After Conal's complaint, the company promised him extra television channels as a make-good but instead sent him a variety of equipment he didn't need. Conal, who says he works for a large American accountancy firm, compiled a spreadsheet showing every erroneous charge he had received from Comcast, which he sent to the company. Comcast then apparently refused to reverse the error.

– The Islamic State has at least three warplanes in northern Syria that could be used against the US-led coalition, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. The human rights group says former Iraqi military officers are training ISIS fighters to fly the warplanes, which are at an airport east of Aleppo, the Los Angeles Times reports. If true, the report suggests that ISIS fighters could turn their weapons on coalition aircraft.

– Mohammed Islam is a 17-year-old senior at New York City's Stuyvesant High School who tells New York magazine he's made $72 million since he was 9 years old by trading stocks and other securities. Well, that's a lot of money for a high school senior, but it's also a lot of money if you're a Wall Street Journal reporter, who interviewed Islam for a story published this week. The story claimed that Islam made the money between classes, homework, and extra-curricular activities. So how did he do it? Well, he started by trading when he was 9 years old with his cousin, who taught him the ins and outs of the stock market.

– Iraqi pilots who have joined ISIS in Syria are training members of the group to fly in three captured fighter jets, a group monitoring the war said on Friday, saying it was the first time the militant group had taken to the air. Reuters reports that the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says the pilot training is being carried out by three Iraqi pilots who have joined ISIS and are learning to fly in the captured jets.

– The fence-jumper who made it through the front lawn and into the White House earlier this month made it further inside the building than had been previously disclosed, according to a report in the Washington Post published Monday. The man who jumped over the White House fence and raced across the front lawn made it farther inside the building than was previously disclosed, barreling past one Secret Service agent and making it inside the building's first floor.
– Canadian media reports say that shots have been fired at the National War Memorial in Ottawa, and a soldier has been shot. The national broadcaster CBC reports that a soldier has been shot.

– Twenty years ago, two Australians bought a hamburger from a McDonald’s—and it’s as good as new, 9News reports. Casey Dean and Eduard Nitz were just 13 and 14 years old when they bought their first McD’s burger, on a whim, in a Armidale, Australia, McDonald’s. “It was the first time we’d ever had a burger,” says Dean. “We thought it was going to be the last time we’d ever have a burger.” Today, the burger is as good as new.

– The FBI has identified the second American killed in ISIS-controlled territory in Syria as 19-year-old aid worker Peter Kassig, a US citizen who joined the militant group last year. Kassig, who grew up in Ohio, was one of the first American fighters to join the Islamic State, which seized control of large parts of Iraq and Syria last year. He was killed in the early hours of Sunday near the border with Syria, reports the AP. A spokesman for the FBI's Cincinnati office tells the AP that Kassig was one of several aid workers killed in the fighting. He says investigators are still trying to determine whether other Americans have been killed. Kassig was working for Doctors Without Borders in Raqqa, the capital of the Islamic State's self-proclaimed capital, Raqqa, when he was killed.

– You may have seen a story going around Facebook that promises you'll be able to float in the air on Jan. 4 as a result of a planetary alignment that will "decrease gravity" for five minutes. Unfortunately, it is total bullshit. The story originates from DailyBuzzLive, a fake news site that admits it occasionally publishes "works of complete fiction," and it's being widely shared because it includes a tweet from NASA that boosts its apparent credibility, Mashable reports. But NASA denies both the tweet and the bogus claim that a planetary alignment will somehow let you float for 3 seconds at a time: "These rumors are false and NASA has no plans to send anyone to space this month."

– A heartbroken woman in Chengdu, China, did the right thing after she was dumped by her boyfriend: Instead of going on a partying bender or staying in and watching Friends reruns, she staked out a spot at the local KFC and went to town on some chicken wings. Tan Shen, 26, says she stopped at a KFC near a train station on her way home from the breakup when she decided you know what, f--- this, this feels right and good and I don't need that asshole anyway. It's all about these wings.

– A schoolboy almost killed by an electric shock from a street lamp now claims he has "magnetic superpowers" like Magneto from X-Men. – A South Korean newspaper says Kim Jong Un is in the hospital because he has become so fat that his ankles broke, the Telegraph reports. According to the Chosun Ilbo, the North Korean leader has gained so much weight that he has become so obese that his ankles broke under his own weight. The Telegraph's sources say that South Korea's military is keeping a close eye on Kim, who is believed to be around 70 years old, because he could be a danger to North Korea's nuclear weapons program.

– Scotland may soon have a new neighbor: North Korea. Kim Jong Un is considering opening a restaurant in the country, experts tell the Edinburgh Evening News. "The Scottish independence referendum catapulted Scotland into the North Korean elite's thoughts," says Michael Madden, editor of the North Korea Leadership Watch blog. Madden says North Korea has long had a strong presence in Scotland, and it's no surprise that the country's supreme leader is considering opening a restaurant there. "The Scottish independence referendum catapulted Scotland into the North Korean elite's thoughts," he says. Madden says the restaurant would serve North Korean favorites, like dog.

– The Apple Watch will start at $349 when it hits stores next month, according to a report on French website iGen.fr picked up by 9to5mac.com. The site also claims that the stainless steel and gold versions of the watch will start at $399 and $499, respectively. Apple hasn't confirmed the report, 9to5mac.com notes.

– A photo of what appears to be a so-called "app manipulation farm" in China has gone viral on social media, and while it's hard to tell exactly what's going on, one thing is clear: It's a place where developers can pay to have their apps' download numbers artificially inflated. The Verge explains: "Because more downloads (perhaps accompanied by positive reviews) enhances apps' chart position, thereby raising their discoverability level, and hopefully prompting people to download them." The photo shows a worker at one of the farms, sitting in front of what appear to be around 100 iPhone 5c units.

– Rumors have been swirling for a while now that Apple is working on a cheaper, gold-colored version of the Apple Watch, but a new report from 9to5mac.com suggests that the company is actually working on a platinum version for the first-generation Edition units, and that it may be using ceramic blending to achieve the extra-durable gold in the first-generation Edition units. The report doesn't go into much detail, other than to say that it's "likely" Apple is working on a cheaper, gold-colored version of the Apple Watch, and that it may be using ceramic blending to achieve the extra-durable gold in the first-generation Edition units, according to a new report from 9to5mac.com.

– If you've upgraded to iOS 8, you may want to stop reading now. The Telegraph reports that some users are reporting that their iWork documents have been deleted from iCloud Drive after they've activated the "All Settings" option. The issue appears to be with the setting under the "General" menu, not with the new iOS operating system itself. If you've already upgraded to iOS 8, you'll still be able to access your iWork files, but if you've already upgraded to iOS 8, you won't be able to access those files. – When it comes to wild mushrooms in the UK, Queen Elizabeth II has a little something extra to add to the "super-strong" category. The Independent reports that a plant in her garden has been found growing so well that it's been dubbed a "magic mushroom." It's not the first time such a plant has been spotted in the monarch's garden, but it's the first time it's been found growing so well that it's been dubbed a "super-strong magic mushroom."

– Valentine's Day is right around the corner, and the Apple Watch is on track to be out by then, according to China-based supply chain sources cited by 9to5mac.com. The sources say that mass production of the watch hasn't even begun yet, but that they're "lucky" to have it out by Feb. 14. That's about a month later than the original release date of April Fool's Day, which was also cited by 9to5mac.com.

– A California company is hoping to revolutionize the security business with autonomous robots. The Knightscope K5 is one of four drones now patrolling Microsoft's Silicon Valley Campus.
