– Jordan's King Abdullah is personally taking part in airstrikes against ISIS in retaliation for the execution of pilot Moaz Kasasbeh, according to reports on Iraqinews.com and Shafaqna news. It's not clear whether he's actually suiting up and flying a plane, or if he's actually commanding the units involved in the mission.

– An attorney for the family of Michael Brown says an audio recording of the shooting that sparked outrage and looting in Ferguson, Mo., does indeed capture the events leading up to the death of the unarmed 18-year-old, the New York Times reports. But Dorian Johnson, the man Brown's family hired to defend him against police, says the recording is "doctored" and "doesn't tell the whole story." He tells the Times that he has listened to the recording several times and that it doesn't capture the immediate aftermath of the shooting, when Brown was shot six times and police ordered him to put his hands up. Johnson, who says he was present when Brown was shot, tells the Times that he doesn't believe the Brown family's version of events—that police opened fire because Brown reached for his gun—and that the audio doesn't capture what happened before and after the shooting. He says he has also listened to the tape several times and doesn't believe it captures the final moments of Brown's life, when police ordered him to put his hands up. "I don't think it does capture what happened before and after the shooting," he says. "I don't think it captures what happened after

– Remember the Comcast customer service call that went viral in July? Well, the company has apparently learned its lesson: If you complain about customer service, you're going to get fired. That's according to a Consumerist report that cites "sources close to the situation." The source says that after the customer service call went viral, Comcast reached out to the man's employer and told it to fire him for his "outrageous" complaint. The man's employer fired him, the source says, though it's not clear if that termination was related to the customer service call.

– The FBI has identified the second American killed in ISIS-controlled territory in Syria as 19-year-old aid worker Peter Kassig, a US citizen who joined the militant group last year. Kassig, who grew up in Ohio, was one of the first American fighters to join the Islamic State, which seized control of large parts of Iraq and Syria last year. He was killed in the early hours of Sunday near the border with Syria, reports the AP. A spokesman for the FBI's Cincinnati office tells the AP that Kassig was one of several aid workers killed in the fighting. He says investigators are still trying to determine whether other Americans have been killed. Kassig was working for Doctors Without Borders in Raqqa, the capital of the Islamic State's self-proclaimed capital, Raqqa, when he was killed.

– An Indian public official has been fired for taking leave 24 years ago and never returning to his desk in the country's notoriously work-shy bureaucracy. An Indian public official has been fired for taking leave 24 years ago and never returning to his desk in the country's notoriously work-shy bureaucracy. Assistant executive engineer A.K Verma went on leave in 1990 after joining India's central public works department a decade earlier. Verma defied bosses' orders to return to work after his requests for additional leave were denied. "He went on seeking extension of leave, which was not sanctioned, and defied directions to report to work," the government said in a statement on Thursday, per the Guardian. An inquiry found him guilty of "wilful absence."

– Google has signed a pair of huge real estate deals that will make the company's presence in Silicon Valley even bigger. The company has signed leases for 2.8 million square feet of office space in Sunnyvale and Redwood City, reports the San Jose Mercury News. The deals will give Google enough space for more than 10,000 workers and the biggest office lease in Silicon Valley history.

– The White House says it's investigating reports that a US drone flew over Syria twice in the space of a few hours yesterday, in violation of US and international law, the BBC reports. Syria's state-run news agency says the drone was over the border in Iraq, according to the AP. The State Department says it's looking into the reports. It's not clear whether the drone was in violation of US or international law, the BBC notes.

– If you’re looking for a secluded, private island in the middle of the Mediterranean where you can get away from the paparazzi and play golf with the world’s sixth-richest athlete, then Tiger Woods’ Viking island is the place for you. The $9.9 million property includes a private ferry, stables, a hunting lodge, a golf hole, a mini-mansion, and a “hill fort” that dates back to the Stone, Bronze, and Iron ages, the Telegraph reports. The island, which Tiger bought in 2000 for $3 million, is on the market again after being put up for sale last year.

– The story of a priest who says he saw a female God while working in a remote part of Massachusetts is making the rounds on Reddit and other sites, but there's one big problem: There's no mainstream media reporting on it, the Dallas Morning News reports. The priest, identified only as Father Mark D'Amore, says he was working in a remote part of Boston's Mattapan Hills when he felt something hit him in the back of the head. He says he fell to the ground and hit his head on the concrete. He says he woke up in a field, saw a light shining from the sky, and saw a female God appear. He says she told him that she was the daughter of Jesus and Mary and that she was ready to welcome him back to the Catholic Church. D'Amore's account has been picked up by radio stations in Texas, including KVIL-FM, but no mainstream media outlets are reporting on it, the Morning News notes.

– A 6-foot-tall mechanical carol-singing bear that's been a hit with residents of a Scottish village is now in danger of being hit with an ASBO, the Telegraph reports. The bear, named Bear Grylls, has been a hit with residents of the Aviemore area of the town since he was unveiled last month, and now they're worried he could be hit with an ASBO over noise complaints. The bear, which lives in a specially made enclosure made of wood, metal, and scaffolding, is equipped with bells, whistles, and a PA system and sings Christmas songs all night long. Residents have complained that the bear's music is so loud they can't hear each other's voices. The bear, who lives in a specially made enclosure made of wood, metal, and scaffolding, is equipped with bells, whistles, and a PA system and sings Christmas songs all night long.

– A salacious sex tape from an Argentinian teacher's affair with her 16-year-old student is likely nothing more than an Internet hoax, reports the New York Daily News. An Argentinian newspaper debunked the racy story.

– Libyan strongman Moammar Gadhafi's grip on power appears to be loosening. At least 11 private jets have been stolen in recent weeks, and Western intelligence agencies fear they could be used in terror attacks on Sept. 11, the anniversary of the Osama bin Laden-orchestrated attacks on New York and Washington that left nearly 3,000 dead, the Los Angeles Times reports. Gadhafi's regime has been cracking down hard on corruption, and the theft of the jets could be a sign of things to come.

– Militants from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria have released a graphic video showing the beheading of American journalist James Foley, reports the New York Times. The graphic video, which shows the decapitation of the 39-year-old photojournalist, was posted online today. Foley, a freelancer who worked for the Global Post, was first captured in Libya in 2012, released, and kidnapped again around Thanksgiving of that year by unknown gunmen in Syria. The video was posted online by the same group that released a video showing the beheading of journalist Steven Sotloff.

– A 77-year-old Japanese woman has been sentenced to 18 months in prison for killing dozens of cats in her neighborhood and making fur coats out of them, the Japan Times reports. The woman was caught on a private investigator's video walking around her neighborhood wearing fur coats made out of dozens of cats. She was also caught eating cat meat. According to court documents, the woman admitted to killing the cats because she "got too much attached to the little critters."

– Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has dismissed reports that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is planning to open a restaurant in her country as "propaganda" from a "provocateur." In a statement issued after a meeting with her North Korean counterpart on the sidelines of the G20 summit in Argentina, Sturgeon said she has "no idea" whether Kim is planning to open a restaurant in Scotland, the Guardian reports. "Scotland is a very special place to me and I hope that North Korea will respect our traditions and values and open a restaurant in our country," she said. "Scotland is a very special place to the people of North Korea and I hope that North Korea will respect our traditions and values and open a restaurant in our country."

– A video purporting to show Saudi Arabia's state television station blurring the image of First Lady Michelle Obama as she and President Obama met the new Saudi King during a visit to that country this week has gone viral, but the White House says it's not true. A short video clip has been circulating online Tuesday that purports to show Saudi Arabia's state television station blurring the image of First Lady Michelle Obama as she and President Barack Obama met the new Saudi King during a visit to that country this week.

– The 18-time Olympic gold medal-winning swimmer's girlfriend has revealed that she is intersex—a fact she has not previously revealed to Phelps, the New York Daily News reports. In a Facebook post, Michael Phelps' longtime girlfriend, Nicole Johnson, says she was born "intersex" to a man and a woman. "I'm taking this time to be open and honest," Johnson writes. "It's been an amazing journey and I'm glad I've been able to share it with you." Johnson says she and Phelps, who has a 15-month-old baby together, are "in love" and "in love with each other for the rest of our lives." She says she has no plans to come out to Phelps.

– Sony's Steve Jobs biopic is in the works, and it's looking for its star. British actor Cristian Bale is in talks to play the iconic Apple founder, reports the Times. Danny Boyle, director of Slumdog Millionaire, will direct, and Aaron Sorkin, who wrote The Social Network, will write the script, notes the Hollywood Reporter.

– It's not every day that a fatwa is issued against building snowmen, but that's exactly what happened in Saudi Arabia this week. Residents in the northern areas of the country braved the cold to build snow camels in a rare tribute to local culture, the Telegraph reports. One man used his snow to promote the colors of local soccer teams, while another opted for the traditional ghitra and agal to cover his snowman's head. But it wasn't all fun and games for Saudis, who were told by a religious scholar that building snow animals is not allowed in Islam.

– If you've ever wanted to quit your job, there's only one place you'd want to go—on your boss's desk. But that's exactly what an iPhone game designer did instead of placing a letter of resignation on his boss's desk, Mashable reports. The man, whose name has not been released, created a letter of resignation that can be accessed only if the user collects 100 points on the final level of his game, Electric Boogie.

– For Joe Riquelme's parents, the miracle came in the form of a plain white envelope containing a handwritten note from their son telling them he had paid off their mortgage. For Joe Riquelme's parents, the miracle came in the form of a plain white envelope containing a handwritten note from their son telling them he had paid off their mortgage

– The leader of Nigeria's Boko Haram extremist group has denied reports of a ceasefire with the government, saying in a new video message that the 200 schoolgirls kidnapped last month have been converted to Islam and married off. In a new video message, Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau says the schoolgirls have converted to Islam and married off, the New York Times reports. Shekau's statement comes after Nigerian President Goodluck Jonathan announced that Boko Haram had agreed to cease hostilities in exchange for the girls' release. But in the new video message, Shekau says the girls are still being held, the BBC reports.

– Banksy is back on the streets of London after what appears to have been a prank gone wrong. The street artist's publicist tells the Independent that reports that he had been arrested in the city are "a hoax." She adds that the artist is still "roaming free" and spraying cans of paint all over the city. The Independent initially reported that Banksy had been taken into custody, but it later retracted the story.

– For the first time since the start of the Syrian civil war, the US appears to be using an unarmed surveillance drone over the Islamic State stronghold of Raqqa. According to local activists, the drone has been circling the city for three hours. If the reports are true, this would suggest that the air environment over Raqqa is similar to what we've seen in Iraq and Afghanistan, the Daily Beast reports. According to the Independent, two photos of the drone appear to show a Predator drone's downward-facing V-shaped tail. The drone doesn't appear to be carrying any missiles, and the available evidence indicates that it's being used for surveillance purposes, rather than, as the Independent puts it, "in a hunter-killer type mission."

– For the first time in three years, North Korea's leader wasn't in attendance at an official event to mark the 69th anniversary of the country's ruling Workers' Party, the Telegraph reports. But while Kim Jong Un was nowhere to be found, a flower basket bearing his name was placed before the statues of his father and grandfather, both of whom ruled the country for decades.

– A Canadian-born woman and resident of Tel Aviv who volunteered to fight alongside Kurdish fighters in Syria is reported to have been captured near Kobani. Gill Rosenberg, a Canadian-born woman and resident of Tel Aviv who volunteered to fight alongside Kurdish fighters in Syria, is reported to have been captured near Kobani. The New York Times has the story here.

– The Apple Watch is supposed to be water resistant, but it turns out that's not all it's cracked up to be. Engadget reports that the company is working on a "showerproof" version of the watch that will also be water resistant. It's unclear if that will be included in the final version of the watch, which is expected to hit stores later this month.

– A South Korean think tank says Kim Yo Jong, the younger sister of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, might be leading the hermit kingdom instead of her brother. Kim Yo Jong, the younger sister of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, might be leading the hermit kingdom instead of her brother, a recent report from Seoul-based think tank, North Korea Intellectuals Solidarity (NKIS) revealed. The report, based on interviews with more than a dozen North Korean defectors, says Kim Yo Jong, who is believed to be around 30 years old, "has a good command of the art of self-defense and the art of self-preservation," according to the Yonhap News Agency.
– Two Australian men think they may be in possession of the world's oldest burger, after they kept a Quarter Pounder with cheese bought for a friend who never turned up to eat it

– A mysterious crater in Nicaragua may or may not have been caused by a meteor, according to NASA scientists. The space agency says it's too early to know for sure what caused the 40-foot-wide crater near the airport in Managua, but "the information available at this time suggests that some other cause is responsible for its creation," the Los Angeles Times reports. According to a NASA blog post, "the biggest mystery is that no one so far has reported seeing a flash of light in the sky that would be expected to accompany such a meteor strike." The blog post adds that "while a meteoritic origin for this crater cannot be ruled out with absolute certainty, the information available at this time suggests that some other cause is responsible for its creation."

– If you're one of those people who can't get enough of the Kardashians, we've got some bad news for you. Khloe Kardashian and Lamar Odom are expecting their second child this summer, reports TMZ, which notes that Khloe's rep confirmed the news to ABC News. "We are very happy to confirm that Khloe and Lamar are expecting their second child this summer," the rep said in a statement. "We are also very happy to be able to share this news with you at this time."

– It's been more than a month since Kim Jong Un hasn't been seen in public, leading to rumors that he's sick and stepping down as North Korea's leader, but the country's official Korean Central News Agency isn't giving up on his whereabouts. "He is still the supreme leader of the DPRK and will remain so," the KCNA says, using the acronym for North Korea. "There is no change in the status of the supreme leader of the DPRK." The KCNA says the country's military and police are ready to deal with any "imminent" threat from South Korea, which has warned of "merciless strikes" if the North doesn't back down from its nuclear weapons program, the BBC reports. South Korea's defense minister said last week that his country is ready to shoot down any North Korean missile "without hesitation."

– Buckingham Palace's gardens are home to hundreds of species of plants and animals, but a newly discovered mushroom is particularly unusual. The red and white spotted Amanita muscaria species—also known as fly agaric—is a hallucinogenic toadstool mushroom, Sky News reports. It was discovered by Alan Titchmarsh, host of the BBC's The Alan Titchmarsh Show, during a tour of the palace's gardens with ecology expert Mick Crawley. Titchmarsh says the toadstool, which can cause hallucinations, has been growing in the gardens for at least a decade, but it wasn't until Crawley showed it to him that he realized it was a hallucinogenic mushroom.

– A 31-year-old Italian nun was rushed to the hospital with stomach pains, only to discover she was pregnant and about to give birth, the Telegraph reports. According to Italian media, the nun, who was originally from South America, was part of a team that went to a remote village in northern Italy to search for a missing 13-year-old girl. The search turned up a child's remains, but it's not clear if the child is the nun's.

– A TV crew was doing a walk-through of Buckingham Palace's garden when they spotted what looked like "magic mushrooms." One of the experts on the show asked, "Is it edible?" to which another replied, "That depends what you mean," the Telegraph reports. The show, called The Queen's Garden, will air on Christmas Day.

– An attorney for the family of 18-year-old Michael Brown says a newly released audio recording could shed light on the fatal shooting by a Ferguson, Mo., police officer. In the recording, a man identified as Brown's father can be heard saying, "I don't know what to do, I don't know what to do, I don't know what to do" as he talks about his son's death at the hands of officer Darren Wilson, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch reports. "I don't know what to say. I don't know what to say. I don't know what to say. I don't know what to say," the man says. "I don't know what to say. I don't know what to say. I don't know what to say.... I don't know what to say. I don't know what to say. I don't know what to say," the man says. "I don't know what to say. I don't know what to say.... I don't know what to say. I don't know what to say. I don't know what to say

– The terrier-schnauzer mix was rescued from a Scottish train station earlier this month after he was found tied to a railing and with a suitcase full of belongings inside, the Guardian reports. Now, offers are pouring in for Kai's new home. "The phone's been ringing off the hook all day," a rep for the Scottish SPCA tells the paper. "We've had over 100 offers to take him on."

– Apple's first major product launch since CEO Tim Cook took over in Tim Cook's shoes hasn't exactly been a roaring success. The company's revenue fell short of estimates for the first time in its history in the fiscal year that ended in September, the Wall Street Journal reports, and that could mean trouble for Cook and the rest of the Apple team as they try to get the new Apple Watch off the ground before the holiday shopping season kicks off in a couple of weeks. Analysts say the watch—which is expected to cost at least $30,000—is unlikely to be a game-changer for Apple as it has been with other high-end gadgets such as the iPhone. "Apple has a lot of work to do before the watch is ready for prime time," a Bernstein analyst tells the Journal. "If they can't get it right, they're going to have to find other ways to make money."

– Sorry to disappoint, fans of Led Zeppelin, but it doesn't look like a reunion will be happening any time soon. According to a report in UK publication The Mirror, the group's famed lead singer Robert Plant literally tore up a contract to reunite the band worth almost $800 million, saying the timing just wasn't right.

– President Trump's decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital has set off a wave of criticism from both sides of the aisle. Here's a look at some of the reactions: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says Trump's move is a "gross violation" of Israel's sovereignty and a "gross violation" of international law." Trump's move is a "gross violation" of Israel's sovereignty and a "gross violation of international law," according to a statement from Netanyahu's office. "The president of the United States has declared war on Israel." British Prime Minister David Cameron says Trump's move is a "gross violation" of Israel's sovereignty and a "gross violation" of international law. French President Francois Hollande says Trump's move is a "gross violation" of Israel's sovereignty and a "gross violation" of international law. "The prime minister of the United States has declared war on Israel." British Prime Minister David Cameron says Trump's move is a "gross violation" of Israel's sovereignty and a "gross violation" of international law.

– It's not every day a nun gives birth in a hospital, but that's exactly what happened toBartolomeo Eustachio in San Severino, Calif., reports the Los Angeles Times. The 84-year-old was admitted to the hospital Saturday with severe stomach pains, but after a CT scan and a blood test, she was determined to be in good health and was able to give birth to her first child, a healthy 7-pound, 11-ounce baby girl, reports the San Diego Union-Tribune. Eustachio has been a missionary in the area for more than 60 years.

– A new video purports to show the beheading of American journalist James Foley by militants from the Islamic State, or ISIS, reports the New York Times. The Global Post says it has seen the video and it appears to show the body of Foley, who went missing in Syria in November 2012. The Global Post is a division of Time Warner, which is owned by Time Warner. The Wall Street Journal says it has also seen the video and it, too, believes Foley's body is that of the journalist.

– A 22-year-old Macedonian man claims his small penis was the reason he was dumped by his girlfriend—and he cut it off and threw it in the trash, the Daily Mail reports. Oliver Ilic called medics after bleeding profusely from his penis, and police found it in the trash after searching his house.

– Apple's biggest product of the year? The MacBook Air. That's the word from 9to5Mac, which reports that Apple has completely redesigned the device, ditching the full-sized USB port, MagSafe connector, and SD card slots for something entirely different. The 12-inch MacBook Air will be " considerably smaller than the current 13-inch version, yet also slightly narrower than the 11-inch model," writes Mark Gurman. "The new 12-inch version is approximately a quarter-of-an-inch narrower."

– The rats have been hiding out in Vogue's swanky new digs at 1 World Trade Center, and the magazine has been forced to close for a few days while exterminators deal with the problem, the New York Daily News reports. According to the New York Post, the rats have been making their home in the magazine's basement, where they've been hiding out from the heat and humidity. "We have had to close the basement for a couple of days because the rats are out there," a source tells the Daily News. "It's crazy." The magazine, which is moving from its old digs to the World Trade Center next month, has been forced to close for a few days while exterminators deal with the problem.

– A patient being treated for Ebola at a hospital in Kansas City, Mo., is a man, not a woman as earlier reported, and he's not being treated for the disease, officials say. The patient, a Nigerian national, is not showing symptoms and is being treated "appropriately," an assistant vice president of the hospital's parent company tells the Kansas City Star. The man was rushed to the hospital Saturday night and placed under quarantine, but it's not clear how sick he is or if anyone else is sick, the Star reports.

– Macaulay Culkin was found dead in his New York City apartment, according to a shocking new report spreading online. Macaulay Culkin was allegedly found dead in his New York City apartment, according to a shocking new report spreading online. Could the Home Alone star really have died? Fans are completely stunned.

– Seven 13- and 14-year-old girls in Bosnia are expecting twins after a school trip to the capital city went horribly wrong, the Telegraph reports. The girls, who are from the town of Banja Luka, returned from a five-day trip to the capital city, Sarajevo, only to discover that they had been on a school trip for five days. "I was shocked," says the mother of a 14-year-old girl who is now seven months pregnant. "I didn't expect this. I didn't expect that there would be such a problem. I didn't expect that there would be such a lack of supervision." The trip was organized by a non-profit group called "The Children's Foundation for Peace and Development"—and the girls were only given permission to take part in one activity per day. "I was shocked," says the mother of a 15-year-old girl who is also pregnant. "I didn't expect that there would be such a problem. I didn't expect that there would be such a lack of supervision."

– Fidel Castro's reign over Cuba is over. The bearded revolutionary, who led a rebel army to improbable victory in Cuba, embraced Soviet-style communism, and defied the power of 10 US presidents during his half-century rule, died tonight, reports the AP. Castro's reign over the island-nation 90 miles from Florida was marked by the US-backed Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961 and the Cuban Missile Crisis a decade later that brought the world to the brink of nuclear war. The 83-year-old leader, who seized power at the age of 21, died eight years after ill health forced him to formally hand power over to his brother, Raul. The bearded revolutionary, who survived a crippling illness in ill health before triumphantly riding into Havana in January 2008, died eight years after ill health forced him to formally hand power over to his brother. Castro's reign was marked by the US-backed Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961 and the Cuban Missile Crisis a decade later that brought the world to the brink of nuclear war. The bearded revolutionary, who survived a crippling illness before triumphantly riding into Havana in January 2008, died tonight.

– Seven 13- and 14-year-old girls in Bosnia went on a school trip this month and ended up getting pregnant, angering their parents and educators, the AP reports. The girls, who are from the town of Banja Luka, were on a five-day school trip to the Bosnian capital of Sarajevo when they became pregnant, according to the country's national coordinator for reproductive health. The trip was approved by the school board, but the girls' parents weren't happy about it, the BBC reports.

– Islamic State fighters have seized at least one cache of weapons airdropped by US-led coalition forces that were meant to supply Kurdish militiamen battling the extremist group in a border town, activists said Tuesday. Islamic State fighters seized at least one cache of weapons airdropped by US-led coalition forces that were meant to supply Kurdish militiamen battling the extremist group in a border town, activists said Tuesday. The cache was meant to supply Kurdish militiamen battling ISIS in a border town in northern Iraq, the Wall Street Journal reports.

– North Carolina has been hit with a rare and freakish amount of snow this weekend, and the National Weather Service is now warning that it could get even worse over the next few days. The state has been hit with as much as 18 inches of snow in some areas, reports the News & Observer, which notes that some areas have already seen more than a foot of snow this weekend. The Weather Service is warning of a "bombogenesis" in the coming days that could bring as much as three feet of snow to parts of the Carolinas, including parts of Virginia, Maryland, and North Carolina. Parts of Pennsylvania have also been hit with up to a foot of snow. In North Carolina, meanwhile, some areas have already seen more than a foot of snow this weekend. NBC's Mike Seidel missed a live report on Saturday night because his back was to the camera.

– Wonkette blogger Rebecca Schoenkopf thinks actor Paul Rudd was among the bystanders who tackled a "violent, homophobic maniac" who attacked a man in a pink shirt at the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport last week. And after reviewing the video, she's pretty sure she's right, notes the Frisky: "A lot white guys look like Paul Rudd, but this guy really looks like Paul Rudd. And on top of that, thanks to the expert sleuth work of comedian Sara Benincasa."

– John Michael O'neal, the 71-year-old Massachusetts man accused of killing his wife's best friend with a hammer last month, has been sentenced to life in prison without parole, the AP reports. O'neal was convicted of second-degree murder in the death of Jillian Dieu, 41, who was found dead in her apartment on Jan. 29. O'neal had been dating Dieu's best friend for more than 20 years. According to a judge's ruling, O'neal used a hammer he found on the floor of his apartment to kill Dieu, then tried to kill himself with the same hammer after she died. Dieu's mother says O'neal told her he thought he was going to kill himself, but she didn't believe him. O'neal, who was divorced from Dieu's mother last year, had been serving time in prison for second-degree murder after being convicted of killing his wife's best friend in 1997. Dieu's mother says O'neal told her he thought he was going to kill himself, but she didn't believe him. "He said, 'I'm going to kill myself,'" she tells the New York Daily News. "I

– Batman v Superman director Zack Snyder took to the streets of Detroit Friday for a photo op in which he posed in the city's new Batmobile, which had been stolen earlier this week, the Detroit Free Press reports. According to Bleeding Cool, which originally broke the story about the car being stolen, Snyder posed in the Batmobile with a number of other Batman-related celebrities, including Henry Cavill, Ben Affleck, and Gal Gadot. Snyder also posed in the Batmobile with Batman's mom and dad.

– Anna Wintour is not happy about Vogue’s new offices at 1 World Trade Center, which are said to be infested with rats and vermin, the New York Daily News reports. According to the New York Post’s Page Six blog, the Vogue staff moved into their new digs on the 25th and 26th floors of the building last month, but they haven’t been able to spend much time there because of the rats and vermin. “I’m not a fan of 1 World Trade Center,” Wintour said in a recent interview. “It’s very, very, very rat-infested.”

– It may feel like winter is slowly squeezing all the sunlight out of your day, but if you see any news stories claiming the Earth is headed for ‘Six Days of Total Darkness’ then don’t start stocking up on the tins of beans and torches just yet. The world is indeed heading for six days of total darkness, according to conspiracy theorists—but if you see any news stories claiming the Earth is headed for ‘Six Days of Total Darkness,’ then don’t start stocking up on the tins of beans and torches just yet.

– Police are searching for the owner of a dog left tied to a railing at a Scottish railway station with its belongings in a suitcase. Kai, a male Shar-Pei crossbreed, was found tied to a railing outside Ayr's main station on Saturday, the Daily Record reports. He was discovered by a member of the public who was walking his dog. Police believe the dog's owner, who hasn't been found, left the suitcase in the station's car park before boarding a train, the Courier reports.

– President Obama says the US will be "relentless" in its fight against the Islamic State after the militants released a video showing the beheading of American journalist James Foley. "The entire world is appalled at the brutal murder of James Foley," Obama said in a statement today. "We will be vigilant and we will be relentless to see that justice is done." The president spoke to Foley's parents this morning and offered no new policy measures to fight the Islamic State, the Los Angeles Times reports.

– Axl Rose has been found dead in his West Hollywood home at the age of 49, reports TMZ. Police entered the home after getting a call about a welfare check and found the rocker unresponsive. He was pronounced dead at a nearby hospital. The cause of death hasn't been determined, but the Los Angeles County coroner's office ruled Rose's death an apparent heart attack. The news comes on the heels of a fake story on MSNBC.com that said, "Guns N' Roses frontman Axl Rose was found dead yesterday from unknown causes in his West Hollywood home."

– A "feminist" blog in the US has caused an uproar with an article claiming that the author of it, "Lana," had an abortion because of her "negative past experiences with men." The post, which has since been taken down, claims that "Lana" had a "negative sexual experience" with a man when she was in her early 20s, and that she ended up aborting his male fetus because of that experience, the Telegraph reports. "In an article so astounding it is difficult to believe it is actually true, 'Lana' even expresses surprise at the news," reads the post, which has been viewed more than 11 million times since it was posted last week. The author has not been identified.

– The Islamic State has released a new video showing the beheading of American journalist James Foley, and while it doesn't make any direct claims about the victim's identity, it does make clear that the man in the black balaclava is indeed an ISIS fighter, reports the New York Times. The video also shows the beheading of a British aid worker, David Haines, as well as the beheading of an Australian aid worker, Peter Kassig. British authorities say they are looking into claims that three British men who fought alongside ISIS in the Middle East may have been involved, reports the Telegraph. (ISIS released a similar video last month.)

– The latest entry in Microsoft's never-ending line of Whoppers: the K5, a self-driving car that takes the place of a human one in the company's fleet. It's based on the Daleks from Dr. Who, of course, and it's being touted as the first self-driving car to get through security at a major US university, reports the Washington Post. It's being rolled out at all of Microsoft's campuses in the next few months, and it's expected to cost the company no more than $5,000 to get it up and running. It's being touted as the first self-driving car to get through security at a major US university, reports the Post. While Daleks "know no fear" and "must not fear," the cold, calculating robots from the Dr. Who series don't exist in the real world yet and Microsoft has had to settle on the next best thing for securing its campuses: the K5.

– The Nigerian government has agreed to a ceasefire with the Islamic extremist group Boko Haram in an effort to secure the release of more than 200 schoolgirls kidnapped in April, the BBC reports. The agreement was announced by the country's president, Goodluck Jonathan, in a meeting with Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau, according to the Guardian. Boko Haram has been terrorizing Nigeria for more than a decade.

– A prisoner released last year as part of an exchange for captured US serviceman Bowe Bergdahl has resumed contact with the Taliban, according to reports. A spokesman for the Taliban's bureau in Doha, Qatar, tells the AP that the group has resumed contact with Bergdahl, who was captured in Afghanistan in June 2009 and held at Guantanamo Bay until he was freed in a prisoner exchange last year. The spokesman says the group has been in touch with Bergdahl's wife, though it's not clear if she has been in contact with him.

– A pizza delivery man in Michigan got a huge surprise when he made a special delivery to a hotel last week. A pizza delivery man in Michigan got a huge surprise when he made a special delivery to a hotel last week. The Detroit Free Press reports on the incident, which took place in the parking lot of a hotel in Grand Rapids. According to MLive.com, the man was supposed to deliver a pizza to the hotel's guest room, but he ended up delivering a pizza to the hotel itself.
